projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A CONTINUATION OF THE HISTORY OF THE REFORMATION To the End of the COUNCIL OF TRENT, In the Year 1563.
Collected and Written by E. B. EÅ¿q
LONDON, Printed in the Year MDCLXXXIX.

div.head: A CONTINUATION OF THE HISTORY OF THE REFORMATION.
BOOK I.

argument.head: The CONTENTS.
argument.p: The Introduction. The Revolt of TranÅ¿ylvania. The Siege and brave Defence of Sigeth, a Town in Hungary. Charles V, reÅ¿igns the Empire: He goes to Spain. John Sleidan's Death and Character. Paul III, a Furious Prince: The War between him and King Philip in Italy: The Peace between them. The Affairs of England. The Dyet of Ratisbonne. The Death of Ignatius Loyola, the Founder of the Order of JeÅ¿uites: And of Albert MarqueÅ¿s of Brandenburg. The unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful Conference at Wormds, between the RomiÅ¿h and ProteÅ¿tant Divines. The War between France and Spain. The Siege, Battle and Taking of S. Quintin. Charles V, his Letter to his Son. The SpaniÅ¿h Army diÅ¿perÅ¿e, and the French increaÅ¿e. A PerÅ¿ecution in France. The Siege and LoÅ¿s of Calais: The Situation and Form of that Town. Guines taken. A TurkiÅ¿h Fleet land in many Places in Italy, and carry many into Captivity. The Dauphin Married to Mary Queen of Scotland. The firÅ¿t Overtures for a Peace between the Kings of France and Spain. Andelot MarÅ¿hal of France ruined by the Arts of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. Thionville BeÅ¿ieged and Taken by the French. The Defeat of the French near Graveling. An unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful Expedition of the EngliÅ¿h againÅ¿t France. The Treaty of Cambray began. The Parliament of England meet; and Queen Mary Dies. The German Affairs, the Death and Character of Charles V. The SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Queen Elizabeth. The Scotch Affairs, and the firÅ¿t Å¿etling of the Reformation in that Kingdom.

div.p:
IT was the Misfortune of this Great Man, John Sleidan, to die in that nick of Time, when the Fates of the two contending Religions, and of all ChriÅ¿tendom, were juÅ¿t upon the Å¿etling: It is true, The Introduction. he lived to Å¿ee the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion Å¿etled in the Dyet of Ausburg, and perhaps he might hear of the ReÅ¿ignation of the Empire by Charles V, to his Brother Ferdinand; but then Death Å¿urprized him before he could give any account of it; for with it he deÅ¿igned to have begun the next Book, in all probability, and to have filled up this with Å¿ome other Accidents; Å¿uch as a large account of the Revolt of TranÅ¿ylvania, and the Siege of Sigeth would have afforded him. But then had he lived till the Year 1563, he Å¿hould have Å¿een the Death of Queen Mary, Henry II of France, and Charles V, and the Å¿etling of the Roman Catholick Religion, by the Determination of the Council of Trent, contrary to the Expectation of all Men; which Å¿eems to be the firÅ¿t Period of the Reformation, and abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary to give the Reader a clear ProÅ¿pect and full View of the firÅ¿t Joynt of this great Revolution. I have therefore perÅ¿uaded the Stationer to add a Suppliment to this VerÅ¿ion, for that purpoÅ¿e; and becauÅ¿e I am a Member of the Religion by Law eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed, and not willing to
offend them of the other PerÅ¿uaÅ¿ions, I reÅ¿olve to advance nothing in it but from Authors, who lived and dyed in the Communion of the Church of Rome, Å¿hewing the matter of Fact with great Brevity, and making few or no Reflections of my own: That Å¿o the Reader may be left entirely to himÅ¿elf, to think what he PleaÅ¿e, and God Å¿hall direct him.

I will begin with the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s of TranÅ¿ylvania: John the laÅ¿t King of Hungary, dyed of Joy for the birth of his Son, year 1556 in the Year 1539: His Son being left thus an Infant, The Revolt of TranÅ¿ylvania. his Mother the Queen Regent, put him under the Protection of Solyman, Emperour of the Turks, to Å¿ecure him from the Violence of Ferdinand, who claimed that Kingdom; and thereupon a Å¿harp War enÅ¿ued, which ended in the advancement of the TurkiÅ¿h IntereÅ¿t, and the loÅ¿s of both thoÅ¿e Princes, the Turk taking Quinque EccleÅ¿iae, Gran and Albaregalis, in the Year 1544; TemeÅ¿war, Lippa, and Å¿ome others in the Year 1548: Whereupon Ferdinand finding himÅ¿elf too weak to deal with that potent warlike Prince, in the Year 1549 offered him 30000 Ducats of yearly Tribute for TranÅ¿ylvania: But this DeÅ¿ign failing, in the Year 1551, he forced the Queen of Hungary to reÅ¿ign TranÅ¿ylvania, to whom in lieu of it he gave CaÅ¿Å¿ovia, and a PenÅ¿ion of 100000 Ducats yearly. And in the Year 1552, he made Stephen Dobus, who had performed great Services for him againÅ¿t the Turks this Year in the Defence of Agria, Vaivode of TranÅ¿ylvania: He continued quietly in the PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it, till the Year 1556; and then another DiÅ¿turbance aroÅ¿e in this Principality, which is Å¿hortly hinted at by King Ferdinand, in his Letter to the Dyet at Ratisbonne. Among other things, Ferdinand had promiÅ¿ed, That he would not burthen TranÅ¿ylvania with any GarriÅ¿ons of Foreigners; But whether out of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity, or for fear of the Turks, he had kept a Å¿trong Guard of SpaniÅ¿h Soldiers there, who had done great Injuries to the Inhabitants; whereupon one Peter Petrowic, underhand, dealt with Solyman for Å¿upplies, and began a Revolt in favour of one John, whoÅ¿e Family is not known, who then aÅ¿pired to this miÅ¿erable Principality, and hoped by drawing the Turks into Hungary, to gain the greateÅ¿t part of that Kingdom for himÅ¿elf, and had called a Dyet at Thorda, in March, 1555, which was diÅ¿appointed by the Spaniards. The Turks were not without their Complaints too, for tho' Ferdinand had Å¿ent AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours to treat a Peace, yet Solyman being engaged in a War with the PerÅ¿ians, he was not at leiÅ¿ure, or perhaps not much inclined to make a Peace with Ferdinand, but kept his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours two Years at ConÅ¿tantinople, to little or no PurpoÅ¿e; and Ferdinand being thus held in SuÅ¿penÅ¿e, was forced to keep great GarriÅ¿ons in his Frontier Towns, and among them the Heyducks were imployed, who having no Pay, made frequent inroads into the TurkiÅ¿h Quarters towards Quinque EccleÅ¿iae, and often Å¿urprized the TurkiÅ¿h Boats, as they paÅ¿Å¿ed upon the Rivers; nor was it in Ferdinand's power to reÅ¿train them, as things then Å¿tood. Hereupon the Turks began a War with the Town of KapoÅ¿war, which was treacherouÅ¿ly reÅ¿igned to them by the GarriÅ¿on, and after it Babotz, and paÅ¿Å¿ing on, they attempted Sigeth, and came within CannonÅ¿hot of it; but LadiÅ¿laus Kerezen, the Governour, gave them Å¿uch a warm Entertainment, that the BaÅ¿Å¿a's Tent being pierced with a Cannon-Å¿hot, he was forced to remove farther off, and three hundred of his Men being Å¿lain in two Sallies, and Winter coming on, he was fain to Withdraw. This paÅ¿Å¿ed in the Year 1555.

In the beginning of the next Year,
Sigeth beÅ¿ieged and moÅ¿t bravely defended by the Germans.
Solyman Å¿ent Haly an Albanian, whom he had recalled from the Wars of PerÅ¿ia, to be ViÅ¿ier of Buda; but with a Command not to enter that City, till he had taken Sigeth: He coming to SirmiÅ¿h, Å¿ent a MeÅ¿Å¿enger to demand Sigeth of Ferdinand, who replyed, He had AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours at the Port, treating of a Peace; he had done no Injury, and therefore deÅ¿ired he might receive none, but was reÅ¿olved to defend himÅ¿elf if he were attacked. Whereupon the BaÅ¿Å¿a comes on, and finds Mark Horwatch Governour of the Town, who had Å¿worn the GarriÅ¿on, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of two thouÅ¿and Foot, and one hundred and eighty HorÅ¿e, to defend the Town to the utmoÅ¿t. The Situation of Sigeth. It is Å¿eated in a marÅ¿hy Plain, and on the North it has Dikes, which bring the Waters of the River Alme into the three Ditches, which Å¿trengthen the Town; On the EaÅ¿t it has a Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle, which had two BaÅ¿tions, and the nature of the Site made it impoÅ¿Å¿ible to make uÅ¿e of Mines againÅ¿t it; and it was then a very Populous Place. Haly came before it the tenth of June, and finding nothing but Force could take it, the thirteenth he raiÅ¿ed a Battery of nine Canon on the South Å¿ide: WhilÅ¿t this was battering the Town on that Side, he plaid his Granadoes on all the other, which burnt moÅ¿t of the HouÅ¿es, and a
part of the Walls, which were made of Clay and Straw; the twentieth of June, the Turks took the CounterÅ¿charpe, and the next Night they filled the Å¿econd Dike with Faggots, and built another Battery on the WeÅ¿t Side of the Town, which the Defendants were not able to deÅ¿troy. The next day, a great Breach being made in the Å¿econd Wall, tho' the Town had burnt ten thouÅ¿and Loads of Wood, which had been thrown in to fill the Dike, yet the Turks, after four furious AÅ¿Å¿aults, which Å¿ucceeded not, took the Town at the fifth, and the GarriÅ¿on retreated into the CaÅ¿tle. The Turks drew a Trench between the CaÅ¿tle and the Town, to Å¿ecure themÅ¿elves; but the TownÅ¿men and Soldiers finding themÅ¿elves too much pen'd up for want of Room, made Å¿o furious a Sally upon the Turks, that they Å¿lew eighty of them, and recovered the Town. The next day, which was the twelfth of July, Haly renewed the Battery on the WeÅ¿t Side, and that Night erected a third Battery againÅ¿t a Tower called Haney, and a Gate near it, and drew a Trench round the Town to drain the Dikes, which he endeavoured to fill under the new Battery, and in this Work he Å¿pent five Days. When by this means he had drained the Dikes, he raiÅ¿ed a fourth Battery over againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle, and began to play it with great Fury againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle, twenty thouÅ¿and Carts being imployed, in the mean time, to fill the Dikes, on the EaÅ¿t Side with Wood; but the Defendants fired that too, and under the Cover of the Smoak, made a furious Sally on the Turks, who were labouring to put the Fire out, and Å¿lew Å¿even hundred of them. They made the Å¿ame Attempt of filling up the Dikes, and with the Å¿ame SucceÅ¿s, on the WeÅ¿t Side, the Wood being burnt, and four hundred Turks cut off by a Sally. Haly by this time began to find his Hopes of prevailing by Force abated, Å¿o he fell to fawning and Flattery, and made them very kind and obliging PromiÅ¿es, if they would Å¿urrender; but this was to no purpoÅ¿e, Å¿o he fell to fill the Dikes with Sacks of Earth, and to raiÅ¿e Works with Skeps to beat off the Defendants. The twelfth of July he raiÅ¿ed another Platform againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle, and battered it with that fury for five Days, that the Town was almoÅ¿t reduced to DeÅ¿peration, and Å¿ent a MeÅ¿Å¿enger to King Ferdinand, to beg Relief; but conÅ¿idering how long they muÅ¿t Å¿tay for it, they re-aÅ¿Å¿umed their wonted Courage, and made a brave Irruption, in which they fired all the Wood that had been thrown into the Dikes. This abated the Fury of Haly Å¿o effectually, that he lay only pelting the Town with his Cannon to the twenty firÅ¿t of July, and then was glad of an Opportunity to draw off to Å¿uccour Babots, which was aÅ¿Å¿aulted by one NadaÅ¿ad,
Babotz beÅ¿ieged. who fought this Army, and made a great Å¿laughter among them: And after this, the ChriÅ¿tians retreating towards CaniÅ¿a loÅ¿t two hundred of their Men, and among them a Brother of NadaÅ¿ad's. Upon this Å¿mall Advantage Haly returned to the Siege of Sigeth, but was entertained with Scorn and Laughter. He began another Battery againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle, and uÅ¿ed all the Arts and Wheedling and Terrour to perÅ¿uade the GarriÅ¿on to yield; but the BeÅ¿ieged returned his CourtÅ¿hip with military Sallies, and Å¿lew a great many of his Men, and in one of them they maintained a Fight eight Hours againÅ¿t all the TurkiÅ¿h Forces, Å¿o that tho' the Town was above half ruined, yet the TurkiÅ¿h General was forced the twenty ninth of July to draw off to Quinque EccleÅ¿iae; after he had Å¿ent away his Cannon and Baggage, he Å¿pent above two thouÅ¿and of his beÅ¿t Men in this Seige, and yet he Å¿lew not above one hundred and Å¿ixteen of the Defendants; but then he Å¿atiated his Fury on the Å¿maller Places. This Haly was an Eunuch of Å¿mall Stature, but very Corpulent, The Character of Haly, the Turks General. Tawny Complexioned, of a Sowre Countenance, fierce Eyes, broad Shouldered, Å¿hort Necked, and having two Fore-teeth like a Bore's Tusks, Å¿o that a more ugly contemptible PerÅ¿onage was never Å¿een; but he was a Man of great Courage and Subtlety. WhileÅ¿t he lay before Sigeth, the Germans Å¿urprized Gran by Scalado;
Gran Å¿urprized by Scalado. a poor Turk came to give him an account of this LoÅ¿s with Å¿o much ConÅ¿ternation in his Looks, that Haly clapt his Hand between his Thighs, and Å¿aid in Å¿corn, This was the dreadful LoÅ¿s when I was deprived of my Virilities. He was not long after forced, with great Å¿hame and DiÅ¿honour, to enter his Government of Buda, where he dyed of Rage and DiÅ¿content. I have inÅ¿iÅ¿ted the longer upon this, becauÅ¿e it was one of the moÅ¿t memorable Sieges in that Age.

Our Author has already given an account of the ReÅ¿ignation of the Kingdom,
Charles V, reÅ¿igns the Netherlands and Spain to his Son. of Naples and the Dukedom of Milan by Charles V, to his Son Philip, Å¿oon after his Marriage to Queen Mary; and this Summer he reÅ¿igned the Netherlands and Spain to him; Å¿o that he had nothing left but the Empire. This great Prince Å¿tripping himÅ¿elf by degrees of all his GreatneÅ¿s and External MajeÅ¿ty, and feeling a great PleaÅ¿ure in the lightning his Burthen, being then at Sudbury in Zealand, and juÅ¿t
ready to imbark for Spain, he made a ReÅ¿ignation of the Empire to his Brother Ferdinand the Å¿eventh of September, in this form. CHARLES, by the Divine Clemency, And the Empire to his Brother Ferdinand. Emperour of the Romans, AuguÅ¿t, &c. to all and every the Electoral Princes, as well EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical as Secular, the Prelates, Counts, Barons, Knights, Nobles, Captains, ViÅ¿counts, Governours, Lieutenants, MagiÅ¿trates, Judges, BurgomaÅ¿ters, ConÅ¿uls, Citizens and Commonalties, and all other the Subjects of the Å¿aid Empire, our Faithful and beloved People, of what State, Dignity or Condition Å¿oever, We wiÅ¿h FriendÅ¿hip, Grace, and every Good Thing. We being admoniÅ¿hed by many and great ReaÅ¿ons, and very much burthened with Our great Age, and with continual Annoyance of our Infirmities, which has almoÅ¿t overpower'd Our Natural Strength, and rendred Our Body infirm, which makes Us unfit for BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s; and having long Å¿ince determined, That Our Kingdom of Spain Å¿hould go to the moÅ¿t Serene Prince, Philip Our Son, King of Spain and England: And having thereupon abandoned Our uÅ¿ual Palace, We have removed with Our Court hither, in order with the firÅ¿t good Wind to embark for Spain, all things being now ready for that purpoÅ¿e, Å¿o that Our Voyage can be hindred by none but God: Wherefore by this Our AbÅ¿ence, the Government of the Sacred Empire belongs to the moÅ¿t Serene and Potent Prince, Ferdinand King of the Romans, Hungary and Bohemia, and Our deareÅ¿t Brother, as being lawfully elected King of the Romans, and the next unconteÅ¿table SucceÅ¿Å¿or after Us; the which Government has even already many Years Å¿ince, by our AÅ¿Å¿ent, been managed by him, in our Name, with great Affection, he having born the Weight of of it (for us) with a true brotherly and kind Solicitude. That therefore the ChriÅ¿tian Commonwealth, and eÅ¿pecially the Sacred Empire, may Å¿uÅ¿tain no Dammage (which God prevent) whilÅ¿t We are afar off; and that Our Å¿aid Brother, the King of the Romans may tranÅ¿act all Affairs with the greater Authority, We have reÅ¿olved and declared, That as King of the Romans, he Å¿hall have Power abÅ¿olutely of himÅ¿elf, without Our Concurrence to do, treat, and command all thoÅ¿e things, which to him Å¿hall Å¿eem neceÅ¿Å¿ary and convenient, to the Dignity, Profit and IncreaÅ¿e of the Å¿acred Empire; in the Å¿ame manner as We could have done the Å¿ame as Emperour of the Romans. In truth there is nothing which We deÅ¿ired Å¿o much, as to have been preÅ¿ent in PerÅ¿on in your Dyet, before this Our Voyage, which is now aÅ¿Å¿embled at Ratisbonne, one of our Imperial Cities, and to have brought the Publick Affairs to their deÅ¿ired End, by your Advice, and then to have committed the Government to Our Brother, the King of the Romans in it, in our Å¿tead, whereby we might have admoniÅ¿hed you, to pay him that Obedience, which is due to him. But Our IndiÅ¿poÅ¿ition of Body, which is known to all, would not Å¿uffer Us to take Å¿o long a Journey, and eÅ¿pecially by Land. BeÅ¿ides, We conÅ¿ider, that the Slipping this favourable SeaÅ¿on for Sailing, is a thing of great ConÅ¿iderationâWherefore, we being not able perÅ¿onally to come to the Dyet, as We deÅ¿ired and determined to do; nor to bring Our DeÅ¿igns to their Effect: Yet We were deÅ¿irous to make known Our Affection and Devotion to you all by this Edict, and diÅ¿covery of our Mind; and thereby expreÅ¿ly to command all and every of you, by the tenour of theÅ¿e Letters, and by the Imperial Authority, under Pain of our greateÅ¿t Indignation, That ye, as hath been often Å¿aid, yield to the Å¿aid King of the Romans Fidelity, Obedience and Reverence, in Our Name, and Å¿tead in all his Edicts, Commands and Actions, and that ye do not reÅ¿iÅ¿t or diÅ¿obey him in any thing, but obÅ¿erve him in all things, as You ought to do to us, if we were preÅ¿ent in the Empire; leÅ¿t by doing otherwiÅ¿e, or Å¿uffering your Å¿elves to be perÅ¿uaded to the contrary, you do excite and procure Our greateÅ¿t Indignation. And this is Our expreÅ¿s and laÅ¿t Will. Given under our Seal at Sudbury in Zealand, the Å¿eventh Day of September, in the Year of our Lord 1556, and in the thirty Å¿ixth Year of our Empire. I have Å¿ought up and tranÅ¿cribed this rare Piece from the Italian Copy, in AlfonÅ¿o Volla, in his Life of Charles V. It was penn'd in Latin, but I could no where find the Latin Copy, and perhaps it was never printed, at leaÅ¿t I am Å¿ure it is very Å¿carce; and not likely to be ever uÅ¿ed again by any Prince, till Time Å¿hall be no more.

The Emperour knew very well, The Emperour's AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours to the Electoral Princes. Å¿aith Thuanus, that next to God, the Right of Electing and Receiving the ReÅ¿ignation or Surrender of the Empire, was in the Å¿even Electoral Princes, and that without their ConÅ¿ent and Authority this could not be done; and to diÅ¿poÅ¿e them to approve and allow this Act of his, he had appointed William of NaÅ¿Å¿aw Prince of Orange, George SigiÅ¿mond, Seldius Vice Chancellour of the Empire, and Wolfang Haler, one of his Secretaries of State, to be his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours
to them: But a War Å¿oon after breaking out between the King of France and his Son King Philip, by the breach of the late Truce, it was two Years ere that Command of his took its effect.
In the mean time John ArchbiÅ¿hop of Trier, of the Family of the Counts of IÅ¿emburg, died, and John Laien Å¿ucceeded him; and Adolph ArchbiÅ¿hop of Cologne was Å¿ucceeded by Anthony his Brother.

The Emperour Å¿et Å¿ail the fifteenth of September, with a Fleet of Å¿ixteen SpaniÅ¿h, The Emperour Å¿ets Å¿ail for Spain. and twenty FlemmiÅ¿h Ships, all Men of War, beÅ¿ides the Admiral, in which he and his two SiÅ¿ters went. At PortÅ¿mouth Å¿even EngliÅ¿h Ships joyned him, and at the IÅ¿le of Wight Å¿even more. He arrived Å¿afely at Laredo, a Port in BiÅ¿caye, where he was entertained by a great concourÅ¿e of the Nobility, and Deputies of the Cities of the Kingdom of Spain. So Å¿oon as ever he Å¿et his Foot upon the Shoar, he proÅ¿trated himÅ¿elf upon the Earth, and kiÅ¿Å¿ing it he Å¿aid, Hail my beloved Mother, His Speech at his landing. naked came I out of my Mother's Womb, and now I return naked to thee again, as to another Mother; and here I conÅ¿ecrate and give to thee my Body and my Bones, which is all the Acknowledgment I can give for all thy numerous Benefits beÅ¿towed upon me. His next care was to make a formal and a publick Renunciation of the Kingdom of Spain to his Son Philip, in this great AÅ¿Å¿embly. After this he Å¿pent two Days at Valladolid with his Grand-Å¿on Don Carolo, inÅ¿tructing that unfortunate Prince in the Rules of Glory and Virtue; and doubtleÅ¿s it was a noble Lecture which Å¿o great a Prince, like another Patriarch, made to his Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Heir.

From hence this Glorious Prince retired to a Place he had choÅ¿en, The deÅ¿cription of the Place in which he lived. to Å¿pend the remainder of his Life, being a Valley in the Borders of Spain and Portugal; equally Delightful for the Temper of the Air, and the PleaÅ¿ant Crown of Hills which incircled it, and Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be the Place where the famous Sertorius was baÅ¿ely murthered. It is well watered with Springs and Rivolets, and rarely Fruitful, and lies about eight SpaniÅ¿h Miles from Placentia, a City of the Kingdom of Leon, by the Town of Scaradilla; this Place he had remarked in Hunting, and had ordered a Å¿mall Apartment of Å¿even Rooms, fourteen Foot Å¿quare to be built for him; and here he lived with twelve Servants, and one HorÅ¿e for his own uÅ¿e, having reÅ¿erved an hundred thouÅ¿and Crowns for his SubÅ¿iÅ¿tence, which was not over well paid neither, Å¿pending his Time in the innocent Arts of Grafting, Gardning, and Reconciling the Differences of his Clocks, which yet he could never make to Å¿trike together; and therefore ceaÅ¿ed to wonder, He had not been able to make Men agree in the Nicities of Religion.

Here he firÅ¿t heard of the breach of Truce between his Son and the King of France; and though he was Å¿omething concerned at it, Thuanus. yet he concluded the RaÅ¿hneÅ¿s of the Old doating Pope, and the Perfidy of the Caraffa's would end in the Ruine of the ProÅ¿perity of France, as it came afterwards to paÅ¿s.

The laÅ¿t Day of October (Å¿aith the great Thuanus) John Sleidan,
John Sleidan's Death and Character. when he had brought down his HiÅ¿tory to that time, with an exact Faith and Diligence, dyed of the Plague at Strasburg, in the one and fiftieth Year of his Age. He was born at Sleidan, a Town in the Dukedom of Juliers, near Dueren, and from thence he took his Name; a PerÅ¿on, who for his Learning and great Experience in Affairs was much eÅ¿teemed by that Age: He had Å¿pent the greateÅ¿t part of his Youth in France; and being entertained in the Family of Bellay, had both learned and done great things in the Service of Cardinal John Du Bellay; but a Å¿harp PerÅ¿ecution ariÅ¿ing in France againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e that were Å¿uÅ¿pected of LutheraniÅ¿me, he went and lived at Strasburg, and Å¿erved that Free City, and being by his own Employments much enformed of the Carriage of Affairs, he added to what he had Å¿een, what he had learned from Men worthy of Credit, and wrote his Book of Commentaries.

Paul IV had Å¿ucceeded Marcellus, a Å¿hort lived Pope, the twenty Å¿ixth of May,
Natura iracundus & pene implacabilis. Natalis Comes. Paul IV a furious Harebrained Prince. in the Year 1555, as John Sleidan has Å¿et forth in his laÅ¿t Book; he was a Man of a Furious and unquiet temper, and made it his great DeÅ¿ign to raiÅ¿e the See of Rome to its former GreatneÅ¿s and Authority; but not conÅ¿idering the preÅ¿ent Å¿tate of things, miÅ¿took his MeaÅ¿ures: The SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion of England had raiÅ¿ed in him extravagant Hopes of Reducing Germany too, under his Obedience; but then the Peace of Religion appeared Å¿o contrary to that DeÅ¿ign, that it irritated him to the utmoÅ¿t, and he threatned the King of the Romans and the Emperour, That in a Å¿hort time he would make them know, to their Sorrow, how much they had offended him, if they did not prevent it by revoking and diÅ¿allowing the things they had granted. That he might have no occaÅ¿ion to proceed as he intended to do, not only againÅ¿t the Lutherans, but even againÅ¿t them too, as Abettors of them. But all this Ranting Zeal miÅ¿Å¿ing its due
Effect he began his Revenges on King Philip, the Son of the Emperour, who was the beÅ¿t Friend that See had then in ChriÅ¿tendom, by denying to admit him to the Kingdom of Naples.

Marc Antony Colonna, a Favorite of Philip King of Spain, had about this time diÅ¿poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed AÅ¿canius his Father, who was a Subject of the Popes, but had a great EÅ¿tate in the Kingdom of Naples, of all that lay in that Kingdom upon pretence that he was infected with HereÅ¿ie, that he favoured the French IntereÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Emperour, and that he lived a diÅ¿Å¿olute Life: And the AccuÅ¿ation had been countenanced and encouraged by King Philip to that height, that the Father, as much as in him lay, at his Death diÅ¿inherited his Son, giving his EÅ¿tates in the Papacy to the See of Rome, and thoÅ¿e in the Kingdom of Naples to Victoria his Daughter, the Wife of Garzia de Toledo. This was made the Pretence of the enÅ¿uing War between the Pope and the King of Spain, into which the French and EngliÅ¿h were drawn too, and all ChriÅ¿tendom almoÅ¿t imbroiled again.

The Pope however, conÅ¿idering that he was not able to deal alone with Å¿o Potent a Prince as King Philip, under pretence of Å¿ending Cardinal Caraffa into France, to congratulate the five Years Truce, imployed his IntereÅ¿t with the King of France, to perÅ¿uade him to break his Faith Å¿o lately given, and to renew the War with Philip. The Pope had before, upon Å¿everal Pretences, clapt up the leading Cardinals, and great Men of the SpaniÅ¿h Faction: And when the King, with all the ReÅ¿pect his Zeal for that See could inÅ¿pire him with, by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, deÅ¿ired the DiÅ¿charge of theÅ¿e PriÅ¿oners, and the ReÅ¿titution of Marc Antony Colonna to his Fathers EÅ¿tate and CaÅ¿tles in the Papacy, the angry Pope Replyed, That he had Authority and Right to puniÅ¿h his Subjects for their Offences. And commanded his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to write to his MaÅ¿ter, not to meddle with what did not belong to him, and that he Å¿hould permit him as Pope, to exerciÅ¿e his Soveraignty freely on his own Subjects. And accordingly he Å¿eized all Colonna's CaÅ¿tles and EÅ¿tates in the Dominions of the Church, pretending to revenge the Wrongs he had done to AÅ¿canius his innocent Father, with the conÅ¿ent of his Mother, who was alÅ¿o Å¿everely treated by the Pope; and not contented with all this, he declared the Kingdom of Naples forfeited to the See of Rome, becauÅ¿e King Philip had neglected the Payment of eight thouÅ¿and Crowns due as a yearly Tribute for that Kingdom, He annexes the Kingdom of Naples to the See of Rome. and now many Years in Arrear; whereupon his HolineÅ¿s publiÅ¿hed an Edict, by which he annexed that Kingdom, as forfeited to the See of Rome; and began to fortifie Paliano a City of Champagna di Roma, thirty miles from Rome to the EaÅ¿t, and put a thouÅ¿and French into it for a GarriÅ¿on, which the more exaÅ¿perated the King of Spain.

The Duke de Alva, who was then Vice-roy of Naples, did all that was poÅ¿Å¿ible to mitigate the Pope; The Duke de Alva begins a a War upon the Papacy. but his SubmiÅ¿Å¿ions and ProteÅ¿tations more incenÅ¿ed him, his Flatterers perÅ¿uading him they proceeded more from Fear than a Reverence of the Holy See, which he Å¿o much pretended. Whereupon the Vice-roy raiÅ¿ed twelve thouÅ¿and Foot and fifteen hundred HorÅ¿e, and entring the Popes Territories, he took Ponte Corvo, upon the River Garigliano, one of the Pope's Towns, in the Borders of Terra di Lavoro, without reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and after that FruÅ¿ilione, the Pope's Forces flying out of it in the Night. Hereupon the Pope alÅ¿o levied ten thouÅ¿and Italian Foot and Å¿even hundred HorÅ¿e, to which he added two thouÅ¿and Gascoigners, which were old Soldiers, Å¿ent him by the King of France; and impriÅ¿oned one Lofredo, who was Å¿ent by the Duke de Alva to perÅ¿uade the Pope to a Peace, before the War was begun, and Å¿taid at Rome for the Pope's AnÅ¿wer.

The Duke de Alva, hearing this, preÅ¿ently marched to Anagni, another City in the Å¿ame Province,
Anagni taken. which the Pope had made his Magazine; but here meeting Å¿ome ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance, he Å¿at down before it, and Å¿ent the Duke of Toledo to take Veruli, in which he found Å¿ome Difficulty, which he revenged by plundering the Town: Another of his Commanders took Babuco, and beat out the Pope's Forces; the other Places made no reÅ¿iÅ¿tance. In the interim, the Walls of Anagni being ruined, the Governour in the night-time blew up the Powder and fled, and left the City to the Mercy of the Spaniards, who plundered it with great Security.

WhilÅ¿t this was doing, Commilo OrÅ¿ino fortified Rome, and prepared it for a Siege, by cutting down all the Trees,
Rome prepared for a Siege. and deÅ¿troying all the HouÅ¿es, Walls, Gardens and Vineyards about it, to the Damage of ten millions of Crowns; which enforced the Citizens to Å¿eek all the means that were poÅ¿Å¿ible to prevent this DevaÅ¿tation and Ruine, but in vain; and there was no leÅ¿s Care taken of the CaÅ¿tle of S. Angelo, five BaÅ¿tions and a CounterÅ¿charpe being added to its former Works. But when the NoiÅ¿e of the taking Anagni and the other Towns came to Rome, nothing could conÅ¿olate
the Citizens, but fearing another Sack like that of Bourbon in the year 1527, they would not be quiet till the Pope Å¿ent EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to Alva to Treat of Peace.

In the mean time Alva took Valle di Montone without reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and finding himÅ¿elf deluded with the pretence of a Treaty, he took PaleÅ¿trina and Segni; after this he marched to Tivoli, which Å¿ubmitted without any diÅ¿pute to his will, who received the City under his Protection, and would not Å¿uffer his Soldiers to enter into it. ThoÅ¿e of Vico-Varo, a Å¿trong and populous Town upon the Teuerone, promiÅ¿ed OrÅ¿ino to defend themÅ¿elves bravely; but Å¿eeing their Fields, Gardens, Vineyards and Countrey HouÅ¿es go to wrack, they deÅ¿ired OrÅ¿ino to provide for himÅ¿elf, who thereupon Å¿ent to Alva for leave to march away with Drums beating and Colours flying, as if no enemy had been near, which the civil good natured enemy granted, and thereupon he entred the Town; and though he promiÅ¿ed to leave but Å¿ixty Spaniards in gariÅ¿on, took the liberty afterward to do as he thought fit. This Town by reaÅ¿on of its GreatneÅ¿s, Strength and PopulouÅ¿neÅ¿s, might have defended it Å¿elf againÅ¿t a greater Army than that of the Spaniards if they had had the Courage; and was Å¿urrendered very opportunely for the Spaniard.

The Pope began to want Money, but durÅ¿t ask none of the Citizens of Rome, becauÅ¿e they were at great charges to fortifie the City: He Å¿olicited the Venetians alÅ¿o, to enter into the War, but they were for a Peace between the Parties; but then there was Å¿o much Pride on the one Å¿ide, and Å¿o much Anger on the other, that nothing could be effected. The French that were in the City were very troubleÅ¿ome to the Romans for want of their pay, which occaÅ¿ioned many Thefts and Robberies, and that in the day time. Alva having refreÅ¿hed his Forces a Å¿mall time after the taking Vico-Varo, drew them into the Field and took ToÅ¿colano San Marino, Grotta Ferrata and GandolÅ¿o, and from Grotta Ferrata marched towards OÅ¿tia. The inhabitants of Nettuno Å¿ubmitted to him, and defended his men againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e of Velletri, who aÅ¿Å¿aulted them in the Suburbs of Nettuno. The Pope Å¿eeing his weakneÅ¿s, Å¿ent again to the French King to declare a war againÅ¿t the Spaniards, and at laÅ¿t obtained his deÅ¿ire in that point.

The Duke De Alva coming before OÅ¿tia (this City was heretofore a very conÅ¿iderable place, but being ruined by Wars and time, and now almoÅ¿t deÅ¿olate, The Seige of OÅ¿tia. though the Governour had beÅ¿towed Å¿ome time and pains in fortifying it) but however this place preÅ¿erved it Å¿elf and beat off the Spaniards with great loÅ¿s Å¿everal times, but at laÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle of it was taken too, after which a Truce enÅ¿ued, and Alva return'd into the Kingdom of Naples with the SpaniÅ¿h HorÅ¿e, leaving the Foot in the Towns he had taken. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e was on the way for Italy with a great Å¿upply, and the Pope in the time of the Truce, was very earneÅ¿t with the Venetians to joyn with him, but to no purpoÅ¿e. And thus Å¿tood Affairs in the beginning of the next year in Italy.

In France, Henry the Second having been won by the Arts of Cardinal Caraffa to break his Oath, the Admiral Coligni the Sixth of January attempted to Å¿urpriÅ¿e Doway,
year 1557 but was diÅ¿covered and prevented, but he took and plundered Leus, The French Affairs. a Town in Artois, uÅ¿ing the people with great barbarity. In the mean time the Duke of GuiÅ¿e had paÅ¿Å¿ed the Alps, in the depth of the winter, with an Army of Twelve ThouÅ¿and Foot and Five ThouÅ¿and and Three Hundred armed HorÅ¿e, and Eight Hundred and Eight Light-HorÅ¿e, with which Forces he beÅ¿ieged Valenza, a Å¿trong Town in the Dutchy of Milan; and after he had battered it five daies,
Valenza taken. Å¿torm'd and took the Town the twentieth day of January, and a few daies after the CaÅ¿tle. He diÅ¿mantled the Town, but at the requeÅ¿t of the Pope, he preÅ¿erved the CaÅ¿tle. From thence he paÅ¿Å¿ed into the Dukedome of Ferrara, where he was reÅ¿pectively entertained by the Duke, who had declared for the Pope, but he would not go with him to Bononia, fearing his Countries might be invaded by the Spaniards and their Allies in his abÅ¿ence; but however the Duke of GuiÅ¿e went thither with his Forces, where he found an hearty welcome, but no Forces to joyn with him, which much diÅ¿pleas'd him.

In the mean time the Pope finding the inconvenience of having OÅ¿tia in the enemies hands, which deprived Rome of the benefit of the Sea,
OÅ¿tia retaken by the Pope. and Å¿ending Å¿ome Forces thither, it was Surrendred, after a Å¿hort defence, upon the account of an Inundation of the River. After which the Pope recovered moÅ¿t of the other Towns as eaÅ¿ily as he had loÅ¿t them.

In the Spring the Duke of GuiÅ¿e began the War with the Sack of Compli, a Å¿mall City of Abruzzo, The War in Italy under the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. which being taken by Scalado was Å¿everely treated; the Spoil of this City was eÅ¿timated at two hundred thouÅ¿and Crowns, great part of which was found in the Ruines of the City, where it had been hid many Ages, and was unknown to the Inhabitants. The 24 of April, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿at down before Civitella, a City of Abruzzo, built upon an high Hill, and very Å¿teep on the North, on the top of which it had a CaÅ¿tle, ruined by its own Inhabitants, in the time of Charles VIII, for fear it Å¿hould have been GarriÅ¿on'd by the French. This City would not yield, and therefore the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was forced to Å¿tay before it till the Cannon could be brought from Ancona and Ferrara to batter it; but when all was done, this Å¿mall place, by the nature of its Å¿ituation, and the Courage of its Inhabitants, baffled all their Attempts, and forced the French, after a long Siege, to retire, and leave it. The Women of this Town contributed very much to the Å¿aving of it, not only by working at the Breaches, tho' many of them were Å¿lain by the Enemies Shot, but alÅ¿o by taking mens Cloaths, and appearing in Arms among them in the Å¿ight of the Enemy, Å¿o that the Defendants Å¿eemed more numerous than indeed they were.

In the mean time, The Duke de Alva takes the Field. Alva having brought an Army of 16000 Foot and 2000 HorÅ¿e, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of Spaniards, Germans and Italians, together with a good Train of Artillery brought him by Sea, he marched out of PeÅ¿cara, May 10, and drove the French out of Givlia, a Sea-port-Town, about ten miles eaÅ¿t of Civitella; whereupon the Duke of GuiÅ¿e having loÅ¿t above half his Army, left Civitella, the 15 of May, when they had lain before it twenty two Days.

The Duke of Florence took the Opportunity of this diÅ¿tracted State of Affairs, and by pretending he was much inclin'd to joyn with the French and Pope againÅ¿t the Spaniards, which would certainly have ruined their Power in Italy, forced King Philip to give up the City and State of Siena to him, who accordingly took PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it July 19. This whole intreague is deÅ¿cribed at length by Thuanus, but I am forced to be very Å¿hort, the nature of this Supplement not admitting Å¿uch long DigreÅ¿Å¿ions.

Towards the latter end of the Summer,
Segni taken by the Spaniards.
Segni, a Å¿trong City of Compagnia di Roma, having made the beÅ¿t Defence it could, fell at laÅ¿t into the Hands of the Spaniards, who plundred and burnt it, and Å¿lew the greateÅ¿t part of the Inhabitants. When the Pope heard the deplorable News of the Sack of Segni, he fell into a fit of Melancholy, and Å¿aid, He deÅ¿ired to be with ChriÅ¿t, and would with great ConÅ¿tancy and Satisfaction, expect the Crown of Martyrdom,; As if (Å¿ays Thuanus) this had been the CauÅ¿e of God: And that he had not been brought into this great Danger and Trouble, by a War which his Relations had involv'd him in, with great RaÅ¿hneÅ¿s and Ambition.

ThoÅ¿e that were about him could not forbear Smiling; and knowing very well, That as the Pope had begun this War without CauÅ¿e or Provocation, Å¿o he might end it when he pleaÅ¿ed upon JuÅ¿t and Honourable Terms, King Philip, and his General, the Duke de Alva, being both extremely addicted to the See of Rome: And therefore taking this Opportunity, they perÅ¿uaded the Pope to Å¿end Alexander Placidi, a Knight of great eÅ¿teem, to the Duke of Alva, to treat about a Peace, by whom alÅ¿o the Cardinal of Sanfloriano Å¿ent a private Account of the beating the French at S. Quintin, which as it Å¿unk the Pope's IntereÅ¿t, Å¿o it raiÅ¿ed the SpaniÅ¿h.

Upon this the Duke de Alva took up a ReÅ¿olution to Å¿urprize the City of Rome by Night, and treat with the Pope within the very Walls of Rome; and he came very early in the Morning under the Walls of Rome, and found the City in a profound Quiet, and altogether unprovided, Å¿o that in all probability he might have Å¿urprized it without the leaÅ¿t ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance; but as he took an Oath of the Captains, That they Å¿hould not Å¿uffer their Soldiers to plunder or Å¿ack the City, Å¿o it is verily thought, upon great ReaÅ¿ons, That his Fear the Switz and Germans would have done this whatever he or his Officers could have done or Å¿aid to prevent it, made him Å¿top, and by his PreÅ¿ence try if he could affright the Old Pope into a Compliance. However, Thuanus is of Opinion, he truly deÅ¿igned to Å¿urprize the City, but that his Heart failed him, when it came to the Point of Execution.

At the Å¿ame time there came Letters from the King of France, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e recall'd. to recal the Duke of GuiÅ¿e into France, where his PreÅ¿ence was abÅ¿olutely needful, and the Pope had his HoÅ¿tages returned, and was left at Liberty to take the beÅ¿t care, he could of his own Affairs: Yet when the Duke of GuiÅ¿e came to ask the Pope's leave to return, upon the account of the great NeceÅ¿Å¿ity of his MaÅ¿ter's Affairs,
there was a Å¿harp conteÅ¿t between the Duke and the Pope, inÅ¿omuch that his HolineÅ¿s told the Duke, He had done very little towards the advancing his Masters IntereÅ¿t, or the Good of the Church in this Voyage, and much leÅ¿s for the Improvement of his own Honour and Reputation. In the mean time the Duke de Alva withdrew his Army to the Town of Colonna.

The Duke of Florence had now obtained what he deÅ¿ired, A Peace between King Philip and the Pope. by gaining the State of Sienna, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was gone for France, the Pope's Forces were Å¿ufficiently baffled, and his Towns lay at the Mercy of the Enemy, his TreaÅ¿ures were Å¿pent, and the Venetians had abÅ¿olutely refuÅ¿ed to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him; So that the Pope was now forced to come to a Treaty of Peace, in good earneÅ¿t, and it was well he had the King of Spain and the Duke de Alva to treat with, conÅ¿idering in what State his Affairs were.

The Peace was however agreed at laÅ¿t, upon theÅ¿e Terms. I. That the Duke de Alva, in the Name of his MaÅ¿ter, Å¿hould beg the Pope's Pardon, and it Å¿hould be granted. II. That the Pope Å¿hould renounce the Amity with France. III. That the King of Spain Å¿hould reÅ¿tore to the Pope one hundred Towns and CaÅ¿tles he had taken in this War, the Å¿ame being diÅ¿mantled firÅ¿t; and that they Å¿hould reÅ¿tore thoÅ¿e EÅ¿tates they had Å¿eized, to the proper owners. IV. That both Parties Å¿hould remit all Wrongs, Injuries and LoÅ¿Å¿es SuÅ¿tained during the War, and Pardon all that had taken Arms on either Side: And that Paliano Å¿hould be put into the Hands of Bernardo Carbone, a KinÅ¿man of the Caraffa's, to be kept by him for both Parties, with a GarriÅ¿on of eight hundred Men, till they Å¿hould otherwiÅ¿e diÅ¿poÅ¿e of it by mutual ConÅ¿ent. TheÅ¿e Articles were publickly Å¿igned at Cavii â¢
Cava the fourteenth of September; but there was a private Article Å¿igned the Å¿ame Day, That John Caraffa Å¿hould have Å¿uch a Recompence for Paliano as Å¿hould be adjudged an Equivalent by the Senate of Venice, who were the Arbitrators in this Treaty. The Place meant was RoÅ¿Å¿ano, a Populous and Rich City in the Kingdom of Naples, which was to be granted to him by the King of Spain, with the Title of a Principality, which he might transfer to whom he pleaÅ¿ed, if not an Enemy of the King of Spain's. That upon the delivery of this Grant and Place, Paliano Å¿hould be diÅ¿mantled, and Caraffa Å¿hould yield up all his Right in it to the King of Spain, which he alÅ¿o might aÅ¿Å¿ign to whom he pleaÅ¿ed, if he were not Excommunicated, or the Pope's Å¿worn Enemy; which was added to exclude Mark Anthony Colonna, and was eaÅ¿ily granted by the Duke de Alva, in complyance with the MoroÅ¿e and Inexorable Humour (they are Thuanus's Words) of the Old Gentleman, who would Å¿oon die, and then the King might diÅ¿poÅ¿e of Paliano as he thought fit.

The Duke de Alva, in a Å¿hort time after went to Rome, and on his Knees begged the Pope's Pardon, with as much Humility as could have been wiÅ¿hed: And the Pope abÅ¿olved him and his MaÅ¿ter with as much HaughtineÅ¿s as ever need to have been uÅ¿ed.

The great DeÅ¿ire I had to lay all this Italian War together, has made me omit Å¿ome things that happened in the former Year,
year 1556 among which one was the Death of Francis Venero, Duke of Venice, to whom Å¿ucceeded Laurentius Prioli, a Learned, WiÅ¿e, Eloquent and Magnificent Gentleman; Å¿o that for many Years after his Death, the Venetians regretted the LoÅ¿s of him, and wiÅ¿hed for Å¿uch another.

In England the PerÅ¿ecution was Å¿o far from extirpating the Reformation, The Affairs of England. that it made it Å¿pread; but the Quarrels at Frankford, among our EngliÅ¿h Exiles, about the Liturgy, had a more PeÅ¿tilent Influence upon that Religion then, and in after Times, than the former had. The Queen, in the mean time was very buÅ¿ie in raiÅ¿ing the Religious HouÅ¿es, and had nothing to diÅ¿guÅ¿t her, till the breaking off of the Truce between her Husband and the King of France, which very much afflicted her every way.

The Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿hipped his Men at Civita Vechia for France, and himÅ¿elf took PoÅ¿t-HorÅ¿es, and went by Land. The Cardinal of Caraffa went Å¿oon after, the Pope's Nuntio, to King Philip, and Augustino Trivultio, to the King of France, to procure a Peace between thoÅ¿e two Potent Princes, who had been engaged in this War by the Pope and his Relations.

In the Interim the Duke of Ferrara was expoÅ¿ed to the ReÅ¿entment of King Philip,
Ferrara reÅ¿cued from Ruine by the Duke of Florence. and had certainly been ruined, if the Prudence of CoÅ¿mo Duke of Florence had not prevented it: FirÅ¿t, by Å¿ending Å¿low and Å¿mall Supplies againÅ¿t the Duke of Ferrara, and then by maintaining and fomenting Differences between the SpaniÅ¿h
Commanders at laÅ¿t, by repreÅ¿enting to the Duke de Alva, who viÅ¿ited him at Legorn, That the King of Spain had no other way of Å¿etling his Affairs in Italy, than by quieting thoÅ¿e Commotions his juÅ¿t ReÅ¿entment againÅ¿t the Duke of Ferrara, had raiÅ¿ed: That all Italy being weary of Wars, promiÅ¿ed themÅ¿elves a Peace would follow upon the Victory of that Prince; but now, if he Å¿hould go on to make one War the cauÅ¿e of another, he muÅ¿t expect to loÅ¿e their Affections; and that mere DeÅ¿paration would enforce them to take other MeaÅ¿ures, and Å¿eek new Allies and new CounÅ¿els. This convinced that Duke, That it was his MaÅ¿ter's IntereÅ¿t to make a Peace with Ferrara, becauÅ¿e then there would be neither Prince nor Commonwealth in Italy, that would have any dependence upon France.

Our Author John Sleidan has only given us the Letter or Speech which began the Dyet at RatiÅ¿bonne, The Dyet of Ratisbonne. but dyed before he could give us any account of the TranÅ¿actions there: After they had conÅ¿ulted of thoÅ¿e things which related to the State, and the TurkiÅ¿h War, there aroÅ¿e Å¿ome debate concerning the compoÅ¿ing the Differences of Religion. And here it was firÅ¿t agreed, That all that had been done in the Treaty of PaÅ¿Å¿aw, and the Dyet of Ausburg, concerning the Peace of Religion, Å¿hould remain firm and immoveable. But then thoÅ¿e of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, preÅ¿ented to King Ferdinand, by their Deputies, a ProteÅ¿tation, in Writing, to this purpoÅ¿e.

p.q: That King Ferdinand had performed a moÅ¿t uÅ¿eful Office, A RemonÅ¿trance of the ProteÅ¿tant Princes. for the good of ChriÅ¿tendom, by Å¿etling a Peace, in the Matters of Religion, between the Princes and the States of Germany: But then he had annexed a Limitation, which was very Grievous, That no ArchbiÅ¿hop, BiÅ¿hop, Abbat, or other EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical PerÅ¿on, Å¿hould receive the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, but that he Å¿hould reÅ¿ign his Office, and be deprived of the Revenues thereunto belonging. That thoÅ¿e of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion did not conÅ¿ent to this Limitation, nor can they now conÅ¿ent to it; becauÅ¿e this was a denying them the Benefit of imbracing the Saving and True Doctrin of the GoÅ¿pel, by which not only the BiÅ¿hops but their Subjects too, were driven out of the Kingdom of God, which was not fit to be done. BeÅ¿ides, it was a Reproach to their Religion, to Å¿uffer thoÅ¿e who Å¿hould imbrace the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, to be judged unworthy of the Sacred MiniÅ¿tery: And therefore they could not approve this ReÅ¿triction in the Dyet of Ausburg, without doing Injury to the Glory of God and their own ConÅ¿ciences; neither can they now conÅ¿ent to it. That this Limitation was an Hindrance to the Å¿o much deÅ¿ired Union of Religion, Å¿eeing thereby the BiÅ¿hops were deprived of the Liberty of Å¿peaking their Minds freely in Matters of Religion, becauÅ¿e they Å¿hould thereby forfeit their Office and Revenues, if they approved of the True Religion. That on the contrary, the Peace would be much Å¿tronger between the Princes and States of the Empire, if Religion were perfectly Free. That therefore the Electors, Princes and States, who had imbraced the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, deÅ¿ired now (as they had alÅ¿o formerly done in the Dyet of Ausburg) That this grievous Limitation and ReÅ¿triction might be aboliÅ¿hed; and that it might be free for all EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical PerÅ¿ons to imbrace the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿uffer their Subjects to imbrace it. That they of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion did not by this, deÅ¿ire that the Revenues of the Church Å¿hould be diÅ¿Å¿ipated, or turned to Profane UÅ¿es, or annexed to certain Families; but they would take great Care to prevent theÅ¿e Inconveniences, and do their utmoÅ¿t in it. And that by this means the true Intention of the Founders Å¿hould be obÅ¿erved, tho' the ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the True Religion Å¿hould be permitted, for it was, without doubt, their DeÅ¿ign, to have the Pious and Sincere Service and WorÅ¿hip of God Promoted and Setled, tho' they err'd in their Choice. That the Electors, Princes and States, aforeÅ¿aid, would Å¿uffer the Publick and Civil BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s of the Empire to be diÅ¿patched in this Dyet at Ratisbonne; but then they had commanded them, their Deputies, not to give any conÅ¿ent to any thing, till the Å¿aid Limitation were taken away: But then, if it was once AboliÅ¿hed and Repealed, they were ready and willing to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t and promote the Publick Affairs in this Dyet, to the utmoÅ¿t of their Abilities.

div.p:
This ProteÅ¿tation or RemonÅ¿trance was very often renewed afterwards in Å¿everal of their Dyets; but being always oppoÅ¿ed by the Princes of the oppoÅ¿ite Religion, and by the Emperours, it could never be obtained; becauÅ¿e they ever thought, That the granting this Liberty, would end in the Rnine of the Roman Catholick Religion. On the other Å¿ide, thoÅ¿e of that Religion wrote Å¿harply
againÅ¿t the Peace of Religion, as it was then eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed by the Treaty of PaÅ¿Å¿aw, and the Dyet of AuÅ¿burg, calling it a LawleÅ¿s ConfuÅ¿ion; and in private, Å¿aying, That as it was obtained by a War, Å¿o it must by a War be revoked.

In the Year 1556, the Thirty firÅ¿t of July, Ignatius Loyola, the Founder of the Order of JeÅ¿uites, died, in the Sixty fifth year of his Age. He was born in Spain, and at firÅ¿t Å¿erved as a Soldier; which Employment he deÅ¿erted in the Year 1521, upon a Wound received at Pampelune. In the Year 1528 he began to gather Companions. In the Year 1534 or 35 this Order was firÅ¿t framed by him; and in the Year 1609 he was Canonized by Pope Paul IV. And (as Petavius Å¿aith) it was confirm'd by Paul III, in 1540, the Twenty Å¿eventh of September. James Lainez, a Spaniard, was this Year his SucceÅ¿Å¿or, and the Å¿econd General of that Order; which had then obtain'd One hundred Colleges in Å¿everal Parts of ChriÅ¿tendom, as one of that Society aÅ¿Å¿ures us.

The Eleventh of March the Dyet, began at RatiÅ¿bonne the laÅ¿t year, was ended. In it there was a Decree of ReceÅ¿s made, That a Friendly Conference Å¿hould be held the Fourteenth of August at Wormes, for the putting an End to the Differences of Religion: That a double Supply of Eight Months Å¿hould be granted to King Ferdinaud, to enable him to carry on the War againÅ¿t the Turks: That the Peace of Religion, and that of the State, Å¿hould be preÅ¿erved with great and exact care; and for the Renewing the Imperial Chamber of Spire, which is the Supreme Court of the Empire.

In April died John Count Palatin of Simeren, PreÅ¿ident of the Å¿aid Imperial Chamber, and the Father of Frederick, who about two years after Å¿ucceeded Otho Henry in the Palatinate of the Rhine. He was a Prince of great Learning, and managed this TruÅ¿t with the higheÅ¿t Commendations both for his Prudence and JuÅ¿tice.

Soon after the great ControverÅ¿ie between the Families of NaÅ¿Å¿aw and HeÅ¿Å¿e, The County of Catzenellobogen Å¿etled by Agreement. which had been depending Fifty Years, and is often mention'd by Sleidan concerning the County of Catzenellobogen was friendly ended at Frankfort upon the Main, by the InterpoÅ¿ition and Mediation of Otho Henry and AuguÅ¿tus Electors, William Duke of Cleves, and others, who were made Judges in this Affair for both Parties, the Landgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e by their award retaining that County, upon paying to William Prince of Orange 1600 Crowns, and reÅ¿igning up to him the Earldom of Diez for 1050 Crowns.

When the time of the Conference appointed by the Dyet drew near, the Divines who were of the AguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, had a Meeting at Frankford on the Main, the FirÅ¿t of August, to adjuÅ¿t their own private Differences before they entred into a Conference with the Roman Catholicks; The Conference at Wormes. Å¿o that this latter was not begun till the beginning of September. At the opening of it, Julius Pflug, BiÅ¿hop of Naumburg, who was PreÅ¿ident in this Conference, deÅ¿ired thoÅ¿e of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, that they would in the firÅ¿t place Å¿hew openly their DiÅ¿agreement with, and DeteÅ¿tation of the Zuinglians, OÅ¿iandrians, SynergiÅ¿ts, and AdiaphoriÅ¿ts: BecauÅ¿e the Peace of Religion was only granted to thoÅ¿e of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion by the Dyet, and this Conference was appointed with none but them, and the Emperor beÅ¿ides knew that moÅ¿t of them had Orders to do this: That therefore Å¿ome benefit at leaÅ¿t might reÅ¿ult from this Conference, they would once for all, by a common conÅ¿ent, condemn theÅ¿e Errors, and there would be much leÅ¿s danger and difficulty in the reÅ¿t. The younger MiniÅ¿ters and Deputies of Saxony eaÅ¿ily aÅ¿Å¿ented, and producing their InÅ¿tructions, were very forward to Å¿eparate the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion from theÅ¿e Errors. But Philip Melancthon (an old wiÅ¿e Man, who Å¿aw the drift of this cunning GameÅ¿ter) Å¿aid the Examination and
Explication of their Å¿everal Doctrins ought to go before the Determination and Condemnation of them; and that till this was done, they ought not to be condemned. The Roman Catholicks, who were weary of the Conference, thereupon would go no further in it, till they had given an Account of this to the Emperor. Ferdinand commanded them to go on, and Å¿aid it was enough if in the ProgreÅ¿s of the Conference, when they had explained the Å¿everal Articles, they did at laÅ¿t remark what was diÅ¿allowed, by the common conÅ¿ent, in each of them. But the BiÅ¿hop of Naumburg refuÅ¿ing to go on, except he were firÅ¿t certain of the Faith of thoÅ¿e he was to diÅ¿pute with, the Conference broke up without effect, when there had only been Å¿ome Papers exchanged between them concerning the Rule of Judging ControverÅ¿ies and Original Sin. And all the blame was by the Roman Catholicks thrown upon the DiviÅ¿ions which were among them. Thus far Thuanus.

Now the deÅ¿ign of this Condemnation was a DiviÅ¿ion of the ProteÅ¿tant IntereÅ¿t; that whereas they were too many for the Romau Catholicks while they were united, they might h â¢ ave the ConÅ¿ent of thoÅ¿e of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion to ruin the Zuinglians, and then they Å¿hould, with the leÅ¿s difficulty, extirpate by the Sword the Lutherans too; and in the mean time they knew very well they were never able to convince them by a DiÅ¿putation, when it was utterly impoÅ¿Å¿ible they Å¿hould ever agree about the Rule that was to end theÅ¿e Differences; the Roman Catholicks AÅ¿Å¿igning the perpetual ConÅ¿ent of the Church: And the Lutherans, the Old and New TeÅ¿taments, and the Ancient Creeds; and allowing no other Writings but as far as they agreed with theÅ¿e, Å¿ome Ages being purer than others. Certainly no wiÅ¿e Man of either Side ever did think that any of theÅ¿e Conferences could put an end to theÅ¿e ControverÅ¿ies; though they have made uÅ¿e of them to promote by Ends. And that Side that was uppermoÅ¿t, hath ever yet reaped the Advantage; and Å¿o it will be, till God himÅ¿elf put an End to this ControverÅ¿ie.

But to return now to the War between France and Spain. The War between France and Spain. The Truce being broken by the Attempt upon Doway, which I have mention'd already; the War went heavily on, becauÅ¿e the Flower of the Nobility and Gentry were gone with the Duke of GuiÅ¿e into Italy, which had much diÅ¿pirited and weakned France. And the Duke de Montmorancy, who from the beginning had a great AverÅ¿ion for this War, which he foreÅ¿aw would end in the Ruin of France, was more intent in levying Soldiers to defend the Borders of the Netherlands, than in proÅ¿ecuting the War againÅ¿t King Philip, and Invading his Dominions. In the mean time, Queen Mary of England, Queen Mary joyns with Spain. being over-perÅ¿uaded by King Philip her Husband, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to it by the Arts of Dr. Wotton, who was then her EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour in France, and by his Nephew, who found the French were well diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to a Rupture with England, if Calice might be the Prince of it, Å¿he I Å¿ay entred into the War too, and Å¿ent an Herald to the French Court with a Declaration to that purpoÅ¿e, who deliver'd it the Seventh of June. The French King took no leÅ¿s care to raiÅ¿e a War between England and Scotland, by way of DiverÅ¿ion, Mary the Queen of Scotland being before this Å¿ent into France to be married to the Dauphin, his EldeÅ¿t Son. So that he thought he had now a Right to Command that Nation to eÅ¿pouÅ¿e his Quarrel; but the Scotch Nobility thought otherwiÅ¿e, and would not Engage in a War againÅ¿t England, when they had no intereÅ¿t of their own to do it.

The Spaniards were all this while intent in providing Men and Arms, and the Twenty fifth of July attack'd the Fort of Rocroy, in the Borders of Champagne and Hainalt, four Leagues from Maribourg to the South; but finding there a greater ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance than they expected, they marched away towards Picardy with an Army of Thirty five thouÅ¿and Foot, and Twelve thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e. The Body of the French Army being but Eighteen thouÅ¿and Foot, and Five thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, and for the moÅ¿t part, both Sides Germans; Å¿o that the French thought it their IntereÅ¿t to coaÅ¿t along by the Enemy, and defend their Borders, and cover their Towns, which was all they could Å¿afely do in this inequality of Forces. There was then a very Å¿mall GarriÅ¿on in St. Quintin, The Siege of St. Quintin. under the Command of Charles de Teligny, Captain of the Troop of Guards belonging to the Dauphin; but the Army coming Å¿uddenly before it, the Sieur de Coligny the PreÅ¿ident of Picardy, put himÅ¿elf into the place with Å¿ome few Forces, and Å¿ent to Montmorancy to come up and Å¿uccour him. This was diÅ¿approved by thoÅ¿e about him as Dangerous, and if things Å¿ucceeded not, DiÅ¿honourable. In the beginning of the Siege, Teligny was Å¿lain in a Sally, by Engaging imprudently beyond his Orders, who
was a PerÅ¿on of great Courage and Strength, InduÅ¿try and Fidelity, and an Experienc'd Commander. And Andelot, The Battel of St. Quintin. who was Å¿ent by Coligny to bring Two thouÅ¿and Foot into the Town, was, by a miÅ¿take of his Guides, miÅ¿led, and falling into the Trenches of the BeÅ¿iegers, he was Å¿lain, and moÅ¿t of his Men cut off; and Montmorancy, attempting to relieve the Å¿ame place, was beaten alÅ¿o, and loÅ¿t Two thouÅ¿and five hundren Men, and himÅ¿elf was taken PriÅ¿oner. This Battel had a fatal effect upon France; for it made the Life of Henry II ever after Unfortunate, and reducing France to the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of a diÅ¿honourable Peace, it became the occaÅ¿ion of the Civil Wars which followed, to the great hazard of the Ruin of that Potent Kingdom, and may Å¿erve as an Example to Princes, not to violate their Faith, whoever diÅ¿penÅ¿e with it.

Montmorancy was from the beginning averÅ¿e to this War,
Montmorancy ruin'd by being taken PriÅ¿oner. and foretold the ill ConÅ¿equences of it; as he was an old, experienc'd, wiÅ¿e Commander, and a great Lover of his Country, Å¿o till then he had lived in great Power, and enjoyed the Favour of his Prince; but now when his good Fortune left him, he loÅ¿t the good EÅ¿teem and Regards of all Men; which from thence forward were conferred upon the Duke of Guize, who employ'd them to the damage of France, The News of this Victory fill'd France with Terror and Sorrow, and the Netherlands with Joy and Courage. The Duke of Nevers, and Å¿ome others of the principal French Commanders however eÅ¿caped.

If the Victorious Army had forthwith marched to Paris, they might have taken it; but King Philip was reÅ¿olved to hazard nothing, but commanded his Army to go on with the Siege of St. Quintin; and the King of France leaving Compeigne, where he then was, and going to Paris, Å¿o quieted the Minds of the People by his PreÅ¿ence and good Words, that things began to Å¿ettle, and the fear in a Å¿hort time to abate.

Coligny kept the TownÅ¿men of St. Quintin two days in Ignorance of this LoÅ¿s, and when they came to hear of it, though he Å¿aw the Town would at laÅ¿t be taken, yet he perÅ¿uaded them to hold it out to the laÅ¿t, that Å¿o the King might have time to recollect his Forces, and be in a condition to oppoÅ¿e the Victorious Enemy. Another of the Andelot's got into the Town, with about Five hundred ChoÅ¿en Men, and Å¿ome few Volunteers of the Nobility; but when all was done, King Philip coming in PerÅ¿on into the Camp, and the Siege being carried on with great diligence, the Town was taken by Storm the 27th of August, The Day of the Battel. and Coligny and Andelot became PriÅ¿oners too, and the latter was wounded. At this Siege there was Eight thouÅ¿and EngliÅ¿h employed, who did great Service; but finding themÅ¿elves ill uÅ¿ed after the Town was taken, they returned to Calis. St. Quintin taken by Storm. There were above Four hundred French Soldiers Å¿lain in this Town, and Three hundred taken PriÅ¿oners; and more had periÅ¿hed, if King Philip, who was preÅ¿ent, had not entred the City, and by Proclamation reÅ¿train'd the fury of his own Soldiers, to whom he granted the Plunder of the Town, which was great, and took particular care that thoÅ¿e who had not been concern'd in the danger of the Storming the Town, might have no Å¿hare in the Plunder of it.

Soon after this Victory, King Philip Å¿ent an ExpreÅ¿s to the late Emperor Charles his Father, who was then in his private Retirement in Spain, deÅ¿iring him to Å¿end his Advice how to proceed; the wiÅ¿e and good Prince return'd him an AnÅ¿wer to this purpoÅ¿e, as the Great Thuanus relates it. A Letter of Charles V, to his Son Philip.
Though this Retreat gives me the utmoÅ¿t Å¿ecurity, yet I received the Account of your Victory with a joyful and a pleaÅ¿ed Mind; and I congratulate the happy and fortunate Beginnings of my beloved Sons Reign; and I render to God Almighty my humbleÅ¿t and devouteÅ¿t Thanks and PraiÅ¿es, who hath not Å¿uffer'd the PerÅ¿idy of his Enemies to go long unpuniÅ¿hed, but has thus Å¿uddenly chaÅ¿tiÅ¿ed the Truce-breakers both in Italy, and on the Borders of the Netherlands. For though my mind foretold me it would come Å¿o to paÅ¿s, and I comforted my Å¿elf with that hope, yet I was vex'd that juÅ¿t at that time, when I had reÅ¿tored ChriÅ¿tendom to her Peace, and was going to compoÅ¿e my Soul in Peace, all things Å¿hould of a Å¿udden be fill'd with an unexpected War and Tumult. But then as to the Advice my Son deÅ¿ires from me, he is not to expect it either now or hereafter. He has with him many grave and wiÅ¿e Men of an approved Fidelity, and bred up to BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s during my Reign, whoÅ¿e CounÅ¿el I would take if I were now at the Helm. Let him conÅ¿ult with theÅ¿e Men, and well conÅ¿idering the weight of their ReaÅ¿ons, after he has firÅ¿t implored the Divine AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance and Grace, let him determine what is beÅ¿t to be done. This WiÅ¿e Prince would neither put himÅ¿elf
to the Trouble of conÅ¿idering what was beÅ¿t to be done, nor his Son to that of approving what perhaps he would not have liked, or of rejecting the CounÅ¿els of a Father, which would have been diÅ¿honourable to both. He had been Å¿o long a Sovereign, that he knew the Thoughts and TenderneÅ¿s of a Princes Heart, and could diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h between Civility nnd reality. And which was moÅ¿t of all, he was really, and not pretendedly Dead to the World.

The Germans tumultuouÅ¿ly demanded their Pay, after the Victory; the EngliÅ¿h alÅ¿o deÅ¿ired leave to return, pretending they had been ill uÅ¿ed, and the King was forced to grant their RequeÅ¿t, to prevent worÅ¿e ConÅ¿equences; So that in a Å¿hort time this victorious Army moulder'd to nothing, tho' his Captains did what they could to perÅ¿uade him to keep his Army up. And, which was yet worÅ¿e, many of the Germans paÅ¿Å¿ed over to the French, and helped to fill up their Numbers; Å¿o that King Philip took only CaÅ¿telet, Han, Chaulnes and Noyon, all Å¿mall Places, and this laÅ¿t by Surprize too. And then, in the latter end of October, was forced to withdraw his Army into the Low Countries, having in the mean time fortified S. Quintin, Han and Chaulnes to preÅ¿erve them.

WhilÅ¿t the SpaniÅ¿h Army was thus mouldering away and diÅ¿perÅ¿ing, the French King was every Day increaÅ¿ing his. The French Army grows great. He had Å¿ent for Å¿ix thouÅ¿and Switz, which were coming out of Piedmont, his German Supplies were come, as far as Is Sur Tille, near Dijon; And the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was every Day expected out of Italy, with the Forces under his Command, who was Å¿ent for, preÅ¿ently after the Defeat of S. Quintin, and was now on the Road with the Duke de Aumale his Brother. And the Duke of Nevers was Å¿trengthning Compeigne with a Royal Fort, by the King's Order.

The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, upon his arrival at S. Germain, was honourably received, and declared General of the Land-Forces, which had till then, from the taking of Montmorencey been in the Hands of the Duke of Nevers. A PerÅ¿ecution in France.

The DiÅ¿order of the War diverted Men from the Thoughts of PerÅ¿ecuting the ProteÅ¿tants in France, Å¿o that now they grew and multiplied very much, even in Paris. The fifth of November, in the Evening, there was a great number of theÅ¿e met in a Place called Bertomier, in S. James-Å¿treet, to perform the Offices of Religion, and to receive the Lord's Supper after their way. This being diÅ¿covered by Å¿ome, that lived near that place, they provided good quantities of Stones, in the neighbouring houÅ¿es, and their Arms ready in the Street; and when in the dead of the Night the Meeting broke up, they that firÅ¿t went out had Stones thrown at them; and a Tumult thereupon ariÅ¿ing, a vaÅ¿t number of the Rabble at that Signal, came running together, and attempted to break into the HouÅ¿e; they that were yet in the HouÅ¿e, adviÅ¿ed by their Danger, drew their Swords, and iÅ¿Å¿ued out, and all of them, except one (who was Å¿lain in the Crowd) made their eÅ¿cape tho' Å¿ome were wounded. The Women, and others, who were leÅ¿s able to Å¿hift, to the number of one hundred and twenty, rendred themÅ¿elves to Jean Martignon, the then Sheriff, who, when it was now Day, carried them to PriÅ¿on, the People being hardly kept from pulling them in Pieces, by the ConÅ¿tables and their Guards. Thereupon there were divers Rumors Å¿pread abroad concerning this Meeting, as is uÅ¿ual in New and Odious Occurrences: The miÅ¿repreÅ¿entations of the Roman Catholicks againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants. That this Rabble met in a Chamber in the Night, to Eat and play the Whore, and that after the Supper was over, they committed promiÅ¿cuous Villanies, the Mother lying with the Son, the Father with his Daughter, and the SiÅ¿ter with her Brother; That the Tables and ProviÅ¿ions were found, and that the Carpets and TapeÅ¿teries had Å¿till upon them the Marks of theÅ¿e Villanies: And becauÅ¿e this was not enough, they added, to enrage the Multitude yet more againÅ¿t them; that they had Communicated in the Blood of a Child. This Account was given to the King, but without any Author to juÅ¿tifie it; but then no Man daring neither to contradict it, for fear of being taken for an Heretick; thoÅ¿e that were of the Religion, wrote a Å¿mall Piece, which they called an Apology, in which they Å¿hew, That the Crimes thus laid to their Charge were meer Slanders, and they cited PaÅ¿Å¿ages out of the Fathers of the Church, to Å¿hew that the Å¿ame Forgeries had been made uÅ¿e of by the Pagans againÅ¿t the Primitive ChriÅ¿tians; and that they might be Å¿ure it might come to the King's Hands, they got it conveyed into his Bed-chamber; which Book was afterwards anÅ¿wered by Anthony de Mouchy, a Divine, and the chief of the InquiÅ¿itors, and by Robert Cenali, BiÅ¿hop of Auranches.

Jean Munier, Recorder of Paris, was appointed to examine the PriÅ¿oners, who reporting their AnÅ¿wers to the Parliament, Nich. Client, a Saintonian, who had been a School-maÅ¿ter many Years in Paris, and was now in the Å¿ixtieth Year of his Age, Taurin Gravelle, an Advocate i nthe Parliament of Paris, and Phillippina Lunia of
rigort, the Relict of one Graveron, a Gentleman, who was dead, were all condemned the fourteenth of September, and the two firÅ¿t were burnt alive, but the latter was firÅ¿t Å¿trangled. And four Days after Nich. Le Cene, a PhyÅ¿ician of Normandy, and Peter Gambara of Poictou were burnt. Francis Rebeziers, born at Stafort in Condomois, and Frederick Danville of Olerone in Bearne, were led with an Iron Ball in their Mouths to the Place of Execution, where they were hanged, and their Bodies burn'd to AÅ¿hes. When they were now going to proceed againÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, a Noble Matron, which was among the PriÅ¿oners, offered a Petition to the Parliament, excepting therein againÅ¿t Å¿everal of the Judges, and offering many ReaÅ¿ons in her Petition, which ought not to be neglected, to have them Å¿et by, and Å¿ome others to be appointed in their Å¿tead at the Trial: Whil the Parliament were conÅ¿idering what they ought to do as to this Petition, there came Envoys from the Switz and ProteÅ¿tant Princes in Germany, to deÅ¿ire the King not to proceed againÅ¿t a Company of miÅ¿erable People, who were of the Å¿ame Religion with themÅ¿elves. And thereupon the Affairs of Philip being then in great ProÅ¿perity, and thoÅ¿e of France in a declining Condition; and the King needing the AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Switz and ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany, for the Recovery of his Country, he Å¿uffered the Parliament to act more mildly with them: So Å¿ome of them were diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed, others turned over to the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Courts, where by the Revocation of the Sentence, they eÅ¿caped Death. Rantigny and Champagne, two married Ladies, were given to their Husbands, who were very averÅ¿e to that Religion, and Ovarty, another Lady, was given into the Hands of Queen Catherine.

The King of France publiÅ¿hed an Edict the Å¿eventeenth of May, commanding all BiÅ¿hops and their Curates to reÅ¿ide upon their Benefices, and to preach to the People, or to appoint others in their Å¿tead, who Å¿hould do Å¿o, upon pain of being deprived of the Profits of their Cures. There had been a Law publiÅ¿hed to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e by Lewis XI, the thirteenth of January 1476, which was now revived, Men judging that Preaching was a likelier way to fix Men in their Religion than Fire and Faggot. But, however, this Edict was not much regarded by the Clergy of France, who were then as Unlearned and Ignorant, as they were Cruel and Bloody.

The Army belonging to King Philip, being, as I have Å¿aid, diÅ¿Å¿ipated, The Siege of Calais. or put into Winter Quarters, and that of France growing daily greater, it was taken into ConÅ¿ideration, How they Å¿hould employ that chargable Body of Men, though the Winter was then in its greateÅ¿t Rigour. The firÅ¿t Debate was, Whether they Å¿hould attempt the Recovery of S. Quintin, and the other Places that were loÅ¿t, or enter upon Å¿ome new Enterprize; and here they reÅ¿olved upon the latter, and the Reduction of Calais having been propoÅ¿ed by Senarpont, Governour of Boulogne, in the latter End of the Summer, if the Misfortune of S. Quintin had not broke their MeaÅ¿ures, they preÅ¿ently reÅ¿olved to reaÅ¿Å¿ume that interrupted DeÅ¿ign. A part of their Forces marched under the Duke of Nevers, pretending they intended to attack Luxemburg and Arlon. Another Part under the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, (who was now General of all the French Forces) pretended to block up S. Quintin, and the other Places that were loÅ¿t. Nevers having paÅ¿Å¿ed through the Territory of Argone, came to Stenay, a Town in the Dukedom of Lorain, and having Å¿taid there a Å¿hort time, Å¿uddenly Å¿ends his part of the Army to joyn the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who lay then at Amiens, who preÅ¿ently marched away for Boulogne, as if he had been Å¿olicitous for the PreÅ¿ervation of it, but Å¿uddenly wheeling about, the firÅ¿t of January,
year 1558 he came to Newnham-bridge, a Fort Å¿eated a mile from the Town of Calais, which commanded the Avenues to the Land-ward: There was another called RiÅ¿bank, which lay near to the Town, and commanded the Harbour on the North of the Town, and upon theÅ¿e two Forts the greateÅ¿t part of the Security of Calais depended.

The Lord Wentworth was then Governour of the Town, but the GarriÅ¿on was not above five hundred Men, and there were not above two hundred TownÅ¿men, able to bear Arms; Å¿o that the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿ending three thouÅ¿and MuÅ¿queteers, and the Soldiers of Newnham-fort, having made one improÅ¿perous Sally againÅ¿t them, and not being relieved by the Governour, the Cannon was brought up againÅ¿t it, which began to batter it the next Morning. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e knew very well the whole Å¿treÅ¿s of the SucceÅ¿s lay in the celerity of his Actions, and accordingly, the next Day, attacked the Fort of Risbank too, which were both yielded the Å¿ame Day, by the order of the Governour.

The Town of Calais is Å¿eated in a Plain, The Site of Calais. and on three Sides of it is almoÅ¿t inacceÅ¿Å¿ible, by reaÅ¿on of the River Hames, part of which fills its Dikes, which are Great and Deep, and the reÅ¿t falls, with Å¿everal other Å¿mall Rivers into the Haven,
on the weÅ¿t Side of the Town. Its Form is Square, and at three of its Corners, it has Royal BaÅ¿tions, and the fourth, which is towards the South, has an Ancient but Å¿trong CaÅ¿tle for its Defence; beÅ¿ides, it has a Å¿trong Bulwork of Earth, which is very high and thick, but is of Å¿o Å¿andy a nature (as the French found after this, to their Damage) that the force of a Cannon Å¿cattered it like duÅ¿t. The Rivers and MarÅ¿hes encompaÅ¿Å¿ing the Town on all Sides, there was no PaÅ¿Å¿age to it but by a CauÅ¿ey from the Fort of Newnham, nor was it poÅ¿Å¿ible for any Ship to enter the Town, but what paÅ¿Å¿ed under the Fort of Risbank, Å¿o that theÅ¿e two Forts were the great Securities of the Town, which were both now in the Hands of the French; after which they lodged on the CauÅ¿ey and Banks twenty Foot Companies, and one German Regiment, and one thouÅ¿and one hundred HorÅ¿e: The MarÅ¿hal de Termes Å¿ecured the Way leading to Guines, with the reÅ¿t of the HorÅ¿e and the Switz. The fifth of January they began to batter the River-gate with four whole Cannon; and three hundred Culverins were imployed againÅ¿t the other parts of the Walls and Bulworks, but their main Battery was againÅ¿t the River-gate, whilÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h drew almoÅ¿t all their Forces on this Side; the Gate and Å¿ome of the next Towers being much battered, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e ordered fifteen Cannon Å¿uddenly to be planted againÅ¿t the CaÅ¿tle, the Walls of which were not faced with Earth within; this Battery was plaid with that Fury, that the NoiÅ¿e of the Cannon was heard as far as Antwerp, which is thirty three German Miles to the North: A great Breach being made there, Andelot was commanded to paÅ¿s the River, and lodge himÅ¿elf upon the other Side with one thouÅ¿and two hundred MuÅ¿queteers; after this they drew the Water out of the Town-Dike, which was thought by the EngliÅ¿h the greateÅ¿t defence they had, and by pitched Hurdles they laid a PaÅ¿Å¿age over the muddy Dikes and marÅ¿hy Grounds for the Soldiers, and Å¿ecured the Foot from the Annoyance of the Small-Å¿hot by other Hurdles about half a foot thick, which had Stakes fenced with Iron to Å¿trike into the Ground, and Loop-holes to Å¿hoot through. The Night after (the Walls being now battered down) the Duke of GuiÅ¿e ordered Grammont, with three hundred Small-Å¿hot, to play all Night into the Breach, to hinder the EngliÅ¿h from making any Works within the CaÅ¿tle, for their Defence. Strozzi was ordered at the Å¿ame time to lodge himÅ¿elf with the Å¿ame number of Foot and one hundred Pioneers, on the other Side, near the Gate, but was beaten off by the EngliÅ¿h Small-Å¿hot, and forced to return to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. The next Morning, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e having ordered the Breach at the CaÅ¿tle to be carefully viewed, Grammont was ordered with three hundred Muskets, to enter the place, who was to be Å¿econded by Strozzi, with the Å¿ame number; theÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ed the Dike in Water up to the Navel, and notwithÅ¿tanding any reÅ¿iÅ¿tance the EngliÅ¿h could make, lodged themÅ¿elves in the CaÅ¿tle, driving thoÅ¿e of the EngliÅ¿h, that had not been Å¿lain, into the Town. The CaÅ¿tle being thus gained, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e put a Å¿trong GarriÅ¿on into it.
