The EngliÅ¿h, Å¿o Å¿oon as the Tide returned again (which filled the Dikes) Å¿tormed the CaÅ¿tle, in hopes to regain that important PoÅ¿t, and being beaten off, they planted four Cannon againÅ¿t the Bridge, and forced open the CaÅ¿tle-gate, and then Å¿tormed it the Å¿econd time, but having loÅ¿t two hundred of their beÅ¿t Men to no good purpoÅ¿e, they then began to treat of a Surrender; which at laÅ¿t was agreed; The Governour and fifty others being to become PriÅ¿oners of War; The Soldiery and TownÅ¿men to be at liberty, to paÅ¿s into England or Flanders, without any Injury, as to their Lives or Liberties: And all the Ammunition, Cannon, HouÅ¿holdÅ¿tuff, Gold, Silver, MerchandiÅ¿e and HorÅ¿e, was to be left to the diÅ¿poÅ¿al of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. On theÅ¿e Conditions was Calais delivered up to the French, the fourteenth of January 1557, 58, when it had been two hundred and ten Years in the hands of the EngliÅ¿h. The Place was no Å¿ooner yielded up but great numbers of Ships came over, who underÅ¿tanding what had paÅ¿Å¿ed, returned back. King Philip had Å¿melt the DeÅ¿ign of the French upon this Place, and had wrote to Queen Mary, that he would put Succours into the Town; but this was Å¿uÅ¿pected, by the EngliÅ¿h, as a DeÅ¿ign to get Calais into his own Hands, and Å¿o his Prediction came to paÅ¿s.

After Calais was taken they fell to conÅ¿ider,
Guines taken. Whether they Å¿hould attack Guines, which was in the Hands of the EngliÅ¿h, and lay two French Leagues from Calais, to the South, or Graveling, a Town of Flanders three Leagues to the N. E. But they reÅ¿olved to attempt Guines, which was nearer, and more neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the Å¿ecuring the PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of Calais, the Lord Gray was Governour of it, who had a good GarriÅ¿on, and had received Å¿ome Succours from King Philip; yet at the firÅ¿t Attack he left the Town, and fled into the CaÅ¿tle; but whilÅ¿t the French were plundering
the Town, returned again, and drove them out, and firing the Town returned into the CaÅ¿tle again, which in a Å¿hort time after he Å¿urrendred, when he had eight hundred EngliÅ¿h, SpaniÅ¿h and Flemmings to have continued the Defence of it; but the Hearts of the EngliÅ¿h were down, for Gray was reputed a good Soldier.

There was now nothing left to the EngliÅ¿h but a Å¿mall Place call'd the Comte de Oye, which had a CaÅ¿tle not Å¿trong, but almoÅ¿t unacceÅ¿Å¿ible, as being Å¿urrounded with unpaÅ¿Å¿able MarÅ¿hes, and which had no PaÅ¿Å¿age but over a Timber-Bridge: This Place lies almoÅ¿t two Leagues from Calais towards Graveling, the GarriÅ¿on of which never Å¿taid for a Summons, but hearing of the loÅ¿s of Guines fled, and left the Place open and unguarded, and Sipetra took poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it, without any further trouble, for the French. Burnet calls this CaÅ¿tle Hammes, and Thuanus Oye; but the CaÅ¿tles of Hammes lay directly between Guines and Calais. One Sir Edward GrimÅ¿tone was then Comptroler of Calais and a Privy CounÅ¿ellor, and he had often given AdvertiÅ¿ement of the ill condition of the GarriÅ¿on; but the TreaÅ¿ury was low, the People diÅ¿contented, and the Thoughts of the Queen and her Council more Å¿et upon extirpating HereÅ¿ie (as they called it) than upon preÅ¿erving this important PoÅ¿t, Å¿o it was loÅ¿t, and the Grief and DiÅ¿honour of this Misfortune Å¿at Å¿o heavy upon the Spirits of the Queen, that Å¿he never joyed after.

The next thing the French undertook was the taking of the CaÅ¿tle of Herbemont, in the ForeÅ¿t of Ardenne, belonging to the Count of BeiliÅ¿teine, which was very troubleÅ¿ome to the Inhabitants of Ivoy; this enterprize Å¿ucceeded well too, and they took the CaÅ¿tle the Å¿ixteenth of February, and after it Å¿everal other Å¿mall Places on the Frontiers, were deÅ¿erted by their GarriÅ¿ons.

This Year a Fleet of one hundred and twenty TurkiÅ¿h Galleys looÅ¿ed from PreveÅ¿a a Port of Epirus, and paÅ¿Å¿ing by BrindiÅ¿i, took and plundred Reggio, A TurkiÅ¿h Fleet land in Å¿everal Places of Italy, and carry many into Slavery. a City in the South of Italy, after which, landing in the Bay di Surrneto, they carried four thouÅ¿and perÅ¿ons into Slavery, among which was a great many Monks and Nuns. The Grief and Shame of this was the greater, becauÅ¿e it was done in Å¿ight of Naples. From thence it Å¿ailed to the CoaÅ¿t of Provence, and having refreÅ¿hed the Sailors, it returned to Minorca, and took the Town of Citadella, with great difficulty, and the loÅ¿s of four hundred Men, after which it returned in AuguÅ¿t into Turkey. The French Fleet, in the Mediterranean was able to do nothing for want of Money, Å¿o the Fear was much greater than the Hurt.

The twenty fifth of May the Dauphine was married to Mary Queen of the Scots, The Dauphine married to Mary Queen of Scotland. yet the Scotch AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors refuÅ¿ed to promiÅ¿e under their Hands and Seals to procure the Dauphine, in the next Convention of their States to be received and owned as King of Scotland; and thereupon four of them dying Å¿oon after, it was Å¿uÅ¿pected that they had been poiÅ¿oned: Yet in the next Convention the thing was granted, and the Earl of Argile was appointed to bring the Marital Crown into France: But in the mean time Mary Queen of England dyed, which occaÅ¿ioned a great Change in England, France and Scotland. The greateÅ¿t part of the Scots were not pleaÅ¿ed with this Marriage; and the French too, underhand, diÅ¿liked it, as tending to the exalting the HouÅ¿e of GuiÅ¿e, and the depreÅ¿Å¿ing that of Montmorency, and GaÅ¿per de Coligny Admiral of France, who were both at this time PriÅ¿oners to King Philip.

A meeting in the mean time being appointed at Perone between Christierna the Mother of the Cardinal of Lorraine and Perrenot BiÅ¿hop of Arras for King Philip, The firÅ¿t PropoÅ¿als of a Peace between France and King Philip. and the Duke and Cardinal of Loraine for the French: Perrenot deploring the progreÅ¿s of the TurkiÅ¿h Arms during this unfortunate War, and above all things the increaÅ¿e of HereÅ¿ie in France and the Netherlands, cunningly offered the HouÅ¿e of GuiÅ¿e their AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance for the ruining Montmorency, Coligny and Andelot, as favourors of the Reformation, when a Peace were once Å¿etled between theÅ¿e two Crowns: The HouÅ¿e of GuiÅ¿e hereby only Å¿eeking to aggrandize it Å¿elf upon the Ruine of theÅ¿e three great Men, and the Spaniards to imbroil and weaken France. The Cardinal, at his return, acquaints the King with what concerned Andelot, intermixing a mention of a Peace with it. Henry II, was a mild and moÅ¿t merciful Prince, but had an implacable averÅ¿ion for the Reformation, which had been inÅ¿tilled into him in his Infancy, by thoÅ¿e who had the Care of him; and he had before this heard Å¿omething of Andelot's Inclinations to favour that Party, and thereupon Å¿ent for him, who waited upon the King at Monceaux, a CaÅ¿tle near Meaux.
Andelot MarÅ¿hal of France ruined by the Arts of the GuiÅ¿es. The King gave him great aÅ¿Å¿urance of his kindneÅ¿s to him, and of his SenÅ¿e of his Merits and Services, and then told him, He was much concerned to hear, from all Places, That he was not Å¿ound in the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Religion; and thereupon asked him what his Belief of the Sacrifice of the MaÅ¿s was. A â¢ delot, who was a Man of Spirit, anÅ¿wered
otherwiÅ¿e than the King deÅ¿ired, and according to Calvin's Doctrin: The King admoniÅ¿hed him, That he Å¿hould conÅ¿ider himÅ¿elf, and not run into MiÅ¿chief: He replied with more confidence than he had Å¿hewn before, That it was a great Satisfaction to him, that the King, whom he and his Family had found a Bountiful MaÅ¿ter, and to whom he had in all things hitherto Å¿hewn himÅ¿elf a most Loyal, Faithful and InduÅ¿trious Subject, had Å¿o far approved of him: But then he was not to play the Hypocrite with God in the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Religion; his Body, his EÅ¿tate, and his Honour were in the Hands of the King, and he might diÅ¿poÅ¿e of them as he thought fit, but his Soul was Å¿ubject to none but God, who gave it, and therefore in this matter he must obey God only as his greatest MaÅ¿ter. This AnÅ¿wer Å¿o intaged the King, that taking his Lance in his hand, and intending only to throw it on the ground, he wounded the Dauphin with it, who Å¿ate beneath him; and the Tables being taken away, he ordered Andelot to be taken into CuÅ¿tody, who was for Å¿ome time detained in the HouÅ¿e of the BiÅ¿hop of Meaux, and from thence he was Å¿ent to the CaÅ¿tle of Melun.

Andelot being thus laid aÅ¿ide, the Baron de Monluc, a PerÅ¿on of good Merit, was made General of the French Foot in his Å¿tead, which was a Place of great conÅ¿ideration in the Army. In the beginning of May,
Thionville beÅ¿ieged and taken. the French Å¿at down before Thionville, with about Five thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e, and Fourteen thouÅ¿and Foot. This Town is Å¿eated in the Dukedom of Luxemburg, in a Plain Country, but Low and MarÅ¿hy, and having the MoÅ¿elle on the N.W. which fills its deep Ditches, on which Å¿ides it has only two BaÅ¿tions, which are Å¿hort, Å¿o that they cannot clear their Dikes, and at a great diÅ¿tance from each other. The reÅ¿t of the City is Å¿ecured by great Towers, which extend themÅ¿elves beyond the Walls, and they again are within well fill'd with Earth. Four thouÅ¿and TownÅ¿men, and Fifteen hundred Soldiers marched out of this place when it was yielded up, moÅ¿t of the latter being wounded on the Head. The French loÅ¿t Four hundred, and had more wounded in this Siege. After this, they took Arlone, another Town in the Å¿ame Dukedom, three German Miles from Luxemburg to the WeÅ¿t, by Surprize, which being burnt by an unexpected Accident, was diÅ¿mantled and deÅ¿erted. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e hearing of this Defeat, return'd to Pierre-pont, in the Borders of Picardy and Champagne, the Twenty eighth of July, that he might be ready at hand to prevent any Attempt might be made on France. The TownÅ¿men meeting, as the CuÅ¿tom is, in a place call'd the Scholars Field, without the Suburbs of St. German, near Paris, a few of them, who were addicted to the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, began to Å¿ing David's PÅ¿alms in French Metre; thereupon the People began, to leave their Sports, and joyning with them, Å¿ung the Å¿ame PÅ¿alms: After this, a greater number, and among them Anthony King of Navarr, and Jonae his Lady, who was already Å¿uÅ¿pected to favour that Religion, fell into the Å¿ame Practice. About the Å¿ame time, The EngliÅ¿h Fleet unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful. News was brought of the arrival of an EngliÅ¿h Fleet of an Hundred and twenty Ships upon the CoaÅ¿t of Normandy, under the Lord Clinton. The French by this time had got together a very great Army, which the King Å¿aw drawn up near Pierre-pont; and King Philip's was not leÅ¿s, but then neither of theÅ¿e Princes were diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to try the Hazards of the War any further; and Montmorency having agreed for his RanÅ¿ome, at the rate of one hundred and Å¿ixty five thouÅ¿and Crowns, and being now grown old, and averÅ¿e from the Thoughts of War, he and ChriÅ¿tierna, the Mother of the Duke of Loraine, went to and for between the two Princes, to promote a Treaty of Peace.

VendoÅ¿me Vidame of Chartres, who was made Governour of Calais, after Thermes was taken PriÅ¿oner, The Treaty of Cambray began. had a DeÅ¿ign upon S. Omers, but it was diÅ¿covered and prevented. In the middle of September, AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours from England, France and Spain met at Cambray, to treat of a Peace in good earneÅ¿t, and the firÅ¿t thing they agreeed upon, was the withdrawing of the two Armies, becauÅ¿e they Å¿eemed very diÅ¿Å¿onant from the End of that Meeting. The fifth of November the EngliÅ¿h Parliament met, The Parliament of England meet, and Queen Mary dies. but in a very ill Temper. The great Thuanus, contrary to his CuÅ¿tom, paÅ¿Å¿eth over Queen Mary without any Character; he could Å¿ay little that was good of her, and would Å¿ay nothing that was ill. ThoÅ¿e of her own Religion are now Å¿o Å¿enÅ¿ible of the Errors of her Government, that they are more put to it for Apologies than Panigyricks on her Memory.

In Germany a Dyet was appointed to meet at Frankford the twenty fourth of February, The German Affairs. to which the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours named by Charles V, before his Voyage into Spain, came and delivered his ReÅ¿ignation of the Empire, by which he had transferred his Authority to Ferdinand his Brother, then King of the Romans, to the Electors, who after a Å¿hort deliberation accepted the Å¿ame, and in a Å¿olemn manner elected and admitted Ferdinand to the Empire, and afterwards crowned him. After his return to Vienna, he Å¿ent Martin GuÅ¿man, his Lord High Chamberlain, to Rome to acquaint the Pope with the ReÅ¿ignation of Charles V, and his Advancement to the Empire, and to aÅ¿Å¿ure his HolineÅ¿s of his good Affections to that See. The moroÅ¿e Old Gentleman would not admit the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, but left the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to be diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed by the Cardinals, who were appointed for that purpoÅ¿e; who muÅ¿t needs make a great buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of it, and reÅ¿olved, That what had been done at Frankford was of no Validity, becauÅ¿e the Holy See had not conÅ¿ented to it, and ChriÅ¿t's Vicar, who was entruÅ¿ted with the Keys of the That is the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticai and Civil Government. CeleÅ¿tial and TerreÅ¿tial Government, without whoÅ¿e ConÅ¿ent, neither Charles could be diÅ¿charged from the Empire, nor Ferdinand be admitted. That no ReÅ¿ignation or Deprivation could be made to or by any other than the Pope. BeÅ¿ides what was done at Frankford, had been tranÅ¿acted by Men infected with HereÅ¿ie, who had loÅ¿t all that Grace and Power, which belonged to them, whilÅ¿t they were Members of the Church of Rome: That therefore Ferdinand was to appear within three Months before the Pope's Tribunal, to anÅ¿wer for his MiÅ¿demeanours, and to Å¿hew his Repentance; and then without doubt he would obtain Pardon from this meek Father: With much more to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e.

Ferdinand was of another Temper, and ordered his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to return, if he were not admitted within three Days, leaving a ProteÅ¿tation behind him. This a little quelled the Pope, who admitted him to a Private Audience the thirteenth of
July, when the Pope excuÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf for not having granted his RequeÅ¿t Å¿ooner, for want of LeiÅ¿ure and Time to examine all the Difficulties which were propoÅ¿ed in this Affair by the Cardinals; and Å¿eeing his LordÅ¿hip could Å¿tay no longer at Rome, he might return when he pleaÅ¿ed, and he would Å¿end an AmbaÅ¿Å¿adour to the Emperour (Å¿o he called Charles V, notwithÅ¿tanding his ReÅ¿ignation) as Å¿oon as was poÅ¿Å¿ible. And thus this thing Å¿tood till the Death of Pope Paul III.

Charles V, late Emperour of Germany, The Death and Character of Charles the Fifth; being at laÅ¿t overpowered by the many DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es which oppreÅ¿Å¿ed him, died the twenty firÅ¿t of September. In this Prince (Å¿aith Thuanus) Fortune and Virtue Å¿trove to Crown his DeÅ¿erts with the utmoÅ¿t degree of Temporal Felicity. And for my part, I take him for the beÅ¿t Pattern which can poÅ¿Å¿ibly be given of a virtuous Prince, in this or any former Age. His laÅ¿t Words were theÅ¿e, Continue in me my dear Saviour, that I may continue in thee. He lived fifty eight Years, Å¿ix Months and twenty five Days, and was Emperour of Germany thirty Å¿ix Years.

Thuanus Å¿aith of him, That no part of his Life was deÅ¿titute of Å¿ome commendable Action, yet he Å¿hew'd the greatneÅ¿s of his Soul moÅ¿t viÅ¿ibly in the cloÅ¿e of it: Before he was wont to conquer others, in this he overcame himÅ¿elf, and reflecting on a better Life, renounced this preÅ¿ent, which was lyable to Å¿o many Chances, before he dyed; and having Å¿o many Years lived to the good of others, began now to live only to God and himÅ¿elf. In all that two Years which went next before his DiÅ¿Å¿olution, he lived in the Society of Å¿ome Monks of the Order of S. Jerome; and by the Advice of one ConÅ¿tantin, his ConfeÅ¿Å¿or, applied himÅ¿elf chiefly to the reading of S. Bernard, and fixing his Soul only on God, thus he argued: His Opinion concerning JuÅ¿tification. That he was unworthy, by his own Merits, to obtain the Kingdom of Heaven; but his Lord God, who had a double Right to it, that of Inheritance from his Father, and that of the Merits of his PaÅ¿Å¿ion, was content with the firÅ¿t as to himÅ¿elf, and has left the Å¿econd to me, by whoÅ¿e Gift I may juÅ¿tly claim it, and truÅ¿ting to this Faith, I Å¿hall not be aÅ¿hamed: For neither can the Oyl of Mercy be put in any other VeÅ¿Å¿el than that of Faith: That this is the only Confidence of that Man who forÅ¿akes himÅ¿elf and relies upon his Lord: That to truÅ¿t any otherwiÅ¿e to ones own Merits was not of Faith but Perfidy: That Sins were forgiven by the Mercy of God, and therefore we ought to believe that none but God can blot them out, againÅ¿t whom only we have Å¿inned, in whom is no Å¿in, and by whom alone our Å¿ins are forgiven, us. TheÅ¿e Doctrins were afterwards thought in Spain to approach Å¿o near thoÅ¿e of the Lutherans, that his ConfeÅ¿Å¿or was burnt for an Heretick after he was dead; and Å¿ome others that were about him had hard meaÅ¿ure, after his Death, on that account, and Lucas OÅ¿iander affirms, in expreÅ¿s Terms, That Charles V, dyed a Lutheran in the Point of JuÅ¿tification.

Queen Elizabeth, preÅ¿ently after her Å¿ettlement, Queen Elizabeth Å¿ucceeds. diÅ¿patched MeÅ¿Å¿engers to all the Princes of ChriÅ¿tendom, giving notice of her SiÅ¿ter's Death, and her SucceÅ¿Å¿ion, and among them, to the Pope alÅ¿o, by Sir Edward Karn, then ReÅ¿ident at Rome. His HolineÅ¿s, in his uÅ¿ual Stile replyed; That England was held in Fee of the ApoÅ¿tolick See, That Å¿he could not Å¿ucceed, being illegitimate, nor could he contradict the Declarations made in that matter by his PredeceÅ¿Å¿ors Clement VII, and Paul III: He Å¿aid it was a great boldneÅ¿s in her to aÅ¿Å¿ume the Crown without his ConÅ¿ent; for which, in ReaÅ¿on, Å¿he deÅ¿erved no Favour at his Hands: Yet if Å¿he would renounce her Pretentions, and refer herÅ¿elf wholly to him, he would Å¿hew a Fatherly Affection to her, and do every thing for her that could conÅ¿iÅ¿t with the Dignity of the ApoÅ¿tolick See. It was great pity this generous Pope Å¿hould fall into Å¿uch Heretical Times; his great Soul would certainly have wrought Wonders berfore the Days of Luther; but now alaÅ¿s! all this Papal MeekneÅ¿s Å¿erved only to render that Å¿inking Ship more deÅ¿picable and hated; for Queen Elizabeth, when Å¿he heard of it, was nothing concerned at it, but immediately Å¿he recalled Karn's Powers, and commanded him to come home: And Popery from hence forward fared very will in England; but then our Affairs have been Å¿o exactly deÅ¿cribed by others, and are Å¿o well known to EngliÅ¿h Men, That I Å¿hall here diÅ¿miÅ¿s them, and apply my Å¿elf wholly to the Foreign Affairs.

Thuanus obÅ¿erves, The Scotch Affairs. That this Year there was rather no War than a Peace in Scotland, for that the whole Kingdom was imbroiled with Rapines and the burning of Towns, two of the principal Nobility of Scotland being carried away captive by the EngliÅ¿h, William Keth Son of the Earl MarÅ¿hal, and Patrick Gray: An EngliÅ¿h Fleet alÅ¿o, under the Command of Sir John Clare, infeÅ¿ted the Scotch Shoars, and burnt a Place, by my Author called Cracoviaca, Kirk-wall, Main-Land, the principal of the IÅ¿les of Orkney, which he Å¿aith was the Seat of the BiÅ¿hop, and the
principal, or rather only Town in thoÅ¿e IÅ¿lands, which he Å¿uppofeth was Å¿everely chaÅ¿tized by Heaven, by a TempeÅ¿t, which Å¿oon after diÅ¿perÅ¿ed the Fleet, leaving a part of the EngliÅ¿h on the IÅ¿land, who were all Å¿lain by the IÅ¿landers and Natives.

This Year alÅ¿o the Reformation of Religion was much agitated, tho not effected in Scotland;
Scotland begins to entertain the Reformation. Alexander Somervill ArchbiÅ¿hop of S. Andrews, with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the reÅ¿t of the Churchmen, condemned one Walter Mills, an old PrieÅ¿t, to be burnt for HereÅ¿ie, and baniÅ¿hed one Paul Mefan, hoping thereby to reÅ¿tore their loÅ¿t Authority, and curb the People; but it had a quite contrary effect, the patient and chearful Martyrdom of Mills incenÅ¿ing the People to that height, that they Å¿poke very freely, or as my Author has it, LicentiouÅ¿ly and SeditiouÅ¿ly of the Church-men, and a Solemn ProceÅ¿Å¿ion being made on the firÅ¿t day of September, in memory of S. Eugenius, or S. Gile's at Edenburgh, of which he was Patron, whoÅ¿e Image was then carried about with great Pomp, the People tore it out of the Hands of thoÅ¿e that bore it, and threw it into the common Drought, having firÅ¿t broke off the Head, Hands and Feet of this Wooden Saint, the Monks and the reÅ¿t of his Friends fleeing, and leaving him to Å¿hift for himÅ¿elf. The Clergy Å¿eeing their Authority thus Å¿inking, aÅ¿Å¿embled in a Synod, the ninth of November, to try if the Å¿eting a good Face, and pretending great ConÅ¿idence would retrieve their Å¿inking CauÅ¿e: But they of the Reformed Party, on the contrary, of all Degrees exhorted one another to perÅ¿evere in the Truth, and not to Å¿uffer themÅ¿elves to be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed by a Å¿mall and weak number of Men: For if (Å¿ay they) theÅ¿e Men proceed by Legal CourÅ¿es, we Å¿hall be too hard for them, if they make uÅ¿e of Force, we are a Match for them. They drew up an AddreÅ¿s alÅ¿o to the Queen Regent, which they Å¿ent unto her by one James Sandelands, an Honourable Baron, and of great account, in it deÅ¿iring, That the Publick Prayers and AdminiÅ¿tration of the Sacraments might be in the Vulgar Tongue, and that the MiniÅ¿ters might be elected by the People. The Regent, tho' a zealous Catholick, yet fearing a Tumult, commanded the PrieÅ¿ts to Å¿ay the Prayers in the Scotch Language. The Å¿ame Demands were made by the Nobility of the Synod, then aÅ¿Å¿embled at Edinburgh: Who replyed, That they muÅ¿t abide by the Orders of the Canon-Law, and the Decrees of the Council of Trent. The Nobility perceiving them thus averÅ¿e to a Reformation, Å¿ent one John Aresken of Dundee a learned Man to appeaÅ¿e them; who with great reÅ¿pect beÅ¿ought them, At leaÅ¿t to grant the People the uÅ¿e of the publick Prayers in their Mother Tongue. The Clergy would nevertheleÅ¿s abate nothing of their former Severity; and the Queen regent, by their PerÅ¿uaÅ¿ion Å¿oon recalled what had been extorted from her. But the Death of Queen Mary of England, and the SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Queen Elizabeth, which happened this Month, Å¿oon turned the Scales, and gave her CauÅ¿e to repent her too great obÅ¿tinacy.

The Learned SpotiÅ¿wood obÅ¿erves, That this Mills was the laÅ¿t Martyr that dyed in Scotland for Religion; That Patrick Lermoth Bailiff of the Regality, abÅ¿olutely refuÅ¿ed to paÅ¿s Sentence of Death, as a Judge upon him, after the BiÅ¿hop had delivered him up to the Secular Power; that in the whole City of S. Andrews a Cord was not to be had for Money, Å¿o that they were forced to take one of the Cords of the ArchbiÅ¿hop's Pavilion, to tie him to the Stake. It had been good Prudence to have deÅ¿iÅ¿ted, when they Å¿aw the whole Body of the People thus bent againÅ¿t them, but they were hurried on to their Ruine, by a blind Rage.

The People of Scotland were no leÅ¿s incenÅ¿ed on the other Side, and reÅ¿olved openly to profeÅ¿s the Reformed Religion, binding themÅ¿elves by PromiÅ¿e and SubÅ¿cription to an Oath, That if any Å¿hould be called in queÅ¿tion for matters of Religion, at any time hereafter, they would take Arms, and joyn in defence of their Religion and Brethren, againÅ¿t the Tyranny and PerÅ¿ecution of the BiÅ¿hops. The principal Men, who joyned in this Bond were Archibald Earl of Argile, Alexander Earl of Glencarne, James Earl of Morton, Archibald Lord of Lorne, Sir James Sandelands of Calder, John Erskin of Dun, and William Maitland of Lethington. To this Bond vaÅ¿t numbers throughout the Kingdom Å¿ubÅ¿cribed, Å¿o that they found their numbers were at leaÅ¿t equal to thoÅ¿e that oppoÅ¿ed them.

div.head: A CONTINUATION OF THE HISTORY OF THE REFORMATION.
BOOK II.

argument.head: The CONTENTS.
argument.p: The Deaths and Characters of Frederick I, and ChriÅ¿tian II, Kings. of Denmark. Frederick II conquereth DietmarÅ¿h. The Affairs of Italy. New BiÅ¿hopricks erected in the Low-Countries. King Philip deÅ¿irous of a Peace with France, that he might be at leiÅ¿ure to extirpate HereÅ¿ie. That DeÅ¿ign diÅ¿covered to the Prince of Orange. The Diet of Germany. Conditions propoÅ¿ed in it by the ProteÅ¿tants for a Council. The Emperor confirms the Peace of PaÅ¿Å¿aw. The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors come to the Dyet. The Life and Death of David George, a famous ImpoÅ¿tor. The Treaty of Cambray produces a Peace at last. The Peace occaÅ¿ioneth a PerÅ¿ecution in France. The King goes to the Parliament of Paris, to awe it into a Compliance: Yet Å¿ome retain their Freedom at the Price of their Lives. The King's AnÅ¿wer. A French Synod held by the ProteÅ¿tant MiniÅ¿ters. The ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany write to the King of France in the behalf of the PerÅ¿ecuted. A CommiÅ¿Å¿ion iÅ¿Å¿ued to Try the Å¿uÅ¿pected Members of Parliament. Du Bourg first Tried. The Å¿ad condition of France during the PerÅ¿ecution. Henry II Å¿lain. The various Characters of that Prince. Francis II Å¿ucceeds him, a Lad of Sixteen Years of age. The PerÅ¿ecution goes on. Slanders against the ProteÅ¿tants. Du Bourg Condemn'd. Minart, a PerÅ¿ecutor, AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inated. Du Bourg Executed. His Character. The rest of the Members of Parliament reÅ¿tored. King Philip prepares for Spain. He takes Ship at FluÅ¿hing. Arrives in Spain. RaiÅ¿eth a great PerÅ¿ecution there. The Death of Pope Paul IV. The Deaths of Å¿everal other Princes. Pius IV Elected. Scotch Affairs. The EngliÅ¿h Affairs relating to Scotland and France. The Scotch Complaints against the French. The War against the French in Scotland. The Death and Character of Mary Queen Regent of Scotland. The French Expelled thence. A ConÅ¿piracy in France. The King of Navar, Conde, Coligni Å¿uÅ¿pected to be in it. An AÅ¿Å¿embly of the Princes of France. A Decree paÅ¿Å¿ed for an AÅ¿Å¿embly of the three EÅ¿tates. The ProteÅ¿tants of France encreaÅ¿e. Francis II dies. A General Council deÅ¿ired, and obtain'd by the Duke of Florence. GuÅ¿tavus King of Sweden dies. The EÅ¿tates of France open'd. The PerÅ¿ecution of Piedmont, which occaÅ¿ioneth a War.

div.p:
THE FirÅ¿t day of January, Frederick I, King of Denmark, who was Elected by the Dyat of that Kingdom, in the Year 1523, inÅ¿tead of ChriÅ¿tian II,
year 1559 depoÅ¿ed by his Subjects for his Cruelty, died at Koldingen, a Town in the Dukedom of SleÅ¿wick, when he had lived Fifty Å¿ix Years, The Death of Frederick I, King of Denmark. Three Months and Twenty Days, and reigned Thirty four Years. He was a Prince of great Moderation and JuÅ¿tice; he overthrew the united Army of ChriÅ¿topher Duke of Oldenburg, and of the City of Lubeck, who had invaded his Inheritance, near AlÅ¿ens,
a City of Fionia, with a great Å¿laughter of their Forces. Having by this Victory obtain'd a Peace, he cauÅ¿ed the holy Scriptures to be tranÅ¿lated into the DaniÅ¿h Tongue, and open'd an UniverÅ¿ity and a Library at Coppenhagen. Not long before his Death he viÅ¿ited his depoÅ¿ed Uncle, who was then in PriÅ¿on, and having diÅ¿cours'd very friendly with him a great while, they mutually forgave each other. By his Queen Dorothy, Daughter of Magnus Duke of Saxony, he had five Children, Frederick II, who Å¿ucceeded him in his Kingdom, Magnus BiÅ¿hop of Æ²pÅ¿al in Livonia, Joane, Ann married to AuguÅ¿tus Elector of Saxony, and Dorothy married to Henry Duke of Lunenburg.
ChriÅ¿tian II, King of Denmark dies. The Twenty third of the Å¿ame Month, ChriÅ¿tian his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or in that Kingdom, followed him, being in the Seventy Å¿eventh year of his Age; he had lived in PriÅ¿on ever Å¿ince the Year 1532, having given (Å¿aith my Author Thuanus) this LeÅ¿Å¿on to all Princes, That if they will Reign well and happily, they must govern their Affections, and not out of a violent lust of inÅ¿ulting over their Subjects, give up themÅ¿elves to the conduct of their PaÅ¿Å¿ions; and that they ought to aÅ¿Å¿ure themÅ¿elves, that God is a Å¿evere Revenger, always ready, and delighting to pluck off their Thrones the most Proud and InÅ¿olent who Å¿hall abuÅ¿e that Power he has intruÅ¿ted them with. Frederick I, being dead, who was a Prince utterly averÅ¿e from war, and neither moved by Ambition nor CovetouÅ¿neÅ¿s to invade what was anothers;
Frederick II conquereth DiermarÅ¿h. his Son Frederick began a War upon the Inhabitants of DietmarÅ¿h, who had heretofore been Å¿ubject to the Dukes of HolÅ¿tein, the BiÅ¿hop of Breme, and the Kings of Denmark Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively, and had often regain'd their Liberty with great LoÅ¿s and DiÅ¿honour to thoÅ¿e Princes that had attempted to reduce this Å¿mall Province; but now their time was come, and Adolph Duke of HolÅ¿tein, this year made a final ConqueÅ¿t of them, for Frederick King of Denmark, in the Å¿pace of one Month.

In the beginning of this Year was a great change of Affairs at Rome. The Affairs of Italy. The Kindred of the Pope had already made themÅ¿elves hated by all ChriÅ¿tendom, and now the Pope himÅ¿elf too fell out with them. they had engaged the Pope in the War with Spain, which had brought Å¿o much LoÅ¿s and Shame upon that See, and its Dominions. In the time of thoÅ¿e ConfuÅ¿ions they had acted many things with great Rapacity, Intemperance and InÅ¿olence without the Pope's knowledge, who finding his TreaÅ¿ure exhauÅ¿ted, had by their Advice raiÅ¿ed great and extraordinary Taxes upon his People; and beÅ¿ides all this, had Å¿old the Places of the Criminal and Civil Judges, Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed the monthly Payments of his Officers, and Å¿eized many of the Lands belonging to the Religious Orders, and had levied two Tenths upon all the Benefices. The War with King Philip being ended, and the Pope having with a calm and diÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿ionate mind heard the Complaints made againÅ¿t his Relations by one Jeremiah, a Fryer of the Theatin Order, and eÅ¿pecially againÅ¿t the Cardinal of Caraffa, began more nearly to inÅ¿pect his own Affairs, and the Lives of his Relations. About the Å¿ame time, CoÅ¿mus Duke of Florenee made great Complaint alÅ¿o of the Caraffa's, becauÅ¿e not content with the extorting what they pleas'd from the HoÅ¿pitals, MonaÅ¿teries and Clergy within the Pope's Dominions (which they lookt upon as their own) they had alÅ¿o by their private Authority done the Å¿ame Wrongs in the Dukedom of Florence, and indeed all over Italy. He thereupon order'd Bongianni Gianfigliacci, his ReÅ¿ident at Rome, to complain of this to the Pope; but then the Caraffa's had prevented him from having any Audience; whereupon CoÅ¿mus wrote a Letter to the Pope, which was by the means of Cardinal Vitelli, an Hater of their InÅ¿olence, deliver'd to the Pope. He having read it, Å¿ent preÅ¿ently for his old Monitor Jeremiah, and by him ordered Vitelli to give him a more exact account of their MiÅ¿demeanors. There was nothing more incenÅ¿ed the Pope againÅ¿t them (who was Imperious and Jealous of his Papal Power to the utmoÅ¿t degree) than that the Cardinal had agreed, without his knowledge or conÅ¿ent, with the Duke de Alva; that his Brother Å¿hould accept of a CompenÅ¿ation from King Philip inÅ¿tead of Paliani, which Place the Pope had deÅ¿igned to unite to his See. Whereupon he preÅ¿ently commanded the Cardinal to leave the Vatican, and not to come any more into his PreÅ¿ence. The Twenty Å¿eventh of January the Pope Å¿ummon'd a great ConÅ¿iÅ¿tory, and in it diÅ¿charged him of the Prime MiniÅ¿try of Affairs, and of the Government of Bononia. He took alÅ¿o from the Duke of Paliani, his Brother, the Command of the Forces of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tick State, and of the Gallies, and deprived the MarqueÅ¿s di Monte Belli of the CuÅ¿tody of the Vatican Palace, declaring againÅ¿t them with that fury, that Å¿ome of the Cardinals attempted to appeaÅ¿e him, and among them Ranutio Cardinal of FarneÅ¿s: To whom he replied, That your Grandfather had done much better, if like me he had Å¿acrificed his private Affections to his PaÅ¿toral Office, and having Å¿everely chaÅ¿tiÅ¿ed your Father's
abominable LuÅ¿ts and Villanies, had thereby prevented the Å¿candal the Impunity of them hath given to the whole World. So that nothing that could be Å¿aid or done, could reduce the old Man from his ReÅ¿olves againÅ¿t them, but tended rather to the encreaÅ¿ing of his Fury. And hereupon he forthwith aboliÅ¿h'd Å¿ome ImpoÅ¿ts, pretending they were exacted without his knowledge: By all which he hoped to obtain the repute of a JuÅ¿t and Upright Prince, and to caÅ¿t the Odium of the ill things which had been done in his Popedom, upon his Relations. After this, he betook himÅ¿elf wholly to the promoting the InquiÅ¿ition, which he call'd the moÅ¿t Holy Tribunal, and here he Å¿hewed a very great Å¿everity, bringing not only Men Å¿uÅ¿pected of HereÅ¿ie, but of Å¿ome other Crimes within their JuriÅ¿diction. Then commanding all Monks and Nuns to their Å¿everal HouÅ¿es, he ImpriÅ¿on'd Å¿ome, and Å¿ent others to the Gallies, for not preÅ¿ently obeying him. His Rigour was Å¿o great in this laÅ¿t, that many left his State, and went and Å¿etled in the State of Venice. He Å¿pent Fifty thouÅ¿and Crowns in Corn, to relieve the Poor in a time of Scarcity, and Å¿etled BiÅ¿hops at Malacha and Cochin, two Cities belonging to the PortugueÅ¿e in the East-Indies, and made the BiÅ¿hop of Goa an ArchbiÅ¿hop, exempting him from the JuriÅ¿diction of the BiÅ¿hoprick of LiÅ¿bon. He alÅ¿o erected many new Sees in the Low-Countries, at the requeÅ¿t of Philip King of Spain, to the Diminution of the JuriÅ¿diction and DioceÅ¿Å¿es of many French and German BiÅ¿hops. TheÅ¿e Sees were Å¿etled at Mechlen, Antwerp, Harlem, Daventrie, Leewarden, Groningen, Midleburg, BoÅ¿leduc, New BiÅ¿hopricks erected in the Low-Countries. Namur, St. Omers, IpreÅ¿s, Gant and Bruges, and were put under the ArchbiÅ¿hops of Cambray, Mechlin and Æ²trecht. This change gave great offence to the Low-Countries, who eÅ¿teem'd itrather an InÅ¿laving than an Honouring of their Country, to have Å¿o many New Sees Å¿etled among them; and the more, becauÅ¿e among other ReaÅ¿ons aÅ¿Å¿igned by the Pope, one was, That theÅ¿e Countries were on all Å¿ides encompaÅ¿s'd with Nations which had caÅ¿t off the See of Rome; Å¿o that the Salvation of the Souls of this People was much endanger'd by SchiÅ¿m, which rendred this Settlement hateful to all thoÅ¿e who favour'd the Reformation; Å¿o that this was one of the principal CauÅ¿es of the War which followed, which in the end proved fatal to many of theÅ¿e New BiÅ¿hopricks.

In the interim, this ConÅ¿ideration had that effect upon the Spirit of King Philip, King Philip deÅ¿irous of a Peace with France, that he might be at leiÅ¿ure to extirpate HereÅ¿ie. that it greatly diÅ¿poÅ¿ed him above all others to enter into a Treaty of Peace with France. He Å¿aw that not only the Licence which attended a War, but the vaÅ¿t number of Germans which he was forced to employ, by their converÅ¿ing with his Subjects in the Netherlands, begat in them a good Opinion of Luther and the Reformation. Henry II of France imprudently communicated to William of NaÅ¿Å¿aw, Prince of Orange, when he was EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador for Philip in France, when they were one day Hunting together, That DeÅ¿ign diÅ¿cover'd to the Prince of Orange.
That King Philip and he had agreed first to extirpate all the Sects which were then riÅ¿ing in the Netherlands, and after that they would joyn their Arms, and do the like in all other places; which being diÅ¿covered by that Prince to the Netherlanders, they entred into ConÅ¿ultation for the preÅ¿erving themÅ¿elves from the Pride of the SpaniÅ¿h Government, and made thoÅ¿e inÅ¿olent Demands of King Philp, when he was going into Spain. This CounÅ¿el was then generally attributed to the Cardinal of Lorain, and Perrenot BiÅ¿hop of Arras, and all concluded, That under the pretence of Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing HereÅ¿ie, King Philip and Henry of France had laid a DeÅ¿ign of Ruining the Civil Liberties of France and the Netherlands. When the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners met, for the concluding the Treaty of Peace between theÅ¿e Princes, they found themÅ¿elves delivered from one difficulty, the ReÅ¿titution of Calais, by the Death of Queen Mary of England; but then Thionville, Verdun and Toul, three Imperial Cities, had been taken in this War by the French, and King Philip thought he was bound in Honour, and by his IntereÅ¿t too, to Å¿ee them reÅ¿tored to the Empire, and yet he Å¿aw the French were as well reÅ¿olved to keep them. Nor was indeed his IntereÅ¿t in the ReÅ¿titution Å¿o great as that of the French was to keep them, he having very effectually provided for his own Security and Benefit, by the gaining other Places.

Hereupon theÅ¿e Princes, by mutual conÅ¿ent, The Dyet of Germany. Å¿ent EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Dyet of Germany, began this Year the Twenty fifth of February, at AuÅ¿burg. The firÅ¿t thing that was done in them, was the celebrating the Funeral of Charles V, with great Solemnity. His Encomium was pronounced by Lewis MadruÅ¿e, then BiÅ¿hop of Trent, and afterwards a Cardinal. After this Ceremony, an Account was given of the Conference at Wormes, for the Reconciling the Differences of Religion; and there appearing no hope of an Accommdation, Ferdinand the Emperor promiÅ¿ed he would take care to have the General Council renewed, and that all Å¿hould obey its
Decrees and Determinations. But the Deputies of the Duke of Saxony, and of Å¿everal other Princes of the Empire oppoÅ¿ed this, affirming that there being no hopes of reÅ¿toring the Peace of the Church by a PopiÅ¿h Council, Conditions propoÅ¿ed by the ProteÅ¿tants for a Council. the Edicts of PaÅ¿Å¿aw and AnÅ¿burg were religiouÅ¿ly to be obÅ¿erved: But the Emperor perÅ¿iÅ¿ting in his former Opinion, they Å¿aid they were not againÅ¿t a Free and General Council in Germany, Å¿o be it were legally aÅ¿Å¿embled by the Emperor, and not by the Pope, and in which the Pope Å¿hould appear as a Party Å¿ubject to the Council, and not as PreÅ¿ident and Judge of all others; and provided the BiÅ¿hops and Clergy might be freed from the Oath they had taken to the Pope, that they might freely Å¿peak their Thoughts: That the Å¿acred Scriptures might be the only Rule by which they Å¿hould judge and determin theÅ¿e ControverÅ¿ies, rejecting all humane Traditions and CuÅ¿toms that were contrary to the Word of God: If the Divines who had embraced the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, might not only be heard, but admitted to give their Votes in the DeciÅ¿ion of theÅ¿e ControverÅ¿ies, and have good Security given them for their going thither; and that they Å¿hould enjoy the Liberty granted them by the Decree of AuÅ¿burg, without any fraud or violence: That the Points in DiÅ¿pute Å¿hould not be determin'd, as is uÅ¿ual in Civil Affairs, by the Plurality of Votes, but by the Rule and PreÅ¿cription of the Word of God: That in the firÅ¿t place, the Decrees of the Council of Trent already made, Å¿hould be cancell'd as vitious, and not legally aÅ¿Å¿embled; and that theÅ¿e things Å¿hould be debated anew. And laÅ¿tly, That if theÅ¿e things could not be obtain'd of the Pope, the Emperor Å¿hould maintain the Peace of Religion, and the Edict of PaÅ¿Å¿aw. TheÅ¿e were the Conditions the ProteÅ¿tants propoÅ¿ed for the holding of a Council.

The Emperior, The Emperor Confirms the Peace of PaÅ¿Å¿aw. who deÅ¿paired of reconciling the differences of Religion on theÅ¿e Terms, and having no other way left him for preÅ¿erving the Peace of Germany, Confirm'd the Peace of PaÅ¿Å¿aw. After this, they took into ConÅ¿ideration the Reduction of the Monies of Germany to their ancient value and purity, and heard the Complaints of William of FurÅ¿temberg, Great MaÅ¿ter of the Knights of Livonia, who obtain'd a Grant of an Hundred thouÅ¿and Crowns for the Levying of an Army for their Protection againÅ¿t the RuÅ¿s: But this Sum Å¿eeming leÅ¿s than the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of their Affairs and of the Times required, the Livonians neglected it, and betook themÅ¿elves to the Protection of SigiÅ¿mund AuguÅ¿tus, King of Poland, to whom they aÅ¿Å¿ign'd Nine of their Å¿trongeÅ¿t Places, upon condition that they might at any time redeem them by the payment of Six thouÅ¿and Crowns, which was confirm'd by a Treaty Signed and Sworn between them and the King of Poland. After which, FurÅ¿temberg reÅ¿igned his Dignity to Gotard Ketler. There was alÅ¿o a Complaint made by the Livonians againÅ¿t the Inhabitants of Lubeck, Riga and Revel, for furniÅ¿hing the RuÅ¿s, who were the Enemies of Germany, not only with all Å¿orts of Merchandize imported by them to Narva, a Town of RuÅ¿Å¿ia, but alÅ¿o with Arms and Ammunition, which for the future, was, by a Law made in this Dyet, forbidden, which was afterwards repeal'd.

The Twenty eighth of March, The French EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors come to the Dyet. the French EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors were introduced into the Dyet, and after they had in an Elegant Speech declared the great Affections their MaÅ¿ter had for the Emperor and the States of Germany; they deÅ¿ired the ancient League might be renewed between the Empire and that Kingdom; and that for the future there might be a firmer and cloÅ¿er Union and FriendÅ¿hip. Upon this the Emperor returned Thanks to the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, Å¿aying, That the King might be aÅ¿Å¿ured of the FriendÅ¿hip of the Empire, the Princes and States, and of his too, if his Actions did agree with his Words, and thoÅ¿e Cities which had lately been taken from the Empire, were reÅ¿tored to it: That this being done, he did not Å¿ee what could hinder their entring into a Å¿incere FriendÅ¿hip. At this the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors replied, That they had no InÅ¿truction concerning what he had propoÅ¿ed about the Cities, but they would given an Account of it to the King their MaÅ¿ter, and in the mean time they deÅ¿ired the States would meet the King's PropoÅ¿als of FriendÅ¿hip with equal Candour. Upon this the AÅ¿Å¿embly broke up, and the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors were re-conducted back with great Civility and ReÅ¿pect; to whom it was hinted, that the Emperor could not but mention the ReÅ¿titution of the Cities, but then that neither he, the Princes, nor the States would break with the King of France, though thoÅ¿e Cities were not reÅ¿tored. They decreed alÅ¿o a Noble EmbaÅ¿Å¿y to the King of France, in which the Cardinal of AuÅ¿burg and ChriÅ¿topher Duke of Wirtemburg were employed.

One David George, a Native of Delft in Holland, born of mean Parents, his Father being a Fencer, and his Mother a mean Woman, and himÅ¿elf unacquainted with
any other than his Mother-Tongue; was a PerÅ¿on of great Å¿eeming Moderation, Å¿o that all took him for a very HoneÅ¿t and well-meaning Man, tho' he was of a Å¿tubborn and incorrigable diÅ¿poÅ¿ition. The Life and Death of David George, a famous ImpoÅ¿tor. He was a PerÅ¿on of a comely Countenance-and good meine, and all the Motions of his Body were Grave and becoming, Å¿o that he Å¿eemed made up of HoneÅ¿ty. This Man Å¿pread amongÅ¿t his Country-men the PeÅ¿tilent Sect of AnabaptiÅ¿ts, to which they were very much diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, and this being done to his great advantage (for he had got a good EÅ¿tate by it) and fearing he might not be Å¿afe, if he continued any longer in his Native Country, where he was accounted the Head of that Sect, he went with Å¿ome of his Followers to BaÅ¿il, in the Year 1544, under the Name of John Bruck, and the firÅ¿t of April made a Speech in the Senate of that City; deÅ¿iring, He might be protected by them, as one forced to flee for his Religion; and that they would receive his Wife, Children, Family and Fortunes, as in a Å¿afe Harbour. The CauÅ¿e, the PerÅ¿on, and the Speech, agreeed Å¿o exactly, and his Temper was Å¿o wholely unknown to them, as well as his former Life, and his Country being very remote, what he Å¿aid appeared Å¿o like Truth, and had happened to Å¿o many others, That AuguÅ¿t 25, having given the uÅ¿ual Oath, he was taken into the Protection of that City; where he lived with the ReÅ¿pect to the MagiÅ¿trate, that Humanity towards the Citizens, and that Civility towards all, obÅ¿erving carefully their Religious Rites, and in all things behaved himÅ¿elf Å¿o well, that he gave not the leaÅ¿t occaÅ¿ion to any to Å¿uÅ¿pect him of any erroneous Doctrin, and he was as well thought of by the moÅ¿t, as he DeÅ¿ired to be, or was eÅ¿teemed by his own Party. Thus he lived very quietly in his Family, obÅ¿erving very Å¿trictly three things: 1. Concealing the Name of David George, by which he was well known in Holland and FrieÅ¿land. 2. Of what State and Condition he was at Home; Å¿o that Å¿ome took him for a PerÅ¿on of good Birth, others for a Nobleman or Rich Merchant. 3. LaÅ¿tly, he took Care not to admit any into his Sect of the City of BaÅ¿il, or of the neighbouring Country: But, in the mean time, he took care by Letters, Books and MeÅ¿Å¿engers, to enlarge his Sect in Holland, and in other Å¿uch diÅ¿tant Places: But as to Switzerland he medled not, for fear he might be diÅ¿covered. Having thus Å¿pent Å¿ix Years, with great PleaÅ¿ure, there happened a thing which gave him Å¿ome DiÅ¿turbance, one of his Followers falling off, upon better Information, and appearing with great Zeal againÅ¿t the Doctrins of his quondam MaÅ¿ter: His HouÅ¿e being alÅ¿o burnt with Lightning, was a Å¿ad PreÅ¿age, That his good Fortune and his Life were near their End. But that which moÅ¿t afflicted him, was, That an able PerÅ¿on was come from Holland, who had given an exact account of him and his Family, to the Citizens of BaÅ¿il; this brought a great DeÅ¿pondence of Mind upon him, and that a SickneÅ¿s, which Å¿eized his Wife alÅ¿o, who dyed firÅ¿t, and David George followed her himÅ¿elf AuguÅ¿t 25, 1556; and he was buried with great Pomp, in the Church of S. Leonard. Thus died that famous ImpoÅ¿tor and Deceiver, who had pretended, That he was greater, and more Divine than ChriÅ¿t, and Immortal; that the Doctrin of MoÅ¿es and the Prophets, ChriÅ¿t and the ApoÅ¿tles, was imperfect, and did not lead to a true and perfect Felicity; but his was Å¿uch as would certainly make him, who rightly underÅ¿tood it, happy: That he was the true ChriÅ¿t and MeÅ¿Å¿iah, the moÅ¿t beloved Son of the Father, who was begotten not of FleÅ¿h but by the Holy GhoÅ¿t, and the Spirit of ChriÅ¿t; which having reduced his FleÅ¿h to nothing, and kept it in a certain place, unknown to the Saints, had at laÅ¿t delivered it to David George; with much more Å¿uch BlaÅ¿phemous NonÅ¿enÅ¿e. After his Death, the Frand broke out, and this Year March 12, his Sons, and all that belonged to him, to the number of eleven, were brought before the Senate, and examined concerning his Name, Country and Doctrin: And they anÅ¿wering as he had taught, were committed to different PriÅ¿ons, and all his Papers and Writings were delivered to the Divines. April 26, the Divines and UniverÅ¿ity having conÅ¿idered them, condemn'd his Doctrin as falÅ¿e, contrary to the Å¿acred Scriptures, pernicious and injurious to JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, and to be exterminated out of the ChriÅ¿tian World. After this, his Sons were diÅ¿miÅ¿s'd out of PriÅ¿on, upon condition they Å¿hould buy no Lands without the Walls of the City, without the PermiÅ¿Å¿ion of the Senate: That they Å¿hould entertain no Travellers, though of their near Relations, but Å¿hould Å¿end them to the publick Inns: That they Å¿hould deliver in all the Books written or printed by David George, and not keep any by them in the Dutch Tongue; and that they Å¿hould Å¿end their Children to the School of BaÅ¿il to be inÅ¿tructed: That they Å¿hould pay a Pecuniary Mulct, if required; and that they, their Wives and Children Å¿hould appear in the Church, and make ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the True Faith, and Renounce that of David George. Two days after, his Body was Å¿entenc'd to be
taken up and burnt, together with his Books and Effigies, by the Hands of the Common Hang-man, in the place where they uÅ¿ally executed Malefactors; and all his Goods they Å¿eiz'd to the Publick TreaÅ¿ure; adding, That if any PerÅ¿on preÅ¿um'd to blame this their Decree, he Å¿hould be liable to the Å¿ame PuniÅ¿hment. His Body was found very perfect, Å¿o that it might be known by his yellow Beard from another Man's, though he had been buried two Years and Å¿ix Months, and was accordingly burnt in a vaÅ¿t concourÅ¿e of Men.

In the beginning of February the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adours met again, The Treaty of Cambray produces a Peace at laÅ¿t. at the CaÅ¿tle of Cambray, to conclude the Treaty, which was broke up upon the Death of Mary, Queen of England. TheÅ¿e two Kings having thus regained their Peace, The Peace occaÅ¿ions a PerÅ¿ecution in France. and disburthened themÅ¿elves of the Cares which the War brought upon them, they betook themÅ¿elves Å¿olely to the Care of Religion, which in France had been under conÅ¿ideration the two foregoing Years, and was then omitted on account of the War and Treaty, but was now reaÅ¿Å¿umed in the heat of a Marriage-FeaÅ¿t. There was one Diana DutcheÅ¿s of Valentinois, a Court-Lady, and one of the King's MiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es, who uÅ¿ed to beg the EÅ¿tates of all Å¿uch as Å¿uffered for any Crime; And the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who were the Promoters of this PerÅ¿ecution, the latter aiming at nothing but Popular ApplauÅ¿e: TheÅ¿e two inÅ¿inuated this Belief into the King; That the Venome of HereÅ¿ie was much Å¿pread in France, and that in truth he was not King of thoÅ¿e Provinces in which that prevailed: That the Impudence of thoÅ¿e who imbraced it, was Å¿o great, that they did not whiÅ¿per it, as heretofore, in the Ear, but preached it openly and boldly throughout the Kingdom, by which the name of God was blaÅ¿phemed, and his MajeÅ¿ties Royal Authority was endangered; for when the Law of God was once confounded, who can QueÅ¿tion, (Å¿ay they) but that all Human Laws will Å¿oon be Å¿ubverted? And that they might the more eaÅ¿ily prevail, they employed Giles MaiÅ¿tre, preÅ¿ident of the Parliament, Jean de S. Andre, Anthony Minart, and Giles Bourdin the King's Attorney, and principally the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e, who was a Man of a fierce DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition and Temper, to incenÅ¿e the King's Mind againÅ¿t the Sectaries, he being no way inclined to Å¿uch Severities. To this end they tell him, That there would little be gained by the Peace, if a more cruel War was fomented and carried on at Home: For that the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e had already got Å¿uch Strength, that if his MajeÅ¿ty diÅ¿Å¿embled a little longer, the Sword of the MagiÅ¿trate and the Laws of the Land would not be able to Å¿uppreÅ¿s it, but he muÅ¿t levy Armies, and himÅ¿elf take the Field againÅ¿t them, as had been done in the caÅ¿e of the AlbingenÅ¿es. That what had hitherto been done, had not had its deÅ¿ired effect, becauÅ¿e all the Å¿everity had been Å¿pent upon the populace and the mean people, the hatred and deteÅ¿tation of which had affected all Men, but very few had taken example by it. That now it was fit to begin with the Judges, many of which had imbraced their Doctrin Å¿ecretly, or favoured them on other accounts, and by their connivance nouriÅ¿hed the DiÅ¿temper, Å¿uffering this Offence either to go unpuniÅ¿hed, or very lightly corrected. Not long after this, the King was prevailed The King goes to the Parliament of Paris to aw it into a Compliance. upon to come into the Parliament in PerÅ¿on, whilÅ¿t the Members were debating about the PuniÅ¿hment of the Sectaries, June 14. He-Å¿eemed rather to labour to conceal his Anger, than to have come with a calm Mind: Among other things he told the Parliament; That having made a Peace he hoped it would turn to the general Good; but he was much concerned that the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Religion, which was one of the principal Cares of a good Prince, had been, during the War, tumultuouÅ¿ly and Å¿editiouÅ¿ly treated by Å¿ome: That therefore he deÅ¿ired for the future, more care might be taken of the ChriÅ¿tian Religion: And becauÅ¿e he heard that affair was this Day to be debated by them, he was come thither; and he admoniÅ¿hed them to proceed in it with Freedom, Å¿aying, It was God's CauÅ¿e, who knew all our Hearts and Thoughts.

Tho' the Members of the Parliament knew the King was brought thither to deprive them of their Liberty; Yet Å¿ome retained their Freedom at the Price of their Lives. yet there were Å¿ome who reÅ¿olved to retain their ancient Freedom at the price of their Lives; and having declaimed againÅ¿t the Manners of the Court of Rome and its ill CuÅ¿tomes, which had degenerated into moÅ¿t pernicious Errors, and given occaÅ¿ion to the riÅ¿e of many Sects; they thence inferred, That the Penalties of HereÅ¿ie were to be mitigated, and the Severities of the Law abated, till the differences of Religion were compoÅ¿ed by the Authority of a General Council, and the DiÅ¿cipline of the Church reformed. And this was the Opinion of all the good Men in the Parliament. Arnold du Ferrier, PreÅ¿ident of the Criminal Court, an honeÅ¿t and a wiÅ¿e PerÅ¿on, and the beÅ¿t Lawyer in France, was the firÅ¿t who propoÅ¿ed this Method, and was followed by many others, among which was Lewis du Faur, a Man of great SenÅ¿e, and of a generous Temper, who added, That all were agreed that the Differences in Religion had occaÅ¿ioned great DiÅ¿turbances, but then (Å¿aid he) we ought carefully to enquire, Who cauÅ¿ed theÅ¿e DiÅ¿orders, leÅ¿t as Elijah anÅ¿wered Ahab, when he reproached him, as the Troubler of IÅ¿rael, it might be Å¿aid to us; It is thou that haÅ¿t troubled IÅ¿rael. Then Anna du Bourg beginning with a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e of the Eternal Providence of God, to which all things are Å¿ubject; when he came to the QueÅ¿tion propoÅ¿ed, Å¿aid, There were many Sins and Crimes committed by Men, which the Laws had already forbidden, and yet the Gallows and Tortures which were imployed, had not been able to prevent the frequent Perjuries, Adulteries, profuÅ¿e LuÅ¿ts, and Profane Oaths, which were not only connived at, but cheriÅ¿hed. ChriÅ¿topher Harlay and Peter Seguier the two PreÅ¿idents Å¿aid with great ModeÅ¿ty, that the Court had hitherto juÅ¿tly and rightly diÅ¿charged its Duty in this Particular, and that it would Å¿till do the Å¿ame without changing, to the Glory of God, and therefore neither the King nor People of France would have cauÅ¿e to repent the truÅ¿ting to it. After theÅ¿e MaiÅ¿tre the PreÅ¿ident made a Å¿harp Harangue againÅ¿t the Sectaries, inÅ¿tancing in the Severities which Philip the AuguÅ¿t is Å¿aid to have employed againÅ¿t the AlbingenÅ¿es, 600 of which he burnt in one day; and in the WaldenÅ¿es, which were maÅ¿Å¿acred with Fire and Smoak, partly in their HouÅ¿es, and partly in the Dens and Caves they had fled to.

The King having obliquely reproached the Court for entring upon this Debate, The King's AnÅ¿wer. without his Order, added, He now clearly Å¿aw, what he had heard before, That there were Å¿ome among them, who deÅ¿piÅ¿ed both his Authority and the Popes. And therefore he exhorted the rest to go on in their Duty. The Reflections of la Faur and du Bourg, who mentioned the Story of Ahab, and the frequent Adulteries, exaÅ¿perated the King more than the reÅ¿t, and therefore he commanded Montmorancy to apprehend them, who again ordered Gabriel de Montgomery, a Captain of the Guard, to take them and carry them to the BaÅ¿tile. Men cenÅ¿ured theÅ¿e Proceedings, as they Å¿tood affected; but the WiÅ¿er were much diÅ¿guÅ¿ted, That the King Å¿hould be Å¿o far impoÅ¿ed on by others, as to come perÅ¿onally into his Court to Å¿ubvert thoÅ¿e Laws he ought to have protected: That he Å¿hould make uÅ¿e of Threats and ImpriÅ¿onments; Å¿aying, That this was a clear InÅ¿tance that he was Å¿ubject to the PaÅ¿Å¿ions of others, and who could think but theÅ¿e things were the forerunners of great Changes? A French Synod held by the ProteÅ¿tant MiniÅ¿ters.

About the Å¿ame time came EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours from the ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany, The ProteÅ¿tant Princes of Germany write to the King of France. with Letters to the King, Å¿ubÅ¿cribed by Frederick Cout Palatine of the Rhine, AuguÅ¿tus Duke of Saxony, Joachim Elector of Brandenburg, ChriÅ¿topher Duke of Wirtimberg, and Wolfang Count of Weldentz. The King entertained the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors kindly, and having read the Letter, Å¿aid he would Å¿uddenly Å¿end them a Å¿atisfactory AnÅ¿wer; but by that time they were arrived at the Borders of France, the Fire, their coming Å¿eem'd to have abated, raged more horribly than ever.

June 19. A CommiÅ¿Å¿ion iÅ¿Å¿ued to try the Å¿uÅ¿pected Members of Parliament. Du Bourg firÅ¿t tried. a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion was iÅ¿Å¿ued to Jean de Saint Andre, the PreÅ¿ident and Promoter of theÅ¿e Troubles, Jo. James de Memme, MaÅ¿ter of the RequeÅ¿ts, Lewis Gayaut, Robert Boet, EuÅ¿tace Bellay, lately a Member of the Court of Parliament, but then BiÅ¿hop of Paris, and Anthony de Nouchy, to try the Members of Parliament, which had been impriÅ¿oned. WhilÅ¿t theÅ¿e miÅ¿erable Men were thus perÅ¿ecuted for their Religion; The Å¿ad Condition of France during the PerÅ¿ecution. and their Favourers, Friends, and Å¿uch as had preÅ¿umed to Å¿peak freely, were by Informers alÅ¿o brought in QueÅ¿tion; there was a Å¿ad Face of Affairs in France, and a Å¿ullen Å¿ilence. The Court, in the interim was never more Jolly, the Preparations for a great Marriage filling it with Mirth and Bravery, which in a Å¿hort time too, had as lamentable a ConcluÅ¿ion. Among other things there was a Tilt prepared, and a Yard made for that purpoÅ¿e, not far from the BaÅ¿tile, in which the Members of the Parliament were then impriÅ¿oned. Some Days being Å¿pent in this DivertiÅ¿ement,
June 29. the King would needs run againÅ¿t the Count of Mongomery, and they breaking their Lances, the Sight of the King's Helmet by accident flying up,
Henry II, of France Å¿lain. he received a Wound in the Eye, and falling from his HorÅ¿e was latched by Å¿ome of his Servants, and carried into a Tower belonging to the BaÅ¿tile. It is Å¿aid, whilÅ¿t they carried him thither, he looked up, and remembring the Members of Parliament which he had committed there, Å¿aid; He feared he had done wrong to thoÅ¿e Innocent Men. The Cardinal of Lorrain, who was preÅ¿ent, angry at it, reply'd; That Thought was put into his Mind by the Devil, the Enemy of Mankind: That he ought to be careful of his Motions, and continue constant in his Faith. Whether this were Å¿o or no, I will not affirm, (Å¿aith Thuanus, my Author) becauÅ¿e I am reÅ¿olved to write nothing without good Authority: The PhyÅ¿icians Å¿aying too, That in theÅ¿e kinds of Wounds the Speech is loÅ¿t. At the Report of this Accident Andrew VeÅ¿ale, a Famous PhyÅ¿ician was preÅ¿ently Å¿ent from BruÅ¿Å¿els by King Philip, that he might however Å¿hew his Good-will to this Prince: But he came too late, the King dying July 2. when he had lived forty Years, three Months and eleven Days, and reigned twelve Years and three Months. The Marriage between Margaret his SiÅ¿ter and Philbert Duke of Savoy, was hereupon haÅ¿ted, that it might be finiÅ¿hed before his Death, and Celebrated it was without any Pomp or Magnificence.

There was great variety of Opinions, Å¿ome extolling his Life beyond ReaÅ¿on, The various Characters of Henry II, of France. as Martial and Brave, and his ConqueÅ¿ts, by which he had enlarged his Kingdom, adding to it a great part of Italy, Scotland and CorÅ¿ica: That having obtained a Victory againÅ¿t Charles V, at Renty, he had reduced that Great Prince to the Thoughts of a Retreat to a Private Life. That recalling his Army out of Italy, he had been able to defend France againÅ¿t the united Forces of King Philip, and Mary of England, and at laÅ¿t had ended the War, at leaÅ¿t by an uÅ¿eful Treaty; and by the Marriages of his Daughter and SiÅ¿ter, had Å¿ecured the Publick Peace. But I Å¿hall for the future be very Å¿hort in the French Affairs, referring the Reader to Davila, and other Writers, of the Civil Wars of France. The King being crowned,
Francis II, a Lad of Å¿ixteen Years of Age, Å¿ucceeds him. And the PerÅ¿ecution goes on. and the Dominion of the Queen Dowager as Guardian, and of the GuiÅ¿es, as Prime MiniÅ¿ters, eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed to the great DiÅ¿Å¿atisfaction of the Princes and Nobility of France, the next Care was to carry on the PerÅ¿ecution againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants: Oliver the Chancellor was imployed againÅ¿t the Members of the Parliament, which were impriÅ¿oned at the time of the King's Death, and S. Andre, and Anthony de Mouchy againÅ¿t the reÅ¿t of the People; who, that they might Å¿pread the terror of their Names over the whole Nation, thought fit to begin with Paris. Their principal Blood-hounds were RuÅ¿Å¿anges, and Claude David, two Mechanicks, and one George Renard, a Taylor, who had all three profeÅ¿Å¿ed the Reformed Religion; and were now imployed, as beÅ¿t acquainted with theÅ¿e Men. They drew in two Apprentices Å¿hortly after, who had deÅ¿erted their MaÅ¿ters: And theÅ¿e, to gain the greater ApplauÅ¿e, Slaunders againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants. confeÅ¿Å¿ed not only that they had Nocturnal Meeting, but (which Å¿aith Thuanus, was a notorious Lie) that they at them uÅ¿ed promiÅ¿cuous Conjunctions after the Candles were put out. The Queen, who was never a Friend to the ProteÅ¿tants, from henceforth was more than ever enraged againÅ¿t them: But Oliver, the Chancellor, Å¿uÅ¿pecting the Story, examined theÅ¿e Lads Å¿eparately, and by their Varying and Contradicting each other, found it to be a mere Lye. However, the Places of Meeting being thus diÅ¿covered, great Numbers of Men and Women were taken and impriÅ¿oned, and others left the Kingdom, whoÅ¿e Goods were Å¿eized and confiÅ¿cated. The King of France had been a long time afflicted with a tedious Quartane Ague, Other Slanders Å¿pread againÅ¿t the poor perÅ¿ecuted ProteÅ¿tants. but overgrowing that DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e, he Å¿hot up in heighth, and grew apace, but was very Pale, and of a Å¿ickly ConÅ¿titution; being removed to Blois, which was his Native Air, his Face of a Å¿udden was overÅ¿pread with RedneÅ¿s, Spots and Carbuncles, whereupon a Report was raiÅ¿ed, That he had the LeproÅ¿ie, and that a great number of Children, of leÅ¿s than Å¿ix Years of Age, had been torn out of the Arms of their Mothers about the Loire, to make a Bath of their Blood for the Cure of the King. In the mean time the ProceÅ¿s was carried warmly on,

At laÅ¿t he adviÅ¿ed them to extinguiÅ¿h theÅ¿e their Fires and repent of their Sins,

He was 38 Years old, and was born at Riom in Auvergne, of a Rich and Noble Family, Anthony du Bourg, a Branch of which had been Chancellor of France under Francis I. His Character. He took his Degrees at Orleance; and was eÅ¿teemed a good Lawyer, and an upright Judge, and many of the moÅ¿t zealous Catholicks interceeded for him, during his ImpriÅ¿onment, and his Death was deplored by many very heartily.
