The reÅ¿t of the Members were reÅ¿tored, by the Court at laÅ¿t; de Thou, one of the Members
of that Court oppoÅ¿ing, and at length maÅ¿tering the more bloody GuiÅ¿ians. The meaner People, who being then in PriÅ¿on, were diÅ¿patched with leÅ¿s Difficulty, Å¿ome being condemned to Death, others to Renuntiation, and others to BaniÅ¿hment. Images erected in the Streets to be WorÅ¿hiped.

About the Å¿ame time there was another Project Å¿et on foot in France, they erected Images of the Saints and Virgin Mary in the Streets and Market Places, and burnt Candles before them in the day-time, Å¿inging Songs to their Honour, and Å¿eting CheÅ¿ts, and if any paÅ¿Å¿ed by without giving Money and worÅ¿hiping the Images, he was preÅ¿ently Å¿et upon by the Rabble as an Heretick, and he eÅ¿caped well if he was only beaten and trodden into the Channel, and loÅ¿t not his Life: Which only Å¿erved to irritate and unite the ProteÅ¿tants the more.

King Philip having made a Peace with France, King Philip prepares for Spain. reÅ¿olved this Year to return into Spain; in order to this he came to Gaunt, and there Å¿ummoned a Chapter of the Knights of the Golden Fleece; from thence he went to Zealand, committing the Government of the Netherlands to Margaret DutcheÅ¿s of Parma, the Wife of Octavio, his SiÅ¿ter, with a guard of 3500 Spaniards, which were all diÅ¿tributed on the Borders of France, in the Fronteer Towns. After the Peace he had principally imployed Granvel BiÅ¿hop of Arras, who had adviÅ¿ed him to leave this Guard, for fear of the Lutherans, which were very numerous in theÅ¿e Provinces, by reaÅ¿on of their Neighbourhood to Germany. The principal Care of theÅ¿e Countries was committed to William Prince of Orange, and the Count of Egmont, who were Men of great Birth, and had particularly deÅ¿erved well of Philip, in his laÅ¿t War with France; theÅ¿e remonÅ¿trated againÅ¿t the leaving of the Spaniards, and freely Å¿aid; They had not much mended their Condition, if when they had preÅ¿erved their Country with their Swords, they muÅ¿t now be expoÅ¿ed in Peace, to the Å¿ervile Yoke of Foreign Forces and an InÅ¿olent Soldiery. King Philip was inwardly diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with this Liberty, yet Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed his ReÅ¿entment; and that he might not Å¿eem to go thence offended with theÅ¿e Great Men; he promiÅ¿ed to withdraw thoÅ¿e Forces within four Months. After this he took Shipping at FluÅ¿hing, AuguÅ¿t 26. being attended by a Fleet of 90 Ships. He takes Ship at FluÅ¿hing. He met with Å¿o great a TempeÅ¿t on the Shoars of Gallicia, that the Ship in which he went, periÅ¿hed, the King being hardly got out of her into a Å¿mall Bark, that waited upon him. Thuanus Å¿aith, He aÅ¿cribed his Delivery to Heaven, and Å¿aid, He was preÅ¿erved by the Å¿ingular Providence of God to extirpate LutheraniÅ¿m: And Meteren, That this TempeÅ¿t was an Omen of the great Calamities that attended him and his States, a great part of the Fleet being Shipwrecked.

He Å¿oon fell to the Work he believed God had call'd him, He raiÅ¿eth a great PerÅ¿ecution in Spain. and began with the extirpation of HereÅ¿ie; Å¿ome few had been put to Death before his arrival, here and there; but the greateÅ¿t part were kept, that he might have the joy of Å¿eeing them burnt at Vallidolid and Seville. September 24. this pompous Shew was begun in the PerÅ¿on of John Ponce, a Son of the Count de Baylen, who was brought forth with great State, and burnt as an ObÅ¿tinate Lutheran; and with him John GonÅ¿alo, a Preacher: After theÅ¿e IÅ¿abella Venia, Maria ViroeÅ¿ia, Cornelia and Bohorquia, which was a Spectacle of great CompaÅ¿Å¿ion and Envy, the laÅ¿t of theÅ¿e being not above 21 Years old, yet Å¿uffering with great ConÅ¿tancy. After theÅ¿e followed Ferdinad de St. Jean, and Julian Ferdinando, John de Leone and Frances ChaveÅ¿ia a Nun, ChriÅ¿topher LoÅ¿ada, a PhyÅ¿ician. and ChriÅ¿topher de Arles a Monk, and GarÅ¿ia de Arras. This laÅ¿t was the Man, who had brought that Spark into Spain, and by his conÅ¿tant and learned Preaching, improved it Å¿o far, that he had brought over to his Opinion the greateÅ¿t Part of the Monks of S. IÅ¿iodore, and of the Inhabitants of Seville: yet afterwards he had deÅ¿erted his Companions, and diÅ¿puted againÅ¿t them too before the InquiÅ¿itors; but being at laÅ¿t convinced of the WickedneÅ¿s of it, he repented; and being brought before the InquiÅ¿itors, reproached them as fitter for Mule-Drivers than Judges of the true Faith, of which they were brutiÅ¿hly Ignorant, tho' they impudently aÅ¿Å¿umed that Title and Office.
ConÅ¿tantio, the ConfeÅ¿Å¿or of Charles V, burnt after he was dead. Giles and ConÅ¿tantio were reÅ¿erved to bring up the Reere, but they both died, yet their Bodies were burnt. This laÅ¿t was ConfeÅ¿Å¿or to Charles V, in the laÅ¿t two Years of his Life and Retirement: Soon after his Death he was impriÅ¿oned, and died in durance. His Body was carried about in a preaching PoÅ¿ture, and the dreadful ghaÅ¿tly look it had, brought. Tears from Å¿ome, whilÅ¿t others laughed at the theatrical HypocriÅ¿ie and Bloody Folly of the Monks.

From hence this Cruel Scene was removed to Vallidolid in October following, Twenty eight Nobles burnt at Vallidolid. where in the preÅ¿ence of Philip, 28 of the Principal Nobility of that Country were bound to Stakes, and moÅ¿t Catholickly and Charitably burnt. Whether Thuanus were weary of the former Cruelties, or wanted exact Informations of the Particulars of
this laÅ¿t, I cannot Å¿ay, but the laÅ¿t is moÅ¿t probable; but however he gives none of their Names or Qualities, and Å¿aith there was Å¿ome Variation in the Time. Thus Spain was preÅ¿erved from HereÅ¿ie (as they call it) not by the Learning or Piety of the Clergy, but the Bloody Zeal of King Philip.

Pope Paul IV, The Death of Pope Paul IV. being worn out with Years, and very much afflicted with a DropÅ¿ie, July 29 Å¿ent for the Cardinals, and told them, He was going the way of all FleÅ¿h; and having adviÅ¿ed them to choÅ¿e a good SucceÅ¿Å¿or, recommended to them The moÅ¿t Holy Office of the InquiÅ¿ition (as he called it) which was the only thing that could preÅ¿erve that moÅ¿t Holy See. He, after this, pointed in another DiÅ¿courÅ¿e to King Philip, whom he Å¿aid God had raiÅ¿ed up as the great Defender of the Catholick Faith; and he added, That he did not doubt but the ChriÅ¿tian Religion would by his CounÅ¿els, however now afflicted, be reÅ¿tored to its Ancient State. He dyed AuguÅ¿t 18. aged 83 Years, having Å¿at Pope four Years, two Months and twenty three Days. WhilÅ¿t he was yet dying, The People of Rome expreÅ¿s their Hatred of him and the InquiÅ¿ition. the People broke open all the PriÅ¿ons, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of the InquiÅ¿ition, which they alÅ¿o Å¿et on Fire, and they were hardly reÅ¿trained from burning the Palace of Minerva, where that Court Sits; with the Å¿ame Fury they beat down the Image of the Pope, and broke off its Head and Right-hand, and three Days it lay expoÅ¿ed in the Streets, to the Contempt and Scorn of all Men, after which it was thrown into the Tiber. After this the Arms of the Caraffa's were demoliÅ¿hed all over the Town. His Body was buried with little Pomp, and a Guard of Soldiers drawn up to Å¿ecure it from the Rage of the Populace.

It is obÅ¿erved, The Deaths of Å¿everal Princes. That this Year was fatal to the Princes of Europe, AuguÅ¿t 17, Lawrence Prioly Duke of Venice died, and was Å¿ucceeded by Jerome, his own Brother, his rare Virtues diÅ¿penÅ¿ing with the Venetian Laws, of not Å¿uffering Honours to continue in the Å¿ame Family, leÅ¿t they might Å¿eem Hereditary. September 1, died Hercules di EÅ¿te Duke of Ferrara, he married Renata, a Daughter of Lewis XII, King of France; and was happy in all his Government, except his taking part with Henry II, in that unjuÅ¿t War againÅ¿t King Philip; as Thuanus calls it: But he was happy in this, That by his Prudence he extricated himÅ¿elf, and came off with little or no Damage, in his Treaty of Peace, with that Potent and provoked Prince.

February 12. died Otho Henry Duke of Bavaria, Count Palatine of the Rhine, and was Å¿ucceeded by Frederick III. April 29 died Francis Otho, Duke of Lunenburg. January 24, died William Prince of Henneberg; Å¿o that within the Å¿pace of one Year died Charles V, two Kings of Denmark, a King of France, a Duke of Venice, a Pope, the Elector Palatine, the Duke of Ferrara, and three Queens, Helionora of France, Mary of Hungary, and Bona Sfortia Queen of Poland.

The Conclave was very much divided in the Election of a new Pope,
Pius IV, elected. between the French and SpaniÅ¿h Factions, each Side labouring to have a Pope of their own IntereÅ¿t; So that this ConteÅ¿t laÅ¿ted three Months; till at laÅ¿t the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors of the other Princes began to remonÅ¿trate, That this long Delay tended only to the improving the Differences in Religion, and the increaÅ¿ing the Enemies of that See. At laÅ¿t, after a Vacancy of four Months and Å¿even Days, John Angelo Medici was elected, December 26. by the Suffrage of forty four Cardinals. He was born at Milan, of obÅ¿cure Parents, and took the Name of Pius IV: He began his Reign with a Pardon of the InÅ¿olencies the People of Rome had committed upon the Arms and Statue of Pope Paul IV, He changeth his Manners to the WorÅ¿e. his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or: But he Å¿oon changed, for he that till then had Å¿eemed the moÅ¿t Courteous, Patient, Good, Grateful and Liberal of Men, preÅ¿ently became quite another Man, and took up other Manners: He reÅ¿cinded all the Acts of his PredeceÅ¿Å¿or, and preÅ¿ently acknowledged the Imperial Dignity to be lawfully inveÅ¿ted in Ferdinand, the Brother of Charles V, and received his EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors with great Civility and ReÅ¿pect.

To return near Home,
Scotch Affairs. the ProteÅ¿tant Religion was already received in all Parts of Scotland, eÅ¿pecially in the Towns and Families of the Nobility and Gentry, tho' in Å¿ecret; but Queen Elizabeth having entertained the Reformed Religion, and Å¿etled it in England, they thence preÅ¿umed Å¿he would be a Å¿ure Friend to thoÅ¿e of that PerÅ¿uaÅ¿ion in Scotland: And a Parliament being called to open May 10. 1559. at Sterling, Alexander Cunigham Earl of Glencarn, and Sir Hugh Cambel, an eminent Knight, and Sheriff of Aire, appeared there in the behalf of the MiniÅ¿ters of the Reformed Religion, who had been Å¿ummoned to appear there by the Regent; who was now reÅ¿olved to diÅ¿Å¿emble no longer, but to excert her Authority, and Å¿hew her Zeal in their Ruine; accordingly Å¿he threatned them Å¿everely, and Å¿aid; She would baniÅ¿h all their Preachers, who under pretence of Religion promoted a Rebellion.
The Deputies amazed with her great Words, oppoÅ¿ed Supplications, remembring her of her PromiÅ¿es; to which Å¿he famrtly replyed, That the PromiÅ¿es of Princes were not to be expected to be fulfilled further than agreed with their Convenience. A MyÅ¿tery which Å¿he ought not to have revealed however, if her Anger had not broken open the ReceÅ¿Å¿es of her Heart. At this the two Deputies replyed, by Glencarne, That if Å¿he would keep no PromiÅ¿e, they would acknowledge her no more, but renounce their Obedience to her, the MiÅ¿chief of which Å¿he ought Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to conÅ¿ider. The BoldneÅ¿s and BriskneÅ¿s of this AnÅ¿wer abated the Regents Anger and Courage, and Å¿he Å¿eemed much calm'd, and replyed; I will conÅ¿ider of it. The news of this being carried that Night to S. John's-Town, the Inhabitants of it met that Night openly in their Churches, and had Sermons. The Queen Regent thereupon ordered all the MiniÅ¿ters, who were come as far as that City, but attended by vaÅ¿t Numbers of the Nobility, Gentry and Commons, in order to their appearing in the Parliament, to return Home, Å¿aying; She would not proceed in the Citation; yet afterward Å¿he declared them Rebels for not appearing. This made many leave her and go over to the ProteÅ¿tants. Whereupon Å¿he commanded one James Halyburton, Mayor of Dundee, to apprehend one Mefan a Preacher, who thought to have lien hid in that Place; and ordered the People to celebrate EaÅ¿ter-Sunday, after the ancient manner. When in this no body would obey her, one Areskin of Dundee went over to them, and aÅ¿Å¿ured them, The Regent was Å¿o exaÅ¿perated, that there was nothing but Ruine to be hoped for at her Hands; and that Å¿he had no regard to her PromiÅ¿e: Thereupon they all reÅ¿olved to diÅ¿Å¿emble no longer with her, but to uÅ¿e Force against Force. One John Knox, a bold and violent Preacher, further inflamed their over-heated Minds by a Seditious Sermon. The Nobility going to Dinner from the Sermon, a Quarrel aroÅ¿e in the Church, and the PrieÅ¿t that interpoÅ¿ed being Å¿everely treated, the Rabble fell upon the Statues and Altars, and deÅ¿troy'd them in a moment; after this, they fell upon the FranciÅ¿can and Dominican Abbeys, where they alÅ¿o deÅ¿troy'd the Images and Altars. The next that Å¿uffered was the CarthuÅ¿ian Abbey, which they demoliÅ¿h'd Å¿o intirely in two days (thought very great) that the Foot-Å¿teps of its Foundations were not eaÅ¿ily to be diÅ¿covered.

The Regent was by this time as much incenÅ¿ed as they; and Å¿wore, She would revenge this Villany with the Blood of the Inhabitants, and the Ruin of the Town. But in the interim the Example Å¿pread, and the Å¿ame things were reacted at Cupre in Fife. The Regent having aÅ¿Å¿embled Å¿ome Forces under Hamilton Earl of Argile, and the Earl of Athole, marched eaÅ¿ily towards St. John's-Town, that the Cannon might overtake them. But the Inhabitants of that Place writing to their Friends what was doing, he Earl of Glencarne came preÅ¿ently to their AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, with Two thouÅ¿and five hundred HorÅ¿e and Foot. And Å¿hortly after they had Seven thouÅ¿and Men in Arms againÅ¿t her; Å¿o that Å¿he now Å¿aw that Force would not do; upon which Å¿he Å¿ent the Lord James Steward Prior of St. Andrews, and one Cambell (who tho' ProteÅ¿tants, continued in their Obedience to her) to treat with the Earl of Glencarne and Areskin, who agreed, May 29, That all Forces being diÅ¿charged, the Town Å¿hould be Å¿et open to the Regent, that Å¿he might refreÅ¿h her Å¿elf a few days in it: That no French Å¿hould yet enter into it, nor come near it by three Miles: That all other ControverÅ¿ies Å¿hould be determined in the next Parliament. Whereupon Å¿he entred the Town, and was honourably received. But one of the Inhabitants being Å¿lain by an inÅ¿olent Soldier, and the Regent expreÅ¿Å¿ing not any Concern for it; They from thence concluded the Treaty would not be long obÅ¿erved, and accordingly about three days after Å¿he ordered the Town to be Å¿ack'd, chang'd the MagiÅ¿trates, and reÅ¿toring the mercenary Scots, Å¿worn to and paid by the French. Being hereupon urged with her PromiÅ¿e, Å¿he anÅ¿wer'd, That PromiÅ¿e was not to be kept with Hereticks, and if Å¿he could make an honest ExcuÅ¿e after the Fact committed, Å¿he would take upon her ConÅ¿cience to kill and undo all that Sect; concluding, That Princes ought not to have their PromiÅ¿es Å¿o Å¿trictly urged upon them; and then went back to Sterling. The Convenience and Strength of the Place, made her think it worth the breach of her Faith to them; but the Lord James Steward the Prior of St. Andrew, and the Earl of Argile, were Å¿o offended with this Procedure, that they left her, and went over to the ProteÅ¿tants, and gave them notice that Å¿he intended to GarriÅ¿on Cupre and St. Andrews, in Fife, with Frenchmen. Whereupon they deÅ¿troyed the FranciÅ¿can and Dominican Abbies of the laÅ¿t City under the ArchbiÅ¿hop's Eyes, yet he durÅ¿t not Å¿hew the leaÅ¿t diÅ¿content at it, but fled into Faulkland. The Regent aÅ¿Å¿embled all the French Å¿he had in the Kingdom, which were two thouÅ¿and, and one thouÅ¿and Scots, and march â¢ d for Cupre the Thirteenth of June. The Earl of Argile, on the other Å¿ide, brought
in one thouÅ¿and ProteÅ¿tants to the Relief of St. Andrews, and Patrick Lermoth Bailiff of the Regality, their Chief Officer, levied five hundred more of the Inhabitants of St. Andrews, and before Ten of the Clock the next Morning there were above three thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e and Foot, which being drawn up to the beÅ¿t Advantage upon the Banks of a Å¿mall River by Mr. James Halleburton, ProvoÅ¿t of Dundee, a Man of good Experience and Valour, and therefore made General that day, made Å¿o formidable an Appearance, that the Regent durÅ¿t not hazard a Battel againÅ¿t them. By this time Å¿he Å¿aw, to her CoÅ¿t, how neceÅ¿Å¿ary it was for Princes not to break their Faith. For when Å¿he would have gladly come to Peace, there could no reliance be made upon her PromiÅ¿e, and Å¿he had nothing elÅ¿e to engage. And when they demanded the French might be Å¿ent away, Å¿he Å¿aid that Å¿he could not do it without order from the King of France. So Å¿he was deÅ¿ired to withdraw the GarriÅ¿on out of St. John's-Town; which when Å¿he refuÅ¿ed, the ProteÅ¿tants marched thither the Twenty fourth of June, and in a few days took it. From thence they march'd to the Abbey of Scone, and took and Å¿ack'd it; and being informed the Regent deÅ¿igned to put a French GarriÅ¿on into Sterling, they went in the night from St John's-Town thither, and Å¿urprized it, and ruined all the MonaÅ¿teries, Images and Altars. They alÅ¿o changed the Religion at Lithgo, Linlithgow. in the way to Sterling, and whereÅ¿oever they prevail'd. The Regent and the French in the mean time retired from Edinburg to Dunbar, expecting till this Storm Å¿hould blow over, and here they heard of the Death of Henry II of France: The ProteÅ¿tants rejoyced at it, as a thing that tended to their Safety, but had like to have made it the occaÅ¿ion of their Ruine, by withdrawing from the Army. The Regent thereupon marched with her Forces to Edinburg, and in the way had a fair opportunity to have fought and overthrown the remainder of their Army, which was prevented by the Duke of Hamilton, and James Earl of DowglaÅ¿s. The Twenty fourth of July a Truce was made to laÅ¿t till the Tenth of January; which the Regent obÅ¿erved Å¿o much the more exactly, becauÅ¿e Å¿he found by Experience that the former breach of PromiÅ¿e had involved her in greater Difficulties and DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es. Yet even here Å¿he could not totally lay aÅ¿ide her old wont, but broke Faith as far as Å¿he durÅ¿t.

It is neceÅ¿Å¿ary here to TranÅ¿cribe Å¿ome of our EngliÅ¿h Affairs which relate to Scotland, The EngliÅ¿h Affairs relating to Scotland. that we may Å¿ee how far, and upon what Provocations Queen Elizabeth was concern'd. Henry II, of France had no Å¿ooner ended his War with King Philip, but he began to caÅ¿t an Eye upon England, as very convenient for the Dauphin King his Son, and Mary Queen of the Scots, and on that Account refuÅ¿ed to recall the French Forces out of Scotland, as by the laÅ¿t Treaty he had promiÅ¿ed; but inÅ¿tead of that, he Å¿ent more thither by Å¿tealth, and was very earneÅ¿t with the Pope to declare Queen Elizabeth an Heretick and Illegitimate, and Mary the Lawful Heir of England; which yet was diligently but under-hand oppos'd by the Imperial and SpaniÅ¿h Agents at Rome. However the GuiÅ¿es never left exciting the credulous and ambitious Hopes of that Prince, of Uniting the Crown of England to that of France, by the means of Queen Mary their Heir, till at laÅ¿t they prevail'd on him to aÅ¿Å¿ert openly the Pretences of his Son and Daughter-in-Law, and to conÅ¿ent they might uÅ¿e this Title, Francis and Mary, by the Grace of God, King and Queen of Scotland England and Ireland, and to quarter the Arms of England with thoÅ¿e of Scotland, upon their Plate, and on the Walls of their Palaces, and the Coats of their Heraulds. The EngliÅ¿h EmbaÅ¿Å¿ador complain'd of this, but to no purpoÅ¿e, as tending to the great Injury of his MiÅ¿treÅ¿s, with whom they had lately made a Peace, they having never done it in the Life of Queen Mary, though there was a War between the Nations: That there were great numbers of Soldiers LiÅ¿ted in France and Germany to be TranÅ¿ported into Scotland upon the Å¿ame Continent with England. So that Queen Elizabeth had juÅ¿t reaÅ¿on to Å¿uÅ¿pect the Intentions of the French, who now breathed nothing but Blood and Death againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants; but that Prince's DeÅ¿igns, whatever they were, periÅ¿hed with him, to the great Advantage of Queen Elizabeth, who had otherwiÅ¿e been attack'd by all the Forces of France and Scotland, both as Illigitimate and an Heretick. Yet Å¿he ordered his Exequies to be celebrated at St. Paul's with great Solemnity, and by Charles Son to the Lord Howard of Effingham her Envoy, condol'd his Death, congratulated the SucceÅ¿Å¿ion of Francis his Son, and promis'd to obÅ¿erve the Peace between them religiouÅ¿ly.

Yet Francis the new King,
Fradcis II, of France, claims England in the Right of Mary his Wife. and Mary his Wife, the Queen of the Scots, (by the Advice of the GuiÅ¿es, who now had got the Government of France, in a manner, into their Hands) Å¿till continued the Claim of the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, and the uÅ¿e of the Arms thereof more openly. And when Throgmorton, the EngliÅ¿h
EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour in ordinany, a WiÅ¿e and Stout Man, Å¿everely expoÅ¿tulated the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s. They replyed, Queen Mary might aÅ¿Å¿ume the Arms of England with Å¿ome Å¿mall DiÅ¿tinction, to Å¿hew her near Relation to that Royal Blood. But he denyed this could be done by the Laws of Heraldry, if the PerÅ¿on uÅ¿ing the Arms of another Family was not derived from a certain Heir. After this they pretended, They only uÅ¿ed theÅ¿e Arms, to force the Queen to lay aÅ¿ide the uÅ¿e of the Arms of France. To which he anÅ¿wered, That twelve Kings of England (as Dr. Woton Å¿hewed in the Treaty of Cambray) had worn the Arms of France, with Å¿o undoubted a Right, that no oppoÅ¿ition had been made to it in any Treaty between France and England. At laÅ¿t, by the InterpoÅ¿ition of Montmorancy, who was no Friend to the GuiÅ¿es, he prevailed, and the Title of England and Ireland, and the uÅ¿e of the Arms of thoÅ¿e Kingdoms was laid aÅ¿ide, becauÅ¿e that great Man thought, It was not for the Honour of France to have any other Title or Arms aÅ¿Å¿umed or engraven on their Seal than that of the King of France. That this one Title was as good as many: And he alÅ¿o Å¿hewed, That the former Kings uÅ¿ed no other, tho' they claimed the Dutchy of Milan, and the Kingdom of Naples. But however, from this UÅ¿e of the Title and Arms of England impoÅ¿ed on this young Queen, by the Arts of the GuiÅ¿es, and the Ambition of Henry II, as from a Fountain, Å¿prung all thoÅ¿e Calamities, which afterwards ruined her: For from this Time Queen Elizabeth was a declared Enemy to the GuiÅ¿es, and a concealed one to the Queen of Scots; which laÅ¿t enmity, was by the Malice of cunning Men, a growing Emulation, and new OccaÅ¿ions, which every day Å¿prung up, Å¿o improved, that at laÅ¿t it ended in her Death. For Princes will endure no Rival, and MajeÅ¿ty is very Å¿enÅ¿ible of Affronts.

The French by the Treaty were to give four HoÅ¿tages for the ReÅ¿titution of Calais within eight Years; but when it was to be done, they would give but three. The French Provocations againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h. The EngliÅ¿h Merchants were ill uÅ¿ed in France: A Servant of Throcmorton's, the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, was Å¿ent by Francis, Grand Prior of France, the Brother of GuiÅ¿e, publickly to the Gallies: A PiÅ¿tol was diÅ¿charged againÅ¿t the EmbaÅ¿Å¿adour, in his own Lodgings: And he had no Plate allowed him, for his Table, but what had the Arms of England engraven on it, in contempt: Du BroÅ¿Å¿ay was alÅ¿o Å¿ent with Supplies of French into Scotland: And the Gallies of France were brought from MarÅ¿eille in the Mediterrancan into the BritiÅ¿h Seas.

This was the State of Affairs between France and England, The Scotch Complaints againÅ¿t the French. when the Troubles of Scotland broke out, and the Lords of the Articles Å¿ent William Maitland their Secretary; who made a deplorable RepreÅ¿entation of the State of that Kingdom to Queen Elizabeth, Å¿etting forth; That Å¿ince the Marriage of their Queen to the Dauphine of France, the Government of Scotland had been charged, the French Soldiers laid all waÅ¿te; The principal Employments were given to Frenchmen, their Forts and CaÅ¿tles put into their Hands, and their Money adulterated to their Advantage. That the DeÅ¿ign was apparently to poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s themÅ¿elves of Scotland, if the Queen Å¿hould happen to die without IÅ¿Å¿ue. Cecil (who was the Queens Prime MiniÅ¿ter) imployed Henry Percy Earl of Northumberland, to find out what the Lords of the Articles deÅ¿igned; and what Means they had to attain their Ends; and upon what Terms they expected Succours from England. They Å¿aid, They deÅ¿ired nothing but the Glory of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, the Å¿incere Preaching of the Word of God, the extirpation of SuperÅ¿tition and Idolatry, the ReÅ¿traint of the Fury of PerÅ¿ecution, and the PreÅ¿ervation of their ancient Liberties. That they knew not for the preÅ¿ent how to effect this; but they hoped the Divine GoodneÅ¿s, which had begun the Work, would bring it to its deÅ¿ired End, with the ConfuÅ¿ion of their Enemies: That they earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired to enter into a FriendÅ¿hip with the Queen of England to the PreÅ¿ervation of which they would Sacrifice their Lives and Fortunes.

The ConÅ¿ideration of theÅ¿e things was not warmly entertained in England, Queen Elizabeth holds off at firÅ¿t; but, be cauÅ¿e the Scots had little Money, and were not over-well cemented among themÅ¿elves; Å¿o they were only adviÅ¿ed, Not to enter raÅ¿hly into a War. But as Å¿oon as the EngliÅ¿h knew that the MarqueÅ¿s of Elboeuf, the Queen of Scots Unkle, was liÅ¿ting Men in Germany by the Rhinegrave, for a War in Scotland, That Cannons were Å¿ent to the Ports, and Preparations made to conquer that Kingdom, and that in greater Quantities than Å¿eemed neceÅ¿Å¿ary to reduce a few unarmed Scots: That the French, to draw the Danes into this War, had proffered, That the Duke of Lorrain Å¿hould renounce his Right to Denmark: And that they were renewing their Solicitations with the Pope, To give a declaratory Sentence for the Queen of Scot,
againÅ¿t the Queen of England: Thereupon Sir Ralph Sadler, a wiÅ¿e Man, was Å¿ent to the Earl of Northumberland, and Governour of the middle Marches, on the Borders of Scotland, at laÅ¿t is forced to unite with the ProteÅ¿tants of Scotland. ReaÅ¿ons aÅ¿Å¿igned for the driving the French out of Scotland. to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him, and Sir James Croft, Governour of Berwick. The EngliÅ¿h Council could not Å¿ee whither all this tended, unleÅ¿s the French deÅ¿igned to invade the Kingdom of England, as well as aÅ¿Å¿ume the Title and Arms of it.

Upon this the Council of England began to conÅ¿ider in good earneÅ¿t, and with great Application of the Scotch Affairs, it was thought a thing of very ill and dangerous Example, that one Prince Å¿hould undertake the Protection of the Subjects of another Prince, who were in Rebellion: But then it was thought impious not to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t thoÅ¿e of the Å¿ame Religion, when perÅ¿ecuted for it. The Å¿ixteenth of November, the King being abroad to hunt,

This Accident changed the Å¿tate of things, and Å¿aved the Life of Conde,

CoÅ¿ â¢ us Duke of Florence, The Duke of Florence come to Rome. perceiving that this Journey of the Pope to Ancona was a Sham, and being invited by the Pope to Rome, reÅ¿olved to go thither, to promote this and Å¿ome other Private BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s he had with the Pope. GuÅ¿tavus King of Sweden dies. which was the Founder of the Line which now reigns in that Kingdom; he was Å¿ucceeded by Eriek his eldeÅ¿t Son. The Celebration of the States of France was inter â¢â¢â¢ tted by the Å¿udden Death of Fracis II. But there being great DiÅ¿contents at the numerous AÅ¿Å¿emblies of the ProteÅ¿tants in many Places, which were now openly held; the finding out a Remedy for this, haÅ¿tned the opening that Convention. In which having Å¿hewn the UÅ¿e of theÅ¿e AÅ¿Å¿emblies, and exhorted all degrees to Peace and Concord, and Å¿hewn 'em the common CauÅ¿es of Sedition and Rebellion, he tells them, That in their times, a new CauÅ¿e, that of Religion, had been added to all the former; As if (Å¿aith he) Religion could or ought to be the cauÅ¿e of a Civil War, which is the greateÅ¿t MiÅ¿chief that can befall a Kingdom, and contains all others in it. And in the Å¿ame HouÅ¿e, if they are divided in Religion, the Husband cannot agree with the Wife and Children, nor one Brother with another. That therefore a Remedy might be had for Å¿o great a Calamity, it had been decreed at Fountain-bleau, That there was need of a Council, and the Pope having Å¿ince declared there Å¿hould Å¿uddenly be one, that Men ought not in the mean time to hammer ont for themÅ¿elves new Religions, Rites and Ceremonies, according to their own Fancies. Let us therefore, Å¿aid he, pray daily for them, that they may be reduced from their Errors, and diÅ¿charging the hateful Names of Lutherans, Huguenots and PapiÅ¿ts, which were introduced by the Enemy of Mankind, and are too like the ancient Factions of Guelfs and Gibellins, let us only retain the Ancient Appellation of ChriÅ¿tians. But then, becauÅ¿e there are many who only pretend Religion, but are in Truth led by Ambition, Avarice and Novelty, it is fit to Å¿uppreÅ¿s theÅ¿e Men in the
very beginning: TheÅ¿e are the Men that ought to be kept under by the Force of Arms.

When the States came to debate, A Difficulty propoÅ¿ed. the Clergy and the Commons were of Opinion, That their Powers were determined by the Death of the late King; and that they ought to return Home: Which was over-ruled by the King of Navar and the Council; And they were ordered to proceed; becauÅ¿e by the Law of France the King never dies; but the Lawful SucceÅ¿Å¿ion is tranÅ¿mitted without any interruption. The Cardinal of Lorraine had deÅ¿ign'd in the former Reign to make a Speech in the Name of the three EÅ¿tates; which was then not oppoÅ¿ed, but now the Commons would not Å¿uffer it, becauÅ¿e contrary to the Ancient UÅ¿age: And for that they had Å¿ome things to object againÅ¿t the Cardinal himÅ¿elf.

Jean l' Ange, an Advocate of the Parliament of Bourdeaux, The Deputy of the Commons Å¿peaks againÅ¿t the Clergy. Å¿poke for the Commons, and remarked three great Faults in the Clergy, Ignorance, CovetouÅ¿neÅ¿s and ExceÅ¿Å¿ive Luxury, which had given Being to the new Errors, and Scandal to the People. That the Preaching of the Word of God, which was the chief cauÅ¿e of the inÅ¿tituting BiÅ¿hops, was totally neglected; and they thought it a Å¿hameful thing, and beneath their Dignity: And by their Example, the Curates had learned to neglect their Duty too, and had ordered the MaÅ¿s to be Å¿ung by Illiterate and Unworthy Stipendaries. That the exceÅ¿Å¿ive Pomp and Avarice of the Clergy (who pretended by it to promote the Glory of God) had raiÅ¿ed an Envy and an hatred of them in the Minds of the People. And therefore he deÅ¿ired that a Council might be aÅ¿Å¿embled, by the order of the King, to remedy theÅ¿e MiÅ¿chiefs.

After him James de Silty Comte de Roquefort, And is Å¿econded by the Deputy of the Nobility. made a Bold and an Elegant Oration in the Name of the Nobility, and taxed the Clergy for invading the Rights, and oppreÅ¿Å¿ing the People, under Pretence of the JuriÅ¿dictions granted them by the Ancient Kings of France. That therefore the King ought, in the firÅ¿t place to take care to reform the Clergy, and aÅ¿Å¿ign good PenÅ¿ions to thoÅ¿e that Preached the Word of God, as had been done by many of his AnceÅ¿tors, which he named.

Jean Quintin le Bourguinon, The Clergy apologize for themÅ¿elves. made a long tedious Speech in the behalf of the Clergy, to Å¿hew; I. That the AÅ¿Å¿embly of the three EÅ¿tates were inÅ¿tituted for the providing for the Sacred DiÅ¿cipline. II. That the King might underÅ¿tand the Complaints of his People, and provide for the NeceÅ¿Å¿ities of his Kingdom, by their Advice, and not for the Reformation of the Church, Which could not Err, and which neither hath, nor ever Å¿hall have the leaÅ¿t Spot or Wrinkle, but Å¿hall ever be Beautiful: But then he ingenuouÅ¿ly confeÅ¿t, That the Sacred DiÅ¿cipline was very much declined from its Ancient Simplicity. That therefore the Revivers of the the Ancient HereÅ¿ies were not to be heard; and all that had Meetings Å¿eparate from the Catholicks, were to be eÅ¿teemed Favourers of Sectaries, and to be puniÅ¿hed. Therefore he deÅ¿ired the King to compel all his Subjects, within his Dominions, to Live and Believe according to the Form preÅ¿cribed by the Church. That the InÅ¿olence of the Sectaries was no longer to be endured, who deÅ¿piÅ¿ing the Authority of the Ancients, and the Doctrine received by the Church, would be thought alone to underÅ¿tand and imbrace the GoÅ¿pel. That this was the next Å¿tep to a Rebellion, and that they would Å¿hortly Å¿hake off the Yoak of the Civil MagiÅ¿trate, and with the Å¿ame BoldneÅ¿s fight againÅ¿t their Prince, that they now imployed againÅ¿t the Church, if Care were not Å¿peedily taken. He deÅ¿ired that all Commerce between them and the Catholicks might be forbidden, and that they might be treated like Enemies, and that thoÅ¿e who were gone out of the Kingdom on the account of Religion, might be baniÅ¿hed. That it was the King's Duty to draw the Civil Sword, and put all thoÅ¿e to Death, who were infected with HereÅ¿ie; to defend the Clergy, and reÅ¿tore the Elections of BiÅ¿hops to the Chapters, the want of which had cauÅ¿ed great Damages to the Church. That it had been obÅ¿erved, That the very Year the Pope granted the King the Nomination of BiÅ¿hops, this SchiÅ¿m began, and has ever Å¿ince Å¿pread it Å¿elf; for in the 1517, Luther, Zuinglius and Oecolampadius Å¿et up, and Calvin followed them. This Speech incenÅ¿ed the whole AÅ¿Å¿embly againÅ¿t him, and eÅ¿pecially the ProteÅ¿tants, who publiÅ¿hed Å¿o many Libels and Satyrs againÅ¿t him, that he Å¿oon after died of Shame and Grief. He was no ill Man, but was a better DecretaliÅ¿t than a Divine; and had never well thought whether a Reformation were needfull or no, But then it ought alÅ¿o to have
been conÅ¿idered that he did not Å¿peak his own Single judgment, but had his matter preÅ¿cribed him by the Clergy for whom he Å¿poke.

After Å¿ome days, the King Signified to the BiÅ¿hops, that they Å¿hould prepare themÅ¿elves for the Council, which was now recall'd at Trent; and the Judges and Prefects were commanded to diÅ¿charge all that were ImpriÅ¿on'd for Religion only, and leave all that were Å¿uÅ¿pected, the free injoyment of their EÅ¿tates and Goods; And it was made Capital to reproach, or injure one the other, on the Account of Religion. After which the AÅ¿Å¿emly was Prorogued to the Month of May, of the next Year.

There was in Piedmont, a Valley called by the Name of PeroÅ¿ia, and St. Martin; Inhabited by about 15000 Souls, whoÅ¿e AnceÅ¿tors about 400 Years Å¿ince had upon the Preaching of Waldus, The PerÅ¿ecution in Piedmont, which OccaÅ¿ioneth a War. Speronus and Arnaldus, made a defection from the Church of Rome, and had at times been Å¿everely treated for it, by the French, under whom they had been; but by the laÅ¿t Treaty were aÅ¿Å¿igned to the Duke of Savoy. This People about the Year 1555, had imbraced the Reformation, and had Å¿uffered it to be publickly preached, tho it was forbidden by the Council at Turin, which the Year following Å¿ent one of its own Members, to inquire after the Offenders and to puniÅ¿h them; to whom the Inhabitants of this Valley delivered the ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of their Faith; Declaring that they profeÅ¿s'd the Doctrin contained in the Old and New TeÅ¿tament, and comprehended in the ApoÅ¿tles Creed; and admitted the Sacraments InÅ¿tituted by ChriÅ¿t; the IV firÅ¿t Councils, viz. thoÅ¿e of Nice, ConÅ¿tantinople, EpheÅ¿us, and Chalcedon; and the Ten Commandments &c. That they believed the Supreme civil MagiÅ¿trates were InÅ¿tituted by God, and they were to be obeyed, and that who Å¿oever reÅ¿iÅ¿ted them, Å¿ought againÅ¿t God. They Å¿aid they had received this Doctrin from their AnceÅ¿tors, and that if they were in any error they were ready to receive inÅ¿truction from the Word of God, and would preÅ¿ently renounce any heretical or erroneous Doctrin which Å¿hould be Å¿o Å¿hewen to them.

Thereupon a Solemn DiÅ¿pute was in Å¿hew, appointed concerning the Sacrifice of the MaÅ¿s, Auricular ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, Tradition, Prayers and Oblations for the Dead, and the Ceremonies of the Church and her CenÅ¿ures; all which were rejected by them, they alledging that they were humane Inventions, and contrary to the Word of God. This ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion was Å¿ent by the Duke of Savoy to the King of France, who about a year after return'd AnÅ¿wer, That he had cauÅ¿ed it to be Examin'd by his learned Divines; who had all condemn'd it as Erroneous and contrary to true Religion; and therefore the King commanded them to reject this ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion and to Submit to the Holy Church of Rome; and if they did not do Å¿o, their PerÅ¿ons and EÅ¿tates Å¿hould be ConfiÅ¿cated. But they on the contrary were reÅ¿olved to Å¿tand by their former ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion. They were thereupon commanded not to admit any Teacher who was not Å¿ent by the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Turin, or the Council there; and that if any Teachers came among them from Geneva they Å¿hould diÅ¿cover or apprehend them, upon pain of Death, and loÅ¿s of all they had. For three years after this, the people of this PerÅ¿waÅ¿ion were let alone and no way moleÅ¿ted; but this Year the Duke of Savoy, much againÅ¿t his will and Inclination, was drawn by the Pope to make a War upon them. In the begining of March, Jean de Carquignau, and one Mathurim and his Wife were taken and burnt; and Å¿everal of the Neighbour Valleys were Plundred, Å¿everal of the Inhabitants were put to death; and about Sixty Å¿ent to the Gallies, and Å¿ome recanted and profeÅ¿s'd the Roman Catholick Religion. After this one Thomas Jacomel a Dominican, was Å¿ent with one Turbis for his AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant, who was a bloody man, to inquire diligently and Å¿everely into all that were Å¿uÅ¿pected; but the Nobility interpoÅ¿ing, there was no great Severity Å¿hewn. The Monks of the Abbey of Pignoral, which was Å¿eated in the Entry of the Valley, on the other Å¿ide, kept a parcel of Souldiers in Pay; and trapping as many of theÅ¿e Poor People as they could, as they paÅ¿Å¿ed to and fro, they uÅ¿ed them very cruelly; and Å¿ome others of the Nobility did the Å¿ame thing; and a Sedition following upon it, they fined the poor Inhabitants One ThouÅ¿and Å¿ix Hundred Crowns. Upon this a Å¿harp war inÅ¿ued, which ended in the Ruine of the AggreÅ¿Å¿ors of the Church of Rome.

The PaÅ¿tor alÅ¿o of PeroÅ¿ia, was taken and burnt with a Å¿low, Fire with many of his Flock, and the Inhabitants were Å¿poiled of all they had, and forced to flee to the Mountains. Being thus inraged with hard UÅ¿ages, in the Month of July, Fifty of them Å¿et upon One Hundred and Twenty Souldiers belonging to the Abbey of Pignoral, put them to flight, and flew the greateÅ¿t part of them; and about Four Hundred more of their party coming up,
they took the Abbey of Pignoral, and delivered all their people which were impriÅ¿oned there. In October following News being brought that the Duke of Savoy was Å¿ending an Army to deÅ¿troy them; They reÅ¿olved that it was not lawful to take Arms againÅ¿t their Prince, but that they would take what they could carry away, and betake themÅ¿elves to the Mountains, and there attend the good pleaÅ¿ure of God, who never forÅ¿akes his own, and can turn the Hearts of Princes which way he pleaÅ¿eth. There was not one Man amongÅ¿t them who repined againÅ¿t this Decree. In after times they had PaÅ¿tors who taught them otherwiÅ¿e, and told them it was not their Prince, but the Pope that they reÅ¿iÅ¿ted, and that they fought not for their Religion, but for their Wives and Children. The Å¿econd of November the Forces of the Duke of Savoy entered their Borders, and the Soldiers attempting to get above them, they betook themÅ¿elves to their Slings, and maintained a Fight againÅ¿t them (though they were but few in number) the Å¿pace of a whole day, with no great loÅ¿s. At laÅ¿t the General finding they were not to be forced, gave them leave to Petition the Duke of Savoy, That they might live in Peace, aÅ¿Å¿uring him that nothing but utter ruin coald have forced them to take Arms againÅ¿t him: for which they humbly implored his HighneÅ¿s's Pardon, and begging the Liberty of their ConÅ¿ciences, and that they might not be forced to Å¿ubmit to the Traditions of the Church of Rome; but might, with his good leave, enjoy the Religion they had learned from their AnceÅ¿tors.

This Petition was Å¿econded by the DucheÅ¿s of Savoy, who was a merciful PrinceÅ¿s, a and had great Power over the Affections of the Duke. It being ever her judgment that this People were not to be Å¿o Å¿everely uÅ¿ed, who had not changed their Religion a few days agon, but had been in PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of it from their AnceÅ¿tors Å¿o many Ages. Upon this they were to be received to mercy; but the Soldiery fell upon them, when they Å¿uÅ¿pected nothing, and Plundered them three days together. The General Å¿eemed to be much concerned at this breach of Faith: yet after this they were fined eight thouÅ¿and Crowns, which they were forced to borrow on great UÅ¿ury, and they were alÅ¿o commanded to bring all their Arms into the CaÅ¿tles the Duke had GarriÅ¿oned in their Country. And at laÅ¿t they were commanded to eject all their PaÅ¿tors (which was granted with the tears of their People) that they might avoid the fury of the Soldiers. The General pretended not to be Å¿atisfied that their PaÅ¿tors were in good truth gone, and when they Å¿uffered them to Å¿earch their HouÅ¿es, the Soldiers Plundered them again, and then burnt their Town. There was one Town called Angrogne, in a Valley of the Å¿ame name, the General pretended to Å¿hew them more favour, and agreed that they Å¿hould have one PaÅ¿tor left them: but they forced him alÅ¿o to flee into the Mountains afterwards, and Plundered his HouÅ¿e, and all his Neighbours, and then injoyned the Sindicks (who are their chief MagiÅ¿trates) to find up, and bring in the PaÅ¿tor; threatning that otherwiÅ¿e they would burn and deÅ¿troy the whole Territory; and when they had Å¿o done then they withdrew.

In the mean time their MeÅ¿Å¿engers were gone with the Petition, mentioned above, to the Duke to Vercelli, where they attended forty days before they could get Audience, and then they were forced to promiÅ¿e they would admit the MaÅ¿s, and when the Prince had upon theÅ¿e terms forgiven their taking Arms againÅ¿t him, they were commanded to ask Pardon too of the Popes Nuncio, which at laÅ¿t they did. During their abÅ¿ence, the Inhabitants of Angrogne had Å¿uffered no Sermons but in private, that they might not exaÅ¿perate the Prince, or make the Affairs of their Deputies more difficult. But they reÅ¿olved when theÅ¿e were returned they would exerciÅ¿e their Religion openly, and not give any thing to the maintaining of the Soldiers, whether their RequeÅ¿t were granted or denied.

In the beginning of January the Deputies returned,
year 1561 and when their Principals underÅ¿tood what had been done, they wrote to the reÅ¿t of the Valleys to give them an account of it; and deÅ¿ired a publick GonÅ¿ultation or Diet. At which it was reÅ¿olved that they Å¿hould all joyn in a League to defend their Religion, which they believed was agreeable to the Word of God, profeÅ¿Å¿ing in the mean time to obey their Prince according to the Commandments of God, and that they would for the future make no Agreement, or Peace, but by a common ConÅ¿ent, in which the freedom of their Religion Å¿hould be Å¿aved. Upon this they grew more Confident, refuÅ¿ed the Conditions offered by the Duke of Savoy, and the promiÅ¿es made by their Deputies. And the next day they entered into the Church of Bobbi, in Arms, and broke down all the Images and Altars, and after a Sermon,
marching to Villar, where they intended to do the like, they met the Soldiers (who had heard what was done) going to Plunder Bobbi, Å¿topped them, and with their Slings Å¿o pelted them, that they were glad to Å¿hift for their lives, and left theÅ¿e Reformers to do the Å¿ame thing at Villar. The Captain of Turin attempting to Å¿top this Rage was beaten, and the Dukes Officers were glad to Å¿eek to their PaÅ¿tors for a PaÅ¿port. After this they beat the Captain of Turin in a Å¿econd Fight. By this time the whole Army drew into the Field, and the Inhabitants of theÅ¿e Valleys not being able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t them, they burnt all their Towns and HouÅ¿es, and deÅ¿troyed all the People they took. In theÅ¿e Broils Monteil, one of the Duke of Savoy's Chief Officers, was Å¿lain by a Lad of eighteen years of age; and Truchet, another of them, by a Dwarf. The Duke of Savoy had Å¿ent Å¿even thouÅ¿and Soldiers to deÅ¿troy this handful of Men; and yet Å¿uch was their Rage and DeÅ¿peration, and the Advantage of their Country, that they beat his Soldiers whereÅ¿oever they met them. And in all theÅ¿e Fights their Enemies obÅ¿erved that they had Å¿lain only fourteen of the Inhabitants, and thence concluded that God fought for them. So the Savoyards began to treat of a Peace, which at laÅ¿t was concluded to the Advantage of theÅ¿e poor deÅ¿picable People. The Duke remitting the eight thouÅ¿and Crowns they were to pay by the former Treaty, and Å¿uffering them to enjoy the Liberty of their Religion: So that he got nothing by this War but loÅ¿s and Å¿hame, the ruin of his People on both Å¿ides, and the deÅ¿olating of his Country.

div.head: A CONTINUATION OF THE HISTORY OF THE REFORMATION.
BOOK III.

argument.head: The CONTENTS.
argument.p: A PerÅ¿ecution in the Low-Countries. The French Affairs. Queen Catharine favoureth the ProteÅ¿tants, but ordereth Montmorency to oppoÅ¿e them. She Å¿uÅ¿pects the deÅ¿igns of the Nobility. The differences of Religion occaÅ¿ion Tumults in France. Various Edicts made. The Cardinal of Lorrain procures the Conference of PoiÅ¿Å¿i. Mary Queen of the Scots leaves France. The three EÅ¿tates of France AÅ¿Å¿emble at Pont-OyÅ¿e. The Conference of PoiÅ¿Å¿i. The RudeneÅ¿s of Laines, General of the JeÅ¿uits. This Conference diÅ¿liked abroad. The Council of Trent recalled. OppoÅ¿ed by Vergerius. The Popes Legates Å¿ent to Princes to invite them to the Council. A Diet of the ProteÅ¿tant Princes at Naumburg. The Queen of England rejects the Council. The Ruin of the Caraffa's. The King of Navarre drawn over to the RomiÅ¿h Party, by the Arts of the King of Spain. Scotch Affairs. The ProteÅ¿tant Religion Å¿etled there by a Parliament. Queen Mary Arrives there. Her beginning favourable to the ProteÅ¿tants. Great kindneÅ¿s at firÅ¿t, in Å¿hew, between her and Queen Elizabeth. The French Affairs. The Edict of January, 1562. Injunctions publiÅ¿hed by the Queen concerning Images. The King of Navarre pretends to promote the Reformation. The Edict of January oppoÅ¿ed by the GuiÅ¿es. The MaÅ¿Å¿acre of VaÅ¿Å¿i. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e entereth Paris. All things in France tend to Civil War. The Queen joyns with the Roman Catholick Party out of fear. Orleans Å¿urprized by the Prince of Conde. The MaÅ¿Å¿acre of Senlis. Roan taken by the ProteÅ¿tants. Several Treaties for a Peace. The Siege of Roan. The King of Navarre Å¿hot. His Death and Character. The Prince of Conde leaves Orleans. BeÅ¿ieges Corbeil. The two Armies come in view. He marches towards Normandy. The Battel of Dreux, in which Montmorency is taken. St. Andre Å¿lain, and the Prince of Conde taken. Coligni and the Duke of GuiÅ¿e become Generals. The Pope fondly rejoyces at this Battel. The Siege of Orleans. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inated. His Death and Character. The Queen deÅ¿ires, and at laÅ¿t makes a Peace, which is diÅ¿liked by Coligni.

div.p:
THIS Year there began a Å¿harp PerÅ¿ecution againÅ¿t all that were Å¿uÅ¿pected to favour the Reformation in the Netherlands,
year 1561 and for the greater terror they burnt the HouÅ¿es of all thoÅ¿e they Convicted for holding private Meetings. Perrenot BiÅ¿hop of Arras, A PerÅ¿ecution in the Low-Countries. and Cardinal Granvel, hoping by this means to prevent the Å¿preading of a Religion in that Country, which had made Å¿uch progreÅ¿Å¿es in Germany and France. They that imbraced this Religion, were no leÅ¿s Å¿candalized by the multiplying the BiÅ¿hopricks, and
thereupon drew up a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of their Faith, to be exhibited to King Philip, beÅ¿eeching him, in the end of it, that he would put a Å¿top to the bloody Executions, which deÅ¿troyed Å¿o many of his innocent People. This ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion was the Å¿ame in Å¿ubÅ¿tance with that publiÅ¿hed by the French ProteÅ¿tants; and amongÅ¿t other things, they took particular care to inÅ¿ert That the Civil MagiÅ¿trate was the Ordinance of God, and therefore was to be obeyed. Their Tributes to be duly paid, and all manner of ReÅ¿pect and Reverence to be Å¿hewed to them; and that Prayers were to be made to God for their preÅ¿ervation.

In the month of February, The French Affair. the new King of France left Orleans, and went to Fontainbleau, where the Prince of Conde waited upon him, and being introduced into the Privy Council, asked the Chancellor if there were any AccuÅ¿ation depending againÅ¿t him, and was told by him and the whole Council, they were intirely Å¿atisfied of his innocence, and leave was given him to demand an Acquital in the Parliament of Paris. And a Decree was made to that purpoÅ¿e, and PubliÅ¿hed by the Order of the Council March 13. after which he went to Paris to proÅ¿ecute his DiÅ¿charge before that Court.

In the mean time Queen Catharine, Queen Catharine favoureth the ProteÅ¿tants. the Regent of France, Å¿eemed very much to favour the ProteÅ¿tant Party, and by her Arts and DiÅ¿Å¿imulation, Å¿o far prevailed upon the Å¿pirit of the King of Navarre, who was their Head, that he told the DaniÅ¿h AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, he did not doubt but he Å¿hould Å¿ee the Reformed Religion Å¿ettled in France within one year. The Queen, on the other Å¿ide, told Montmorency, That Å¿he counived at them for the preÅ¿ent, that Å¿he might the more eaÅ¿ily elude the deÅ¿igns of the King of Navarre, by Å¿eeming to comply with him. But then (Å¿he Å¿aid) he and the other great Men of that Kingdom ought to oppoÅ¿e them, and to complain that the Religion of their AnceÅ¿tors was every where violated and deÅ¿piÅ¿ed. She deÅ¿igned by this, FirÅ¿t, To divide the great Men in the Point of Religion. Secondly, To weaken the IntereÅ¿t of the King of Navarre. And thirdly, To preÅ¿erve the RomiÅ¿h Religion in France. But Montmorency, who was her InÅ¿trument, deÅ¿igned only the laÅ¿t, yet he was very active in it. The Queen in the interim carried her diÅ¿Å¿imulation Å¿o far, that Å¿he ordered Jean de Monluc, BiÅ¿hop of Valence, who was a great favourer of the Reformation, and no Enemy to the ProteÅ¿tants Doctrine, to Preach frequently at Court, and She and the King were Å¿ometimes preÅ¿ent at his Sermons. He would Å¿ometimes Å¿peak very freely againÅ¿t the Corruptions that were in the Doctrine and DiÅ¿cipline of the Church, and obliquely tax the Papal Authority. The favour the Queen Å¿hewed to this BiÅ¿hop, made Montmorency Å¿uÅ¿pect that in her Heart Å¿he had a kindneÅ¿s for the ProteÅ¿tant Party, and that underhand Å¿he and Navarre had one and the Å¿ame deÅ¿ign. And thereupon he deÅ¿erted her, and joyned with the GuiÅ¿es, his (till then) Mortal Enemies, the DucheÅ¿s de Valentois procuring the Reconciliation. Magdalen of Savoy, Wife to Montmorency, was alÅ¿o an implacable enemy to the Reformation, and hated Coligni the Admiral, for that and other cauÅ¿es, and therefore Å¿he perpetually Å¿timulated him againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants.

Francis Montmorency, The younger Montmorency's Advice to his Father. Son of the ConÅ¿table, was a perÅ¿on of great Prudence, and he wiÅ¿ely adviÅ¿ed his Father not to loÅ¿e the leaÅ¿t of his friends in Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary a time (for he foreÅ¿aw a TempeÅ¿t would ariÅ¿e in France) of what Religion Å¿oever they were: that it did not become a wiÅ¿e Man to endeavour to gain new friends with the loÅ¿s of his old ones, and to prefer the uncertain friendÅ¿hip of reconciled enemies before the tried affections of his old Acquaintances. That if he rejected Conde, Coligni, and Rochefoucault, on the Account of Religion, he would deprive his Family of the affiÅ¿tance of three great Men, and perhaps the Queen would think never the better of him: therefore his advice to his Father was to Å¿it Å¿till, and let Coligni, and the GuiÅ¿es fight it out, without taking part on either Å¿ide, and in all probability GuiÅ¿e would be worÅ¿ted; and he would become the Arbitrator of the two contending Religions. And in the mean time, it was moÅ¿t certain, there were many great Errors, by length of time crept into the Church, which he ought not to defend, becauÅ¿e they were injurious to the MajeÅ¿ty of God. The good old Gentleman was much moved at this Advice from his Son, but made no other anÅ¿wer to it, than That he certainly knew that if the Religion were changed, the Civil Government would be changed too. That he cared not what became of him, if his little MaÅ¿ters did well, and the Actions of Henry II. might not be called in queÅ¿tion; who was a wife Prince, and his good MaÅ¿ter. So he periÅ¿hed in his firÅ¿t reÅ¿olves, believing he was obliged to defend the CauÅ¿e of Religion againÅ¿t his beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t ancient, and tried friends.

The Pope Å¿eeing his JuriÅ¿diction and Authority decline Å¿o faÅ¿t in Germany,
year 1560 England, and France, The pretended SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion of the Cophthites. greedily embraced a pretended Overture made by one Abraham, a Syrian ImpoÅ¿tor, who pretended he was Å¿ent by the Copthites, an EaÅ¿tern Sect of ChriÅ¿tians, to make a Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Holy See; whereupon he Å¿ent ChriÅ¿topher Roderick, and John BaptiÅ¿ta Elianus, two JeÅ¿uits, to them; who gained nothing by this MiÅ¿Å¿ion, but an exact Account of the Opinions of theÅ¿e Cophthites, and a certainty of the Frauds of this pretended AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador Abraham, who had feign'd this MiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Pope for his own Ends.

This Mortification was Å¿oon after attended by another,
Livonia falls off from the See of Rome. not leÅ¿s afflictive to his HolineÅ¿s, for Gothard Ketler, MaÅ¿ter of the Teutonick Order in Livonia, intirely Å¿ubmitted to SigiÅ¿mond King of Poland, which put an end to that Order; when it had flouriÅ¿hed there 357 years. He was thereupon made Duke of Gurland and Semigallen, and Governor of Livonia, and, Marrying a Wife, withdrew himÅ¿elf and his Subjects from the See of Rome. The ArchbiÅ¿hoprick of Riga was alÅ¿o about the Å¿ame time changed into a Dukedom, John Kothewick, â â the laÅ¿t ArchbiÅ¿hop of that See, embracing the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, put himÅ¿elf under the Protection of the Crown of Poland, and was by SigiÅ¿mond made Duke of Lithuania. This ArchbiÅ¿hoprick was founded in the year 1215, by the procurement of the Knights of the Teutonick Order, the City being then and a long time after, the Seat of the MaÅ¿ter of it, who divided the Sovereignty and AdminiÅ¿tration of JuÅ¿tice with the ArchbiÅ¿hop. After this Å¿hort DigreÅ¿Å¿ion, which the Reader is deÅ¿ired to Pardon, I Å¿hall now return to the proÅ¿ecution of the French Affairs.

The new FriendÅ¿hip between Montmorency and the GuiÅ¿es was a very frightful thing to the Queen Regent, The Queen Å¿uÅ¿pects the deÅ¿igns of the Nobility. who Å¿ought all the way Å¿he could poÅ¿Å¿ible to divide their Affections, for the preÅ¿erving her own Authority, and therefore Å¿he was very AnxiouÅ¿ly inquiÅ¿itive to find, whether this new KindneÅ¿s between two Å¿uch Ancient Enemies tended. The Prince of Conde in the mean time was declared Innocent by the Parliament of Paris the Thirteenth of June, and his DiÅ¿charge Recorded. The Differences in Religion not only diÅ¿quieted the Court, The Differences of Religion occaÅ¿ion Tumults. but the Provinces alÅ¿o, the two Parties reproaching each other with the Names of PapiÅ¿t and Huguenot. An Edict to reÅ¿train them. The Cardinal of Lorrain was Alarm'd at this, and repreÅ¿ented to the King and Queen: That the whole Kingdom was fill'd with Conventicles; That the meaner Å¿ort ran to the Sermons out of curioÅ¿ity, and were eaÅ¿ily corrupted; That the Ancient Ceremonies were little frequented or regarded, and that they were already derided and Å¿corn'd by many; That great numbers every day forÅ¿ook the Church, and went over to the ProteÅ¿tants. The Edict of July. So he would needs have had a new Edict forthwith publiÅ¿hed, to prevent theÅ¿e Inconveniences. That therefore moÅ¿t were of opinion, that notwithÅ¿tanding theÅ¿e differences, they ought to be received into the Communion of the Church, which would end in the Peace of the Church; That the uÅ¿e of Images, which was forbidden by God, and, as to Adoration, diÅ¿proved by St. Gregory, ought to be taken away; That the late invented FeaÅ¿t of the Holy Sacrament might be aboliÅ¿hed, it being unneceÅ¿Å¿ary, and the cauÅ¿e of great Scandal and Offence; and that this MyÅ¿tery was InÅ¿tituted for a Spiritual WorÅ¿hip, and not for Shew and Pomp; year 1562

The Å¿ame Month, but Å¿ome few days before it, The King of Navar pretends Å¿till to promote the Reformation. the King of Navar wrote a Letter to the Elector Palatine, in which, he teÅ¿tified his great deÅ¿ire to promote a Reformation, and that he hoped to have found a way to reconcile Differences, by the Conference of PoiÅ¿Å¿i. Thus that Conference ended

The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e called to Court by the King of Navar. Though this Tumult happened againÅ¿t his will, and contrary to his expectation, yet the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, to excuÅ¿e himÅ¿elf and his Servants, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e uÅ¿es ill Arts to Å¿ecure his Servants who began the Tumult. And his next care was to excuÅ¿e it to the Duke of Wirtemburg, to whom he Å¿ent a Letter to that purpoÅ¿e, laying the fault on the InÅ¿olence of the Rabble, which truÅ¿ting in their number, had begun to fling Stones at his Servants. Beza, who was there, replied, That if it were Å¿o, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e ought to have complained to the King, and not to have permitted his Servants to have become their own Judges; and turning to the King of Navar, he Å¿aid, He was Å¿ent by the Church to complain of this wrong, which has ever been readier to Å¿uffer, than to act Injuries; and that yet he ought to remember, that Anvil had broke many Hammers; in the mean time, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e went to Paris, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e entereth Paris. without taking any notice of the King, where he was entertain'd with greater Ceremony and ReÅ¿pect, and had a greater Attendance than became a Subject; the Queen began to fear the King of Navar, GuiÅ¿e, and Montmorancy, would, under the Pretence of Religion, Å¿et up a Triumvirate, which would bring her and the King under their Power; Å¿o that Å¿he had no other remedy, but to put her Å¿elf and her Son under the Protection of the Prince of Conde, and by her Letter, to deÅ¿ire him to Å¿tand by them. The Queen upon this, puts her Å¿elf and the King into the Protection of the Prince of Conde. But then Å¿he did this very privately, and by her EmiÅ¿Å¿aries, that Å¿he might not alienate the hearts of the People, and of a great part of the Nobility, from her, by Å¿eeming to promote the new Religion, and by the Envy of that, be excluded from having any Å¿hare in the Government. In the mean time, that Å¿he might conÅ¿ult her own Å¿afety, Å¿he went with the King of Navar to Melun, whither M. de Marle, and Claude Martel, one of the Ae â¢ ili â¢ . Officers of Paris, who was in great eÅ¿teem amongÅ¿t the People, came to her, and repreÅ¿ented the great Danger Paris was expoÅ¿ed to by the Forces of the Prince of Conde, and Å¿aid, it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary She and the King Å¿hould come thither forthwith, and he having many armed Men about him, he deÅ¿ired the Citizens might have their Arms reÅ¿tored to them, which had been taken away by Montmorancy: which laÅ¿t, Å¿he rather delayed, than denied, becauÅ¿e Å¿he Å¿aw they would have them whether Å¿he would, or no. From thence Å¿he went to Fontain-bleau, to gain time to conÅ¿ider what was to be done, and was in Å¿uÅ¿pence whether Å¿he Å¿hould go for Orleans, whither Conde was going, or truÅ¿t to the Regal Authority, and go to Paris. Navar went in the mean time from M â¢ an to Paris,
and Lodged with Montmorancy, where, there was a Council held every day, without the Prince of Conde: And the Government of the City was taken from young Montmorancy, by the Advice of his Father, and given to the Cardinal of Bourbon.

Every thing now tended to an open rupture, All things in France tend to a Civil War. and rumours were Å¿pread abroad, that the Catholicks, in all Parts of the Nation, were ill uÅ¿ed by the ProteÅ¿tants, which Reports were (true, or falÅ¿e) Å¿et on foot by the Cardinal of Lorrain. The Populace was exaÅ¿perated, and having regain'd their Arms, were the more enraged for the having had them taken away; and therefore could no longer be kept in order. The Prince of Conde Å¿eeing his Danger, that he might not Å¿eem to expoÅ¿e his own Party to the Å¿ury of their Enemies ãâã propoÅ¿ed to the Cardinal, that he would leave the City, if GuiÅ¿e and the oth â¢â¢
â¢ onfederates would do Å¿o too at the Å¿ame time, that it might not be endanger ãâã an inteÅ¿tine Sedition; which was accepted, and the Duke of GuiÅ¿e went to
â¢â¢â¢ tainbleau, with a great Retinue, to the King and Queen, and the Prince of Conde, went to Meaux, and la Ferte Aucoulph upon the Marne. As Å¿oon as they were thus gone, M. de Marle took into the City MD men for its Security, which Montmorancy the younger had refuÅ¿ed to do whileÅ¿t the City was under his Care: The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, when he went to Fontain-bleau, carried with him many Armed men, that he might fright the Queen from her Cabals with the Prince of Conde, and Å¿o draw her, by a Å¿ecret Fear, to joyn with him; The Queen out of Fear joyns with the Catholick Lords commonly call'd the Triumvirate. and the Stratagem took. She had before carefully enquired into the Numbers and Riches of the ProteÅ¿tants, that Å¿he might know, what Å¿he and the King might expect from them, but Å¿he could not be aÅ¿Å¿ured of any thing, only that there were 2150 AÅ¿Å¿emblies in the Nation, the Delegates of which proffered her and the King their Services in caÅ¿e of NeceÅ¿Å¿ity; but when Å¿he deÅ¿ired a more particular and exact account, they Å¿uÅ¿pected, Å¿he had Å¿ome ill deÅ¿ign againÅ¿t them, and declined giving her an exact account of their Secrets, reflecting on her inconÅ¿tancy which they much Å¿uÅ¿pected.

In the mean time,
Conde comes up towards Fontain-bleau.
Conde was coming to Court as the Queen had ordered him, and was at Pont Sainct Clou, within two Miles of Fontain-bleau; which when the Queen heard, all things were put into ConfuÅ¿ion, as if a Siege had been expected, the Populace running into diÅ¿order, and the MagiÅ¿trates conniving at it. The Queen would gladly have Å¿tood Neuter, but the Confederates told her plainly, they knew Conde was come to get the King into his Power, The Tyiumvirate Å¿eize the King. and they were reÅ¿olved to carry him to Paris, and if Å¿he pleaÅ¿ed, Å¿he might follow him; and Å¿o they carried him to Melun, not giving her any time to conÅ¿ider of it. The next day after,
Montmerancy appears very zealous againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants at Paris. the King and the Queen were brought up to the Louvre, the Confederates pretending they were not Å¿afe elÅ¿ewhere. The Prince of Conde was coming towards the Court, but hearing that the Queen out of levity or fear was joyned with the Triumvirate, and was gone to Paris, The Prince of Conde betrayed by the Queen into a diÅ¿advantageous War. he Å¿eeing the Enemy in poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the King's PerÅ¿on, concluded they had got a great Advantage over him, and yet that the Die being caÅ¿t, it was too late to go back, Å¿o he went to Orleans to meet d' Andelott, and Å¿ent to Coligni the Admiral to come thither to him. The Seventh of April the Prince of Conde Å¿ent a Letter to all the ProteÅ¿tant Churches and Nobility in France,

The next day he put out a ManifeÅ¿to, wherein he largely unfolded the Truth, that the bottom of their DeÅ¿ign was, to deprive the ProteÅ¿tants of France of that Liberty which had been granted them by the King's Edict, The Catholicks begin the War to deprive the ProteÅ¿tants of the Liberty granted them by the Edict of January. which he proved amongÅ¿t other things by the MaÅ¿Å¿acre of VaÅ¿Å¿y, which he Å¿aid was deÅ¿ign'd for a Signal to the whole Nation to do the like. The Prince of Conde and the MiniÅ¿ters write to the Princes of Germany. The Å¿ame Seventh day of April, The King and Queen affirm they were at Liberty in their Declaration. the King and Queen put out a Declaration at Paris, wherein they affirmed, that the report of their Captivity was falÅ¿e, and Å¿candalouÅ¿ly feigned by the Prince of Conde, for a colour to his Seditious PractiÅ¿es: And that they came willingly, and not by force, to Paris, that they might conÅ¿ult of the means of Å¿ettling this Commotion. The Prince of Conde underÅ¿tanding by a Letter he received from the Elector Palatin, The Princes of Germany much divided about the true cauÅ¿e of this French War. The 15th of April,

A Tumult ariÅ¿ing the next Night, Å¿ome of the Catholicks were Å¿lain, and others put into PriÅ¿on. So from the Third of May till the City was re-taken, the ExerciÅ¿e of the RomiÅ¿h Religion was totally omitted. And after that Pont del' Arche and Caudebec. Soon after they took Pont de l' Arche, which, being taken by the Roman Catholicks, the ProteÅ¿tants took Caudebec beneath Roan, and when they might have demoliÅ¿hed it, they endeavoured to keep it, but it was Å¿oon after re-taken by the Roman Catholicks, and Å¿o the City was reÅ¿train'd on both Å¿ides. Upon this, 300 HorÅ¿e and 1500 Foot were Å¿ent againÅ¿t them, which for Å¿ome time had the better of the Citizens. Diepe. Caen and Bayeux.
Caen, Bayeux were alÅ¿o taken and Reform'd by the ProteÅ¿tants.

Mans was taken by the ProteÅ¿tants the Third of April without ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance,
Mans taken by them. and in the mean time Forces were raiÅ¿ed by both Parties, the Queen in her Heart being pleaÅ¿ed to Å¿ee the Prince of Conde EÅ¿pouÅ¿e her CauÅ¿e, and deÅ¿iring to abate the Pride of the GuiÅ¿es, and therefore Å¿he was earneÅ¿t to have a Treaty, hoping by this means to have both the Parties at her Devotion. The Prince of Conde, the firÅ¿t of May, had Å¿ent her a Letter with Å¿ome Terms for an Accommodation, which were, That the Edict of January, which had been violated by the ConÅ¿pirators, Å¿hould be obÅ¿erved. 2. The Injuries committed upon the ProteÅ¿tants, Å¿everely puniÅ¿hed by the MagiÅ¿trates. 3. GuiÅ¿e and his Brothers, and Montmorancy, &c. who had raiÅ¿ed this War, Å¿hould leave the Court, and return to their Å¿everal Governments, till the King was of Age to undertake the Government, and determine himÅ¿elf this ControverÅ¿y. And then he would lay down his Arms, and retire to his home. The Fourth of May it was AnÅ¿wered, That the King would obÅ¿erve
the Edict of January every where but at Paris. That all Slaughters, Spoilings and Injuries committed, Å¿hould be inquired into and puniÅ¿hed, but he would not Å¿end GuiÅ¿e, Montmorancy, and St. Andre from the Court, becauÅ¿e he was Å¿atisfied as to their Loyalty, needed their CounÅ¿el, and ought not to Å¿et any Mark of DiÅ¿honour on them. But then they were willing for the Å¿ake of the Publick Peace to retire, if thoÅ¿e that were in Arms in Orleans and all over the Nation would firÅ¿t go home, reÅ¿tore the Places taken by them to their former Liberty, and yield that Obedience to the King they ought, and that the King of Navar Å¿hould Å¿till retain the Command of the Army. The Prince of Conde perceiving by this AnÅ¿wer that the Triumvirate were reÅ¿olved not to leave the Court, and that they only pretended the Danger of laying down their Arms before him, without taking any Notice of the HoÅ¿tages he had offered fot their Security in that caÅ¿e, Å¿uÅ¿pected there was fraud in the bottom, and would not comply neither, alledging, That the King's PreÅ¿ence was their Å¿ecurity, whereas he had nothing but the Equity of his CauÅ¿e to Plead.

After this the Triumvirate put in a Petition to the King, The Triumvirate deÅ¿ire no liberty Å¿hould be granted to the ProteÅ¿tants. DeÅ¿iring that an Edict might be made, 1. That no Religion but the Roman Catholick Å¿hould be Admitted in the Kingdom. 2. That all the King's DomeÅ¿ticks, Captains, Governours and MagiÅ¿trates Å¿hould be of that Religion, and whoever did not publickly profeÅ¿s it, Å¿hould be deprived of all Honour and Publick Employments, Å¿aving to them their EÅ¿tates. 3. That all BiÅ¿hops and Clergymen Å¿hould profeÅ¿s the Å¿ame, or be deprived of their Revenues, which Å¿hould be brought into the Exchequer. 4. That all the Churches which were deÅ¿troyed, Å¿poil'd, or defaced, Å¿hould be reÅ¿tored, and thoÅ¿e that were guilty of theÅ¿e Sacriledges puniÅ¿hed. 5. That all Å¿hould lay down their Arms, upon what pretence Å¿oever they had been LiÅ¿ted, or by whom Å¿oever. And they that had no CommiÅ¿Å¿ion from the King, Å¿hould be treated as Traitors. The 26th and 27th of May the King of Navar commanded all the ProteÅ¿tants to depart from Paris, The Triumvirate draw out of Paris. ordering that no injury Å¿hould be done to them or their Goods in their retreat or abÅ¿ence on pain of Death: And perceiving that nothing could be effected by Treaties, the Triumvirate drew their Forces out of Paris, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting in Four thouÅ¿and Foot and Three thouÅ¿and Armed HorÅ¿e, about which time the Queen invited the Prince of Conde to a Conference, and they met in the beginning of June at Thoury a Village in la BeauÅ¿Å¿e, with all the Cautions uÅ¿ual in Å¿uch CaÅ¿es. But that Treaty proving ineffectual, the Prince of Conde drew his Army out too, which was then Four thouÅ¿and Foot and Two thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e. The Prince of Conde had more of the Nobility of France in his Army than the other fide, either out of Love to the Religion, or hatred to the GuiÅ¿es, or by the Å¿ecret Orders of the Queen. The Prince of Conde maintain great Order in his Army at firÅ¿t. BeÅ¿ides his Army had a Å¿evere DiÅ¿cipline, and Publick Prayers were Å¿aid Morning and Evening at the head of each Company: There were no Oaths, no Quarrels heard of, but the PÅ¿alms were devoutly Sung in the Camp, there was no Dice, no Tables, no Rapines, all was ModeÅ¿ty, and the leaÅ¿t Faults were Å¿everely puniÅ¿hed, Å¿o that the Country Man or Merchant might live or travel by the Army in perfect Å¿ecurity; and their great deÅ¿ire was, that they might be led againÅ¿t Paris. The 21th of May the Army marched from Orleans, and there was another Treaty for a Peace, and another Conference with the Queen, A Å¿econd Treaty between the Queen and Conde. who thanked him and all the Great Men that came with him for the good Service they had done her and the King, in a time of Å¿uch great need; Å¿aying they were worthy of the higheÅ¿t Rewards and Honours, and praying them to perÅ¿evere in it, and to ConÅ¿ult the good of the Kingdom. She excuÅ¿ed what Å¿he had done in the mean time for the other Party, by Å¿aying, They were more in number who embraced the Roman Catholick Religion, and therefore it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary there Å¿hould be no other Religion Å¿uffered in France than that. At this Conde replied he could not Å¿ubmit to Å¿o hard a Condition. For if the Peace of Religion were taken away, a War would follow, which would be very difficult and laÅ¿ting. This proving ineffectual too, the Prince of Conde marched to La Ferte Alez,
Boigency Å¿ack'd. Blois. and took and Å¿ack'd Boigency, a Town upon the Loire. The Triumvirats Army marched right to Blois which the ProteÅ¿tants had taken not long before, and GariÅ¿on'd, but the Place being
weak, they retreated to Orleans, and left it to the Catholicks, who ExerciÅ¿ed unheard of Cruelties, and put moÅ¿t of the ProteÅ¿tants to the Sword, or drown'd them in the River, though they recovered the Town without one blow Å¿triking. From thence they marched to Tours, Tours. which had but a little before been Å¿urprized and reformed by the ProteÅ¿tants, contrary to the will of the WiÅ¿er People, who forclaw the ill conÅ¿equence of it. The Country in the mean time was expoÅ¿ed to Rapine, under pretence of Extirpating Hereticks, the great Men conniving at it, or being well pleaÅ¿ed: And a War was Proclaimed againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, and all Men were commanded to treat them as the Enemies of Mankind, on the account of the Sacriledges committed in the Churches, becauÅ¿e the Church Plate was taken to be Minted for Money to pay the Army, and the Images and Altars were generally beaten down where the ProteÅ¿tants prevail'd. The ProteÅ¿tants took Angers the 5th of April,

Tours retaken by the Roman Catholicks. The 13th of May, Amiens. the ProteÅ¿tants were forbidden their Meetings at Amiens, their Books Å¿ought out and burnt, and, amongÅ¿t them, all the Bibles they found in French, and the Pulpit with them, and Å¿ome few of them were flain in the Tumult. At Abbeville, there was a greater Tumult raiÅ¿ed by the Roman Catholicks, and many of the Soldiers in the CaÅ¿tle, and of the Inhabitants of the Town, were murdered, upon a pretence they favoured the Prince of Conde's IntereÅ¿t, and the Governour of the Town was aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inated in his HouÅ¿e, and his naked Body was dragged about the Town; and another Gentleman moÅ¿t barbarouÅ¿ly murdered. At Senlis, Senlis. many of the ProteÅ¿tants were aÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inated, and Å¿ome were put to death by the Decree of the Parliament of Paris on other pretences. I have tranÅ¿cribed only a very few of the horrid and inÅ¿ufferable Villanies, committed by the Roman Catholicks of France, in this War, from Thuanus: For Å¿o madly did they dote upon their Images and Altars, that when ever they got any of the ProteÅ¿tants into their hands, they treated them with unheard-of Cruelty and Rage; whereas, all their Fury Å¿pent it Å¿elf on the Statues, Pictures, Altars, and Relicks, of their Churches, or in Å¿ome places on their Tombs; and if Å¿ome few Slaughters happened, in was in the Surprize, or taking of Places, before they were maÅ¿ters of them; but the Roman Catholicks raged moÅ¿t, where the ProteÅ¿tants were leaÅ¿t able to reÅ¿iÅ¿t them.

The Prince of CondÃ© hearing, that his Party was worÅ¿ted in Normandy, Å¿ent Lewis de Lanoy with three hundred HorÅ¿e, who, with Å¿ome difficulty, arrived at Roan the 11th of June, and rectified the DiÅ¿orders he found in that place; Normandy. the ProteÅ¿tants would have expell'd the Roman Catholicks out of the City, but he perÅ¿uaded them only to diÅ¿arm them, and Å¿wear them to live peaceably. Roan, in a Å¿hort time after this, was beÅ¿ieged, from the 29th of June, to the 11th of July, by the Roman Catholicks, but then they were forced to withdraw, and the City remained in the ProteÅ¿tants hands. In the interim, a Treaty was carried on by the Vidame de Chartres, with Queen Elizabeth, for Succours, which diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed many, tho' the Roman Catholicks, in the mean time, had called in German and Swifs Auxiliary Forces, to Å¿upport their Quarrel. The Roman Catholick Army, The Roman Catholicks retake Poictiers and Bourges. in the mean time, took Poictiers, after a Å¿harp Siege, which yet might have holden out longer, where they plundered the ProteÅ¿tants, and put many of them to the Sword: And after that, Bourges, being beÅ¿ieged by the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, was, at laÅ¿t, Å¿urrendered by the Cowardize or Treachery of Mr. de Yvoy, the chief Commander, when the Roman Catholicks had almoÅ¿t Å¿pent all their Ammunition, and the Admiral had taken that which was Å¿ent to Å¿upply them from Paris. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and his Party, after they had taken Bourges, The Siege of Roan reÅ¿olved on. were divided in their Opinion, Å¿ome adviÅ¿ing, the Army Å¿hould march to the Siege of Orleans, as the Capital of the adverÅ¿e Party; and others, that they ought firÅ¿t to take in Roan, as more eaÅ¿y to be reduced, and of no leÅ¿s advantage, becauÅ¿e preventing the EngliÅ¿h from powering great numbers of Men into France: So at laÅ¿t this Party prevailed, and that Siege was undertaken.

Montgomery, who by misfortune Å¿lew Henry the Second, was, by the Prince of CondÃ©, appointed to command here in Chief, who entered the place the 18th of September, with 300 HorÅ¿e; and having added Å¿ome new Works to St. Catherins, he built a new Fort at St. Michaels, which he called by his own Name. The Terms of the ProteÅ¿tants League with England. About the Å¿ame time, a League was concluded between the EngliÅ¿h and the ProteÅ¿tants, at Hampton-Court; by which, the Queen was to Å¿end 6000 men into France, 3000 of which, were to keep Haure de Grace in the King's Name, for a place of Safety for thoÅ¿e of the Religion, and the reÅ¿t were to be employed in the Defence of Diep and Roan, and Å¿he was to Å¿upply 140000 Crowns for the Charge of the War; the Forces were immediately Å¿ent from PortÅ¿mouth, and landed at Haure de Grace, under the Command of the Earl of Warwick. The 13th of October, the BeÅ¿iegers Å¿tormed the City, from 10 'till 6 at Night, the EngliÅ¿h and Scotch Å¿uÅ¿taining the brunt, and at laÅ¿t repelling them, the next day they Å¿tormed it 6 hours more, to the loÅ¿s of 600 men. The 15th of October, The King of Navar Å¿hot at the Siege of Roan. the King of Navar was Å¿hot in the left Shoulder with a Musket Bullet in the Trenches. There were Å¿lain in this Siege, about 4000 Men on both Å¿ides. The 17th of November, He dyes. the King of Navar died of his Wounds, having received the Sacrament according to the CuÅ¿tom of the Church of Rome; but blaming his own wavering and unconÅ¿tant temper in the matters of Religion, and Å¿aying, If he recovered, he would embrace the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and live and dye in it. The Queen had entered a Treaty with the Inhabitants of Diep, for the recovery of that place, before Roan was taken, and they were amazed with the Dangers that City was in,

The Å¿ame Conditions were granted to them of Caen. The next Care, was, to clear Haure de Grace of the EngliÅ¿h, whither the Earl of Warwick came, two days after the Å¿urrender of Roan.
Diep retaken by the ProteÅ¿tants. The 20th of December, the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿urprized Diep again, without any conÅ¿iderable oppoÅ¿ition, the Inhabitants no way conÅ¿enting to it, and excuÅ¿ing it to the Queen, as done without their aid, knowledge, or conÅ¿ent, and thereupon great numbers of them went into the Low-Countries, fearing they Å¿hould be treated with the Å¿ame Cruelty, as they of Roan had been, when that City was taken, for which, they were ill uÅ¿ed by Montgomery, who was the procurer of this Surprize.

The News of the loÅ¿s of Roan, The ProteÅ¿tants beaten in Guienne. was brought to the Prince of CondÃ©, when he was in great pain for Andelett, Å¿ent by him into Germany, to bring him Å¿ome ProteÅ¿tant Forces: This ill News came attended with the defeat of MonÅ¿ieur de Burie, in which, 2000 were Å¿lain in the Field, and many more loÅ¿t in the Retreat the 9th of October.
