The Sieur d'Andelott,
Andelot hardly obtains Succours in Germany. who was Å¿ent into Germany to obtain Succours, met with great Difficulties, the Court of France having Å¿ent one Envoy after another to break his MeaÅ¿ures, and render the ProteÅ¿tant Princes averÅ¿e to War: And when the Emperour had called a Diet to meet in November, for the chooÅ¿ing Maximilian, his Son, King of the Romans, the Prince of CondÃ© Å¿ent one Jaques Spifame, heretofore BiÅ¿hop of Nevers, an eloquent and brisk Man, who gave in the ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith, publiÅ¿hed by the French ProteÅ¿tants in the AÅ¿Å¿embly of the States, for the vindicating them from the aÅ¿perÅ¿ions of thoÅ¿e monÅ¿trous Opinions, which their Enemies had raiÅ¿ed from them. And very welcom they were, the taking of Roan, and the defeat of Ver, having reduced their Reputation, Forces, The Prince of Conde takes the Field. and Hopes, to a very low ebb: The Prince of CondÃ© hereupon marching out of Orleans the firÅ¿t of November, with the whole Army, and a Train of Artillery, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of 8 Pieces, the 11th of November, he took Pluviers, in the ForreÅ¿t of Orleans,
Pluviers taken by the Prince of Conde. a populous Town, by Surrender; and becauÅ¿e they had preÅ¿umed to defend it with 4 Foot Companies; he hanged two of the Captains, and all the PrieÅ¿ts he found in it, and diÅ¿arm'd the Common Soldiers, and made them take an Oath, that they Å¿hould not hereafter bear Arms againÅ¿t him. In this place, he found great quantities of ProviÅ¿ions, part of which, he Å¿ent to Orleans, and reÅ¿erved the reÅ¿t for the uÅ¿e of his Army. The Terror of this prevailed Å¿o far upon the GariÅ¿on of Baugy, that they durÅ¿t not Å¿tay for a Summons, but retired to ChaÅ¿teaudun. Here the Prince of CondÃ© entered into a ConÅ¿ultation, whether they Å¿hould march away for Paris, and take and rifle the Suburbs of that great City: But the King, Queen, and a numerous Army, being there, they concluded the City could not be taken; and conÅ¿equently, that this Ravage would turn to their damage and diÅ¿grace, and make a Peace difficult, if not impoÅ¿Å¿ible, when Å¿o many innocent People had been ruin'd and undone. Having therefore taken La Ferte Aucoulph upon the Marre, Dourdan, and Mont-Leheri, he Å¿ate down before Corbeil,
Corbeil beÅ¿ieged by the Prince of Conde. which was under the Government of MonÅ¿ieur Pavan, with the Regiment of Picardy, and Å¿ome Companies of that of Champagne; The taking of which place, and cutting off the ProviÅ¿ions, would have very much incommoded the City of Paris.

The 17th of November, the Prince of CondÃ© Å¿ummoned the place, and being denied it, a Å¿mall SkirmiÅ¿h enÅ¿ued, and the next day S. Andre entered it with Succours from Paris. About the Å¿ame time, the News of the death of the King of Navar was brought into the ProteÅ¿tant Camp; and the Queen's EmiÅ¿Å¿aries began to give out Speeches, that the Prince of Conde Å¿hould Å¿ucceed in his PoÅ¿t: And the Queen her Å¿elf Å¿ent to invite him to a Conference, which was rejected. The 22th, there was another Conference deÅ¿ired, which Å¿erved for a pretence to withdraw the Army from Corbeil, which, by this time, was too well mann'd for the Prince to deal with; whereupon he marched towards Paris, The two Armies come in view of each other. the Catholick Army being then come up, and in Å¿ight, Å¿o that the two Armies pelted each other with their Cannon: Two days after, the Prince came to Juvicy, and the next to SauÅ¿Å¿aye; there the motion for a Conference was again renewed, and the Queen was to come as far as Port Angel for that purpoÅ¿e: But the Prince either not being well, or fearing Å¿ome Treachery, excuÅ¿ed himÅ¿elf, and Å¿ent Coligni to treat with Montmorancy, his Uncle. Montmorancy, on the other Å¿ide, to diÅ¿Å¿ipate the Prince's JealouÅ¿ie, croÅ¿Å¿ed the Seyne, and came to him. From thence, the Prince marched on towards Paris, and, three days after, Coligni, who led the Vangard, attack'd the Suburbs of St. Victor, which cauÅ¿ed a grievous ConÅ¿ternation in Paris; Å¿o that if there had been then no GariÅ¿on in the City, the Inhabitants would have opened their Gates, and fled for their Lives; and Jacques Gillis, PreÅ¿ident of the Parliament at Paris, a violent PerÅ¿ecutor of the ProteÅ¿tants, died, for fear they were come to take Revenge on him for the Blood he had Å¿hed, and he was Å¿ucceeded by ChriÅ¿topher de Thou, a perÅ¿on of great moderation and integrity, and a lover of his Country, but addicted to none of the Factions that embroiled France; who was promoted by the Queen. The Prince's Army conÅ¿iÅ¿ted then in 8000 Foot, 5000 HorÅ¿e, and 7 Cannons. The 2d of December, the Queen, attended by the Cardinal of Bourbon, the Prince of Roche Å¿ur Yon, Montmorancy and his Son, and the Seigneur de Gonnor, met the Prince, Coligni, Genly, Gramont, and EÅ¿ternay, at a Conference. A Treaty with the Queen, and the Terms propoÅ¿ed by the Prince of Conde. The Prince demanded, that the ProteÅ¿tants might freely meet, wherever they deÅ¿ired it, and not elÅ¿ewhere. That then the EngliÅ¿h, and other Strangers, Å¿hould depart the Nation, and the Cities Å¿hould be reÅ¿tored into their former State. That no perÅ¿on Å¿hould be called to account for any thing done during the War. That there Å¿hould be a free General Council held (if it might be had) within Å¿ix Months; and if not, then a National Council of France. The Queen, as to the firÅ¿t, excepted Paris, Lyons, the Cities on the Fronteers, all thoÅ¿e that had Parliaments, and all that had no Meetings Å¿ince the Edict of January; the Churches to be reÅ¿tored, and no ExerciÅ¿es in them, but what was according to the ancient form, and Conde deÅ¿ired, they might meet in the Suburbs of the Fronteer Cities. The Conference was continued four days, and then ended without any Agreement, the ProteÅ¿tants, by that time, being reÅ¿olved to try the Fortune of a Battel.

The 10th of December, the Prince withdrew the Army from Paris, The Prince marcheth towards Normandy, to meet the EngliÅ¿h Succours. and retreated to PaloyÅ¿eau; the next day, he marched to Limoux; and the third, to Valenza, a place of PleaÅ¿ure; the fourth, to St. Arnoul, the Inhabitants of which, out of fear, Å¿hut their Gates, whereupon it was taken and plundered, and the PrieÅ¿t Å¿everely treated, and here the Army Å¿tayed two days. The King's Army (for Å¿o now it was called) marched to EÅ¿tamps, and finding it GariÅ¿on'd by the Princes
Forces, they left it, and marched to Chartres, which was a Å¿tronger place, and had a greater GariÅ¿on. The Prince of Conde was enraged, to be thus deluded by a Sham-Treaty, and had Å¿ome Thoughts to have return'd to Paris, which was wiÅ¿ely prevented by Coligni, who adviÅ¿ed him to march towards Normandy, and joyn with the EngliÅ¿h at Havre de Grace, who had a good Body of Foot, which they wanted moÅ¿t of all, and where they expected Money from England; which, tho' it was very difficult, yet the Germans beginning to be mutinous for their Pay, it was reÅ¿olved upon. The 15th of December he marched to Ablium. Ably, and the next day to Gallardon, which, refuÅ¿ing him entrance, was taken, and the Inhabitants ill uÅ¿ed; from hence, he went to Mintenon, where he croÅ¿Å¿ed the Seyne, and went to Aulnay. Here the King's Army overtook them, and paÅ¿s'd the Eure before him unperceived; The King's Army overtake the Prince. there was in it 16000 Foot, and 2000 HorÅ¿e, which lay encamped between the Villages of L'EÅ¿pine and Blainville, and the HorÅ¿e, being fewer than thoÅ¿e with the Prince, was divided into four Squadrons, and placed between the Foot, which were covered by theÅ¿e two Villages on both Å¿ides, and on the right hand with Wagons too; but the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was with a Party of HorÅ¿e on the left Wing. The Battel of Dreux.
Andelot had that day a fit of his Tertian Ague, yet he took his HorÅ¿e, and went to view the King's Army, and finding it very dangerous to attack them in that PoÅ¿t, adviÅ¿ed they Å¿hould turn toward Treon; but Montmorancy ordered the Cannon to play juÅ¿t as they were going to march that way, which cauÅ¿ed Å¿ome diÅ¿order in the firÅ¿t Troops of Conde's Army: Whereupon he fell in upon the SwiÅ¿s, whereas he ought to have charged the oppoÅ¿ite HorÅ¿e, and by this means, beÅ¿ides, he expoÅ¿ed his own Foot naked to the Van-Guard of the Enemy, which paÅ¿Å¿ed by untouched; however, the SwiÅ¿s were broken into, and diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, and the German HorÅ¿e made a great Slaughter of them. Danville, eldeÅ¿t Son to Montmorancy, came thereupon with three Troops to their Relief, in which Action, Gabriel Montmorancy his Brother was Å¿lain; Rochefoucault fell upon the next Squadron of SwiÅ¿s, but was repulÅ¿ed by their Pikes, with loÅ¿s. At the Å¿ame time, Coligni fell upon Montmorancy, who was in the Rere, â Montmorancy taken PriÅ¿oner. and broke it all in pieces. Montmorancy had his HorÅ¿e Å¿lain under him, and as he mounted another, was wounded in the Face, and taken by one R. Sewart; Beauvais was alÅ¿o taken, but died Å¿oon after of his Wounds: And Anglure de Givry, and the Duke de Aumale, were beaten down, and trod to Death by the HorÅ¿e. The Regiment of Bretagne was alÅ¿o diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, Å¿o that there was only one Squadron of SwiÅ¿s entire, which repelled the Germans, and there were Å¿ome French HorÅ¿e which make a Front; but at length they were charged in the Rere by de Mouy, but then he alÅ¿o was charged by Biron, with three Troops in the Flank, and Å¿oon after taken, his HorÅ¿e being Å¿lain.

The Van-Guard, in which the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿tood, was all this while entire; he was in the Army as a private Gentleman, and had no Command, becauÅ¿e he would not fight under Montmorancy: At his Advice, St. Andre fell then upon the Prince of Conde, when all his Forces were weary and diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, and firÅ¿t broke the Prince's Foot, which were very much Å¿laughtered by the Spaniards that followed the GaÅ¿congners and Germans, who firÅ¿t broke in upon them. After this, GuiÅ¿e, Damville, St. Andre, by the advice of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, turn the Fortune of the day, and gains the Victory on the King's Å¿ide. The Prince of Conde taken PriÅ¿oner. St. Andre Å¿lain by Coligm. and St. Andre, all united with the reÅ¿t of the King's HorÅ¿e, fell upon the Prince's HorÅ¿e, which, being diÅ¿ordered by three Field-pieces fired upon them, was Å¿oon broken, Andelot doing all that was poÅ¿Å¿ible to rally the Germans, but it proving impoÅ¿Å¿ible, he rode to Teron, and at laÅ¿t eÅ¿caped. Conde and Coligni got together 200 HorÅ¿e, but could not perÅ¿uade the Germans to return to the Charge, they pretending, their PiÅ¿tols were loÅ¿t: They alÅ¿o diÅ¿ordered and diÅ¿couraged the French HorÅ¿e, Å¿o that the Prince of Conde was forced to flee; he had received a wound in the Hand, and his HorÅ¿e was Å¿hot in the Thigh, and fell; and Danville coming up, as he was remounting, he was taken PriÅ¿oner: Soon after this, Montmorancy was in vain endeavoured to be recovered. In the interim, Coligni rallying 300 Armed HorÅ¿e, and 1000 Germans, charged St. Andre, and the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, with greater Fury than they had Å¿hewed in the firÅ¿t: In this Rencounter, St. Andre was Å¿lain by one Baubigny, whom he had injured, after he was taken and carried off. He was a PerÅ¿on of great Natural Parts, but very lewd and wicked, tho' a Man of Courage; under Henry the Second he had been in good EÅ¿teem, and was now employed on the account of his Abilities. 'till the Divine Vengeance overtook him for his Crimes, and cut him off, by the Hand of one he leaÅ¿t feared of all the World; which may give great Men a good hint, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e force Coligni to Re
â¢â¢â¢â¢ . not to do Injuries, on preÅ¿umption of their Power, but to revere Fortune. The King's Army was again declining, when the Duke of GuiÅ¿e came up with a Party of Foot, and charging Coligni in the Flank, he retreated,
becauÅ¿e not Å¿upported with equal Numbers, but with a Å¿oft pace, and carrying off two Pieces of Cannon. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e followed him a while, but Night coming on, he was forced to give over the PurÅ¿uit. Coligni went to Neufville, and GuiÅ¿e returned to the Camp. The fight laÅ¿ted four hours. It was obÅ¿erved, there was no Forlorn Hope, tho' the Armies faced each other an hour before the Fight began. That both the Generals were taken, and the Victory changed Å¿everal times between them, and was at laÅ¿t doubtful, to whom it belonged.
Coligni would have Å¿ought the next day. Coligni would have perÅ¿uaded the Germans to fight the next day, which had certainly ruined the King's Army, if they would have done it, but they would not. The Duke of Nevers was mortally wounded by a Servant of his own, by accident. There was about 8000 Å¿lain, of which, 3000 were ProteÅ¿tants. 1500 Germans were taken by the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, and Å¿ent home without Arms. Montmorancy was hurried to Orleans, and Conde was kindly treated by the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who was now become General in the King's Army: That Night, they two lay together in one Bed, as well as Å¿upped at one Table, to both their great Commendations. The next day, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e Å¿ent an account of what had happen'd to the Queen to Paris, who, by this time, was Å¿ufficiently afraid of his prevailing Fortune, tho' Å¿he had no great Good-will for the Prince of Conde; but then Å¿he rarely diÅ¿Å¿embled her Thoughts, and ordered publick Thanks to be given to God for the Victory, and Å¿ent the Duke of GuiÅ¿e a CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, to be General of the King's Forces.

The day after the Fight,
Coligni General of the ProteÅ¿tants. Coligni drew up the remainder of the ProteÅ¿tant Army in Battel array, and marching towards the Enemy, that he might obÅ¿cure the Fame of the overthrow, and recollect Å¿uch as had eÅ¿caped: He lodged that Night at Gailard, and the next at Aunea, a CaÅ¿tle in BeauÅ¿e, where he was by common ConÅ¿ent made General, during the abÅ¿ence of the Prince of Conde. From thence, he marched to PuiÅ¿et, and Å¿o to Patey, where he Å¿tayed two days, and then deÅ¿igned to Å¿urpriÅ¿e Å¿ome Forces he heard were Å¿ent to Blois; he followed them as far as Freteval in VendoÅ¿me, and arrived at Baugy, with a deÅ¿ign to repair the Bridge, and diÅ¿perÅ¿e his Forces into Winter Quarters in Sologne and Berry, whither he heard the Duke of GuiÅ¿e intended to Å¿end his, that they might be the nearer to beÅ¿iege Orleans in the beginning of the Year.

Tho' there are Å¿ome Particulars relating to the Year 1562, which I Å¿hall hereafter return to; yet I think it the beÅ¿t way, to carry on the Thread of the French Affairs to the end of the War here, and then return back to the other.

The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, in the beginning of January,
year 1563 thought fit to Å¿olicit Frederick RolÅ¿houÅ¿e, a Subject of the Landtgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, who Å¿aid, He was Å¿ent by his MaÅ¿ter, an old Friend and Allie of the Crown of France, to deliver the King from the ReÅ¿traint he was put under by the Enemies of his Government, and to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the faithful Defenders of the French IntereÅ¿t: Thereupon, the 22th of January, the Queen went to BloiÅ¿e, where Å¿he publiÅ¿hed a Declaration in the King's Name and her own, to aÅ¿Å¿ure the Landtgrave, That all thoÅ¿e Reports, which had been Å¿pread abroad of the ReÅ¿traint of her and her Son, were falÅ¿e, and Å¿et on foot by the ProteÅ¿tants only, as a colour of their Sedition, that they might arm and raiÅ¿e Forces in Germany; and therefore Å¿he hoped, that when he, and the reÅ¿t of the German Princes, Å¿hould underÅ¿tand the truth of this, they would not aid or abet the Rebels of France againÅ¿t their lawful Prince, contrary to the Oaths given by their AnceÅ¿tors. This Declaration was Å¿igned, for the greater confirmation, by Alexander, the King's youngeÅ¿t Brother; Henry, Prince of Navar; Charles, Cardinal of Bourbon; Lewis de Bourbon, Duke de MonpenÅ¿ier; and Charles de Bourbon, Prince de Roche-Å¿ur-Yon. Soon after the Fight alÅ¿o at Dreux, there was a General Pardon publiÅ¿hed, to all that Å¿hould return to their Allegiance to the King. The Pope fondly overjoyed with the Victory at Dreux. When the Pope heard of this Victory, he was Å¿trangely joyed at it, conceiving, this one Battel would put an end to the Power of the ProteÅ¿tants in France, he expecting that effect from Force and Violence, which the French hoped for only from a Council. But however, he thought himÅ¿elf now delivered from a great part of his Cares, and made it his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to precipitate the Council, tho' he knew, the Germans would proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t it, whom he did not at all regard; and as for the King of France, he thought, the Joy of the Victory would give him Å¿atisfaction enough. The Council was as much joyed as any body, but eÅ¿pecially the Cardinal of Lorraine, for his Brother's good Fortune in this Battel, to whom all was aÅ¿cribed in a Speech made there the 10th of January.

Coligni entering Berry, led his Army to Ceel, the Å¿econd of January, a place, which the PrieÅ¿ts of that Province had choÅ¿en, to Å¿ecure the Church TreaÅ¿ures in,
which now, to their great damage, they perÅ¿uaded the TownÅ¿men to defend, it being Å¿oon taken, and all that Plate melted down, and the Inhabitants very Å¿everely uÅ¿ed for their ReÅ¿iÅ¿tance, and Å¿everal of them hanged, the PrieÅ¿ts eÅ¿caping in the Tumult. In BeauÅ¿Å¿e, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e took EÅ¿tampes, after which, he beÅ¿ieged Pluviers with 800 HorÅ¿e, who took the Suburbs; the GariÅ¿on of which, Å¿allying out, retired to Orleans, leaving their Carriages behind them. WhilÅ¿t the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was buÅ¿ie in preparing NeceÅ¿Å¿aries for the Siege of this great City, Andelot, who had undertaken the Defence of it, was as intent in fortifying and Å¿toring the City with all things that were neceÅ¿Å¿ary. There were in it 14 Companies of Germans, and 4 of TownÅ¿men, and many of the Nobility, all well Armed.

The Queen, The Prince of Conde carried to Blois. when Å¿he had Å¿tayed a while at Chartres, went with the King to Blois, (as is Å¿aid) carrying with them the Prince of Conde under a Å¿trong Guard; from whence, Å¿he Å¿ent him to the CaÅ¿tle of Onzain, a Å¿trong place in AngoumoiÅ¿e. Coligni was, in the mean time, wholly intent on the appeaÅ¿ing of the Germans, fearing they would mutiny for their Pay, which, he Å¿aid, would be Å¿ent in a Å¿hort time from England; Å¿o that, at laÅ¿t, he obliged them to promiÅ¿e, they would not deÅ¿ert him. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e, having quitted BeauÅ¿Å¿e, was by this time come to Baugy, where there were Å¿ome SkirmiÅ¿hes of no great conÅ¿equence between him and the ProteÅ¿tants. Some mention was made alÅ¿o of a Peace, the PrinceÅ¿s of Conde propoÅ¿ing, That her Husband, and Montmorancy, Å¿hould be Å¿et at liberty to that end, but there was nothing done in it. The Sieur Boucart, a Commander under Coligni, was coming before, Trimoville, a Town upon the Loire, which was under one Potin, commanded it to Å¿urrender; which being refuÅ¿ed, he took it by force, and put the Inhabitants to the Sword; amongÅ¿t whom, were 36 PrieÅ¿ts: From whence, he went to Gien, which was preÅ¿erved out of his hands by three Companies of Spaniards, who were Å¿ent thither for the approaching Siege of Orleans. Coligni, in the mean time, left Gergeau, and went to Orleans, to conÅ¿ult with the other Commanders what was beÅ¿t to be done, and there it was reÅ¿olved, the Germans Å¿hould be Å¿ent into Normandy, to be ready to receive their Pay out of England, which their Commanders readily accepted; Coligni went with them, and Gramont undertook the defence of Orleans, Andelot being Å¿ick. Coligni was all the way plied with MeÅ¿Å¿ages from the Queen, for a Peace, to hinder his Journey: The firÅ¿t of February, he arrived with 4000 HorÅ¿e at Trcon, and took a view of the place, in which the late Battel was fought, from thence he went to Eureux: He took Å¿oon after St. Pere de Melun, a rich MonaÅ¿tery, and finding great Riches in its Church, which had been given by the Sea-men, he took its Wealth, and, which was worÅ¿e reÅ¿ented, deÅ¿troyed thoÅ¿e Images which were moÅ¿t addreÅ¿Å¿ed to in DiÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es. Soon after, eight EngliÅ¿h Ships came to Havre de Grace, in which, were five EngliÅ¿h Companies, eight Cannon, great quantities of Ammunition and Money; whereupon he reÅ¿olved to take the CaÅ¿tle of Caen, before he went back to Orleans, and, the firÅ¿t of March, raiÅ¿ed a Battery of four Cannon againÅ¿t it, and took it in a few days, tho' the Duke of Elboeuf was Commander of it, who muÅ¿t have been taken too, but that Coligni was in haÅ¿t to relieve Orleans.

The Duke of GuiÅ¿e began the Siege of Orleans the 7th of February, The Siege of Orleans. and attack'd the Suburb de Olivet, which Andelot had ordered to be deÅ¿erted; but, by the negligence of the Germans, had like the next day to have proved the loÅ¿s of the City, GuiÅ¿e his Forces getting into it, before the Germans and French could withdraw, and fire the HouÅ¿es; many of them periÅ¿hed in the Crowd, at the paÅ¿Å¿age of the Bridge which led to the City, and was then imbaraÅ¿Å¿ed with the Goods the Germans had heaped up there: But Andelot making a Å¿harp Sally at the Head of a Troop of Gentlemen, opened the way, and kept off the Enemy; it's Å¿aid however, 800 of the BeÅ¿ieged periÅ¿hed in this Tumult; others Å¿ay, not half the number: But yet, however, it was a great loÅ¿s, and much incommoded the City. Two days after, the other Suburbs were taken. The 18th of February, the Duke of GuiÅ¿e wrote to the Queen, That the Siege was very forward, and that, in a few days, he Å¿hould Å¿end her the joyful News it was taken; but the Å¿ame day, towards night, as he was riding with Å¿ome Officers, The Duke of GuiÅ¿e wounded by one Poltrot. he was Å¿hot in the Side by one John Poltrot, near his Armpit. This perÅ¿on was a Gentleman of EngouleÅ¿me, and brought up as Page in the Family of Francis Boucart Baron d' Aubeterre, and having in his Childhood lived in Spain, could imitate that Nation to a wonder, and was commonly called, The Little Spaniard, he had long Å¿ince reÅ¿olved to be the death of this great Man, and had foretold it publickly, and was Å¿o much the leÅ¿s Å¿uÅ¿pected, becauÅ¿e he was thought a cloÅ¿e diÅ¿Å¿embling Fellow. Being Å¿ent by his MaÅ¿ter to learn an Account
of the Battel of Dreux, he found Coligni at the Siege of Ceel, who gave him Money to buy a fleet HorÅ¿e; after which he never returned to his Lord, and this made Coligni Å¿uÅ¿pected, as conÅ¿cious of the DeÅ¿ign. From thence he went to the Duke of GuiÅ¿e his Quarters, and contracted an Acquaintance with his Servants, and this day after a Prayer to God to direct him, lying in wait, Shot him as he was returning home in the Evening. Poltrot fled into the next Wood, and they who purÅ¿ued him could not find him; and when he had rode all night, and quite tired his HorÅ¿e, next morning he came to Pont Olivet by Orleans; which being unknown to him, and therefore thought by him to be very diÅ¿tant from the place he fled from, he laid him down to Å¿leep, and was taken upon Å¿uÅ¿picion by the Searchers, and being known, was brought to the Queen to St. Ilario, and Examined concerning the Fact, and by whoÅ¿e Procurement he did it. He Å¿aid, he had been twice Å¿olicited to it by Coligni, and had at laÅ¿t conÅ¿ented to it upon the perÅ¿waÅ¿ion of Beza and another MiniÅ¿ter, but he Å¿aid, the Prince of Conde, Andelot, and the Sieur de Soubieze knew nothing of it. He adviÅ¿ed the Queen to have a care of her Å¿elf too, becauÅ¿e the ProteÅ¿tants were ill affected to her Å¿ince the Battel of Dreux, and that MonpenÅ¿ier and SanÅ¿ac were alÅ¿o deÅ¿igned to be cut off: An Account of which ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion being Å¿ent to Cologni by a German PriÅ¿oner, the 12th of March he publiÅ¿hed a Paper in his own defence, in which he call'd God and Man to WitneÅ¿s, that he never Å¿aw nor knew Poltrot before the laÅ¿t January, and he had given him Money and employed him as a Spie in the Duke of GuiÅ¿e his Camp, That when he went into Normandy, he had given him 100 Crowns to acquaint Andelot with what paÅ¿Å¿ed there; and that all he had Å¿aid beÅ¿ides were lies and falÅ¿ehoods; That though he was not much concern'd for the death of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e, who was an Enemy to the King, and to the Reformation, and all that Embraced it, yet he ever deteÅ¿ted theÅ¿e ways of Proceeding, and had never by himÅ¿elf or any other asked any Å¿uch thing of Poltrot, though he had before this diÅ¿covered, and could prove Å¿uch deÅ¿igns were entred into againÅ¿t Conde, Andelot, and himÅ¿elf, before the Queen and Montmorancy, to whom he had produced good AÅ¿Å¿urances of it. Beza alÅ¿o in the Å¿ame Paper, Å¿aid, he never Å¿aw Poltrot in all his Life; and Rochefocault Å¿aid the Å¿ame. Coligni Å¿ent the Å¿ame day a Letter to the Queen to intreat her to keep Poltrot, that the truth of his innocence might be made out from him, before he were Executed. The Death and Character of the Duke of GuiÅ¿e. The Duke of GuiÅ¿e in the mean time died the 24th of February, having purged himÅ¿elf of the MaÅ¿Å¿acre of VaÅ¿Å¿ay, and AdviÅ¿ed the Queen to make a Peace as Å¿oon as was poÅ¿Å¿ible. He was a Great Man in the Opinion of his Enemies, a good Soldier, and both fortunate and prudent in his Actions, but falling into a divided Factious State, he was by his Brother Charles, a violent Man, miÅ¿led, though he often deteÅ¿ted his AdviÅ¿es. Though he had no Command in the Battel of Dreux, yet he alone procured the Victory, this made him the Å¿ole General, and being terrible to the ProteÅ¿tants, it haÅ¿tened his Ruine, but then it had ill ConÅ¿equences (though at firÅ¿t it occaÅ¿ioned a Å¿peedy Peace) in after times. The Children of the Duke growing up in the Civil Wars which followed, inherited the popularity of their Father, and under the Pretences of Religion, and the Sloath of the Kings of France, endeavoured firÅ¿t to Revenge their Fathers Death on the ProteÅ¿tants, and at laÅ¿t turned their Arms againÅ¿t the Royal Family, to the great hazard of its Ruine and their own too.

Soon after the Duke of GuiÅ¿e was wounded, the Queen Å¿ent Henry de Cloet, The Queen earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ires a Peace. and the BiÅ¿hop of Limoges, to the PrinceÅ¿s of Conde and Andelot, to treat of a Peace Å¿everal times. And when he was dead, Å¿he yet more earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired it, fearing Conde and Montmorancy, the Heads of the two Parties. Or, as Davila Å¿aith, being deÅ¿irous to drive out the Foreign Forces before they could Å¿ettle themÅ¿elves, and above all, the EngliÅ¿h out of Havre de Grace. BeÅ¿ides Å¿he wanted a General to Head the Kings Forces, Montmorency being then a PriÅ¿oner, and none of the reÅ¿t being equal to the Prince of Conde, Coligni, or Andelot; beÅ¿ides, the Royal Revenues were by the War reduced to Å¿o low an Ebb, that they were forced to borrow of their Neighbours to Å¿upport the War. In the mean time Francis de Briqueville Baron de Columbiers was employed by Coligni to take Bayeux, before which he came the 12th of February, and though at firÅ¿t repulÅ¿ed, yet upon the bringing four Cannon from Caen, he took the City the Fourth of March, the GariÅ¿on helping him to plunder it, and many of the Inhabitants, eÅ¿pecially of the Clergy, were Å¿lain, becauÅ¿e they were thought to have occaÅ¿ion'd the reÅ¿iÅ¿tance which was made. Soon after St. Lo was deÅ¿erted, and fell into the hands of the ProteÅ¿tants, and after it Auranches. Vire had expell'd the ProteÅ¿tants, and pretended to defend it Å¿elf, but was taken by Storm towards Night, which increaÅ¿ed the Calamities of the Inhabitants. Honfleur was taken by De Mouy, the Fourteenth
of March. About this time Coligni having made Montgomery Governor of Normandy, went from Caen with a gallant Army towards LiÅ¿ieux, where he was excluded by the GariÅ¿on, and from thence to Bernay, which preÅ¿uming to do Å¿o too, he took the Town and made a great Å¿laughter of the Inhabitants, deÅ¿troying all their Images and Altars, and handling their PrieÅ¿ts very Å¿everely. The 7th of March the Prince of Conde and Montmorancy were brought to the IÅ¿land Boaria near Orleans under Å¿trong Guards, The Treaty of Peace between the Prince of Conde and Montmorancy. and a Treaty of Peace was opened: And Montmorancy declaring he would never conÅ¿ent to the Edict of January, other Conditions were propoÅ¿ed, to the great diÅ¿Å¿atisfaction of the ProteÅ¿tants. Conde, upon his promiÅ¿e, had leave given him to enter Orleans, where he treated with the ProteÅ¿tant MiniÅ¿ters, but finding them reÅ¿olved to Å¿tand to the Edict of January, the 12th of March he came to an Agreement with the Queen, which was Å¿ubÅ¿cribed by the King the 19th of the Å¿ame Month. The Terms of which were, The Articles agreed on. That, 1. All the Nobility Å¿hould permit what Religion they pleaÅ¿ed, who had Sovereign Authority, in their JuriÅ¿dictions. That all Noblemen Å¿hould have the free ExerciÅ¿e of Religion in their Families, if they did not live in Corporate Towns. That in every Generalite or Prefecture one City Å¿hould be aÅ¿Å¿igned for thoÅ¿e of the Religion. And, that wherever they had at this day a Liberty, they Å¿hould Å¿till enjoy it. All Offences were remitted, and the Royal Moneys Å¿pent in the War; and Conde was acknowledged the Kings faithful and Loyal KinÅ¿man; and the Nobility, Captains, and all others who had aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted him, were pronounced to have done all things for the Kings Service, and with a good Intention.

Coligni was kept in Normandy by the Flattering ProÅ¿perity of his Arms,
Coligni not pleaÅ¿ed with the Peace. and though he was, by many Letters from the Prince of Conde, preÅ¿Å¿ed to haÅ¿ten his Journey to Orleans, yet he did not arrive there before the 23 of March. The next day he could not diÅ¿Å¿emble his diÅ¿content at the Terms of the Treaty of Peace, telling the Prince publickly, That he wondered, how they could be prevailed upon to clap up a Peace upon Å¿uch diÅ¿advantageous Conditions, when the Affairs of the ProteÅ¿tants were in Å¿o flouriÅ¿hing a Å¿tate. That they ought to have remembred, that in the beginning of the War, the Triumvirate had conÅ¿ented, that the Edict of January Å¿hould be reÅ¿tored, and that now two of them (the King of Navar and the Duke of GuiÅ¿e) were Å¿lain, and Montmorancy was their PriÅ¿oner, and conÅ¿equently a Security for the Prince of Conde; Why Å¿hould not they have had the Å¿ame Terms? That the reÅ¿traint of the ProfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the ProteÅ¿tant Religion to one place in a Province, was to give up that by a daÅ¿h of the Pen, which their Sword could never have obtained. That what was granted to the Nobility could not be denied; and they would Å¿oon Å¿ee it was Å¿afer to Å¿erve God in the Suburbs of great Cities, than in their Private Families; and that it was uncertain whether their Children would be at all like them. But however nothing could reÅ¿cind an Agreement made by common conÅ¿ent. Thus ended the firÅ¿t Civil War of France.

I have tranÅ¿cribed this whole Account of the firÅ¿t Civil War of France from the great Thuanus, abridging it as much as was poÅ¿Å¿ible, and purÅ¿uing the Actions only of the great Armies; becauÅ¿e if I had taken in all he relates of the various Actions between the two Parties in the Å¿everal great Cities and Provinces, it would have Å¿well'd infinitely beyond the deÅ¿ign of this Work, or otherwiÅ¿e have been Å¿o dark as not to be eaÅ¿ily intelligible. And if the Reader compare this Å¿hort Account with that given by Davila, he will Å¿oon Å¿ee, how little the Å¿incerity of that HiÅ¿torian is to be relied on, and how Å¿mall the ReaÅ¿on is, for him to treat the Huguenots as Rebels in all the CourÅ¿e of this War.

When the War firÅ¿t began, the ProteÅ¿tants acted purely on the defenÅ¿ive, but after Å¿everal local MaÅ¿Å¿acres, they began to pull down Images and Altars in Revenge, for the blood-Å¿hed of the other Party, and finding, to their coÅ¿t, this did but enrage the Roman Catholicks againÅ¿t them, and made them the more cruel, they fell next upon the PrieÅ¿ts and Monks, as the Authors of their Calamities, this more incenÅ¿ing the Roman Catholicks; And they again uÅ¿ing the moÅ¿t horrid barbarities that were ever practiÅ¿ed by Men, the ProteÅ¿tants roÅ¿e likewiÅ¿e in their Executions on them; Å¿o that if this War had continued a few years, France muÅ¿t have been depopulated. Now though in all this the Roman Catholicks were the firÅ¿t AgreÅ¿Å¿ors, and forced the ProteÅ¿tants to this Å¿everity in their own defence, yet their Writers cunningly omitting the Provocation, or Å¿ofting the Actions of their own Party, Å¿et forth at large the Cruelties of the Hereticks, (as they call them) and many times aggravate them above what is true; but Thuanus, though a Roman Catholick, was too great a Man to be guilty of Å¿o falÅ¿e a repreÅ¿entation, and who ever pleaÅ¿eth to conÅ¿ult him, will find, I have been very favourable to the Roman Catholicks in this AbÅ¿tract, and have not Å¿ought occaÅ¿ions to make them odious without cauÅ¿e.

div.head: A CONTINUATION OF THE HISTORY OF THE Reformation of the Church.
BOOK IV.

argument.head: The CONTENTS.
argument.p: The Cardinal of Ferrara leaves France. The CauÅ¿es of the Delay of the Council. The Pope's Legates Å¿ent to Trent. The Prohibition of Books taken into ConÅ¿ideration. The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors arrive at Trent. The French King's Reflections on the Proceedings of the Council. The French Clergy arrive there. The Pope's Fear of them. Maximilian Son of Ferdinand the Emperor choÅ¿en King of the Romans. The Emperor diÅ¿likes the Proceedings of the Council. The SpaniÅ¿h AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors received in the Council. The Fathers of Trent much DiÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with the Peace made in France. The Queen of Navarr cited to Rome, and many of the BiÅ¿hops by the InquiÅ¿ition. The French King's Declaration againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Proceedings. The Queen Mother of France complains of the Council. The Pope Gains the Cardinal of Lorrain to his Side. That Councils have no Authority over Princes. The AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors of France ProteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Council, and retire to Venice. The Council ended. The CenÅ¿ure of the Council. The State of Religion in Piedmont. A Tumult in Bavaria for the Cup. The RomiÅ¿h ReaÅ¿ons againÅ¿t granting Marriage to the Clergy and the Cup to the Laity. The Siege and Surrender of Havre de Grace. Charles the IX. declared out of his Minority. The Scotch Affairs.

div.p:
HAVING thus diÅ¿patched what concerns the firÅ¿t French War,
year 1562 I now return to the Affairs of the ReÅ¿t of ChriÅ¿tendom in the Year 1562. And here I will firÅ¿t begin with the HiÅ¿tory of the Council of Trent. WhilÅ¿t the recalling this Council was agitated with great heat, The Cardinal of Ferrara leaves France. the Cardinal of Ferrara, the Pope's Legate in France after the Revocation of the Edict of January, Å¿eeing all things there in the Å¿tate he deÅ¿ired, he took his leave of the King and returned into Italy. Before he went, however, he took care to furniÅ¿h the King with Money to carry on the Siege of Orleans, which he took up of the Bankers of Paris. He had raiÅ¿ed a vaÅ¿t Expectation of this Council in the minds of all thoÅ¿e who had yet any KindneÅ¿s left in their Hearts for the See of Rome; and the more, becauÅ¿e they thought the Edict of January which had cauÅ¿ed the War, would then fall of CourÅ¿e, it being made only by way of ProviÅ¿ion till a Council Å¿hould determine otherwiÅ¿e. As the Cardinal was in his Journey Fifty HorÅ¿emen came out of Orleans under the Command of one MonÅ¿ieur Dampier, and Å¿urprized all his Mules, HorÅ¿es, and TreaÅ¿ures, and when he Å¿ent a Trumpeter to demand them again, the Prince of Conde made AnÅ¿wer, That this magnificent and warlike Equipage did not befit PaÅ¿tors and the SucceÅ¿Å¿ors of St. Peter, but rather Commanders and Generals of War who were in Arms for Religion. Yet if he pleaÅ¿ed to recal the 200000. Crowns which he had furniÅ¿hed
the Triumvirate with to carry on the War againÅ¿t him, and the Italian Forces out of France, he would then reÅ¿tore all he had taken to his Eminence.

The Council which was appointed to meet at EaÅ¿ter of the former Year, was delay'd to the beginning of this; The CauÅ¿es of the Delay of the Council. the Pope putting it off, becauÅ¿e he was as much afraid of the SpaniÅ¿h BiÅ¿hops as of the French National Council. He had been neceÅ¿Å¿itated to grant great Contributions to King Philip to be levied upon his Clergy, and he thought the BiÅ¿hops would on that Å¿core come with exaÅ¿perated Minds to the Council; and all his Thoughts were bent on the keeping the Papal Power undiminiÅ¿hed, rather than on Å¿atisfying the juÅ¿t Compaints of the Nations. At laÅ¿t being forced by an unreÅ¿iÅ¿table neceÅ¿Å¿ity he Å¿ent Hercules Gonzaga, The Pope's Legates Å¿ent to Trent. Jerom Seripand, and StaniÅ¿laus HoÅ¿io out of his BoÅ¿om, to be his Legates at Trent. And not long after he added to them James Simoneta, and Mark Sitico BiÅ¿hop of Altemberg in TranÅ¿ylvania, who had orders to open the Council again the Eighteenth of January 1562. That thoÅ¿e things might be therein treated of which the Proponentibus Legatis. Legates Å¿hould propoÅ¿e, and in the Å¿ame Order, for the taking away the Calamities of theÅ¿e Times, the appeaÅ¿ing the ControverÅ¿ies of Religion, the ReÅ¿training deceitful Tongues, the Correcting the AbuÅ¿es of depraved Manners, and the obtaining a True and ChriÅ¿tian Peace, by Å¿uch means as the Holy Council Å¿hould approve of. The French Clergy inÅ¿iÅ¿ted, That mention Å¿hould be made of a Free and General Council to be call'd for the Quieting of their Differences, becauÅ¿e their ProteÅ¿tants would never Å¿ubmit to the Determinations of the former SeÅ¿Å¿ions. On the contrary, the Spaniards profeÅ¿Å¿ed they would only continue the former Council; and therefore they uÅ¿ed a middle way, and decreed, A Council Å¿hould be Celebrated. The SpaniÅ¿h BiÅ¿hops were as much diÅ¿Å¿atisfied becauÅ¿e all the Power of propoÅ¿ing was given to the Legates, and taken from the other BiÅ¿hops, and complained of it to King Philip; who Ordered his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to treat the Pope about it, that the Council might be free. The Pope AnÅ¿wered the AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, That he was not at leiÅ¿ure to diÅ¿pute about Ablative CaÅ¿es PoÅ¿itive, and the Genders of Words, and that he had Å¿omething elÅ¿e to do. And in private he Å¿poke of the Calamities and Dangers of France with the Å¿ame unconcernedneÅ¿s. For when one of the French Cardinals deplored the Danger the See of Rome was in of loÅ¿ing that Kingdom, he replied, What then? if as long as I am BiÅ¿hop of this City I Å¿hall not be forced to abate any thing of the GreatneÅ¿s of my Table, and the Magnificence of my Buildings. And when they inÅ¿iÅ¿ted to have the Manners of Men and the DiÅ¿cipline of the Church throughly Reform'd, he Å¿aid, In that Particular he would Å¿atisfie France to the full, and take Å¿uch Care in it, that they Å¿hould all of them Repent that they had mentioned a Reformation. Adding, That he foreÅ¿aw that the Kingdom would be divided on the account of Religion, but he did not value the loÅ¿s of it a Farthing. All which ExpreÅ¿Å¿ions Å¿aith Thuanus, Are in the Letters of the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador that was then at Rome, out of which I have faithfully TranÅ¿cribed them; and the Letters are now in my Hands. The HiÅ¿tory of this Council is Å¿o well deÅ¿cribed by Petro Soave Polano, a Venetian, which is in EngliÅ¿h, that I need the leÅ¿s inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon it; but I Å¿hall however remark Å¿ome few things from Thuanus and others, for the Enlarging or Confirming the Credit of that HiÅ¿tory, which is much cryed down by the Roman Catholicks; as certainly they have good ReaÅ¿on to be offended with that Author, who with Å¿o much Truth and Impartiality has diÅ¿covered the Artifices of that AÅ¿Å¿embly, for the keeping up the Grandeur of the Court of Rome, and the SuppreÅ¿Å¿ion and Baffling that Reformation, which the moÅ¿t Learned of the Church of Rome then Å¿o much deÅ¿ired and panted after.

The Second SeÅ¿Å¿ion was held the Twenty Å¿ixth of February, The Prohibition of Books taken into conÅ¿ideration. in which a Decree paÅ¿s'd againÅ¿t Reading Books Å¿uÅ¿pected of HereÅ¿ie, and a Å¿afe Conduct and an Invitation was given to all that would come to the Council. Seventeen BiÅ¿hops were by Name appointed to bring in a Catalogue of Å¿uch Books as were intended or thought fit to be Prohibited. Polano obÅ¿erves, that they carried this Å¿o high as to deprive Men of that Knowledge which was neceÅ¿Å¿ary to defend them from the Æ²Å¿urpations of the Court of Rome, by which means its Authority was maintained and made Great. For the Books were Prohibited and Condemned, in which the Authority of Princes and Temporal MagiÅ¿trates is defended from the Æ²Å¿urpations of the Clergy; and of Councils and BiÅ¿hops from the Æ²Å¿urpations of the Court of Rome, in which their HypocriÅ¿ies or Tyrannies are manifeÅ¿ted, by which the People, under pretence of Religion are deceived. In Å¿umm, a better MyÅ¿tery was never found out than to uÅ¿e Religion to make Men inÅ¿enÅ¿ible. However this may help to keep thoÅ¿e in their Church which they now have; it doth certainly by Experience render them very Contemptible to all others, and
unable to defend their Religion; which is eÅ¿pecially true of their Laity.

The Fourth of March the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of the Safe Conduct was diÅ¿patched in a Congregation; A debate whether EpiÅ¿copacy and ReÅ¿idence are of Divine Right. and a Debate was raiÅ¿ed and purÅ¿ued with great Heat by the SpaniÅ¿h BiÅ¿hops, That EpiÅ¿copacy was inÅ¿tituted by God without any Medium; and that ReÅ¿idence and their Pastoral Deligence, in feeding their Flock, was of Divine Right, which they deÅ¿ired might be Confirmed by the Decree of the Council. But becauÅ¿e this tended to the EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hing the Authority of the BiÅ¿hops, and the Abating that of the Pope, his HolineÅ¿s was much concern'd at it, and having conÅ¿ulted the Cardinals about it, they by common conÅ¿ent Delayed, and by ambiguous AnÅ¿wers deluded the Fathers at Trent, and at laÅ¿t totally baffled them in this Point. The Second SeÅ¿Å¿ion was appointed to be the Twelfth of April, which was then prorogued to the Fourth of June, and from thence to the Fifteenth of the Å¿ame Month. In the mean time the King of France Å¿ent Lewis de Sanct Gelais Sieur de LanÅ¿Å¿ac, The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Arrival. Arnold de Ferrier, PreÅ¿iders of Paris, and Guy du Faur Sieur de Pibrac, his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Council, who arrived at Trent the Nineteenth of May. LanÅ¿Å¿ac Å¿oon after wrote a Letter to give an Account of their being come to the French ReÅ¿ident at Rome, in which he Å¿aid he thought they ought in the firÅ¿t Place to take care that an Event contrary to their Expectation might not attend the Council; that the Pope Å¿hould Order his Legates to Å¿hew great patience to thoÅ¿e who Å¿pake, proceed Å¿lowly in all things, attend the Arrival of thoÅ¿e BiÅ¿hops who were coming, and allow a Liberty without condition to all that were to Vote or Speak, and not fall under the old Reproach of having the Holy GhoÅ¿t Å¿ent them from Rome in a Portmanteau; and laÅ¿tly, that they Å¿hould take care that what was Decreed at Trent to the Glory of God, Å¿hould not be malignantly Interpreted and Traduced; or, it may be, Corrupted at Rome by a Company of Idle Men: He deÅ¿ired therefore he would endeavour to obtain theÅ¿e things of the Pope, as he did; but the Pope took this Liberty very ill, and deÅ¿ired, That no Prejudice might be done to his Authority by the French BiÅ¿hops. Adding, That he reÅ¿erved the Reformation of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical DiÅ¿cipline, and of the Court of Rome to himÅ¿elf; and that he might with greater Convenience attend this and the TranÅ¿actions at Trent, he intended to go to Bononia. The pretence of this Journey was the Crowning of the Emperor in that City, who was Å¿aid to be coming thither for that purpoÅ¿e: But the reality was, the Pope was afraid the World Å¿hould think him more Å¿olicitous for the preÅ¿ervation of the Papal Power, than for his PaÅ¿toral Cure. The Demands of the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors in the Council. The Twentieth of May the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors were admitted in a Congregation, where they made an unacceptable Oration, an abÅ¿tract of which is in Polano: Thuanus Å¿aith, The Speech was made the Fourth of June, and that amongÅ¿t other things they deÅ¿ired, That the MiÅ¿Å¿als and Breviaries might be Reformed, and the Lectures which were not taken out of the Holy Scriptures might be cut off; That the Sacrament of the Lords Supper might be allowed in both Kinds according to the deÅ¿ire of many Nations; And alÅ¿o the Liberty of eating FleÅ¿h, and that the Severity of their FaÅ¿ts might be abated; That Marriage Å¿hould be allowed to the Clergy of Å¿ome Countries; That the multitude of Humane ConÅ¿titutions Å¿hould be retrenched, and Prayers in the Vulgar Tongue faithfully TranÅ¿lated, mixed with the Latin Hymns. Before this the AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador of the Duke of Bavaria had alÅ¿o demanded the giving of the Cup in the Lords Supper to the Laity as abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary for the PreÅ¿erving thoÅ¿e who had not yet Å¿eparated themÅ¿elves from the Communion of the Church of Rome, but were much offended with this denial, and for the Recovery of thoÅ¿e who had left it. And accordingly there were about Fifty of the moÅ¿t Learned of the Fathers of the Council who were for granting it, and amongÅ¿t them Gonzaga PreÅ¿ident of the Council, though all his Collegues diÅ¿Å¿ented. But the SpaniÅ¿h BiÅ¿hops oppoÅ¿ed it, and others thought it was fit firÅ¿t to Å¿end Legates into Germany who Å¿hould Å¿ee and report it to the Council whether it were neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and how it might be done. This was debated in a Congregation the Twenty eighth of AuguÅ¿t; but in the Twenty Å¿econd SeÅ¿Å¿ion held the Seventeenth of September it was rejected, and all were Anathematized, That did not allow the Church to have taken away the Cup from the Laity, &c. upon juÅ¿t Grounds. When the Germans Å¿till inÅ¿iÅ¿ted that it might be granted again to Å¿ome People; the Council to free themÅ¿elves from their importunity, turned them over to the Pope, who according to his Prudence was to do what he thought UÅ¿eful and Salutary. Before this the Pope being preÅ¿s'd to Grant the Cup by the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador about a Year Å¿ince, had referred it to the Conclave of Cardinals, and they and he had referred it to the Council; and now the Council Å¿ends it back to the Pope. Oh the Å¿tupid Patience of theÅ¿e Men!

When LanÅ¿Å¿ac gave the King of France an Account of what had been done, he Å¿aid in his AnÅ¿wer, That he liked what had been done as yet at Trent; but could not but obÅ¿erve that they went very Å¿lowly about the Reforming of the EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical DiÅ¿cipline, The French Kings Reflections on the Proceedings of the Council. and the Manners of the Clergy; and in the mean time were in great haÅ¿te to EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the Points of Doctrine; That therefore it was Å¿uÅ¿pected when this was with Levity enough perform'd, there would be an end put to the Council, and no care be taken for the former, that Å¿o this procedure would afford no Benefit to the Church in this diÅ¿tracted State of ChriÅ¿tendom, and eÅ¿pecially to France. That about Thirty Years Å¿ince, when Fire and Sword had Å¿o unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sfully been imployed to Cure the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e, all Men looked upon a General Council as the Sheet-Anchor: That he wiÅ¿hed nothing had been done in the beginning of this Council for the Alienating the Minds of the Churches Enemies, but rather that they had by all means been allured, and invited to it; and if any had been prevail'd upon to come, that they Å¿hould have been treated by the Fathers of the Council with KindneÅ¿s and Humanity as Children. For to what end were all theÅ¿e careful and diligent DiÅ¿quiÅ¿itions and DiÅ¿putations concerning the Doctrine, Å¿eeing there was no debate but between the Catholick and ProteÅ¿tant in theÅ¿e Points? And as to the ProteÅ¿tants their Definitions Å¿ignified nothing, but only gave them OccaÅ¿ion to Å¿ay their Opinions were condemned by the Council without hearing what they had to Å¿ay for them: That therefore it Å¿eemed more adviÅ¿able to have endeavoured to have brought them into the Council; for fear they Å¿hould in time withdraw all thoÅ¿e who adhere to the Church: For it was a vain furmiÅ¿e that the ProteÅ¿tants would ever Å¿ubmit to thoÅ¿e Decrees which were made when they were abÅ¿ent. That therefore he was of Opinion, That the Reforming the Manners of the Church-men, and the DiÅ¿cipline ought to be their firÅ¿t and greateÅ¿t Care, and the other to be for a time Å¿uÅ¿pended; for this would be acceptable to all Men. And laÅ¿tly, LanÅ¿Å¿ac was ordered to get the next SeÅ¿Å¿ion Prorogued to the latter end of October, 1563. that the French Clergy might be preÅ¿ent at it; or at leaÅ¿t that the publiÅ¿hing of the Canons might be deferred till then. When LanÅ¿Å¿ac had repreÅ¿ented all this to the Council, he deÅ¿ired in the King's Name, That Å¿eeing in the former SeÅ¿Å¿ions Å¿ome things had been decreed to the prejudice of the Liberties of the Gallicane Church, it being an ancient Privilege belonging to them to repreÅ¿ent by their Kings, or their AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, what they thought uÅ¿eful or neceÅ¿Å¿ary for them, that this Liberty Å¿hould for the future be preÅ¿erved; and that if any thing were Acted to the contrary of it, it might be recalled. In the mean time, the Thirteenth of November, The Cardinal of Lorrain and the French Clergy arrive at Trent. the Cardinal of Lorrain, and about Forty of the French BiÅ¿hops came to Trent with Å¿ome Divines, who were met without that City by the Pope's Legates, and Å¿ome of the other BiÅ¿hops, and of the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors. In this Journey the Cardinal of Lorrain went to Inspruck to meet the Emperor before he went to the Diet at Francfort where he had Å¿ome Conferences in private with that Prince about the Affairs of Religion.

The Pope and the Cardinals at Rome were alarm'd at this coming of the French Clergy, The Pope allarm'd at it, as if Å¿o many Enemies had invaded him. as if Å¿o many Enemies had invaded them, and all things were in an Hurry to make Preparations againÅ¿t them. There were new Legates, and a new Squadron of Italian BiÅ¿hops, who might out number the French, preÅ¿ently to be Å¿ent to Trent. And the Pope wrote to King Philip to Order the BiÅ¿hops of his Dominions to unite their CounÅ¿els and Votes with the Italian BiÅ¿hops, that neither the ReaÅ¿ons nor the Votes of the Æ²ltramontane BiÅ¿hops might prevail againÅ¿t them. And in his private Audience with L' IÅ¿le the French ReÅ¿ident at Rome, he ridicul'd the Cardinal of Lorrain, by calling him, The other Pope who had Three hundred thouÅ¿and Pounds the Year Revenue, out of Å¿everal EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Benefices, when he (good Man) was content with the Å¿ingle BiÅ¿hoprick of Rome; and it is an eaÅ¿ie thing (Å¿aith he) for the Cardinal with his belly full to praiÅ¿e FaÅ¿ting, and admoniÅ¿h others to be content with one Benefice. The French King had Å¿ent Francis de Bolliers, Sieur de Manes, to diÅ¿Å¿ipate and remove this JealouÅ¿ie of the Pope's, at the approach of the French BiÅ¿hops, and to acquaint his HolineÅ¿s with his Intentions. For that it was commonly Å¿aid, That the Cardinal was Å¿ent to get the TranÅ¿actions in the Conference of PoiÅ¿ey laÅ¿t Year confirm'd by the Synod, That the Cup might be granted to the Laity, That the Clergy might be allowed Matrimony, That the Liturgy might be in the Vulgar Tongue, That the BiÅ¿hops might have but one DioceÅ¿s, and that none Å¿hould be Elected to that Dignity who could not Preach to the People. As to the firÅ¿t Manes excuÅ¿ed the Conference of PoiÅ¿ey, and Å¿aid, It was appointed by the Queen and the Cardinal for the gaining time, and the retarding or keeping
back thoÅ¿e inteÅ¿tine Commotions they foreÅ¿aw, and for the Å¿topping the Mouths of the Sectaries, who complained every where that their ReaÅ¿ons had never been heard; That they deÅ¿igned in the Interim to levy Forces Å¿o that if they could not convince the Sectaries by ReaÅ¿on, they might by force reduce them to their Duty. That nothing was done in that Conference. And as to the other Points the Cardinal and French Clergy had no other InÅ¿tructions than what had been Å¿ent to the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors of France, and that they brought no prejudged Opinions with them to the Council. The Pope was much concern'd upon the Account of a Report that the BiÅ¿hops of France had moved their King to Å¿top the Payment of FirÅ¿t Fruits by the Clergy of France to the See of Rome. And he Å¿aid this was contrary to their Pacts and Agreements with him; which was, That this Affair Å¿hould be tranÅ¿acted with the Pope only in a friendly way. But then after all, nothing Å¿o much Å¿tartled the holy Man as a Report, that a Peace was treating Å¿ecretly with the ProteÅ¿tants, and that they would have Liberty given them to Preach and he foreÅ¿aw, that if France were once quieted, the Council could not be hurried to a ConcluÅ¿ion, but things would be well conÅ¿idered, and perhaps the ProteÅ¿tants muÅ¿t be heard in it, and amongÅ¿t them Queen Elizabeth of England, which he feared beyond ExpreÅ¿Å¿ion. For he thought the Cardinals of Lorrain and Ferrara were Å¿o UÅ¿eful and NeceÅ¿Å¿ary to the King of France, that he could never have Å¿pared them to attend the Council, where there was no need of them if he had not had Å¿ome Å¿uch peÅ¿tilent DeÅ¿igns to promote. Whereupon he muÅ¿tered up all the Prelates he could poÅ¿Å¿ibly, not admitting any ExcuÅ¿e, The Popes fears of the French BiÅ¿hops never to be Å¿topp'd. and Å¿ent many alÅ¿o who had reÅ¿igned their Benefices to the Council, together with the Coadjutors of other BiÅ¿hops, that Å¿o he might have the more Votes, believing he was now in the utmoÅ¿t degree of Danger; and as if he had not had enough of his own he borrowed Å¿ome Prelates of his Friends too: And amongÅ¿t them he got leave of the Duke of Savoy that Anthony Bobba BiÅ¿hop of CaÅ¿Å¿ale, who was then that Princes AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador in the Court of Rome; and Lewis Vanini de Teodolis BiÅ¿hop de Bertinoro, a PerÅ¿on of great Learning and Eloquence, who had excuÅ¿ed his Attendance in the Council upon his want of Health, Å¿hould now forthwith be diÅ¿patched to Trent. When this laÅ¿t was going thither, he is Å¿aid to have conÅ¿olated and Å¿trengthened the good Pope in his Anxiety and Fears of the Event, with an AÅ¿Å¿urance, That he would certainly get the Victory over the Council, which was a very Acceptable Saying to the Pope; and that he for that good News KiÅ¿s'd the BiÅ¿hop of Bertinoro, when he took his Leave to go to Trent, bidding him be careful to get the Victory he had promiÅ¿ed him. And when after this Å¿ome flying Reports came to Rome, that Å¿ome QueÅ¿tions were moved in the Council to the prejudice of the Papal Authority by the BiÅ¿hops, he was Å¿o moved at it, that in the ConÅ¿iÅ¿tory before all the Cardinals, he cried out, he and the Romans were betrayed, whileÅ¿t he maintained an Army of Enemies at Trent with great expence. By which expreÅ¿Å¿ion he aimed at the Italian BiÅ¿hops, who were his PenÅ¿ioners, and kept there by him in great numbers. And Jo. BaptiÅ¿ta Adriani writes, He was juÅ¿t upon the Point of inhibiting the Council, and had done it if CoÅ¿mus Duke of Florence had not averted him from that dangerous and Å¿hameful project.

The 8th.
Maximilian Son of Ferdinand choÅ¿en King of the Romans. Polano in his HiÅ¿tory of the Council of Trent, Å¿aith the Election was made the 24th. of November. So that the firÅ¿t date Å¿eems to be the day of the opening of the Diet. day of September Maximilian the EldeÅ¿t Son of Ferdinand the Emperor was choÅ¿en King of the Romans at Francfort upon the Maine, in a Diet there aÅ¿Å¿embled for that purpoÅ¿e. StroÅ¿chen a Polander by birth, who was then AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador for Solyman the Emperor of the Turks, was preÅ¿ent at Francfort, and Å¿aw this Ceremony, being Å¿ent to Å¿ettle a Truce for eight years between thoÅ¿e Princes, which had been a long time Å¿ought by Busbequius at ConÅ¿tantinople. The Emperor was by this League to pay Thirty Millions of Hungarian Duckets for a Tribute by the year. In this Diet the Princes of the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, and their Allies gave in their opinion concerning the Council in Writing, as they promiÅ¿ed they would in the Convention at Naumburg. They Å¿aid they could not come to this Impious Council which was Indicted by Pope Pins the Fourth, becauÅ¿e not Å¿o aÅ¿Å¿embled as was preÅ¿cribed in their Appeals to a pious, free and lawful Council, given in heretofore in Å¿everal Diets of Germany. This Diet ended about the end of December, and the Emperor went by Wormes, Spire, WeiÅ¿Å¿emburg, Strasburg, SchleÅ¿tat, and BaÅ¿il, to Friburg in BriÅ¿gow, being in all places received with great Honour; and in the laÅ¿t of theÅ¿e places he held a Diet for AlÅ¿atia, and then by ConÅ¿tance he went in February to InÅ¿pruck, where he Å¿taid Å¿ome time on the account of the Council of Trent, which he hoped might be ended in the leÅ¿s time if he were near it.

The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors when they came to the Council of Trent were furniÅ¿hed with certain InÅ¿tructions what they were to ask, but had Orders to Å¿uppreÅ¿s them till they had conferr'd with the Emperors AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, which happened to have much what the Å¿ame demands. But by this time the Court of France Å¿eeing there was no care taken to Å¿atisfie the Emperor, and that things were carried with great Å¿lowneÅ¿s, ordered their AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to open their Grievances, which were contain'd in Thirty four Articles,
year 1563 and were accordingly unfolded to the Council the 4th. of January; as they may be Å¿een at large in Polano his HiÅ¿tory, Pag. 609. I Å¿hall not here trouble the Reader with them. The 10th. of January the King of France ordered his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to aÅ¿Å¿ure the Pope that the Annals which were taken away in the AÅ¿Å¿embly of the States of France, lately held at Orleans, Å¿hould for the future be paid to the Pope; he hoping by this means to have him more ready to grant his deÅ¿ires, tending to the peace of the Church, which the Pope's AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador largely promiÅ¿ed. On the 14th. of February a Decree was made concerning the ReÅ¿idence of BiÅ¿hops and PaÅ¿tors with great difficulty and oppoÅ¿ition, which all tended to the obtaining the Judgment of the Council, That the Pope has full power to feed, and govern the Æ²niverÅ¿al Church. By which means they at laÅ¿t prevailed Å¿o far upon that jealous Nation, that the power of the BiÅ¿hops in the end was very much abated, and that of the Pope was enlarged and exalted; and the BiÅ¿hops were contented to act as the Popes Delegates, and by his Authority, and in his Name to exerciÅ¿e their Functions. About this time it was that the Cardinal of Lorrain went again to the Emperor to InÅ¿pruck, which cauÅ¿ed a great fear in the Pope's party in the Council, for that they Å¿uÅ¿pected he went to adjuÅ¿t with that Prince the ways to bring the Papal power under.

In the beginning of March the Emperor wrote a Letter to the Pope (after he had conÅ¿ulted the BiÅ¿hops of Quinque EccleÅ¿iae, The Emperor diÅ¿likes the Proceedings of the Council. who went to InÅ¿pruck to him) wherein he Å¿ignified to his HolineÅ¿s, That after his Son in the laÅ¿t Diet was Elected King of the Romans, and Crown'd, and that he had viÅ¿ited his Cities upon the Rhine, he was come to InÅ¿pruck to promote the Affairs of the Church in the Council as became the Supreme Advocate and Procurator of the Church; but that to his great grief he underÅ¿tood that things were Å¿o far from going as was to be deÅ¿ired, and as the publick State of Affairs required, that it was to be feared, if Å¿peedy remedies were not applied, the Council would be ended in Å¿uch manner, as it would give offence to all ChriÅ¿tendom, and become ridiculous to all thoÅ¿e who had made a defection from the Church of Rome, and fix them more obÅ¿tinately in thoÅ¿e opinions they had embraced, tho' very differing from the Orthodox Faith. That there had not been any SeÅ¿Å¿ion celebrated for a long time, and that it was commonly given out, the Fathers and Doctors in the Council, had contentions and differences amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, which were unworthy of that moderation which they ought to have, and tended very much to the detriment of that concord which was hoped for from them; and yet theÅ¿e conteÅ¿ts frequently broke out to the great Å¿atisfaction of their AdverÅ¿aries: That there was a report, That the Pope intended to diÅ¿Å¿olve or Å¿uÅ¿pend the Council; and he adviÅ¿ed him not to do it, becauÅ¿e nothing could be more Å¿hameful or damageable; and which, beÅ¿ides, would certainly cauÅ¿e a great defection from the Church, and bring a great hatred on the Papacy, and from thence cauÅ¿e an equal contempt of all the Clergy; That this diÅ¿Å¿olution or Å¿uÅ¿penÅ¿ion would certainly procure the AÅ¿Å¿embling of National Councils, which the Popes have ever oppoÅ¿ed as contrary to the Unity of the Church, and which thoÅ¿e Princes which were well affected to the See of Rome, had hitherto hindred in their Dominions; but after this they could find no pretence to deny or delay them any longer. Therefore he deÅ¿ired the Pope to lay aÅ¿ide that thought, and to apply himÅ¿elf Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to the celebration of the Council, allowing the Ancient Liberty to all in its full extent, that all things might be diÅ¿patched rightly, lawfully, and in order, and thereby the mouths of their AdverÅ¿aries, who Å¿ought an opportunity to calumniate, might be Å¿topp'd. That it
would become his HolineÅ¿s to attend the Council in perÅ¿on if his health would permit it; and he earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired he would, That he (the Emperor) if the Pope thought fit, would alÅ¿o come thither, that they both by their preÅ¿ence might promote the Publick buÅ¿ineÅ¿s. That the Pope might compoÅ¿e and decide many difficulties which had ariÅ¿en from his abÅ¿ence. The Emperor Å¿ent a Copy of this Letter to the Cardinal of Lorrain alÅ¿o, and deÅ¿ired he would promote thoÅ¿e things which tended to the Glory of God, and the good of ChriÅ¿tendom.

The 21th. of May the Count de Luna, AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador for the King of Spain, The AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador of Spain received in the Council. was received in a Congregation; and there was a Speech made in the behalf of that Prince in the AÅ¿Å¿embly, by one Pedro Fontidonio de Segovia a Divine, who extoll'd above meaÅ¿ure the care of his MaÅ¿ter in the Affairs of Religion, and eÅ¿pecially his Å¿everity Å¿hewn towards Sectaries; he Å¿aid this Prince Married Mary of England, only to the end he might reÅ¿tore the Catholick Religion in that flouriÅ¿hing Kingdom. A little before this time the news of the Peace made with the ProteÅ¿tants of France, came firÅ¿t in Generals, and Å¿oon after the particular Articles. The Fathers at Trent much diÅ¿Å¿atisfied with the Peace made in France. For the Foundation of a State, which is Religion, being removed, it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the Temporal Å¿hould come to deÅ¿olation; whereof the Edict made before was an example, which did not cauÅ¿e Peace and Tranquility, as was hoped, but a greater War than before. The truth is, theÅ¿e men would have all the world fight out their quarrel to the laÅ¿t man, and then if their Catholicks periÅ¿h, they are as unconcerned as for the Hereticks; and accordingly ever Å¿ince that time they have made it their buÅ¿ineÅ¿s firÅ¿t to hinder all Treaties of Peace, wherein any liberty was granted to the ProteÅ¿tants; and when they could not gain that point, to make them be broken as Å¿oon as was poÅ¿Å¿ible; tho this too has for the moÅ¿t part turn'd in the end to their great loÅ¿s and Å¿hame. The French Court Å¿hew their ReaÅ¿ons for it. The French Court perceiving how the Fathers of Trent took the Peace, Ordered the Cardinal of Lorrain to Å¿hew the great Dangers which from the Civil War threatned that Kingdom; and to aÅ¿Å¿ure the Council that it was the intention of the King to diÅ¿Å¿ipate the Factions of France by a Peace, that he might be at leiÅ¿ure to attend Å¿eriouÅ¿ly the reÅ¿titution of the Peace of the Church. But when this would not be allowed neither, the Queen Å¿ent Renate de Birague, PreÅ¿ident of Dauphine, to aÅ¿Å¿ure the Fathers, That their Intentions were not to Å¿ettle a New Religion in France, nor to Å¿uffer it to grow up and encreaÅ¿e, but that having diÅ¿armed their Subjects, and quieted the Tumults, they might with the leÅ¿s trouble return to the Methods uÅ¿ed by their AnceÅ¿tors, for the reducing their people into the way, and the Unity of the Å¿ame Catholick Religion. That this could never be done but by the Authority of a lawful and free, either General or National Council: that a General Council Å¿eemed the Å¿afer way, but then it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary that a liberty and Å¿ecurity Å¿hould be given to all that would to come. That tho' this had been done by the Pope and the Fathers; yet the place was Å¿uch; and Å¿o Å¿ituate, that being rather in Italy than Germany, the ProteÅ¿tants could not think themÅ¿elves Å¿ufficiently Å¿ecure. For they deÅ¿ired a Council in Germany, and thought they were not Å¿afe if it were any where elÅ¿e: That not only they of Germany, but the EngliÅ¿h, Scotch, Danes and Swedes, were of the Å¿ame mind, and it was very unjuÅ¿t to condemn Å¿o many Nations unheard, and beÅ¿ides it was unprofitable too, for whereas all good men hoped that this Council would procure an Unity, on the contrary it would cauÅ¿e a greater oppoÅ¿ition and enmity, when theÅ¿e Nations Å¿aw themÅ¿elves neglected; and by the inconvenience of the place, as it were excluded out of the Council. For it was fit for none but weak and credulous men to think they would ever Å¿ubmit to the Decrees of a Council in which they had never been admitted, nor heard; but it was to be feared on the other Å¿ide that their minds being exaÅ¿perated, their patience would turn to fury, and they would traduce to PoÅ¿terity the
Decrees of the Council; and in the preÅ¿ent age treat them with a virulent Å¿harpneÅ¿s in their Writings. Therefore Birague was Ordered to deÅ¿ire the Council might by the conÅ¿ent of the Fathers and Pope be transferr'd into Germany, to Worms, Spire, BaÅ¿il or ConÅ¿tance. This DiÅ¿courÅ¿e would not edifie at Trent, and he was Å¿ent on the Å¿ame Errand to InÅ¿pruck to the Emperor, and to Vienna to his Son Maximilian.
