In order to this, The Pope's Bull to the Inquifitors. the Pope puts out a Bull dated the 7th. of April, by which he grants power to the Cardinals, appointed InquiÅ¿itors General for all ChriÅ¿tendom, to proceed Å¿martly and extrajudicially, as Å¿hall Å¿eem convenient to them againÅ¿t all and Å¿ingular the Hereticks, and their Abettors and Receivers, and thoÅ¿e who are Å¿uÅ¿pected to be Å¿uch abiding in the Provinces and places in which the filth of the Lutheran HereÅ¿ie hath prevailed; and to which it is notorious, there is not a Å¿afe and free entrance; tho' the Å¿aid perÅ¿ons are adorn'd with the EpiÅ¿copal, ArchiepiÅ¿copal, Patriarchal Dignity, or Cardinalate, without any other proof to be made of the Å¿afety or freedom of the AcceÅ¿s. But Å¿o that Information be firÅ¿t made, and that they be cited by an Edict by them to be affixed to the Doors of the Palace of the Holy InquiÅ¿ition, &c. admoniÅ¿hing and requiring them to appear perÅ¿onally, and not by their Proctors, before the Å¿aid InquiÅ¿ition, within a certain and limited time, as the Å¿aid InquiÅ¿ition Å¿hall think fit, upon pain of Excommunication denounced, SuÅ¿penÅ¿ion, and other lawful pains. And if they Å¿hall not Å¿o appear, they Å¿hall be proceeded againÅ¿t in the Å¿ecret ConÅ¿iÅ¿tory, and a Å¿entence decreed againÅ¿t them (tho' abÅ¿ent) as convict, and confirm'd with a clauÅ¿e of Derogation. Tho' this Bull was contrary to all Laws, Several French Cardinals and BiÅ¿hops cited to Ronte; yet the InquiÅ¿itors preÅ¿umed upon it to cite Å¿ome BiÅ¿hops of France, and with them Odet de Coligni Cardinal de ChaÅ¿tillon, who had embraced the Opinions of the ProteÅ¿tants, and was now call'd Count de B â¢ auvais, he having been formerly BiÅ¿hop of that City; St. Roman ArchbiÅ¿hop d'Aix, John Monluck BiÅ¿hop of Valence, Jean Anthony Caracciolo Son of the Prince de Melphe; Jean BrabanÅ¿on BiÅ¿hop of Pamiez, And the Queen of Navarr alÅ¿o. Charles Guillart BiÅ¿hop of Chartres. And as if this had been intended but for a Å¿tep to her; the PrinceÅ¿s Joan Labrett Queen of Navarr, Relict of Anthony late King of Navarr. All which I Å¿ay, by a Bull dated the 28th. of September, and affixed at Rome, were cited to appear before the InquiÅ¿ition, within Å¿ix Months, and the Queen was told, That if Å¿he did not, Å¿he Å¿hould be deprived of her Royal Dignity, Kingdom or Principality, and Dominions, as one convicted: and the Å¿ame Å¿hould be pronounced to belong to whoÅ¿oever Å¿hould invade it. The King and Queen of France, and all the Nobility were extremely exaÅ¿perated with theÅ¿e proceedings of the Pope; and the Bull being read in the Council of State, D'OiÅ¿el the then Ordinary AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador in the Court of Rome, The French King declares againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Proceedings againÅ¿t the Queen of Nevarr. was ordered to acquaint the Pope, That the King could Å¿carce give any credit to the firÅ¿t reports which were Å¿pread in Å¿everal Pamphlets in France, till the Citation which was fixed up in Å¿everal places in Rome, was read to him; at which he was much troubled, becauÅ¿e the Queen of Navarr was in MajeÅ¿ty and Dignity equal to any other Prince in ChriÅ¿tendom; and had from them the Title of SiÅ¿ter. 2. That the danger which threatned her was of ill example, and might in time be extended to any of them, and therefore they were all bound to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t and defend her in this common cauÅ¿e, and the more becauÅ¿e Å¿he was a Widow. 3. But the King of France above all other, becauÅ¿e nearly related to her, and her late Husband, who was one of the principal Princes of the Blood Royal, and had loÅ¿t his Life in his Å¿ervice in the laÅ¿t War againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants; leaving his Children Orphans, the EldeÅ¿t of which was now in the King's Court, and under his care: That the King could not neglect the cauÅ¿e of this Å¿orrowful Widow, and her Orphan and Children, who appeal'd to his fidelity, and the Memory of his AnceÅ¿tors; who had in all times of affliction Å¿uccoured the Princes of Germany, Spain, and England. That Philip the Bold, the Son of St. Lewis, had with a potent Army defended an Orphan-Queen of Navarr, and brought her into France, where Å¿he was after Married to Philip the Fair, from whom Joan the preÅ¿ent Queen of Navarr was lineally deÅ¿cended. And that John Labrett the Grandfather of this Queen being in like manner perÅ¿ecuted by one of the Popes, and driven out of a part of his Kingdom; the reÅ¿t had been defended and preÅ¿erved by Lewis the Twelfth, and his SucceÅ¿Å¿ors. That the Popes themÅ¿elves have heretofore fled to the French
for protection when they have been expelled out of their Sees, who had often reÅ¿tored them, defended and enriched them with the grant of many Territories: That this Queen was Å¿o near a Neighbour, and Å¿uch an Allie to the Crown of France, that no War could be made upon her without the great damage of France: That all Princes were IntereÅ¿ted in the FriendÅ¿hip and Peace of their Neighbours, and obliged to keep all Wars at a diÅ¿tance from them for the preÅ¿ervation of their own quiet and Å¿ecurity. Since therefore his MajeÅ¿ty Å¿aw by this Bull that there was a deÅ¿ign to deprive his Ancient Allies of their Dominions, and at pleaÅ¿ure to Å¿et up others in their Å¿tead, he had juÅ¿t reaÅ¿on to fear that as the Spaniards had heretofore on Å¿uch pretences poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd themÅ¿elves of all the Countries to the Pyrenaean Hills, Å¿o that in time they might paÅ¿s them too, and deÅ¿cend into the Plains of France, and Å¿o a diÅ¿mal and deÅ¿tructive War might be rekindled between theÅ¿e powerful Princes, to the great hazard and ruin of ChriÅ¿tendom. LaÅ¿tly, the Queen of Navarr being a Feuditary of the Crown of France, and having great PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions in that Kingdom, was under the Protection of the Laws of it, and could not be drawn out of it to Rome, either in PerÅ¿on, or by Proxy; no Subject of France being bound to go to Rome; but if the Pope had any cauÅ¿e againÅ¿t them, he was obliged to Å¿end Judges to determine upon the place even in thoÅ¿e CaÅ¿es that came before him by Appeal. That therefore this Citation was againÅ¿t the MajeÅ¿ty, Law, and Security of the Crown of France; and tended to the diminiÅ¿hing of the eÅ¿teem of that King and Kingdom. That if the Form of this Proceeding were conÅ¿idered, what could be more contrary to the Civil Law than to force a man out of his proper Court, and condemn him in another without any hearing? For there are Laws, That no accuÅ¿ed perÅ¿on Å¿hall be cited out of the Limits of the JuriÅ¿diction in which he lives, and that the Citation Å¿hall not be obÅ¿cure and perfunctory, but declared to the proper perÅ¿on, or to his family. And the ConÅ¿titution of Pope Boniface the Eighth, That Citations Å¿et up in certain places of Rome Å¿hould be of force, was recall'd by Clement the Fifth, and the Council of Venna, as hard and unjuÅ¿t, or at leaÅ¿t mitigated; and it was decreed that they Å¿hould not be uÅ¿ed, but when there was no Å¿afe coming to the perÅ¿on accuÅ¿ed: But in France, where the Queen of Navarr reÅ¿ides, it cannot be pretended that there is no Å¿afe coming to her. And what can be more contrary to Natural Equity than to condemn unheard? It is forbidden by the Canons and Decrees of Councils, and there is a noble example of this in Ammianus Marcellinus, where Pope Liberius, being urged by ConÅ¿tantius to condemn AthanaÅ¿ius, choÅ¿e rather to be baniÅ¿hed, than to Å¿entence him without hearing. And in the Judgment againÅ¿t Sixtus the Third, who was accuÅ¿ed of InceÅ¿t, Valentinian the Emperor obÅ¿erved the Å¿ame method, and made him appear and anÅ¿wer in a Synod before Fifty BiÅ¿hops. For the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on the Sentence of Nicholas the FirÅ¿t, againÅ¿t Lotharius the Son of St. Lewis, for having two Wives, was thought void and null. Nor was this Sentence againÅ¿t the Queen of Navarr of better force, becauÅ¿e Å¿he was abÅ¿ent and unheard. That the Popes have always Å¿hewn that reÅ¿pect to Crown'd heads, as to admoniÅ¿h them by their Legates, before they decreed ought againÅ¿t them. So Alexander the Third Å¿ent two Cardinals to Henry the Second into England, when he was accuÅ¿ed of the Death of Thomas a Becket A.B. of Canterbury, That he might purge himÅ¿elf before them of this crime. So of late Clement the Seventh, did the like in the caÅ¿e of Henry the Eighth, to whom he Å¿ent Cardinal Campeius. And if it were granted that the Judgment were rightly paÅ¿Å¿ed, how could the Dominions of the Queen be expoÅ¿ed for a prey, and given to the firÅ¿t Invader, they belonging to the King as Lord of the Fee? Therefore the King believes that the Pope is deceived by falÅ¿e reports, and inÅ¿tigated by the craft of his MiniÅ¿ters, who not regarding the publick peace, have drawn him from his natural goodneÅ¿s, to CounÅ¿els which are diÅ¿honourable to his HolineÅ¿s, and deÅ¿tructive to his Authority, and to that of the See of Rome, tending to the alienating of the hearts of his friends from him, and the diÅ¿turbing of the Peace of ChriÅ¿tendom. And his MajeÅ¿ty is the more perÅ¿waded of the truth of this, becauÅ¿e his HolineÅ¿s Å¿o earneÅ¿tly eÅ¿pouÅ¿ed the IntereÅ¿t of Anthony the Husband of this Queen in his life-time; and endeavoured to perÅ¿wade King Philip to reÅ¿tore to him the Kingdom of Navarr, or at leaÅ¿t to give him the IÅ¿land of Sardinia as an Equivalent. But then there is nothing more offends the King than the conÅ¿idering that whereas Å¿o many Kings, Princes, and Free States above Forty years Å¿ince have defected from the See of Rome, and committed the offence charged upon the Queen, and Å¿o by the rule of JuÅ¿tice ought to be firÅ¿t puniÅ¿hed as firÅ¿t offending; yet the Pope has
not proceeded in the Å¿ame way, or with equal Å¿everity againÅ¿t any of them; Å¿o that from hence it is clear that an occaÅ¿ion is Å¿ought by her enemies to oppreÅ¿s and ruin her by Å¿urprize, whileÅ¿t Å¿he is a Widow, her Children Orphans, the King of France who ought to protect her being a Minor, and diÅ¿turbed by Civil Wars; and for this reaÅ¿on the King is the more obliged to defend her from injury, and himÅ¿elf from contempt, Å¿eeing without acquainting him with it, they have begun this ProceÅ¿s againÅ¿t a Queen Å¿o nearly related to him. That if this AccuÅ¿ation had been made on the account of Religion, and for the Glory of God, the Pope ought in the firÅ¿t place to have Å¿hewn his care of her Å¿oul, and from the Word of God to have adminiÅ¿tred fitting Remedies, and not to have proÅ¿cribed her Kingdoms and Dominions, The DepoÅ¿ing of Princes, and diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of their Dominions, the cauÅ¿e of great Calamities. and given them for a prey to the firÅ¿t Invader. The Pope has a Supremacy given him, That he may conÅ¿ult the Salvation of Souls, and the repoÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿tendom, and not that he may deprive Princes of their Kingdoms, and diÅ¿poÅ¿e of their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions at his pleaÅ¿ure; which the former Popes have never been able to do in Germany and other places, without bringing great reproach and diÅ¿honour on the Church, and diÅ¿turbances upon the World. That therefore the King deÅ¿ired with the greateÅ¿t humility that he could or ought, that the Sentence againÅ¿t the Q. of Navarr Å¿hould be revok'd, and all the Pope's MiniÅ¿ters Å¿hould be inhibited from proceeding in this cauÅ¿e by a publick Act; and if this were not done, the King Å¿hould be forced againÅ¿t his will to make uÅ¿e of the Å¿ame remedies his AnceÅ¿tors had imployed in the like caÅ¿es, according to the Laws and Rights of his Kingdom. But before all things he proteÅ¿ted he Å¿hould do this unwillingly, and therefore they only Å¿hould bear the blame who by their raÅ¿hneÅ¿s had forced him to uÅ¿e the power God had given him, in Å¿o juÅ¿t a cauÅ¿e, and to implore the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of his friends againÅ¿t them.

There was at the Å¿ame time diÅ¿tinct Memorials, and larger InÅ¿tructions Å¿ent to the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador for the Defence of the BiÅ¿hops, The BiÅ¿hops defended by the King alÅ¿o. and D'OyÅ¿el who was an active MiniÅ¿ter, prevail'd upon the Pope to have the Proceedings againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hops Å¿topt, and the Sentence againÅ¿t the Queen of Navarr revok'd and aboliÅ¿hed. So that at this day it is not to be found amongÅ¿t the ConÅ¿titutions of Pope Pius the Fourth. The 18th. of May there having been no conÅ¿ideration had of the XXXIII. Articles put into the Council the 4th. of January, The Queen complains of the Proceedings of the Council. the Queen wrote to LanÅ¿Å¿ac her AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, complaining very bitterly of the delays and Å¿hifts which had been made in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and Å¿aid that the hope good men had hitherto had of the Å¿ucceÅ¿s of this Council, and the opinion of their Å¿incerity who met in it, would both vaniÅ¿h without any fruit, and their diÅ¿Å¿imulation and connivance would more and more inflame the wrath of God againÅ¿t us, who had now made it manifeÅ¿t unto all men that the affairs of the Church needed a Reformation, and a Å¿evere correction; and to that purpoÅ¿e had invited and brought together from all parts of the Earth, Å¿o many men famous for their Piety and Learning to this Council; and if after all this he Å¿hall Å¿ee us Å¿till Å¿tubbornly reÅ¿iÅ¿t his will; he will be neceÅ¿Å¿itated to puniÅ¿h thoÅ¿e men who have hindred Å¿o good a work, and Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary to the peace of the Church: That therefore the King had wrote to the Cardinal of Lorrain to aÅ¿Å¿emble a Congregation of the French Clergy, and after a mature deliberation had amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves to demand earneÅ¿tly of the Fathers of the Council that theÅ¿e things might be conÅ¿idered and determin'd as Å¿oon as was poÅ¿Å¿ible. But the Cardinal was by this time won over to the Pope's Å¿ide, The Pope gained the Cardinal of Lorrain to his Å¿ide, and was willing to Å¿acrifice the Å¿afety of France, and the King's Will, to the IntereÅ¿t of the former. In order to this he delayed the Execution of his Orders from day to day; and at laÅ¿t that he might totally diÅ¿appoint them, asked leave of the King to go to Rome, believing the Kings AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors would do nothing in his abÅ¿ence. And not long after LanÅ¿Å¿ac obtained leave to return into France. Who went to Rome. The Cardinal of Lorrain went from Trent towards Rome the 18th of September, and with him five of the French BiÅ¿hops: But the other French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors did nevertheleÅ¿s inÅ¿iÅ¿t Å¿toutly to have the Articles conÅ¿idered by the Council; who, that they might elude this purÅ¿uit, made Å¿ome Decrees which had Å¿ome reÅ¿pect to thoÅ¿e things the French had deÅ¿ired, but which aimed at the granting a Liberty and Immunity to the Clergy againÅ¿t all the Laws, Privileges, Liberties, and JuriÅ¿dictions, and Lawful Authorities of all Kingdoms, States and Princes; which being Å¿een by La Ferriere and Du Faur the King's AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors at Trent they by their MaÅ¿ter's Order oppoÅ¿ed the Å¿aid Decrees. The 27th. of September, the King by a Letter having commanded his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon their firÅ¿t Demands; and to aÅ¿Å¿ure the Council, that as none of the ChriÅ¿tian Princes Å¿hould exceed him in the fervor of true Piety, and a deÅ¿ire to promote the

Liberties and Power of Soveraign Princes. That they neither could nor ought to inquire into the Civil AdminiÅ¿tration, which was not Å¿ubject to their Court, nor to derogate from thoÅ¿e ConÅ¿titutions and CuÅ¿toms which had been long enjoyed by Princes; nor to Anathematize Kings; all which things tended to Sedition, and the interruption of the publick Peace: That he would not Å¿uffer that Authority which he had received from his AnceÅ¿tors to be weakned by their unjuÅ¿t cenÅ¿ures. But then the King did truÅ¿t to their wiÅ¿dom and conÅ¿cience, that they would not approve of by their preÅ¿ence, or conÅ¿ent to any thing which was prejudicial to the Royal Authority, Prerogative or Dignity of the King or Kingdom of France. But however it Å¿hews the Å¿enÅ¿e great men had of the Council of Trent, at that time when it was beÅ¿t underÅ¿tood.

A little before this time the Emperor being about leaving InÅ¿pruck, The Emperor oppoÅ¿eth the intended Proceedings of the Council againÅ¿t Queen Elizabeth. diÅ¿covered that they conÅ¿ulted at Rome and Trent about proceeding againÅ¿t Queen Elizabeth of England; and he wrote to the Pope and the Legates, that if the Council would not yield that fruit which was deÅ¿ired that they might Å¿ee an Union of Catholicks to reform the Church; yet at leaÅ¿t they Å¿hould not give occaÅ¿ion to Hereticks to unite themÅ¿elves more, which they would do in caÅ¿e they proceeded againÅ¿t the Queen of England. When the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors had put theÅ¿e two Rubs in the way of the Council, The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors leave Trent, and go to Venice. they retired, as the King their MaÅ¿ter had before commanded them, to Venice; and gave an account of what they had done to the Cardinal of Lorrain at Rome, and to the King of France; this laÅ¿t approved it, but the former having made his private Market with the Pope, who extremely flattered this proud, turbulent, vainglorious Prelate, was very much diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with what the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors had done in his abÅ¿ence at Trent. Thus far Polano.

The Emperor who was come as far as InÅ¿pruck to promote the Council, The Emperor goes from InÅ¿pruck before the Council was ended. finding that his being there did not only no good, as he thought it would, but rather the contrary; the PopiÅ¿h Prelates Å¿uÅ¿pecting his deÅ¿igns were againÅ¿t the Authority of the Court of Rome, and were accordingly afraid of every thing, Å¿o that the Difficulties and SuÅ¿picions did turn into bitterneÅ¿s, and encreaÅ¿e in number. The Catholick Princes being blinded and miÅ¿led by their Education, The ReaÅ¿ons why the Council had no better Å¿ucceÅ¿s. and not underÅ¿tanding that the right of calling Councils was in themÅ¿elves, as it was of old in the ChriÅ¿tian Emperors, who call'd all the Ancient General Councils, thought that they Å¿hould by force of Arguments and modeÅ¿ty, extort Å¿ome Reformation from them, but when they Å¿aw they could not agree amongÅ¿t themÅ¿elves what was abÅ¿olutely neceÅ¿Å¿ary, France and the Empire asking more than King Philip was willing to admit, and the Pope being as Å¿toutly reÅ¿olved whatever happened not to Å¿uffer his Power, Grandeur or Wealth to be abated. I Å¿hould here have ended this Continuation, The State of Religion in Piedmont. but that I have been forced to leave Å¿ome things unÅ¿poken to continue the thread of my Relation, which I will now go back to and gather up, that the Story may be the more compleat and perfect. ReaÅ¿ons againÅ¿t granting Marriage to the Clergy. But the Council had good reaÅ¿on to deny this laÅ¿t, becauÅ¿e (Å¿ay they) it is plain that Married PrieÅ¿ts will turn their affections and love to their Wives and Children; and by conÅ¿equence to their HouÅ¿e and Country, and Å¿o that Å¿trict dependance which the Clergy hath on the ApoÅ¿tolick See, would ceaÅ¿e; and to grant

Camden in his HiÅ¿tory of Queen Elizabeth aÅ¿Å¿ures us, The French Affairs after the Peace till the end of the Council. the true reaÅ¿on why the Prince of Conde clapt up this Peace upon Å¿uch eaÅ¿ie and diÅ¿advantageous terms, was becauÅ¿e he had been deluded by the Queen with the vain hopes of Å¿ucceeding his Brother the King of Navarr, as General of all the Forces of France; and that he Å¿hould marry the Queen of Scotland too, which he afterwards refuÅ¿ed.

The EngliÅ¿h were then poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿s'd of Havre de Grace, The Siege of Havre de Grace. and had a GarriÅ¿on in it; and now both the ProteÅ¿tants and the Roman Catholicks united their Forces to deprive them of it, without repaying any of the Money the Queen had expended in the War, or conÅ¿idering what need they might after have of that PrinceÅ¿s's protection and aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance. Both parties on the contrary proteÅ¿t, That if the EngliÅ¿h do not forthwith reÅ¿tore that place, they Å¿hould forfeit their Right to Calais, which was reÅ¿erved to them by the Treaty of Cambray; and when this would not do, they proclaimed a War againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h in France the 7th. of July; which was return'd them by the EngliÅ¿h till they Å¿hould reÅ¿tore Calais. The French thereupon (without ever reflecting on their own ConÅ¿piracy againÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h) began a loud complaint, That the EngliÅ¿h came not to protect the French in their diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿es, but to get the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Town, dealing with them not as with Brethren, but as Foreigners. His MeÅ¿Å¿enger whom he Å¿ent with this AnÅ¿wer happened to meet one Monie a ProteÅ¿tant French Captain, with whom he had been familiarly acquainted in the Siege of Roan, to whom he Å¿aid, He much wondred to Å¿ee the ProteÅ¿tants of France, who were of the Å¿ame Religion with the EngliÅ¿h, and for whoÅ¿e relief they came into France, in the Camp againÅ¿t them. There came Å¿ome Ships with Relief from Eugland, but the Plague continuing, the Queen to preÅ¿erve Å¿o many brave men, gave order to the Earl of Warwick
to Å¿urrender the place, upon as Honourable Terms as he could get. The 28th. of July the Articles were Signed; the next day there came Å¿ixty Ships, and 1800 men to the Relief of the place, but it was too late; Å¿o the EngliÅ¿h that remain'd,
Havre de Grate Å¿urrendred to the French. were Å¿ent on Board the Fleet, who had the misfortune to carry this Plague with them into England, and within one year there died in London only, A Plague in London. 21530 perÅ¿ons of this DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e. There was Å¿o much joy in France for the recovery of this Å¿mall place, that the Chancellor of France Å¿aid openly, That now the moÅ¿t malicious muÅ¿t needs confeÅ¿s, That the granting Liberty of ConÅ¿cience had at once delivered France from a moÅ¿t deÅ¿tructive Civil War, united the Princes of the Blood Royal, and enabled them to recover too what had been Å¿eized by their Enemies during the War, and that chiefly by the help of the ProteÅ¿tants, who before were Å¿o dreadful to them, whileÅ¿t they fought for their Religion.

The Queen, to cut off all pretences to the GuardianÅ¿hip of the King, by the advice of the Chancellor,
Charles the Ninth declared out of His Minority by the Parliament of Roan. reÅ¿olved to have him declared out of his Minority by the Parliament of Roan; purÅ¿uant to a ConÅ¿titution of Charles the Fifth King of France, made in the year 1373, tho' he had then entered only into the Fourteenth year of his age; which was accordingly done the 19th. of AuguÅ¿t; when he declared again, That he was reÅ¿olved not to Å¿uffer his Edicts to be diÅ¿puted by his Subjects, as had been done during his Minority; and eÅ¿pecially the laÅ¿t, for the peace of Religion, which he was reÅ¿olved to make all his Subjects obey, till it was otherwiÅ¿e Å¿etled by a Council. This Decree met with Å¿ome oppoÅ¿ition from the Parliament of Paris, which pretends to be the Supreme Court of that Kingdom; and Å¿aid, they ought to have had the honour of declaring the King of Age, and no other, which was Å¿oon over-rul'd.

The deÅ¿ire I had to proÅ¿ecute the Affairs of France, The Scotch Affairs in 1562. and the Story of the Council of Trent, has kept me from mentioning Scotland and its Affairs; Å¿o that I am behind hand with that Kingdom two years. In the beginning of the year 1562, Mary Queen of the Scots, took her ProgreÅ¿s towards the North: At Sterling Å¿he was Petition'd by certain CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners of the Church for the AboliÅ¿hing of the MaÅ¿s, and other SuperÅ¿titious Rites of the Roman Religion, the puniÅ¿hing BlaÅ¿phemy, the contempt of the Word of God, the Profanation of the Sacraments, the Violation of the Sabbath, Adultery, Fornication, and other like Vices condemn'd by the Word of God, but not puniÅ¿hable by the Laws of Scotland. That all Suits for Divorce Å¿hould be remitted to the Judgment of the Church; or at leaÅ¿t, truÅ¿ted to men of good knowledge and converÅ¿ation; and that PopiÅ¿h Church-men might be excluded from places in the SeÅ¿Å¿ion and Council. And Å¿o in a rage turn'd her back and left them.

In January 1563. John Hamilton ArchbiÅ¿hop of St. And 1563. Andrews was committed to the CaÅ¿tle of Edinburgh, for Å¿aying and hearing MaÅ¿s; the Abbot alÅ¿o of CorÅ¿ragnal,
John Hamilton ArchbiÅ¿hop of St. Andrews committed for hearing MaÅ¿s. and Prior of Withern, had the Å¿ame treatment; and divers PrieÅ¿ts and Monks were cenÅ¿ured for the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e. The Scots thought by theÅ¿e Severities to terrifie the Queen into a compliance with their Religion. However certain it is, Å¿ome of the ProteÅ¿tants made her an ill requital: For in AuguÅ¿t following, certain of the Queens Family remaining in the Palace of Edinburgh call'd Holy-Rood HouÅ¿e, and having a PrieÅ¿t to attend them, and perform the RomiÅ¿h Service in the Chapel, divers of the Inhabitants of Edinburgh, out of curioÅ¿ity or devotion reÅ¿orting thither, great offence was taken at it, and the Preacher began to complain of it as a diÅ¿order. Whereupon Å¿ome of the Citizens went thither to Å¿ee if it were Å¿o; theÅ¿e being denied Admittance, they forced the Gates of the Queens Palace; took Å¿everal of thoÅ¿e who were there aÅ¿Å¿embled and carried them to priÅ¿on; the PrieÅ¿t and Å¿ome few others eÅ¿caping by a PoÅ¿tern, or Back-door. This Uproar was very great, and yet it was related to the beÅ¿t advantage to the Queen, who was then out of Town; Å¿he was very much incenÅ¿ed, as Å¿he had good reaÅ¿on, againÅ¿t theÅ¿e Zealots; and Å¿wore Å¿he would Å¿hortly make them Examples of her Royal Indignation. The Earls of Murray and Glencarne however wiÅ¿ely interpoÅ¿ed and appeaÅ¿ed her anger for the preÅ¿ent. Soon after John Knox was call'd before the Council,
John Knox call'd before the Council for Sedition. and charged as the only Author of this InÅ¿olent Sedition, and likewiÅ¿e for Å¿tirring up the people by his Circular Letters to Tumults, whenever he thought fit. He anÅ¿wered, That he was never a
Preacher of Rebellion, nor loved to Å¿tir up Tumults; contrariwiÅ¿e he always taught the People to obey their MagiÅ¿trates and Princes in God. As to the Convocation of the Subjects, he had received from the Church a Command to advertiÅ¿e his Brethren when he Å¿aw a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of their Meeting, eÅ¿pecially if he Å¿aw Religion to be in peril: And had often deÅ¿ired to be diÅ¿charged of that burthen, but Å¿till was refuÅ¿ed. Then Å¿peaking to the Queen with wonderful boldneÅ¿s: His bold AnÅ¿wer. He charged her in the name of Almighty God, as Å¿he deÅ¿ired to eÅ¿cape his heavy wrath and indignation, to forÅ¿ake that Idolatrous Religion which Å¿he profeÅ¿s'd, and by her power maintain'd againÅ¿t all the Statutes of the Realm. He was going on when the Earl of Morton, then Chancellor of Scotland, fearing the Queen might be yet more exaÅ¿perated againÅ¿t all the ProteÅ¿tants of her Kingdom, by his indiÅ¿creet zeal, commanded him to hold his peace and go away. After this, things were carried more peaceably between the Queen and the Church, the Earl of Murray making it his buÅ¿ineÅ¿s to propound their Petitions to her, and to return her AnÅ¿wers to them.

div.head: A TABLE OF THE Principal Matters Contained in this HISTORY.

list.head: A.
list.item: ADiaphoriÅ¿ts, who, Pag. 478, 481.

Adolph Count Schawenburg is made ArchbiÅ¿hop of Cologne by the Pope, 417. Enters upon the ReÅ¿ignation of the ArchbiÅ¿hop, 418. His firÅ¿t MaÅ¿s, 457. Makes his publick Entry into Cologne, 499. He leaves Trent, 543. He makes a League with the HouÅ¿e of Burgundy, 560.

Adrian Å¿ucceeds Leo X. 50. Sends a Legate to the Diet of Nuremberg, 54. And a Breve to Frederick, Ibid. Writes a long Letter to the States aÅ¿Å¿embled at Nuremberg, 55. He Proclaims Charles the Fifth's Election, 18. AnÅ¿wers Luther's Letter kindly, 31. Makes a Speech to Charles the Fifth, 37. Is concerned in the Ban by which Luther was ProÅ¿cribed, 49. He aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts OÅ¿iander, and BaniÅ¿hes thoÅ¿e Ministers who refuÅ¿e his Doctrine, 511.

Albert Marquis of Brandenburg aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts Duke Maurice, 417. He keeps Rochlitz, 420. Is taken PriÅ¿oner by the Duke of Saxony, Ibid. Set at liberty, 428. Goes into France to mediate a League between the French King and Duke Maurice, 549. His Declaration of War againÅ¿t the Emperor, 551. He joins D. Maurice and the Landgrave's Son, 555. He waÅ¿ts the Country about Ulm, 556. He is very cruel to the Norembergers, 561. Fines the BiÅ¿hops of Bamberg and Wurtzburg, 562. Makes Peace with the Norembergers, Ibid. He writes to the City of Ulm to yield to him, 563. He deÅ¿erts the Confederates, and wars in his own Name, 567. Breaks in upon the BiÅ¿hops of Mentz and Triers, Ibid. Demands his chief CaÅ¿tle of the BiÅ¿hop of Triers, Ibid. He falls upon the BiÅ¿hops upon the Rhine, 571. His Demands of the StraÅ¿burgers, Ibid. He beÅ¿ieges Frankfort, 572. Makes a Peace with the Emperor, 575. Beats the French at Pont a MouÅ¿Å¿on, Ibid. Complains to the Franconian BiÅ¿hops, 577. RefuÅ¿es an Accommodation at Heidelberg, and declares War againÅ¿t the BiÅ¿hops of Franconia, 578. Takes Bamberg, and Å¿poils the Country, Ibid. Makes War upon Duke Maurice, 581. War is declared againÅ¿t him, Ib. His AnÅ¿wer to their Declaration, 584. His Territories are invaded, Ibid. He is routed by D. Maurice, 585. Writes a Letter to D.
Maurice's Subjects, 586. Renews the War againÅ¿t the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, 591. Is routed by him, Ibid. He retires towards France, 592. He is ProÅ¿cribed, 594. Sues in vain to have it taken off, 595. He RemonÅ¿trates to the Diet of Ausburg againÅ¿t the Norembergers, 599. By continuing the War he is at laÅ¿t Outed of all, 601. Goes into France, 604. Writes to the Diet at Frankfort, Ibid.

Albert of BrunÅ¿wick killed, 404.

Aquinas (Tho.) chiefly quoted to prove Indulgences, 3. Studied at Cologne and Paris. 4. Scholar to Albertus Magnus, Ibid. Sainted by Pope John XXII, Ibid. Dies, An. 1274. Ibid. Called Angelical Doctor, Ibid.
Arbitrators, Elector of Mentz, and Prince Palatine choÅ¿en to mediate between the ProteÅ¿tant Princes, and the Emperor, 154. Their AnÅ¿wer to the Prince's PropoÅ¿itions, 158.
AriÅ¿totle better uÅ¿ed by the Lovain Doctors than Luther, 29.
ArnÅ¿tadt, a Town in Thuringia, a Convention of ProteÅ¿tants there, 251.

D'Avalos (Ferd.) MarqueÅ¿s of PeÅ¿cara, heartens the ImperialiÅ¿ts to Fight at Pevia, 79. AccuÅ¿es the French King, 295.

AuÅ¿trian Nobility Petition Ferdinand for Liberty of ConÅ¿cience, 285. They renew their InÅ¿tances, 287. They AddreÅ¿s again, 628. Their Reply to Ferdinand's AnÅ¿wer, 630. Ferdinand's AnÅ¿wer to their Reply, 632.

Book Printed in French againÅ¿t the HuckÅ¿ters of Sacred things, 178. An Account of it, Ibid.

They are Routed by George TruchÅ¿es at Lippen, Ibid. The Boors in Algow diÅ¿perÅ¿e themÅ¿elves, Ibid. They RiÅ¿e in Franconia, Ibid. Killed Count HelfenÅ¿tein at WinÅ¿perg, Ibid. Are Routed by TruchÅ¿es, 81. He puniÅ¿hes thoÅ¿e who killed Count HelfenÅ¿tein, Ib. Another body takes Wirtzburg, Ibid. Are Routed by TruchÅ¿es, Ibid. Æ²p in Lorrain. Ibid. There Defeated. Ibid. And every where elÅ¿e in Germany, Ibid. Many killed TreacherouÅ¿ly, after PromiÅ¿e of Life, Ibid. The demands of the Boors in Schwabia, 90.

Brentius (John) in great DiÅ¿treÅ¿s at Hall about the Interim, 461. Received by the D. of Wirtemberg, 462. He draws up a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Divines in the Dutchy, and is eÅ¿teemed by the Duke, 515.

BrunÅ¿wick (Hen. D. of) hot againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 239. His Letters to the BiÅ¿hop of Mentz and Eldo, intercepted by the Landgrave, 246. He Quarrels with the Elector of Saxony, 247. Bull de Coena Domini, what, 42.
Bull (Golden) what, 19.
Buren (Maximilian Count of) comes to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Emperor, 397. He joins the Emperor, 403. Takes DarmÅ¿tadt, 414. And Frankfort upon CompoÅ¿ition, Ibid. Dies, 478.

Campegio (Cardinal) goes to Nuremberg, 66. Writes to the Elector Frederick Duke of Saxony, 67. His Speech to the Princes of the Empire, 68. His Reply to their AnÅ¿wer, 69. His AnÅ¿wer to the Deputies from Strasburg, 73. makes a Speech at the Diet at Worms, 271.

Cardinal. The Delegate Cardinals draw a Model of Reformation, 233. The Cardinals at the Council of Trent anÅ¿wer Mendoza's Speech, 360.

CaroloÅ¿tadius (Andrew) diÅ¿putes with Eckius at Leipzick, 22. Pulls down Images at Wittemberg, 52. Goes over to the EnthuÅ¿iaÅ¿ts, ibid. Writes againÅ¿t Luther about the EuchariÅ¿t, 97. ExcuÅ¿es himÅ¿elf from being engaged with the Boors, ibid. Begs Luther's Protection, ibid.

Cajetan (Tho. Card.) Å¿ent by Pope Leo to the Diet at Ausburg, 4. Exhorts the Princes of the Empire to defend it againÅ¿t Selymus the Turk, ibid. Treats with Luther at Ausburg, 7. Commands Stupits to treat privately with Luther, 8. Exclaims againÅ¿t the Council of ConÅ¿tance in the Council of Lateran, 10. Writes to Frederick, complaining againÅ¿t Luther, ibid. PubliÅ¿hes Leo's Bull at Lintz, 12. Sends it to the BiÅ¿hops of Germany, ibid. ExaÅ¿perated the Breach of Luther, 24.
CaÅ¿a (John) ArchbiÅ¿hop of Beneventum, the Pope's Legate at Venice, 475. Writes in defence of Sodomy, 477.

Catharine of AuÅ¿tria Wife to Henry the Eight, dies, 202.

Charles Duke of Bourbon, beÅ¿ieges MarÅ¿eilles, 76. Takes Rome, 109. Blocks up the Pope in the CaÅ¿tle of St. Angelo, Ibid. His Soldiers commit great InÅ¿olencies, Ibid. Dies, 110. Is attainted by the French King, Ibid.

Thence into the Low-Countries, ibid. Summons the Electors to Aix la Chapelle, 36. Meets them there, 37. Enters the Town in Å¿tate, ibid. The Ceremonies of his Coronation, ibid. His Oath, ibid. Goes to Cologne, and calls a Diet to Worms, 38. PromiÅ¿es Luther a publick hearing at the Diet, 41. Writes to Luther, and gives him Å¿afe Conduct, 42. Writes to the Princes againÅ¿t Luther, 44. ProÅ¿cribes him 48, 49. Makes War with Francis I, 50. And takes Milain, ibid. Returns into Spain, 51. Goes into England by the way, and makes a League with Henry VIII. ibid. AnÅ¿wers the Complaints exhibited by the free Cities againÅ¿t the Diet at Nuremberg, 66. Complains to the Diet, that the Decree of Worms was not obÅ¿erved, 73. Chides the States and Princes for attempting to call a General Council, 75. Takes King Francis PriÅ¿oner at Pavia, 79. DeÅ¿ires that a Diet may be called at Ausburg, 96. Treats a Peace with Francis, 102. The Articles of Peace, ibid. Writes to the Diet at Spire, that the Decree at Worms Å¿hould be kept, 103. Marries the King of Portugal's Daughter, 105. AnÅ¿wers Pope Clement's angry Letter, 106. His Letter to the College of Cardinals, 107. He anÅ¿wers the Confederates PropoÅ¿als, 109. He leaves off publick Sports, when he underÅ¿tood that Rome was taken, 109. AccuÅ¿es the French King of
Breach of Faith, 112. AnÅ¿wers the French King's Challenge, 115. Calls a Synod to be held at Spire, ibid. AnÅ¿wers the ProteÅ¿tant AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors at Piacenza, 124. Confines the ProteÅ¿tant AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to their Lodgings, 125. Calls a Diet at Augsbourg, 126. Is Crowned at Rome by the Pope, ibid. Makes his Entry into Augsbourg, 127. Makes a Speech to the Princes of the Diet, ibid. ConÅ¿ents at laÅ¿t that the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion Å¿hould be read to him, 129. His Speech to the Princes, 133. He threatens the ProteÅ¿tant Princes, 134. Debates with them about a Decree. 135. As alÅ¿o with the Deputies of particular Cities, 138. Denies the Liberty which the ProteÅ¿tants demanded, 139. ReÅ¿cinds Albert of Brandenburg's TranÅ¿actions with the King of Poland, ibid. Calls the Electors together to chooÅ¿e a K. of the Romans at Cologne, 142. His ReaÅ¿ons for chooÅ¿ing a King of the Romans, 143. He commands the ProteÅ¿tants to acknowledge Ferdinand King of the Romans, 148. He gives them notice of a TurkiÅ¿h InvaÅ¿ion, ibid. Calls a Diet at Spire, 152. Removes it to Ratisbon, 155. And confirms a Peace there to all ProteÅ¿tants, 160. Sollicites for aid againÅ¿t the Turks to little purpoÅ¿e, 161. Goes to Italy, 162. Writes into Germany to obey Ferdinand, ibid. Makes a League with Pope Clement, ibid. His AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador goes with the Pope's Legate to the D. of Saxony, ibid. His AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador's Speech to the Duke, 163. Stands to the determination of Ferdinand concerning the D. of Wirtemberg, 174. Goes into Africa, 180. Takes Goletta, ibid. ReÅ¿tores Muley Hazem to the Kingdom of Tunis, ibid. Encourages the ProÅ¿ecutions of the Imperial Chamber, 184. His Speech againÅ¿t the French King, 204. Writes to the ProteÅ¿tants in Germany, 208. Is unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful in France, ibid. Sends Eldo his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to Smalcald to treat with the ProteÅ¿tants, 212. Makes a Truce with the King of France, 232. Meets Francis at Aigues Mortes, 239. Accommodates with the ProteÅ¿tants at Francfort, 248. Goes through France into Flanders, 252. His AnÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 255. He puniÅ¿hes the City of Ghent for its InÅ¿urrection, 262. He writes to the Elector of Saxony, and the Landgrave about a Peace, 263. Denies the D. of Cleve's Petition, 266. Confirms the Decree at Haguenaw, 269. Invites the ProteÅ¿tants to meet at Wormes, ibid. He diÅ¿Å¿olves the Conference at Wormes, 272. Appoints PerÅ¿ons to conferr at Ratisbon, 276. His Exhortations to them, ibid. Referrs Religious Matters to a Council. 282. He makes a Private Grant to the ProteÅ¿tants, 283. Complains of the D. of Cleve, ibid. Sails into Africk, 285. LoÅ¿es his Fleet by a Storm, ibid. Writes to the Senate at Metz to allow no Change in Religion, 298. His ManifeÅ¿to againÅ¿t the French King to the Pope, 300. His AnÅ¿wer to the Cardinals of the Mediation who were Å¿ent by the Pope, 303. His Soldiers waÅ¿te Juliers, and take Duren, ibid. Writes to the ProteÅ¿tants from Genoa, 311. Has an Interview with the Pope, 312. RefuÅ¿es to Confirm Parma and Piacenza to the Pope's Son, ibid. Delivers Leghorn and the CaÅ¿tle of Florence to CoÅ¿mo Medicis, ibid. Makes his Son King of Spain, ibid. Makes a League with the K. of England, ibid. AnÅ¿wers the ProteÅ¿tants AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors from Smalcald, ibid. RefuÅ¿es to make up the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s with the D. of Cleve, 313. He threatens the HildeÅ¿heymers, ibid. Writes to the Senate of Cologne, ibid. Goes to Bonne, 314. Makes a proÅ¿perous War upon the Duke of Cleve, 315. ReÅ¿tores him upon his SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, ibid. Sends to the City of Metz to renounce the Reform'd Religion, 316. Goes into Guelderland, 317. Makes the French yield at Landrecy, ibid. AnÅ¿wers the Saxons and Landgrave's Letter, ibid. Opens the Diet of Spire with a Speech, ibid. Waves the ControverÅ¿ie between the D. of BrunÅ¿wick and the Confederate ProteÅ¿tants, 319. His Expedition into France, 326. Makes a Pacification with the French King, 327. Makes Severe Edicts againÅ¿t the Lutherans in the Netherlands, 342. Comes to Wormes, 348. His EmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the K. of Poland, ibid. Endeavours a Treaty of Peace with the ProteÅ¿tants, 349. Makes a Truce with the Turk, 351. Takes the Clergy of Cologne into his Protection, ibid. Cites the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Cologne, ibid. Writes to the Doctors of the Conference at Ratisbon, 359. AnÅ¿wers the ProteÅ¿tant AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors about the Elector of Cologne, 360. He goes to Spire, on his way to Ratisbon, 367. Treats with the Landgrave and the Elector Palatine there, 368. Comes to Ratisbon, 374. Opens the Diet, ibid. Sends the Cardinal of Trent to Rome to Å¿ollicite for aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, 375. Makes Preparation for War, ibid. AnÅ¿wers the ProteÅ¿tant Deputies, 376. Writes to the ProteÅ¿tant Free Cities, ibid. Writes to the Duke of Wirtemberg, 377. He Å¿ends an EmbaÅ¿Å¿ie to the Switzers, 380. Makes a League againÅ¿t the Reformed, 381. Acquaints the Elector Palatine with the ReaÅ¿ons why he made War upon the ProteÅ¿tants, 383. His Letter to the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Cologne, 385. His Forces at Ratisbon, 389. He Outlaws the Elector of Saxony, and the Landgrave, ibid. Invites D. Maurice to take PoÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of the Landgrave's and the Saxon's Territories, 391. RefuÅ¿es to hear the ProteÅ¿tant MeÅ¿Å¿engers, 394. And anÅ¿wers their Objections, ib. Is joined by the Pope's Troops, ibid. An account of his Army, 395. He marches to Ratisbon, ibid. His great Courage, 398. He and the Pope pretend different cauÅ¿es of the
War, Ibid. His Letter to the ProteÅ¿tant Switzers, Ibid. He takes Donawert by Surrender, 405. Is MaÅ¿ter of the Danube, 406. Is oppreÅ¿Å¿ed at Gienghen a Town on the Danube, and uÅ¿es Tricks to get off, 407. The Plague in his Camp, Ibid. Removes his Camp, 410. Recovers by Surrender Å¿everal Towns in Frankenland, 412. Writes a Å¿evere Letter to the Duke of Wirtemberg, Ibid. Commands his Subjects not to obey him, 413. Takes Ulm by Surrender, Ibid. Is reconciled to the Duke of Wirtemberg, 415. Several ProteÅ¿tant Cities yield to him, 416. Goes to Ulm, 417. He receives Lindaw and EÅ¿ling into favour, Ibid. Commands the Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Cologne to Å¿tand by the Popes Sentence, Ibid. He raiÅ¿es Forces againÅ¿t the Elector of Saxony, 419. He receives the Strasburghers SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, 423. His Letters to the States of D. Maurice, Ibid. And to thoÅ¿e of Prague, Ibid. Another Letter of his to the States of Bohemia, 425. His Expedition againÅ¿t the Duke of Saxony, 426. His celerity in overtaking him, 427. Defeats him and takes him PriÅ¿oner, Ibid. Condemns the Duke of Saxony to Death, Ibid. PropoÅ¿es conditions of Peace to him, and calls a Diet at Ulm, 428. PropoÅ¿es Conditions of Peace to the Landgrave, 430. AnÅ¿wers the Landgrave at Hall, 432. Detains him PriÅ¿oner treacherouÅ¿ly, 433. Intends to fall upon Magdebourg, but is diverted by Vogelsberg's raiÅ¿ing Troops in Germany, 434. Is reconciled to Å¿ome Towns in Saxony, 435. PubliÅ¿hes his Pacification with the Landgrave, Ibid. Squeezes Money from the Germans, 436. And proÅ¿cribes Magdebourg, Ibid. Solicites the Switzers to make a League, 437. Makes a Truce with the Turk, Ibid. Moves the College of Princes to deÅ¿ire the Pope to remove the Council to Bononia, 439. AnÅ¿wers the PropoÅ¿als made by the Cities of the Empire at Augsbourg, 441. Sends an EmbaÅ¿Å¿y to the Pope about the Council, Ibid. ExcuÅ¿es the Landgrave's Confinement, Ibid. RefuÅ¿es to Å¿et him at Liberty, 442. Confines him cloÅ¿ely, 443. He makes a Report to the States concerning a Council, 453. RaiÅ¿es Money of the States at the Diet, 460. Makes a Reformation in EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Matters, 463. Which is approved of by the BiÅ¿hops, 464. His anÅ¿wer to the States about Disbanding of the Army, 466. He Writes to the Princes about receiving the Interim, 468. ProÅ¿cribes Å¿everal who Å¿erved under the ProteÅ¿tants, Ibid. Changes the Government of Augsbourg, 469. Determines for the Count of NaÅ¿Å¿aw againÅ¿t the Landgrave, 470. Sends Spaniards privately to ConÅ¿tance, Ibid. AnÅ¿wers to the deÅ¿ires of the Strasburghers, 471. Outlaws the City of ConÅ¿tance, Ibid. And will hear no Plea's in their behalf, Ibid. He diÅ¿Å¿olves the Government of Ulm. 472. Goes to Spire and Å¿o into the Netherlands with the Saxon and the Landgrave, 473. He detains the Duke of Saxony, 474. Sends the Popes Indult to the German BiÅ¿hops, 483. Writes to the States out of the Netherlands, and appoints a Diet, 493. He comes to Augsbourg with his Son, 496. His Å¿evere Decree againÅ¿t the Lutherans in the Netherlands, 497. Which is very injurious at Antwerp upon account of Trade, 498. His Army beÅ¿ieged Tripoly, 500. He commands the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick to lay down Arms, Ibid. He complains of the Magdebourghers and Bremers, 501. Moderates the Edict of Religion in the Netherlands, lb. He is very earneÅ¿t that the Magdebourghers Å¿hould be ProÅ¿ecuted, 503. And deÅ¿ires to know why the Interim is not obÅ¿erved, Ibid. His Edict againÅ¿t the Magdebourghers, 504. Is very Å¿evere upon the Landgrave after his fruitleÅ¿s endeavours to eÅ¿cape, 505. Quarrels with his Brother about a SucceÅ¿Å¿or to the Empire, Ibid. His Edict againÅ¿t all that AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the Magdebourghers, 512. He pronounces Å¿entence againÅ¿t the Landgrave for the LordÅ¿hip of Dietz, 513. PubliÅ¿hes a Declaration againÅ¿t Octavio FarneÅ¿e, 515. Calls the States to the Council of Trent, Ibid. AccuÅ¿es the French King of AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting the Turk, 518. PubliÅ¿hes a Declaration againÅ¿t him, 522. His anÅ¿wer to the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors who intercede for the Landgrave, 534. He anÅ¿wers the complaints of the Spiritual Electors, 535. His AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors have long and frequent Conferences with the Saxon, Wirtemberg and Strasburg, Agents at Trent, 538. RaiÅ¿es Soldiers to oppoÅ¿e the Confederate Princes, 557. His Men make an IncurÅ¿ion into Champaigne, 558. He flies from InÅ¿pruck to Villach, 560. Sets the Duke of Saxony at liberty, Ibid. His Letter to the Princes Mediators, 568. His anÅ¿wer to their Letter, 569. His anÅ¿wer to the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Letter, 570. Changes the Government of Augsbourg, 573. He charges the Franconians to appoÅ¿e MarqueÅ¿s Albert, 574. goes into Lorrain and to Strasbourg, Ibid. Lays Å¿iege to Metz, 575. His Army in the Netherlands takes HeÅ¿din, 576. He riÅ¿es from the Å¿iege of Metz, Ibid. He Writes to MarqueÅ¿s Albert, 577. His anÅ¿wer to his own AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors about the ControverÅ¿y between Albert and the Franconian BiÅ¿hops, 579. Befieges and takes TeroÃ¼anne, 580. Retakes HeÅ¿din, 586. His advice to the Princes of Germany, Ibid. He FurniÅ¿hes Albert with Money underhand, 591. Carries the War into Picardy, Ibid. Ratifies the ProÅ¿cription of Albert, made by the Imperial Chamber, 598. His Letter to the States of Germany, 606. His anÅ¿wer to the German
Princes, 616. Makes the Duke of Alba his General in Milan, Ibid. His Fleet engages the French Fleet, 618. He reÅ¿igns the low Countries to his Son Philip, 620. Goes into Spain. 638.
Charles Prince of Spain Born, 350.
ChriÅ¿tian I. King of Denmark dies, 62.

ChriÅ¿tian II. King of Denmark overthrows Steno Stura. 62. Burns his dead Body, Ibid. LoÅ¿es Sweden, Ibid. Is baniÅ¿hed from Denmark, Ibid. Appeals to the Diet at Nurenberg, Ibid. Is taken PriÅ¿oner, 161. His Son dies, Ibid.
ChriÅ¿tian, Wife to the Landgrave, Sollicites for the Landgrave's ReleaÅ¿e, 441. Dies for Grief, 485.

ChriÅ¿topher Succedes his Father Ulric in the Dutchy of Wirtemberg, 502. His Dutchy is rid of the Spaniards, 528. He Å¿ends AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Council of Trent, Ibid. They are gulled in the Council by the Cerdinal of Trent, and the Emperors AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 530. They apply themÅ¿elves to Count Monfort, 537. They join with the Saxon AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, and the Deputies to Sollicite a hearing of the ProteÅ¿tant Divines in the Council of Trent, 537. &c. They leave the Council, 541. New AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors are Å¿ent from the Duke of Wirtemberg to Trent, 543. The Wirtemberg Divines go to Trent, Ibid. Who exhibit their ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, Ibid. They PubliÅ¿h their ProteÅ¿tation there, 544. At the breaking up of the Council, the Wirtemberg AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors give in their Opinion of it, 547.
Cheregatus (FranciÅ¿cus) Legate to P. Adrian at Nuremberg, 57.

Cities of the Empire complain againÅ¿t the Diet at Norimberg, 65. and in the Diet of Spire againÅ¿t the Decree of Wormes, 103. They complain againÅ¿t Mendicant Friars, 104. Immunities of the Clergy, Ibid. And againÅ¿t Holy daies, Ibid. Cities for the Reformed Religion ProteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Decree of Spire, 120. Are for acknowledging Ferdinand King of the Romans, 151. Some Cities quarrel at the Taxes laid at Coblentz to carry on the War at MunÅ¿ter, 198. Catholick Cities Complain that they are Excluded from the Princes Councils at Ratisbon, 282. Some Cities refuÅ¿e at Spire to grant Å¿ubÅ¿idies againÅ¿t the French, 326. They refuÅ¿e to Å¿ubmit to the Council of Trent at Augsbourg, 440.
Clareback (Adolph) Burnt at Cologne for Religion, 121.
Clement the V. inÅ¿erts into the Canon-Law that Emperors are Subject to the Pope, 38.

Clement the VII. Å¿uccedes to Adrian, 66. Sends Cardinal Campegio to the Diet at Nuremberg, Ibid. Writes to D. Frederick of Saxony, Ibid. Sends a Golden RoÅ¿e to Henry the VIII. of England, 75. Writes to the Parliament of Paris, 97. Enters into a League with Charles the V. 105. Writes expoÅ¿tulatory Letters to him, 106. Writes to the King of Poland to be ready to Å¿end Deputies to a General Council, 142. Sends a Legate to the Duke of Saxony, 162. His Legate's Speech to the Duke of Saxony, Ibid. Goes to MarÅ¿eilles to meet Francis, 168. Marries his Neice, Catharine de Medicis, to his Son Henry, Ibid. Dies, 174.

Cleve: Duke of Cleve Å¿ues to the Emperor for Guelderland, 266. His Treaty with the French King, 277. Marries the Queen of Navarre's Daughter, Ibid. Retakes Duren, 304. A Pacification Attempted between him and the Emperor, 307. Submits to the Emperor, 315. Renounces his League with France, and demands his Wife, 316. Intercedes with the Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Cologne to lay down his BiÅ¿hoprick, 418.
Coblentz, a Town in the BiÅ¿hoprick of Triers, upon the Confluence of the Rhine and the MoÅ¿elle, 13. Some Princes meet there to quiet the Stirs of MunÅ¿ter, 197.

Cologne Æ²niverÅ¿ity Condemns Luther's Writing, 27. Condemn and burn Reuchlin's Book, 30. The Elector of Cologne (Herman) calls a Provincial Council, 209. Endeavours a Reformation, 310. Confers with Bucer, Ibid. Oppos'd by the Clergy, 311. Who PubliÅ¿h their Anti-Didagma, Ibid. And oppoÅ¿e Bucer, Ibid. The BiÅ¿hop Mediates for the Duke of Cleve, 313. The Clergy plead againÅ¿t their Arch-BiÅ¿hip, 340. They appeal to the Pope and Emperor, Ibid. The Arch-BiÅ¿hop AnÅ¿wers their appeal, Ibid. They SubÅ¿cribe the Appeal, 341. The Arch-BiÅ¿hop is cited by the Emperor and the Pope, 351. AnÅ¿wers to his Citation to the Emperor, 352. Appeals to a Council, 411. The Arch-BiÅ¿hop is depoÅ¿ed by the Pope, 417. He is PerÅ¿waded to reÅ¿ign his BiÅ¿hoprick, 418. Vide Adolph Count Schauwenbourg. Herman the Old BiÅ¿hop dies, 573.
Conclave: The Ceremonies there practiÅ¿ed in the chooÅ¿ing of Popes, 489.
Confederate Princes againÅ¿t Charles the V. propoÅ¿e conditions to him, 109. Vide Maurice.
ConÅ¿ecrations of all Sorts, Bells, Churches, Altars, &c. 481, 482.

ConÅ¿tance Council decreed a Pope Å¿ubject to a Council, 9. That Å¿afe Conducts Å¿hould be Null to declared Hereticks, 47. That the Laity Å¿hould Communicate in one Kind, Ibid. The BiÅ¿hop of ConÅ¿tance (Hugh) oppoÅ¿es Zuinglius, 51. Sends a Book about Images to the Senate at Zurich, 72. They aboliÅ¿h Popery, 112. They Å¿end Deputies with humble SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to the Emperor, 469. Their BiÅ¿hop dies of an Apoplexy, Ibid. They repulÅ¿e the Spaniards who would Å¿eize the Town, 470. Æ²pon their being proÅ¿cribed, they deÅ¿ire the Switzers to intercede for them, 471.
They Å¿urrender intirely to the HouÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria, 474. The Conditions upon which K. Ferdinand receives them, ibid.

Contarini (Card.) the Pope's Legate at Ratisbon, his Opinion at the Diet, 279. His Exhortation to the BiÅ¿hops, 280. His Speech is communicated to the States, ibid. He gives in other Papers to the Diet, 281. ProteÅ¿ts by Letter againÅ¿t a National Council, 282. AccuÅ¿ed to the Pope, and dies, 299.
CoÅ¿imo Å¿ucceeds Alexander de Medicis in the Dutchy of Florence, 210. Marries Eleanor Daughter to the Viceroy of Naples, ibid.
CoÅ¿mus, vide CoÅ¿imo.
Coyre, BiÅ¿hop of Coyre recalled by the GriÅ¿ons from the Council of Trent, 529.
Cranmer (Tho. A. B. of Canterbury) calls Bucer and Fagius into England, 479. Vindicates himÅ¿elf from the aÅ¿perÅ¿ions of the PapiÅ¿ts, 590. Is Å¿ent to the Tower, ibid. Burnt at Oxford, ibid.
CreÅ¿centio (Cardinal) the Pope's Legate at the Council of Trent, 518. Dies at Verona, 548. Falls Å¿ick with Å¿eeing an Apparition of a Black Dog, ibid.

CuÅ¿anus (Nicolaus Cardinal), vide SigiÅ¿mund.

list.head: D
list.item: DEcius (Philip) writes for the Council of PiÅ¿a, 27.

Ditlebius (Valentine) his Letter to Frederick, 33.

list.head: E
list.item: EBleben (ChriÅ¿topher) Negotiates a Peace for the Landgrave, 430. Dies for Grief that the Conditions were Å¿o treacherouÅ¿ly kept, 434.

DiÅ¿putes at Baden with Oecolampadius, 105. DiÅ¿putes with Leonard CaeÅ¿ar, 110. AnÅ¿wers the AuguÅ¿tan ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, 130. AnÅ¿wers the ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Confederate Cities, 139. Elector, vide Albert, 14. The Elector's AnÅ¿wer to the Emperor at Ratisbon, 281. The Electors of the Rhine meet about the Elector of Cologne, 356. The Electors Å¿eparate their Councils at the Diet of Ratisbon, 375. EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Electors Å¿evere for the Interim, 477. And hold Synods wherein the Trinkets of Popery are reÅ¿tored, 481. Empire, vide Princes.

EnthuÅ¿iaÅ¿ts begin to Preach in Germany, 52.

EraÅ¿mus writes to Frederick in Luther's behalf, 21. And to Luther Encouraging him to go on, but calmly, ibid. And to Rome in favour of Reuchlin, 31. Writes about Free-will, 75. VVrites againÅ¿t the Reformers under the Title of GoÅ¿pel-teachers, 122. VVrites to Campegio to promote Æ²nity in Germany, 133. His

ExorciÅ¿ms with the Cermeonies, 481.
EyÅ¿enach, a Town in Thuringia, a Convention of the ProteÅ¿tants there, 244.

list.head: F.
list.item: FAber (John) Deputy to the BiÅ¿hop of ConÅ¿tance at Zurick, 57.
Faber (Jacobus) StapulenÅ¿is perÅ¿ecuted by the SorboniÅ¿ts, 98. The King of France writes on his behalf out of Spain, ibid.
Farel (William) Preaches at Metz, 290.
FarneÅ¿e (Cardinal) his Speech to the Emperor againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 264. Retires from the Emperors Court, 266. Goes to the Diet of Wormes with the Emperor, 348. Goes from thence to Rome, 349.

FarneÅ¿e (Octavio) General of the Pope's Troops which help'd the Emperor againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 394. Has Parma Å¿ecur'd to him by P. Julius the III, 492. Puts a French GarriÅ¿on into Parma, 513. Is Cited to Rome, ibid. PurÅ¿ues the BuÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Parma, 514. Being Å¿upported by the French King it occaÅ¿ions a VVar, ibid.

Ferdinand Arch-Duke of AuÅ¿tria Marries, 50. Executes the Ban Å¿everely againÅ¿t the Lutherans, 54. Claims the Kingdom of Hungary, after K. Lewis's death, 105. Is made K. of Bohemia, 110. His Claim to Hungary what, 114. Made K. of the Romans, 144. The Terms upon which the ProteÅ¿tant Princes promiÅ¿e to acknowledge him, 157. Makes a Treaty of Peace with the D. of Saxony, 173. Allows Ulric to be D. of Wirtemberg, ibid. Inhibits the ProÅ¿ecutions of the Imperial Chamber, 184. SuÅ¿pends them till the Meeting of the next Diet, 185. Sends an EmbaÅ¿Å¿ie to the Switzers not to aid the French againÅ¿t the Emperor, 207. Is routed by the Turks, 231. Goes to the Diet at Haguenaw, 267. His PropoÅ¿als to the ProteÅ¿tants there, 268. His AnÅ¿wer there about the Proceedings of the Imperial Chamber, 269. Prepares to invade Hungary, 270. Sends Alaski his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to Solyman, ibid. Is overthrown at Buda, 284. His AnÅ¿wer to the AuÅ¿trian Nobility, 287. His Speech to the Diet at Spire, 288. Opens the Diet at Nurenberg, 298. Makes an unÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful War in Hungary, 304. Opens the Diet at Nurenberg, 305. His AnÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants Petition, 307. Is acknowledged King of the Romans by the D. of Saxony, 325. His Daughter is Betrothed to the D. of Saxony's Son, ibid. Opens the Diet at Wormes, 343. AnÅ¿wers the Deputies of the ProteÅ¿tants, 345. Goes to the Diet at Ratisbon, 374. Denounces War againÅ¿t the Saxons, 409. His AnÅ¿wer to the Bohemians, 417. His Demands to the Bohemians, 420. His Letters to the Bohemians, 423. He AnÅ¿wers their Letters, 424. He writes to them again, 425. His CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to the Convention of States in Bohemia, 426. His Army, ibid. Writes again to the Bohemians, 428. Writes to them again from Leutmeritz, 431. Goes to Prague and forces the Bohemians to Å¿ubmit, 434. Obtains vaÅ¿t Sums of Money from the Free Towns, 436. RaiÅ¿es Money of the States at the Diet, 460. Receives ConÅ¿tance, and impoÅ¿es Å¿trict Conditions upon them, 474. Complains at the Diet of Augsbourg of the Irruptions of the Turks, 511. Aid is granted him by the Princes at Norimberg, 512. Treats with D. Maurice about Peace at Lintz, 556. Goes to PaÅ¿Å¿aw to Mediate a Peace, 563. PreÅ¿Å¿es D. Maurice to Å¿tay a while for the Emperor's AnÅ¿wer, 568. Goes again to the Emperor to Villach, ibid. Brings the Emperor's AnÅ¿wer back to PaÅ¿Å¿aw, 569. He there anÅ¿wers the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador in the Emperor's Name, 570. Opens the Diet of Augsbourg, 598. PubliÅ¿hes an Edict about Religion, 602. Which is anÅ¿wered by the States of his Country, ibid. He comes to Augsbourg, 607. Opens the Diet with a Speech, ibid. What effect it had upon the Diet, 610. BaniÅ¿hes two hundred ProteÅ¿tant MiniÅ¿ters out of Bohemia, ibid. Invites the Princes to the Augsbourg Diet, 612. Mediates between PapiÅ¿ts and ProteÅ¿tants at Augsbourg, 624. AnÅ¿wers thoÅ¿e Papers that were diÅ¿perÅ¿ed in the Diet, 625. His AnÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants Reply, 626. Sollicites the Princes of Germany againÅ¿t the Turk, 628. AnÅ¿wers the AddreÅ¿s of the AuÅ¿trian Nobility, 630. Replies to the AuÅ¿trians AnÅ¿wer, 631. Is Sollicited by the Bavarians for Liberty of ConÅ¿cience, 633. He goes into Bohemia, ibid.
Fevre d'EÅ¿taples, vide Faber StapulenÅ¿is.
FiÅ¿her BiÅ¿hop of RocheÅ¿ter, Beheaded for not acknowledging King Henry Supream Head of the Church, 180. Made Cardinal in PriÅ¿on, ib.
FliÅ¿ted (Peter) burnt at Cologne for his Religion, 121.
Florentines aid the French againÅ¿t Charles, 131. Send AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to him with SubmiÅ¿Å¿ions, 132. They yield to him after a years Siege, ibid.
Fox (Edw.) BiÅ¿hop of Hereford, his Speech to the ProteÅ¿tants at Smalcald, 188. DeÅ¿ires a Private Conference, 189. Which is allowed, ib.
France, a PerÅ¿ecution of the Lutherans there, 175.

Francis King of France, Competitor for the Empire, 13. Is troubled that Charles V. is preferr'd, 19. Makes a League with the Switzers, 48. Takes Milan, 76. BeÅ¿ieges Parma,
ibid. Is taken PriÅ¿oner there, 79 Writes into France in Favour of Faber StapulenÅ¿is, 98 Falls Å¿ick in PriÅ¿on, 102. Treats a Peace with Char. V. ibid. Leaves two Sons HoÅ¿tages in Spain, 103. But makes a League with the Pope and Venetians againÅ¿t the Emperor, 105. VVrites to the Princes of the Empire, 108. PubliÅ¿hes an Apology for engaging in VVar with Char. V. ibid. Sends Letters of Defiance to Char. V. 112. Makes a League with Henry VIII. ibid. Challenges Char. V. to a Duel, 112. Concludes a Peace with him at Cambray, 121. The Articles of it, ibid. His Letter to the ProteÅ¿tant Princes, 149. Marries Catharine de Medicis to his EldeÅ¿t Son Henry, 168. He goes in ProceÅ¿Å¿ion to St. Genevieve, 178. He writes to the German Princes to take off MiÅ¿underÅ¿tandings, 179. Sends Bellay to Smalcald to the ProteÅ¿tants, 182. His Opinion about the Points of ControverÅ¿ie in Germany, 186. He offers to enter into a League with the ProteÅ¿tants, 187. Makes VVar upon Savoy, 203. Defeats Charles's Armies in Provence and Picardy, 208. VVrites to the Princes of Germany, inveighing againÅ¿t the Emperor, ibid. Marries his EldeÅ¿t Daughter Magdalen to James V. of Scotland, 209. Complains of the Emperor in the Parliament of Paris. 210. His AuÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants Letter, 230. Chides the D. of Wirtemberg by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador at Francfort, 249. Gives private AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to the D. of Cleve, to whom he propoÅ¿es a Marriage with his Niece, 266. He is diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ed with the Emperor, ibid. Sends an AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to Haguenaw, 267. PerÅ¿ecutes the Lutherans, ibid. Commands Supplications for Peace to be made throughout his Kingdom, 269. Sends AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Diet at Spire, 289. Their Harangue there, ibid. Prepares for a War againÅ¿t the Emperor, 292. Purges himÅ¿elf of PeÅ¿cara's AccuÅ¿ations, 296. Appoints Prayers for Å¿ucceÅ¿s to his Army, ibid. Declares War, ibid. Sends Longueville and Van RoÅ¿Å¿em into Flanders, ibid. Attaques Charles in five places, ibid. With not much SucceÅ¿s, ibid. He demands aid of the Turk, ibid. His Speech to the Rochellers, 305. His AnÅ¿wer to the Emperor's Letter to the Pope, 307. Takes Luxembourg, 316. His men retire from Landrecy, 317. He Å¿ends an EmbaÅ¿Å¿ie to Spire, 319. His Herald is ill receiv'd at Spire, ibid. He beats the Emperor at Carignan, 323. The Speech of his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, who Å¿hould have gone to Spire, 324. Concludes a Peace with the Emperor at SoiÅ¿Å¿ons, 327. His AnÅ¿wer to the Switzers about the WaldenÅ¿es, 347. He makes a Peace with King Henry VIII. 382. He refuÅ¿es to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 403. He Å¿uffered the ProteÅ¿tants to be PerÅ¿ecuted, and 14 Burnt, 411. He dies, 424. Was a great Patron of Learning, and Learned himÅ¿elf, ibid. Gave 100000 Crowns apiece to the Landgrave, and the Saxon, ere he died, 425. Is Buried, 429.
Francis the Dauphin dies Å¿uÅ¿pected of PoiÅ¿on, 208.

Maurice, 406. Writes to Ulm to the Confederates for AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, 409. Is in danger upon the Retreat of the Army, 412. RaiÅ¿es contributions upon PapiÅ¿ts, Ibid. Writes to the States of D. Goes to Leipzick to DiÅ¿pute, 21. OppoÅ¿es the Popes Supremacy againÅ¿t Eckius, 22. Writes SubmiÅ¿Å¿ively to the Pope at Miltitz's deÅ¿ire, 23. His Character of the Court of Rome, 24. He anwÅ¿ers the Lovain and Cologne Divines, 27. He Writes to Charles V. 31. And to the States of the Empire, Ibid. And SubmiÅ¿Å¿ively to the BiÅ¿hop of Mentz, 32. And to the BiÅ¿hop of Mersburgh, 33. OppoÅ¿es the Popes Bull, and appeals to a General Council, 36. Writes about the BabyloniÅ¿h Captivity, Ibid. Condemns the Doctrine of the Å¿even Sacraments, Ib. Writes againÅ¿t the Popes Bull, Ibid. His Books burnt by the Popes MeÅ¿Å¿engers to Frederick, 39. He burns the Canon-Law and the Popes Bull, Ibid. His reaÅ¿ons for it, Ibid, 40. AnÅ¿wers AmbroÅ¿ius Catharinus, 40. PromiÅ¿es to appear at Wormes in a Letter to Frederick, 41. Is put into the Bull de Coena Domini, 42. Turns it into High-Dutch and writes AnimadverÅ¿ions, Ibid. Goes to Wormes, ibid. Is diÅ¿Å¿waded from it, Ibid. To no PurpoÅ¿e, Ibid. Owns his Books, ibid. Takes time to conÅ¿ider of his defence, ibid. has a day allowed, ibid.
