His AnÅ¿wer to the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, 45. Parlies with them, 46. Submits to the next General Council, ibid. Goes home from Wormes, ibid. Writes to the Emperor for Protection upon the Road, ibid. And to the States, ibid. Drolls in his AnÅ¿wer to the PariÅ¿ian CenÅ¿ure of his Books, 47. Writes Letters to Å¿trengthen his Friends in his Retirement, 49. And Books againÅ¿t the MaÅ¿s and MonaÅ¿tick Vows, and one againÅ¿t Latomus, ibid. AnÅ¿wers Henry the VIII. Å¿harply, 50. Returns to Wittemberg, 51. ExcuÅ¿es it to Frederick, ibid. DiÅ¿approves the taking down of Images, 52. He writes to the Boliemians to perÅ¿wade them to Æ²nity, 53. Writes againÅ¿t falÅ¿e BiÅ¿hops, ibid. Calls himÅ¿elf Preacher of the GoÅ¿pel, ibid. RefuÅ¿es to Å¿tand to the Determination of any under God, 54. TranÅ¿lates Adrian's InÅ¿tructions to the Diet, with Remarks, 60. Interprets the Decree of the Diet at Nuremberg, 64. And adds thereto a DiÅ¿courÅ¿e againÅ¿t Private MaÅ¿Å¿es, 65. AdmoniÅ¿hes the Princes of Germany, 75. Writes de Servo Arbitrio againÅ¿t EraÅ¿mus, ibid. Warns the Saxons of Muncer, 86. Writes a Book to prevent Sedition, ibid. His AnÅ¿wer to the Demands of the Boors in Schwabia, 90. His Momtory EpiÅ¿tle to the Princes and Nobility, 94. His General EpiÅ¿tle to Nobility and Boors, 95. His Alarm againÅ¿t the Boors, 96. CenÅ¿ured as too Å¿harp, ibid. He defends it afterwards, ibid. Writes againÅ¿t CaraloÅ¿tadius, about the EuchariÅ¿t, 97. Æ²ndertakes his Protection upon his SubmiÅ¿Å¿ion, ibid. Marries a Nu â¢ , ibid. Differs with Zuinglius about the EuthariÅ¿t, ibid. Writes Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ively to Henry VIII. 100. And to George D. of Saxony, 101. Complains of K. Henry's AnÅ¿wer, 102. Has a Conference with Zuinglius at Marpurgh, 121. Writes to the BiÅ¿hops at the Diet of Augsbourg, 140. Comforts Melancthon, ibid. He defends the League of Smalcald, 148. He perÅ¿wades the Leipzickers to continue ProteÅ¿tants, 168. He juÅ¿tifies himÅ¿elf from the Charge of Rebellion, ibid. Quarrels with EraÅ¿mus, 170. Writes againÅ¿t the AnabaptiÅ¿ts at MunÅ¿ter, 199. Wrote againÅ¿t the Draught of a Reformation, publiÅ¿hed by the Delegate Cardinals, 238. VVrites againÅ¿t the Antinomians, 244. Preaches at Leipzick, 250. He publiÅ¿hes a Book about the Authority of Councils, ibid. He writes againÅ¿t the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, 272. He InÅ¿talls AmÅ¿torfius, 288. VVrites againÅ¿t Phlugius, ib. VVrites a Camp Sermon for thoÅ¿e who went againÅ¿t the Turks, 292. His Opinion about MagiÅ¿tracy, 293. His Å¿econd Camp Sermon, 294. His Prayer againÅ¿t the rage of the Turks, 295. He writes about the Sacrament, 340. AnÅ¿wers what the Lovain Doctors wrote againÅ¿t the Reformation, 343. PubliÅ¿hes a Book againÅ¿t the Roman Hierarchy, 349. His TheÅ¿es about Government, ib. His Ludicrous Pictures about the Pope, ibid. VVrites to diÅ¿Å¿wade the ProteÅ¿tants from ReleaÅ¿ing the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, 354. He goes to IÅ¿leben to be an Arbitrator between the Counts Mansfeild, 362. Falls Å¿ick, ibid. His Prayers, 363. Dies, ibid. Is buried at Wittemberg, ibid. His Life, ibid. His Skill in the German Language, ibid. His undaunted courage, ibid.

list.head: M.
list.item:
MAgdebourg, refuÅ¿es to Å¿ubmit to the Emperor, 434. Is ProÅ¿cribed, 436. In great diÅ¿treÅ¿s upon that account, 485. They publiÅ¿h a ManifeÅ¿to, 486. Another ManifeÅ¿to of theirs, 496. They are routed by the D. of Mecklenbourg, 500. Conditions are propoÅ¿ed to them, 501. They publiÅ¿h a third Declaration, ibid. They Sally out briskly upon Maurice, 502. They anÅ¿wer the Deputation
of their own States, 502. They overcome D. Maurice in a Sally, and take the D. of Mecklenbourg PriÅ¿oner, 505. They are Å¿ollicited to Å¿urrender, 506. The Declaration of the States and Clergy againÅ¿t them, ibid. Their AnÅ¿wer to it, 508. A Mutiny in the Town, 515. They accept of a Peace, 528. Their Preachers Vindicate themÅ¿elves to D. Maurice, 529. They get credit by their conÅ¿tancy, ibid.
Malvenda opens the Conference at Ratisbon, 359. Treats of JuÅ¿tification, ibid. AnÅ¿wers Bucer, ibid.
Mantua, a Council called to meet there, by P. Paul III. 207. The D. of Mantua demanded a GarriÅ¿on before the Council Å¿hould Å¿it, 230.
Marcellus II. choÅ¿en Pope, 615. Dies after a Reign of 22 days, ibid.
Marot (Clement) an account of him, 310.

Mary Q. of Hungary made GoverneÅ¿s of the Netherlands, 149. Goes to Augsbourg to Mediate for the mitigation of the Emperors Edict, 501. Holds a Convention of the States of the Netherlands at Aix la Chapelle, 560. She Å¿tops the Landgrave at MaÅ¿tricht, 573.
Mary Q. of Scots, Troubles in her Minority, 316. Affianced to Prince Edward of England, ibid. Is carried into France, 477.

Mary (Daughter to Henry VIII.) Proclaims her Å¿elf Queen of England, upon K. Edward's death, 589. Enters London, ibid. Makes Gardiner Chancellor, ibid. Beheads the D. of Northumberland, ibid. She EÅ¿tabliÅ¿hes the PopiÅ¿h Religion again in England, 591. Orders a publick DiÅ¿putation at London, 593. DiÅ¿Å¿olves K. Edward's Laws about Religion in Parliament, 595. Marries Pr. Philip of Spain, ibid. Breaks Wiat's ConÅ¿piracy, 596. Beheads Jane Grey, and the Duke of Suffolk, ibid. BaniÅ¿hes Foreign ProteÅ¿tants out of England, 597. PubliÅ¿hes a Book of Articles about Religion, ibid. Commits the PrinceÅ¿s Ellizabeth to the Tower, 598. Her Marriage with K. Philip is Å¿olemnized with great Å¿plendor, 604. Calls a Parliament, wherein England is again Å¿ubjected to Rome, 605, 606. DiÅ¿Å¿olves that Parliament, 607. Burns Å¿everal for Religion, ibid. She mediates a Peace between the Emperor and King of France, 616. It was reported that Å¿he was with Child, ibid. She encreaÅ¿es the PerÅ¿ecution in England, ibid. Her AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors return home from Rome, 618. She calls a Parliament, where Å¿he propoÅ¿es the ReÅ¿titution of the Church-Lands, in vain, 627.

Martyr (Peter) comes into England and profeÅ¿Å¿es Divinity at Oxon, 443. DiÅ¿putes there about the Lord's Supper, 483. Is in trouble upon Edward's Death, 590. Applies himÅ¿elf to Cranmer, ibid. Gets leave to be gone, ibid. Goes to Zurich, 637.
Matthews (John) a great Prophet among the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, commands a Community of Goods, 194. Runs Truteling through with a Pike by InÅ¿piration, ibid. Is run through himÅ¿elf by a Soldier, ibid.

Maurice (D. of Saxony) Marries the Landgrave's Daughter, 272. Quarrels with the Elector of Saxony, 292. Is wounded in Hungary, 304. RefuÅ¿es to enter into the ProteÅ¿tant League after his Father's death, ibid. Makes Laws for the Government of the Country, 311. Endeavours an accommodation between the D. of BrunÅ¿wick and the Landgrave, 353. PerÅ¿wades the D. of BrunÅ¿wick to Å¿urrender, 354. Purges himÅ¿elf of Treachery, ibid. Holds a Secret Conference with the Emperor at Ratisbon, 380. Has a Conference with K. Ferdinand, 391. Calls a Convention of the States at Chemnitz, 405. ConÅ¿ults againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, ibid. His Friends write to the ProteÅ¿tants, 406. He writes to the Landgrave, ibid. Writes to the Elector, 409. And to his Son, ibid. Takes moÅ¿t of the Electors Towns, ibid. Is ill Å¿poken of, and Lampoon'd by the ProteÅ¿tants, 410. PubliÅ¿hes a ManifeÅ¿to to clear himÅ¿elf, ibid. Joins Ferdinand to go towards Bohemia, 423. Intercedes for the Landgrave, 429. Writes to the Landgrave to comply, 430. Receives Wittemberg with the reÅ¿t of the Electorate from the Emperor, 431. Exacts an Oath of Allegiance of John Frederick's Subjects, ibid. PromiÅ¿es the Landgrave to interceed with the Emperor at Hall, 433. And RemonÅ¿trates about it, ibid. Receives the Wittemberg Divines GraciouÅ¿ly, 435. He is inveÅ¿ted in the Electorate Solemnly at Augsbourg, 457. Calls a Convention at MeiÅ¿Å¿en, who draw up a Form of Religion for Saxony, 478. Intercedes with Prince Philip for the Landgrave, ibid. Writes to the States to clear himÅ¿elf from the imputation of Popery, 484. His Deputies at Augsbourg proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Council of Trent, 499. He engages in the Expedition againÅ¿t the Magdebourghers, 502. He is made GeneraliÅ¿Å¿imo of that War, 503. He attacks the Magdebourghers, 504. Defeats Heideck and Mansfeldt, ibid. He promiÅ¿es the Landgrave Aid Å¿ecretly, 505. Routed in a Sally by the Magdebourghers, ibid. PropoÅ¿es Conditions of Peace to the Town, 515. Commands his Divines to draw up a ConÅ¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of their Faith, ibid. Demands a Å¿afe Conduct for his Divines to go to the Council of Trent, 516. Sends the PropoÅ¿als to the Magdebourghers by Heideck, 521. He holds a Convention about the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Magdebourg, 525. He takes an Oath of Fidelity from the men of
â¢ atzenelbogen, 526. He concludes a Peace with the City of Magdebourg, 528. Complains of the Preachers, ibid. Hatches a War againÅ¿t the Emperor, 529. Sends AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Emperor about the Landgrave, 531. He holds a Conference with Prince William, the Landgrave's
Son, 534. His AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors come to Trent and declare their InÅ¿tructions, 537. They join with the Agents of Wirtemberg and Strasburg to Å¿ollicite for the hearing of the ProteÅ¿tants in the Council, ibid. The Saxon Divines are upon their way to come to the Council, 541. The AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors complain againÅ¿t Pelargus, ibid. Maurice Å¿ends Letters to his AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 542. They leave Trent Å¿ecretly, ibid. His care for the releaÅ¿e of the Landgrave, 549. He declares War againÅ¿t the Emperor, 550. Takes the Field and joins with Marq. Albert, 555. He goes with the other Princes, and beÅ¿ieges Ulm, 556. Treats with Ferdinand of Conditions of Peace, ibid. Writes to the French King, 558. His Army SkirmiÅ¿hes with the ImperialiÅ¿ts, 559. A Mutiny in his Camp for want of Pay, ibid. His Soldiers make the Emperor fly from InÅ¿pruck, 560. Which is Plundered, ibid. They PubliÅ¿h a Declaration, ibid. He reÅ¿tores the Outed MiniÅ¿ters, ibid. His Grievances at the Treaty of PaÅ¿Å¿aw, 563. His PropoÅ¿als at the Treaty, 566. He is impatient of delay, and haÅ¿tens Ferdinand, 568. He returns to the Confederates, 569. BeÅ¿ieges Franefort, ibid. At laÅ¿t he accepts a Peace, 571. Sends his Forces into Hungary, 573. Sends CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to treat with John Frederick's CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners to no purpoÅ¿e, 577. Went to Heidelberg to mediate between Albert and the BiÅ¿hops, 578. Makes a League with the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, ibid. Declares War againÅ¿t Marq. Albert, 581. He overcomes Albert, and is killed in the Fight, 586. His Death foretold by Prodigies, ibid.

Maximilian (Emperor) holds a Diet at Augsbourg, 4. Writes in AuguÅ¿t 1518. to Pope Leo to correct Luther, and to put an end to his growing HereÅ¿ies, 5. Dies, Jan. 12. 1519. 13. Sends AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Council of PiÅ¿a, 26. Goes off to Pope Julius, 27. Sends Langus to the Lateran Council, ibid. CommiÅ¿Å¿ions HogoÅ¿trate and Reuchlin to examine JewiÅ¿h Books, 30. Wars with the Switzers, 469.
Maximilian (Son to Ferdinand) comes into Germany out of Spain, 505. Is well beloved, ibid. He returns home from Spain, 529. Is honourably received at Trent, 535. Goes to BruÅ¿Å¿els, 637.
Mecklenbourg, vide George D. of Mecklenbourg.
Mechlin almoÅ¿t conÅ¿umed by Lightning, 392.
Medices, the riÅ¿e of that Family to GreatneÅ¿s, 169.
Meinier PreÅ¿ident of the Parliament of Aix perÅ¿ecutes the WaldenÅ¿es, 345. Æ²Å¿es the Inhabitants of Merindol and Cabriers barbarouÅ¿ly, 345, 346.
MeiÅ¿Å¿en, John BiÅ¿hop of MeiÅ¿Å¿en, OppoÅ¿es Luther about Communion in both kinds, 25.

Melancthon (Philip) comes to Wittemberg, 21. Goes to Leipzick, ib. AnÅ¿wers the PariÅ¿ian CenÅ¿ure of Luther's Books, 47. Comes to the Diet at Augsbourg, 127. One of the ProteÅ¿tant Deputies there to mediate an Accommodation, 132. Very much diÅ¿conÅ¿olate, 140. Comforted by Luther, ibid. Comes to Cologne, 310. Defends Bucer, 311. His Opinion about Indifferent Things, 481. He draws up a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith for the Saxon Divines, 515. Congratulates John Frederick's Å¿afe Return home, 574. Sends Letters of Comfort to the BaniÅ¿hed Bohemian Preachers, 613.

Mendoza Å¿ent by the Emperor to the Council of Trent, 360. AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador to Strasbourg, 419. His Speech to the Pope about the Council from the Emperor, 443. Sends the Pope's AnÅ¿wer to the Emperor, 445.

Mentz, the Seat of the Elector, four German miles from Francfort, 13. Elector of Mentz, vide Albert. The Elector approves the Interim craftily in the Diet, 460. Sends the Pope's Indult into the Landgraviate, 483. Denies to RegiÅ¿ter Manrice's ProteÅ¿tation againÅ¿t a Council, 499. He leaves Trent, 543. He flies from Albert of Brandenbourg, 567. He dies, 614.
Mersburgh, BiÅ¿hops AnÅ¿wer to Luther, 33.
Milan, the Council removed thither from PiÅ¿a, 27.
Miltitz (Charles) Bedchamber man to Pope Leo, vide Wittemberg. Miltitz Å¿ent by Leo to Frederick againÅ¿t Luther, 12. Treats with Luther, 23. And the AuguÅ¿tine Friars concerning him, ibid.
Minden proÅ¿cribed by the Imperial Chamber, 245.
Mirandula (Joannes Picus) his Books CenÅ¿ured, 28.

Monte (Cardinal de) the Pope's Legate at Bononia, His AnÅ¿wer to the Pope's Letter, 444. His InÅ¿olent Æ²Å¿age of Vargas the Emperor's AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador at Bononia, 446, 447. Made Pope, and called Julius III. 492.

Montmorency (Anne) made ConÅ¿table of France, 239. Is in diÅ¿grace, 277. Gains Favour with Henry II. King of France. Takes Metz for the French King, 555. His Treaty with the Deputies of Strasbourg, 557.
More (Sir Thomas) Chancellor of England, 180. Beheaded for not denying the Pope's Supremacy, Ibid.
Morin (John) under-ProvoÅ¿t of Paris proÅ¿ecutes the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿everely, 175.
Morone (John) Legate to P. Paul III. at Spire, 291.
MuleaÅ¿Å¿es K. of Tunis outed of his Country comes to Augsbourg, 457.

Muncer (Thomas) begins to Preach in Franconia, 52. An account of his EnthuÅ¿iaÅ¿m, 83. Settles at MulhauÅ¿en, 84. Turns out by the Rabbles help all the MagiÅ¿trates, ibid. Joyns with the Boors of Swabia and Franconia,
Ibid. Is routed by Count Mansfield, Ibid. Retires with his Gang to Franck-hauÅ¿en, Ibid. His Speech to the Rabble, 85. His men frighted, 86. Routed by the Princes Army, Ibid. 5000. of them taken, Ibid. Muncer taken at Franck-hauÅ¿en, Ibid. Racked to confeÅ¿s his accomplices, Ibid. Beheaded, Ibid.

MunÅ¿ter a City in WeÅ¿tphalia poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, 174. The Senate EÅ¿tabliÅ¿h the Reformed Religion there, 191. They make a treaty with the BiÅ¿hop, 192. BaniÅ¿h the AnabaptiÅ¿ts, Ibid. They are Tumultuous there, 193. It is beÅ¿ieged by its BiÅ¿hop, Ibid. Who is aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by the Neighbouring Princes, 194. A great Famine in the City, 198. The Princes threaten to Å¿end the Force of the Empire upon them, 197.
Murner (Thomas) a FranciÅ¿can Friar complains to Campegio againÅ¿t the Senate of Strasbourg, 73.
MuÅ¿culus (Wolfgangus.) flies from Augsbourg to Bern for not Å¿ubÅ¿cribing the Interim, 461.

list.head: N.
list.item: NAples a Å¿edition there becauÅ¿e of the InquiÅ¿ition, 434.

NaÅ¿Å¿aw (Count of) deÅ¿ires the Elector of Saxony to come to the Diet at Spire, 152. Henry of NaÅ¿Å¿aw Charles V's. General in Picardy, 208. Æ²nÅ¿ucceÅ¿sful there, Ibid. William, Son to Count NaÅ¿Å¿aw Å¿ucceeds the Prince of Orange, 327.
Naves diÅ¿courÅ¿es with Count Solmes about the War deÅ¿igned againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 357. Speaks to the Landgrave at Spire in the Emperors name, 368. Dies, 419.
Naumbourg, the Chapter chooÅ¿e Phlugius for their BiÅ¿hop, 288.
Netherlands, Reformation gets footing there, 341.
Northumberland (John D. of) Marries his Son Guilford Dudley to the Lady Jane Gray, 580. Is Å¿iezed on at Cambridge, 589. And beheaded by Q. Mary, Ibid.

Nuremberg, a Diet convened thither, 51. Their MiniÅ¿ters accuÅ¿ed to the Popes Legate, 62. The Acts of the Diet PubliÅ¿hed, 63. The treaty of Pacification removed hither from Schurnfurt, 160. A Peace is there concluded, Ibid. A Holy League there drawn up amongÅ¿t the PopiÅ¿h Princes, 245. Another Diet there, 298. The decree of that Diet, 299. The Netherlands AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors accuÅ¿e the D. of Cleve in the Diet, 306. The Decree of the Diet, 307. Their quarrels with Albert of Brandenbourg, 561. Vide Albert, their AnÅ¿wer to Albert's RemonÅ¿trance, 599.

list.head: O
list.item: O BerÅ¿teyn (Ulrick Count) made General of the Army againÅ¿t the MunÅ¿ter mad Men, 197. His Soldiers are tumultuous for want of Pay, 200. He carries the Town at laÅ¿t, 201.
Ockham (William) Condemned by the Æ²niverÅ¿ity of Paris, 28. What his Doctrine, 29.
Oecolampadius (John) Preaches at BaÅ¿il, 76. He embraces the Doctrine of Zuinglius, 97. DiÅ¿putes at Bern, 111. Meets Luther at Marpurg, 121. Dies, 156.
Orleans, vide FranciÅ¿can Friars.
D. of Orleans dies, 352.

OÅ¿iander comes to Marpurg to the Conference betwixt Luther and Zuinglius, 121. Sets up a new Sect about JuÅ¿tification in PruÅ¿Å¿ia, 511. Rails againÅ¿t Melancthon and the Saxon Divines, 512. Dies at Coningsberg, 575. His Sect in PruÅ¿Å¿ia promiÅ¿e to Å¿ubmit to the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion, 632.
Otho Prince Palatine Embraces the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, 300. Recovers his Country, and Joyns with the Confederate Princes, 556.
Oxford, a diÅ¿pute there concerning the Lord's Supper, 483.
Oxline (John) a MiniÅ¿ter carried by force from his HouÅ¿e by the Governour of Turegie, 76. This OccaÅ¿ions the Canton of Zurich to remonÅ¿trate, 77.

list.head: P.
list.item: PAlatine (George) vide Spires.
Palatine (Prince) vide Lewis, vide Otho.
Palaeologus (John) Emperor of ConÅ¿tantinople comes to the Council of Ferrara, 10.
Pall, the exceÅ¿Å¿ive charge of it, 273. The Ceremony of its ConÅ¿ecration, 274.

PaÅ¿Å¿aw a Treaty there, 563. The Princes Mediators there anÅ¿wer Maurice's Grievances, 564. And they anÅ¿wer the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Speech, 565. They exhort the Emperor to a Peace by Letters, 566. They anÅ¿wer the Emperors Letters, 568. The heads of the Pacifitation, 572.

Paris Doctors of that Æ²niverÅ¿ity appealed againÅ¿t P. Leo for Abrogating the Pragmatick Sanction, 10. CenÅ¿ure the Books of Reuchlin, 30. And condemn Luther's Books, 47. An Account of the Faculty of Divinity at Paris, 48. A Young Gentleman of ThoulouÅ¿e burnt there for Religion, 239. They are Å¿evere upon the Lutherans, 296. The manner of Proceedings upon him, 297. Their Divines at Melun draw up Articles againÅ¿t the Reformation, 342. The Parliament anÅ¿wers the K. of France's Edict, 619.

Paul III. (FarneÅ¿e) choÅ¿en Pope, 174. InÅ¿tructs
Vergerius how to Å¿tave off a Council, 175. IÅ¿Å¿ues out Bulls to call a Council, 206. And others to reform the Vices of Rome, 209. Prorogues the Council called at Mantua, 230. Is Sollicitous to reconcile the Emperor and the King of France, 232. Appoints a Committee of Cardinals to Examine the Corruptions of the Church of Rome, 233. Nominates Vicenza for the SeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Council, 238. Returns to Rome, 241. Prorogues the Council without Limitation, 250. Sends his Legate to the Emperor, 264. Makes War upon Perugia, 266. The Speech of his Legate at the Diet of Spire, 291. Allows a Council to be held at Trent, 292. Sends Cardinals to mediate between the French K. and the Emperor, 303. Commends the Chapter of Cologne in a Letter to them, 313. Writes an AnÅ¿wer to the Letter of the Princes, 320. Writes a Å¿harp Letter to the Emperor to chide him for the Decree of Spires, 337. Creates Å¿everal Cardinals, 340. Summons the Council once more to Trent, Ibid. Endeavours to raiÅ¿e a War againÅ¿t the Lutherans, 348. Sends his Legates to Trent, 360. Writes to the SwiÅ¿Å¿e BiÅ¿hops to come to the Council of Trent, 374. Excommunicates the Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Cologne, Ibid. Writes to the Switzers to perÅ¿wade them to joyn againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 382. He publiÅ¿hes a Bull declaring the cauÅ¿es of the War againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 388. Makes the Count Schawenbourg Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Cologne, 417. His anÅ¿wer to the Cardinal of Trent and Mendoza, 444. His Letter to his Legate at Bononia, Ibid. His anÅ¿wer to the Emperors AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, 445. And Letter to the German BiÅ¿hops, ibid. His anÅ¿wer to the Emperors, AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, to juÅ¿tifie the removal of the Council to Bononia, 450. His animadverÅ¿ions upon the Interim, 459. Sends Legates into Germany, 473. Who bring an Indulgence or Indult of Å¿everal things, 482. He dies, 487. Libels come out againÅ¿t him with accounts of his horrid LuÅ¿ts, 488. His Funeral, ibid. He inÅ¿tituted the order of the JeÅ¿uits, 615.
Paul IV. (Caraffa) choÅ¿en Pope, 615.
Pelargus (AmbroÅ¿e) Reflects inÅ¿olently upon the ProteÅ¿tants in the Council of Trent, 541.
De PenÅ¿ier a Lutheran Divine recants at Paris, 309.
PeÅ¿cara, vide d' Avalos.
Peter Pence, what, 170.
Petro AloiÅ¿io, P. Paul III's BaÅ¿tard, D. of Parma and Piacenza, 438. Is AÅ¿Å¿aÅ¿Å¿inated at Piacenza, 439. His flagitious life, Ibid.
Phefecorn (John) a Convert Jew, 29. His Petition to Maximilian, Ibid. Writes againÅ¿t Reuchlin, 30.
Phifer a Companion of Muncer's, 84.

Philip Landgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, his Spaech to his Soldiers againÅ¿t Muncer, 85. His diÅ¿courÅ¿e with Muncer, 86. Arms for fear of a Confeder my againÅ¿t the ReÅ¿erned Religion, 114. Departs privately from the Diet at Augsbourg, 131. Makes a League for Å¿ix years with the Reformed Switzers, 141. AnÅ¿wers the Arbitrators, 154. Endenvours to reÅ¿tore Ulric Duke of Wirtemberg, 169. And brings it about, 173. Writes to acquaint the Emperor with his Proceedings for Duke Ulric, 174. Makes his Å¿ubmiÅ¿Å¿ion to Ferdinand about Ulric's buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, 179. Commands his Divines to anÅ¿wer the An â¢ thaptiÅ¿ts Books, 198. He Å¿ends an anÅ¿wer to their mad PropoÅ¿als, Ibid. Goes to the Convention at EyÅ¿enach, 244. Intercepts the D. of BrunÅ¿wick's Letter, 246. He Writes in his own Vindication to the German Princes, 247. ExcauÅ¿es the D. of Wirtemberg to K. Francis by Letter, 249. He anÅ¿wers the Emperors Letter about a Pacification, 263. Joyns with the Elector of Saxony againÅ¿t the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, 298. OppoÅ¿es the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick, 353. Submits to an accommodation, Ibid. Receives the D. of BrunÅ¿wick upon Å¿urrender, 354. Writes to the Emperor concerning him, Ibid. Writes again, 355. AnÅ¿wers the Emperors Letter, Ibid. Writes to Granvel about the War intended againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, 356. Writes to Naves about the Å¿ame buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, 358. Goes to Spire to Meet the Emperor, 368. Treats with him, Ibid. And with Granvel and Naves, 370. And with the Emperor again, 373. Is courteouÅ¿ly diÅ¿miÅ¿Å¿ed, Ibid. Sends notice to Ratisbon of the Emperors Preparations, 376. He arms againÅ¿t the Emperor, 384. His Forces, 388. He Å¿ends his Son William to Strasbourg, ibid. RefuÅ¿es to Confer with the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick, ibid. His Men skirmiÅ¿h with the Spaniards, 395. His bold advice to Å¿et upon the Emperor, 397. Comes near the ImpertaliÅ¿ts with his Army, 404. A SkirmiÅ¿h between him and the Prince of Sulmona, 407. His Letter to the Mauricians, ibid. And to Maurice, 408. Is in danger upon the Retreat of the Army, 412. Writes to Maurice his Son-in-Law, ib. He rejects the Emperor's PropoÅ¿als, 423. He juÅ¿tifies himÅ¿elf from the Reproaches about Surprizing Francfort, 426. Is invited to come to Leipzick, 429. Articles of Peace are propoÅ¿ed to him, 430. Which he accepts, 431. Goes to Hall to the Emperor, 433. Signs the Articles, and Å¿ubmits to the Å¿ame in PerÅ¿on, ibid. Is detained PriÅ¿oner, 433. Letters are Å¿pread abroad in his Name as if he allowed of the Interim, 463. Is carried PriÅ¿oner into Flanders, 473. And Å¿ent to Oudenard, 474. His Subjects refuÅ¿e the Interim, 477. New InterceÅ¿Å¿ions for him in vain, 479. The MiniÅ¿ters in his Country refuÅ¿e the Pope's Indult, 483. He attempts an eÅ¿cape,
504. Not Å¿ucceeding, is kept cloÅ¿e PriÅ¿oner, 505. He relieves the OppreÅ¿Å¿ed MiniÅ¿ters Liberally, 517. He is Å¿et at liberty, and Å¿topt again, 373. He returns into his own Country, 574. He accepts a Mediation in the Difference with the Count of NaÅ¿Å¿aw, about Catzenelbogen, 617. Which Å¿till keeps in SuÅ¿pence, 620. Has a Meeting with AuguÅ¿tus Elector of Saxony, 633.
Philip Prince Palatine Governor of Vienna when Solyman beÅ¿ieged it, 121. Forces him to raiÅ¿e his Siege, Ibid.

Philip Son to Charles V. comes through the Netherlands into Italy, 477. Is received at Genoa, Ibid. And at Milan, 478. Goes into Germany, Ibid. Enters BruÅ¿Å¿els, 479. Homage is done to him in the Low Countries, 485. He marries Queen Mary in England, 604. He has Naples and the Kingdom of JeruÅ¿alem, Ibid. With the Dutchy of Milan reÅ¿igned to him, 605. Goes into Flanders to meet his Father, 618. He enters upon the Government of the Netherlands, Ibid. Sends AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors into Germany to acquaint them with his New Government, 628.

Phlugius (Julius) vide Gropper. ChoÅ¿en by the Chapter of Naumbourg to be their BiÅ¿hop, 288. Is admitted one of the PreÅ¿idents of the Conference at Ratisbon, 359. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts in drawing up the Interim, 454.
Phlugius (CaÅ¿par) heads the Bohemian Confederates, 423. Is condemned of High TreaÅ¿on, 434.
Picards, a Sect of the Bohemians, 53.
Picus, vide Mirandula.
PiÅ¿a, Council there, 26. Called by Cardinals, Ibid. ReaÅ¿ons of Å¿o doing, Ibid. SuÅ¿pends P. Julius, 27. Remove to Milan, Ibid.
P. Pius's Decree concerning appeals, 35. He altered his Opinion from what it was at the Council of BaÅ¿il, 36. Excommunicates SigiÅ¿mund, ibid.
Poiet (William) Chancellor of France diÅ¿graced, 299.

Pool (Reginald Cardinal) Å¿ent Nuncio from the Pope to the French King, 210. Writes a Book called a Defence of EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿tical Æ²nity, ibid. Made Cardinal by P. Paul III. 211. LoÅ¿es the Popedom on Å¿uÅ¿picion of LutheraniÅ¿m, 490. Is detained in Germany by the Emperor, 594. Returns into England, 605. Reconciles the Nation to the See of Rome, 606. Writes to the Emperor and King of France to mediate a Peace, 615.
Popes anciently Å¿ubject to Emperors, 38.
Pragmatick Sanction, vide Paris.
PrieÅ¿ts, the Ceremony of their Degradation, 64.
Prietias (SylveÅ¿ter) writes againÅ¿t Luther, 3. He aÅ¿Å¿erts the Pope to be abÅ¿olute head of the Church, ibid. Replies to Luther, 4.

Princes of the Empire diÅ¿agree about the Emperor's Letter againÅ¿t: Luther, 44. Complain of the Pope's Proceedings in the Affairs of Germany, 60. Return an AnÅ¿wer to Adrian's Letter to the Diet, ibid. Draw up an account of the Grievances of Germany, which they gave to the Pope's Legate, 63. Their anÅ¿wer to Campegio's Speech at Nuremberg, 68. They write to Charles V. to make haÅ¿te into Germany, 108. They write again, 110. Write from Spire to the Senate at Strasburg, 116. Princes of the Reformed Religion ProteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Decree of Spire, 119. Deliberate about a League amongÅ¿t all ProteÅ¿tants in Germany, 122. They anÅ¿wer the Emperors PropoÅ¿als at Augsbourg, 133. Several of the Princes declare upon what Terms they allow a King of the Romans, 157. ProteÅ¿tant Princes refuÅ¿e a league with Francis againÅ¿t the Emperor, 187. ThoÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿embled at Coblentz write Å¿everely to the AnabaptiÅ¿ts at MunÅ¿ter, 197. Catholick Princes Opinion at Ratisbon, 281. They anÅ¿wer the Legates Letter, 283. They Interceed for the D. of Cleve, Ibid. Some of them writes to the Pope, 320. The PopiÅ¿h Princes Å¿eparate anÅ¿wer at the Diet at Wormes, 344. They write to the Bremers, 501. They meet at Noremberg, 512. Several Princes Å¿end AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Emperor to interceed for the Landgrave's Liberty, 533. Others deÅ¿ire the Erench King to deÅ¿iÅ¿t from his inroads into Germany, 558. A Convention of them meet at Francfort, 579. They write to the Emperor about the Peace, 616.
ProteÅ¿tant Princes, vide Princes, vide ProteÅ¿tant.

ProteÅ¿tants, the Original of the Name, 120. their AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors had audience of Charles at Piacenza, 123. They appeal to his AnÅ¿wer, 125. They conÅ¿ult of a League at Smalcald, ibid. And quarrel about Religion, ibid. Break up without a final ReÅ¿olution, ibid. The ProteÅ¿tant Deputies meet at Noremberg, 126. ReÅ¿olve that Religion Å¿hould be debated at Augsbourg, 129. PreÅ¿ent a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion of Faith to the Emperor, ibid. PreÅ¿s to have it read, ibid. The ProteÅ¿tants defend the AuguÅ¿tane ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion in writing, 131. AnÅ¿wer TruchÅ¿es's Speech, 134. They debate with the Emperor about Religion, 135. They leave the Diet, 137. The Deputies of the AÅ¿Å¿ociate Princes demand liberty of ConÅ¿cience from the Diet at Augsbourg, 139. The ProteÅ¿tant Princes write to the Kings of France and England to wipe of thoÅ¿e Calumnies which had been thrown upon them, 145. They Å¿ummon all the ProteÅ¿tant Confederates to Smalcald, 147. They Å¿ollicite the Dane and Northern Princes, and Free Cities to join with them, ib. Their AnÅ¿wer to the Emperor's Summons, 149. the ProteÅ¿tant Princes refuÅ¿e to acknowledge Ferdinand K. of the Romans, 151. They anÅ¿wer the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors of the Elector of Mentz and the Palatine at Smalcald, 153. Both parties of the ProteÅ¿tants have a good underÅ¿tanding about the Lords Supper, 159,
Their Conditions of Pacification, ibid. They give in a full anÅ¿wer, 164. Their decrees in order to a Council, 167. They give in their AnÅ¿wer to Vergerius's PropoÅ¿als for a Council, 181. They meet at Smalcald, ibid. Their anÅ¿wer to the French AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador at Smalcald, 185. Their anÅ¿wer to the EngliÅ¿h AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, 188. They proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Proceedings of the Imperial Chamber, which Å¿hall be contrary to Charles and Ferdinand's Decrees, 189. They draw up Articles of a League with Henry VIII. 204. They meet at Francfort, 206. And receive Å¿everal Cities into the League, ibid. They break off CorreÅ¿pondence with Henry VIII. Ibid. They Å¿end Complaints to the Emperor againÅ¿t the ProÅ¿ecutions of the Imperial Chamber, 208. They anÅ¿wer the Emperors Letter, 209. They meet at Smalcald, 212. Their anÅ¿wer to Eldo the Emperors AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, 215. Their rejoynder upon Eldo's reply, 221. Their Decrees at Smalcald, 226. Their ReaÅ¿ons why they refuÅ¿e to Meet at Mantua, whither P. Paul III. had conven'd them, Ibid. They Å¿end ReaÅ¿ons of their Actions to K. Francis, 230. The ProteÅ¿tant Princes meet at BrunÅ¿wick, 239. Their AnÅ¿wer at EyÅ¿enach, 244. They call a Convention at ArnÅ¿tadt, 251. They Å¿end AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Emperor into Flanders, 253. They write to the French King, 254. They meet at Smalcald, 255. They anÅ¿wer the AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Å¿ent by Granvel to procure a Pacification, 257. They anÅ¿wer King Henry's PropoÅ¿itions, 262. Make a Decree to interceed with the French King for the ProteÅ¿tants if he would not take it ill, Ibid. And reÅ¿olve to oppoÅ¿e the Proceedings of the Imperial Chamber, ibid. Their anÅ¿wer to King Ferdinand's PropoÅ¿als at Haguenaw, 268. Their AnÅ¿wers to the Emperors PropoÅ¿als, 276. They interceed with the French King for the ProteÅ¿tants, 277. They addreÅ¿s to the Emperor in the Diet, 279. Their anÅ¿wer to Contarini's Papers, 280. They Petition the Emperor, 281. They anÅ¿wer Contarini's Letter againÅ¿t a National Council, 283. They abÅ¿olutely decline the Jurisdiction of the Imperial Chamber, 304. They Petition Ferdinand at the Diet of Noremberg, 306. They oppoÅ¿e the decree of the Diet, 307. They meet at Smalcald, 312. Send AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Emperor at Spire, ibid. They meet at Francfort, 317. They proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick's voting at the Diet, 319. They accuÅ¿e the Duke of BrunÅ¿wick publickly in the Diet, 322. They perÅ¿iÅ¿t in their AccuÅ¿ation, 323. Their anÅ¿wer to Ferdinand at Wormes, 344. Their Petition to him, 345. The ProteÅ¿tants meet at Francfort, 356. Reports are Å¿pread of a War againÅ¿t them, ibid. Another meeting at Francfort, 357. They Å¿end Deputies to interceed for the Elector of Cologne, ibid. They are accuÅ¿ed of a ConÅ¿piracy, ibid. They Å¿till urge the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of Cologne, 360. The ProteÅ¿tants Deputies meet at Wormes, 373. They complain at Ratisbon that Diazi's Murder was unrevenged, 374. Their Opinion of the Council of Trent, 375. They are apprehenÅ¿ive of War, ibid. They demand the reaÅ¿on of the Preparations, 376. Their Deputies return home from Ratisbon, 380. The firÅ¿t of their Commanders, ibid. Their Deputies meet at Ulm, 381. They Å¿end to the Venetians and GriÅ¿ons, ibid. They Å¿end AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to the Switzers, 383. They Petition the Emperor, 384. They Å¿end AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors to France and England, 385. They write to the MarqueÅ¿s of Brandenbourg to diÅ¿Å¿wade him from aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ting the Emperor, 387. They publiÅ¿h a ManifeÅ¿to againÅ¿t him, Ibid. Their firÅ¿t exploits in the War, 388. They write to the D. of Bavaria, 392. Their demands of the Switzers, 393. They declare War againÅ¿t the Emperor, ibid. They diÅ¿pute what Title to give the Emperor, 394. They march to Ratisbon, ibid. The names of the principal Confederates, 395. The Spaniards break into their Camp, ibid. Their overÅ¿ight in not taking the Landgrave's advice, 397. Their addreÅ¿s to the Bohemians, 399. Their Declaration concerning Incendiaries Å¿ent out by the Pope, ibid. Their anÅ¿wer to the InÅ¿trument of ProÅ¿cription, ibid. They raiÅ¿e their Camp from IngolÅ¿tadt, 403. They write to the reformed Switzers, 404. They loÅ¿e an opportunity of taking the Emperor at Grienghen, 407. Their Council of War writes to Maurice, 408. They write to Å¿everal Imperial Cities and Princes to joyn with them, ibid. The Confederates Deputies meet at Ulm, 409. AnÅ¿wer the Elector of Saxony's demands, ibid. They Å¿end an EmbaÅ¿Å¿y into France and England, 411. They are in danger and withdraw their Camp, ibid. In the retreat they run a riÅ¿que, 412. They differ from the Catholicks at Augsbourg about the Council of Trent, 440. They are Sollicited to Å¿ubmit to the Council, ibid. Their AmbaÅ¿Å¿ors at Trent inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon Å¿uch a Å¿afe conduct for their Divines as was granted at the Council of BaÅ¿il, 539. The demands of their Divines in the Council, 546. The ProteÅ¿tant Princes make a League at Nuremberg, 614. They acquaint the Emperor with it, ibid. Their anÅ¿wer in the Diet of Augsbourg to the PapiÅ¿ts Allegations, 623. Their reply to Ferdinand's AnÅ¿wer to their Papers, 626.
PruÅ¿Å¿ia vide Albert of Brandenbourg, vide SigiÅ¿mund of Poland, vide Wolfgang grand MaÅ¿ter.

list.head: R.
list.item: RAtisbon, Catholick Lords there with Campegio, confirm the Decree at Wormes againÅ¿t Luther, 74. Make Regulations for the Reformation of the Clergy, 75. The Princes do not meet at Ratisbon at the Diet, 110. The Diet removes thither from Spire, 155. The Articles of the Treaty of Nurenberg are there confirmed, 160. A Diet there, 272. The Acts of the Diet at Ratisbon, 275. The PreÅ¿idents and WitneÅ¿Å¿es at the Conference, 276. The Acts of the Diet, 278. The Decree of the Diet, 283. They promiÅ¿e Aid againÅ¿t the Turks, ib. A Conference is appointed there, 351. The Names of the Conferrers, ibid. It is refuÅ¿ed by the PapiÅ¿ts, 352. The Conference opened, 358. The Names of the PreÅ¿idents, ibid. The Points diÅ¿puted upon, ibid. It breaks up, 359. A Diet there, 374.
Reformation in Germany, its Original, 273.
Religion, thoÅ¿e of the Reformed Religion begin to form a League, 105.
Renate Prince of Orange is killed, 327.

Reuchlin (John Capnio) CommiÅ¿Å¿ioned to examine JewiÅ¿h Books, 30. His AnÅ¿wer to Maximilian, ibid. AnÅ¿wers Phefercorne's Book, ibid. Is Cited to Mentz, ibid. Excepts to HogoÅ¿tratus as a Judge, ibid. Appeals to the Pope, ibid. Is acquitted at Rome, ibid. Dies, 55.
Rhodes taken by Solyman, 57.
Richard Elector of Triers, vide Triers.
Ridley (Nicholas) BiÅ¿hop of London burnt at Oxford for Religion, 619.
Rochell, an InÅ¿urrection there, 304. Quieted, 305.
Rome, Court of Rome, it's DeÅ¿cription, 24. A great Inundation there, 137.
Roman Clergy, vide Jews.
Romans, vide King of the Romans.
Rotman (Bernard) Preaches up the Reformation at MunÅ¿ter, 190. Declares himÅ¿elf an AnabaptiÅ¿t, 192.

list.head: S.
list.item: SAmÅ¿on (Friar) Preaches Indulgences at Zurick, 22.
Savoy, D. of Savoy quarrels with Geneva, 203. LoÅ¿es moÅ¿t part of his Country to the French, ibid. AccuÅ¿es the French King, 323. Dies, 602.
Saxons embrace Luther's Doctrine of the EuchariÅ¿t, 97.
Saxony, Prince of Saxony's AnÅ¿wer to the Arbitrators, 159. Quarrels in the Churches there about Indifferent things, 481.

Scherteline (SebaÅ¿tian) marches towards InÅ¿pruck with his Army for the ProteÅ¿tants, 388. Leaves the Camp, 406. Retires from StraÅ¿bourg to ConÅ¿tance, 418. A Fine is Å¿et upon his Head by the Emperor, 554. He raiÅ¿es men in Germany for the French King, ibid. Is reconciled to the Emperor and King Ferdinand, 594.

Schwabian Confederates beat Ulric D. of Wirtemberg, 80. They refuÅ¿e a Truce with the Boors, ibid. They rout the Boors at Saltzbourg, 81. An Account of the Schwabian League, 82. The Schwabian Cities mediate betwixt Albert and the City of Noremberg, 562.
Schwinfurt, a Town upon the Main, there the Princes mediate an Accommodation, 156. The Treaty is removed to Norenberg, 160.
SepÅ¿y, vide SepuÅ¿io.
SepuÅ¿io claims the Crown of Hungary after K. Lewis's death, 105. vide Vaivod of TranÅ¿ylvania. Dies, 269. His Son put under Solyman' Protection, 270.
Servetus (Michael) Burnt at Genoa, 593.

Seymour (Edw.) D. of SomerÅ¿et, Protector of K. Edward VI. and the Kingdom in his Minority, 418. Is ImpriÅ¿oned, 485. Releas'd, and Marries the D. of Northumberland's Daughter, 492. Is again made a PriÅ¿oner, 528. And Beheaded, 538.
Sforza (Francis) obtains the Dutchy of Milan of Charles V. 122. Marries ChriÅ¿tina the K. of Denmark's Daughter, 174. Dies, 180.
Sibylla of Cleve, Wife to John Frederick Elector of Saxony, Å¿ollicites the Emperor for her Husband, 429. Is received GraciouÅ¿ly by the Emperor, ibid. She dies, 596.
Sickius (Francis) at War with the BiÅ¿hop of Triers, 56.
SickneÅ¿s, Sweating SickneÅ¿s in Germany, 121.
Sidonius (Michael) a Champion for the MaÅ¿s at Augsbourg, 437. AÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ts in Compiling the Interim, 454.
Siena revolts from the Emperor, 573. Is BeÅ¿ieged by the D. of Florence, 598. Retaken by the Emperor's Forces, 615.
SigiÅ¿mund takes CuÅ¿anus PriÅ¿oner, 36. Appeals from the Pope to a Couucil, ibid. Calls the Council of ConÅ¿tance, 47. Begs the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the Empire againÅ¿t ZiÅ¿ca, ibid.

SigiÅ¿mund K. of Poland Wars againÅ¿t Albert, Great MaÅ¿ter of the Teutonick Order, 99. Makes him D. of PruÅ¿Å¿ia, ibid. His AnÅ¿wer to the Emperor's AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 348. His Plea given in by his AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador Alaskia about the Dutchy of PruÅ¿Å¿ia, 445. He dies, 450.
Sixtus IV's Decree concerning the Virgin Mary, 377.

Sleidan (John) Å¿ent by the ProteÅ¿tants AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador into England, 352. Sent Deputy from Strasbourg to the Council of Trent, 529. He applies himÅ¿elf to the Emperor's AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 531. Complains of Gropper to the Council of Trent, 535. Joins with the Wirtemberg and Saxon AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors in their Sollicitations
with the Emperor's AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, 537. Takes leave of the Emperor's AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, who Å¿tops him, 545. Leaves Trent, 546. Deputy from Strasbourg to the French King, 557. Treats with him, and the ConÅ¿table, ibid. Dies, 638.

Smalcald, a Town in Franconia, belonging to the Landgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, vide ProteÅ¿tant. League at Smalcald, 142. The Confederates of the League expoÅ¿tubate upon the motion to chuÅ¿e a King of the Romans, 143. The League renewed, 189. A Convention of the ProteÅ¿tants there, 212.

Solyman makes War in Hungary, 50. Takes Belgrade, 51. And Rhodes, 57. Invades Hungary, 103. BeÅ¿ieges Vienna, 121. Breaks up the Siege, ibid. Makes a new Irruption into AuÅ¿tria, 161. His Troops are defeated, ibid. ImpriÅ¿ons Alaski, Ferdinand's AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador, 271. Strangles his Son MuÅ¿tapha, 594.
Solmes (Count) vide Naves.
Spira (Francis) his diÅ¿mal Story, 475.

Spires, BiÅ¿hop of Spires appointed to hear Reuchlin's CauÅ¿e, 30. Decrees in favour of him againÅ¿t HogoÅ¿tratus, ibid. A Diet held there, 103. The States there differ about Religion, 104. But their Breaches are made up, ibid. And they make a Decree about Religion, ibid. The Princes AÅ¿Å¿embled here write to the Senate of Strasbourg about the MaÅ¿s, 116. The Diet there aÅ¿Å¿embled, 118. They refuÅ¿e the Deputies of Strasbourg to Å¿it in the Diet, ibid. They make a Decree about Religion, ibid. The Princes of the Reformed Religion proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Decree, 119. As alÅ¿o the Free Cities, 120. A Diet call'd thither, 152. Removed to Ratisbon, 155. Another Diet called there, 288. A mighty full Diet, 317. A Decree there which angers the PapiÅ¿ts, 325.

States of the Empire. Some at Ratisbon deÅ¿ire to referr every thing to the Pope's Legate, 279. They treat with tho D. of Cleve to reÅ¿tore Guelderland, 285. They Å¿end a MeÅ¿Å¿age from Nurenberg to the Saxon and Landgrave about the D. of BrunÅ¿wick, 299. Write to the Switzers not to aid the French King, 321. They acquaint Maurice the Elector of Brandenbourg with the Emperor's ReÅ¿olution about the Landgrave, 442.

Strasbourg, PrieÅ¿ts marry there, 66. The BiÅ¿hop cites them, ib. They juÅ¿tifie themÅ¿elves, ibid. The BiÅ¿hop writes to Campegio, complaining of the Senate, 73. The Senate juÅ¿tifie themÅ¿elves to Campegio, ibid. And Parly with him upon his AnÅ¿wer, 74. The PopiÅ¿h Clergy complain againÅ¿t the Senate to the Council of the Empire, 76. The Senates AnÅ¿wer, 79: Their MiniÅ¿ters draw up an Apology, ibid. Quarrels there about the MaÅ¿s, 115. They Å¿uence the PopiÅ¿h MiniÅ¿ters, ibid. The BiÅ¿hop complains to the Diet at Spire, 116. MaÅ¿s aboliÅ¿hed there, ibid. Their Deputies proteÅ¿t, upon their being denied to Å¿it in the Diet, 118. Their Divines anÅ¿wer EraÅ¿mus, 122. Makes a League with the Evangelick Cantons of Switzerland, 126. Which is reÅ¿ented by the Council of the Empire, ibid. They with Å¿ome other Confederate Cities exhibit a ConfeÅ¿Å¿ion at Augsbourg to the Emperor, 130. They debate the matter further againÅ¿t the Emperor, 138. They are oppugned by PopiÅ¿h Divines, ibid. They Å¿et up a School, 241. Their Letter to the Emperor to diÅ¿Å¿wade him from the War, 378. They make their Peace, and are Å¿ined, 423. They refuÅ¿e the Interim, 464. And Å¿tand to it to Granvell, 465. They Å¿end their Judgment of the Interim to the Emperor in a Letter, 471. In a ConÅ¿ultation they reÅ¿olve to accept of the Interim, 472. They Å¿end Deputies with another Letter to the Emperor, 473. Their BiÅ¿hop writes to them about yielding, ib. They are commanded to agree with their BiÅ¿hop, 474. They write to the Emperor of the BiÅ¿hops unreaÅ¿onable demands, 478. The BiÅ¿hop Å¿ays MaÅ¿s again, 479. Quarrels between him and the Senate about the publick ProfeÅ¿Å¿ors, 480. The Senate and the BiÅ¿hop agree, 485. MaÅ¿s firÅ¿t Å¿aid in the Cathedral, 491. Derided by the People, ibid. Whence the PrieÅ¿ts fly, ibid. The BiÅ¿hop complains to the Emperor, 496. But the Breach is made up, ibid. The BiÅ¿hop complains againÅ¿t the Preachers, 513. The Senate Å¿ends Sleidan their Deputy to the Council of Trent, 529. vid. Sleidan. They anÅ¿wer the Demands of Marq. Albert, 571.
Stroza (Peter) a Florentine gulls the ProteÅ¿tants with PromiÅ¿es of Money, 404.
Stupitz (John) General of the AuguÅ¿tine Friars, 2.
Stura (Steno) vide ChriÅ¿tiern.
Sturmius (James) dies, 594.
Sweden, vide GuÅ¿tavus.

Switzers oppoÅ¿e the Election of Francis I. to the Empire, 14. An account of their Commonwealth, 48. Had a CuÅ¿tom that PrieÅ¿ts Å¿hould publickly keep Concubines, 51. They complain againÅ¿t Zuinglius in a Convention of EÅ¿tates, 66. They aÅ¿Å¿emble at Lucern, and make Edicts againÅ¿t the New Religion, 67. They RemonÅ¿trate againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e of Zurick, 69. They join with Zuinglius in the Doctrine of the EuchariÅ¿t, 97. They meet 12 Cantons to DiÅ¿pute at Baden, 105. The PopiÅ¿h Cantons make a League with Ferdinand, 118. Seeds of Civil Wars ariÅ¿e amongst themÅ¿elves, 120. Which are taken up, ibid. They make a League for Å¿ix years, with the Landgrave of HeÅ¿Å¿e, 141. Do not refuÅ¿e to join in the League of Smalcald, if ComprehenÅ¿ion be allow'd them, 148. Not admitted into the League, 151. The PopiÅ¿h Cantons League againÅ¿t the Zurichers, 155. They overcome
the Zurichers, 156. They overcome them again, ibid. They conclude a Peace, ibid. The ProteÅ¿tant Cantons interceed with the French King to remit his Severities towards the ProteÅ¿tants, 210. They anÅ¿wer the Letter which was Å¿ent to them by the States of the Empire, 323. Interceed to the French King for the WaldenÅ¿es, 347. They give an anÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants. EmbaÅ¿Å¿y, 392. They anÅ¿wer the Emperors Letter, 398. The ProteÅ¿tant Cantons differ in their AnÅ¿wer about the War from the PopiÅ¿h ones, 399. Their AnÅ¿wer to the ProteÅ¿tants demands, 404. Two ProteÅ¿tant Cantons refuÅ¿e a League with Henry II. King of France, 484.
Sylvius (Aeneas) vide P. Pius.

list.head: T.
list.item: TEcelius (John Tetzel) a Dominican writes againÅ¿t Luther's ninety five TheÅ¿es, 2.
Teutonick order its inÅ¿titution, 99. They Å¿ubdue PruÅ¿Å¿ia, ibid.
Thomas of Becket Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Canterbury, 241. Killed by Å¿ome of King Henry II's Court, ibid. His rich Shrine, ibid. Canonized, 242.
Toledo (Don FranciÅ¿co de) AmbaÅ¿Å¿ador from the Emperor at the Council of Trent, 374. Treats vigorouÅ¿ly with the ProteÅ¿tant AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors there, 539.

TranÅ¿ylvania Vaivod claims the Kingdom of Hungary againÅ¿t Ferdinand, 112. Writes about it to the Princes of the Empire, ibid. Invites Solyman into Germany, 121. Is made King of Hungary by Solyman, ibid. Dies, 269. His Son is delivered up to Solyman, 285. Made Vaivod of TranÅ¿ylvania, ibid. TranÅ¿ylvania revolts from Ferdinand, 633.
Tregerus (Conradus) diÅ¿putes with the Preachers of the Reformed Religion at Bern, 111.

Trent nominated by the Pope to hold a Council, 292. Allowed by the Catholick Princes of Germany, ibid. ProteÅ¿ted againÅ¿t by the ProteÅ¿tants, ibid. The Council called, 296. It is opened, 361. The firÅ¿t SeÅ¿Å¿ion, ibid. The decrees of it, 362. The Å¿econd SeÅ¿Å¿ion, ibid. The third SeÅ¿Å¿ion, 373. The fourth SeÅ¿Å¿ion with its decrees, 377. The French AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors Speech in the Council, ibid. It is put off, 391. What number of BiÅ¿hops were there, ibid. Decrees made there about JuÅ¿tification, 416. The Å¿eventh SeÅ¿Å¿ion, 422. The Council is divided and Å¿ome go to Bononia, 425. The Emperors Deputies commanded not to Å¿tir thence, ibid. The Councilis divided, 439. Cardinal of Trent Å¿peaks to the Pope about removing the Council, 443. The Council meets once more at Trent, 513. Sits formally, 518. Receives the French King's Letter, ibid. The Ceremony of their SeÅ¿Å¿ions, 520. The may of making Articles and Canons, 521. They decree the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of the Lords Supper, 525. They leave Å¿ome things to be diÅ¿puted when the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿hould come to the Council, 526. The form of their Å¿afe conduct, ibid. They anÅ¿wer the French Kings Letter, 527. They make decrees about Pennance and Extream Æ²nction, 530. Long debates about a Safe Conduct at Trent, 539. They are wonderfully divided, 546. Fly from Trent in haÅ¿te, 547. And they prorogue the Council for two Years, 548.
Treves, vide Triers.

Triers (Elector) makes a Speech for Francis I. 16. PerÅ¿wades Luther to yield, 46. Very courteouÅ¿ly, ibid. Richard the Elector makes War with Francis Sicking, 56. Not for Religion, ibid. Kills Å¿everal Boors at Wormes, 81. After they had thrown down their Arms, ibid. Dies, 149. The Elector of Triers leaves the Council of Trent, 542.

TruchÅ¿es (George) Head of the Schwabian League, 80. Routs the Boors in Schwaben, ibid. And at Winsberg, 81. Burns the Town, ibid. Routs others in Franconia, ibid. Makes a Speech to the ProteÅ¿tant Princes in the Emperors Name, 134.
Turegie, vide Oxline.
Turks (vide Solyman) their Original, 295. They invade Hungary, 314. They take Tripoly, 518. Their Fleet takes CorÅ¿ica, 591. Their Fleet Å¿cours the CoaÅ¿ts of Italy, 617.

list.head: V.
list.item: VAiod, vide TranÅ¿ylvania.
Valla (Laurentius) his book cenÅ¿ured, 28.
Vargas (FranciÅ¿co de) and Martino VelaÅ¿co, the Emperors AmbaÅ¿Å¿adors, proteÅ¿t againÅ¿t the Council at Bononia, 446.
Venetians make a League with the Emperor againÅ¿t Francis, 204. They conclude a Peace with the Turk, 252. They publiÅ¿h a Proclamation about Religion againÅ¿t the reformed, 468.
Venize (Gabriel) Provincial of the AuguÅ¿tans in Germany, vide Leo.

Vergerius (Peter Paul) the Popes Legate at Augsbourg, 127. Had orders to manage the buÅ¿ineÅ¿s of a Council cautiouÅ¿ly, 166. Is recalled into Italy by P. Paul III. 174. And Å¿ent back with the old InÅ¿tructions, 175. ConÅ¿ults with the Duke of Saxony at Prague, 180. Sent to Naples to the Emperor, 204. Appointed of the Committee to draw up a Bull for the calling of a Council, ibid. His Speech at Wormes, 272. Talks with Spira at
Padua, 475. Turns ProteÅ¿tant, 476. PerÅ¿wades his DioceÅ¿s of JuÅ¿tinople to joyn with him, ibid. Being PerÅ¿ecuted, Å¿ettles in the Valteline, 477. And thence removes to Tubing, ibid. Writes a Book to diÅ¿Å¿wade the Switzers from Å¿ending to the Council of Trent, 528.
